column3: Clinton's Final Chapter: Single-Minded, Full-Steam Run at a Global Agenda
column9: For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the...
column10: For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty last fall to a tear-gas-filled week in Seattle that badly damaged his global economic agenda. But some of his biggest victories in 1999 were also scored abroad, from the air campaign over Serbia that largely halted ethnic bloodshed to the Northern Ireland accord that offers the first prospect of peace there.

column3: $8 Million Offered to End Attica Inmates' Suit
column8: Front Page; New York and Region
column9: Determined to conclude one of the longest and ugliest chapters in criminal justice history, a federal judge announced today that the inmates who were beaten and tortured during the 1971 Attica prison uprising have been offered a settlement of $8...
column10: Determined to conclude one of the longest and ugliest chapters in criminal justice history, a federal judge announced today that the inmates who were beaten and tortured during the 1971 Attica prison uprising have been offered a settlement of $8 million from New York State. The settlement, which provides an additional $4 million for lawyers' fees, is believed to be the biggest ever in a prisoners' rights case. But it may also be remembered as one of the longest and most vexing to hammer out, coming 25 years after a class-action civil suit was filed on behalf of 1,281 inmates over the storming of the western New York prison by state troopers. The uprising and siege left 43 people dead and more than 80 wounded.

column3: Seattle Will Drop Most of Trade Protest Cases
column9: Seattle officials said today that they were dropping all but about 40 of the unresolved misdemeanor cases stemming from the tumultuous street protests of the World Trade Organization meeting here a month ago.    At least a few protesters said they...
column10: Seattle officials said today that they were dropping all but about 40 of the unresolved misdemeanor cases stemming from the tumultuous street protests of the World Trade Organization meeting here a month ago. At least a few protesters said they opposed the city's move because they hoped to use their trials to showcase the city's mishandling of the demonstrations, which grew so raucous and tense that the National Guard was called in and the police used tear gas and rubber pellets to disperse the crowds.

column3: In Turbulent Times, a Prison Boiled Over
column9: Even before the rioting started on Sept. 9, 1971, the state prison in Attica, N.Y., was in ferment. So was the entire country.    Two months earlier, angry Attica inmates had petitioned state correction officials to ease chronic overcrowding and...
column10: Even before the rioting started on Sept. 9, 1971, the state prison in Attica, N.Y., was in ferment. So was the entire country. Two months earlier, angry Attica inmates had petitioned state correction officials to ease chronic overcrowding and censorship rules, and to improve conditions that limited them to one shower a week and one roll of toilet paper a month. A sign of the brewing unrest was a fast that the prisoners held on Aug. 22 in memory of George Jackson, a prominent black radical who had been killed by prison guards in California during a breakout attempt.

column3: Irate Cuban-Americans Paralyze Miami
column9: Energized by a new cause, hundreds of Cuban-Americans shut down much of Miami today with waves of civil disobedience, temporarily blocking access to the Port of Miami and choking traffic on dozens of busy streets to protest the Clinton...
column10: Energized by a new cause, hundreds of Cuban-Americans shut down much of Miami today with waves of civil disobedience, temporarily blocking access to the Port of Miami and choking traffic on dozens of busy streets to protest the Clinton administration's decision to return 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez to his father in Cuba. About 135 protesters were arrested by riot police officers, who led most of them away peacefully in plastic handcuffs as the crowd chanted, ''Libertad Elian, libertad Elian.''

column3: Attica: Settled, But Not Healed
column9: Nearly 30 years after 43 people were killed and more than 80 were injured at the uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in upstate New York, a court settlement will require the state to pay $8 million to surviving inmates and $4 million to...
column10: Nearly 30 years after 43 people were killed and more than 80 were injured at the uprising at the Attica Correctional Facility in upstate New York, a court settlement will require the state to pay $8 million to surviving inmates and $4 million to their lawyers. But New York has not admitted, and will not have to admit, any wrongdoing, even though inmates were killed, beaten and tortured after state troopers stormed the prison.

column2: ATTICA CORRECTIONAL FACILITY; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; SUITS AND CLAIMS AGAINST GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TORTURE
column3: The Nation; Attica: Exorcising the Demons, Redeeming the Deaths
column9: THE immediate spark, not that it matters after so many years, was a series of misunderstandings. One evening, hours after a prison guard mistakenly thought they had been fighting, two inmates were taken from their cells for punishment. A rumor, no...
column10: THE immediate spark, not that it matters after so many years, was a series of misunderstandings. One evening, hours after a prison guard mistakenly thought they had been fighting, two inmates were taken from their cells for punishment. A rumor, no more true than the phantom fight, spread through the cellblock that both had been beaten. In a way, the whole thing was pretty silly. The consequences were anything but.

column2: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT; REVIEWS; NINETEEN HUNDRED SIXTIES; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
column3: Mom, Dad: Where Were You in the 60's?
column9: SOME bearded, beaded sage once remarked that if you could remember the 1960's, you probably weren't a part of them. This, of course, raises the shagadelic question: how can you forget something that will not go away?    From the repackaging of the...
column10: SOME bearded, beaded sage once remarked that if you could remember the 1960's, you probably weren't a part of them. This, of course, raises the shagadelic question: how can you forget something that will not go away? From the repackaging of the music (more and better quality is available now from Rhino, Rycodisc and Sony Legacy than was ever available at the time), the artifacts to the resurrection of the zeitgeist with Austin Powers, Woodstock 99 and the street theater at the World Trade Organization protests in Seattle, the decade seems to want to stick around.

column2: JOHNSTON, BILL; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS

column9: A federal prosecutor who told Attorney General Janet Reno that information about the 1993 Branch Davidian siege might have been withheld from her resigned today, his office said.      The departure of Assistant United States Attorney Bill Johnston...
column10: A federal prosecutor who told Attorney General Janet Reno that information about the 1993 Branch Davidian siege might have been withheld from her resigned today, his office said. The departure of Assistant United States Attorney Bill Johnston came four months after he was pulled off the case and five months after he sent his letter to Ms. Reno.

column10: When Dr. Veronique Vasseur began working at La Sante prison in Paris, the experience was so shocking that she started keeping a diary. Within days she had met inmates so deranged or depressed that they had swallowed rat poison, forks or drain cleaner.

column3: Acting Editor, Specialist in Business Coverage, Is Made Permanent at The Post
column9: The New York Post, which has built its rowdy reputation on front-page coverage of crime (''Headless Body in Topless Bar''), sports (''Bellichicken'') and politics (''Shame on Hillary'') is naming as its editor a journalist who has spent her entire...
column10: The New York Post, which has built its rowdy reputation on front-page coverage of crime (''Headless Body in Topless Bar''), sports (''Bellichicken'') and politics (''Shame on Hillary'') is naming as its editor a journalist who has spent her entire career covering business (as in ''You've Got Deal''). Xana Antunes (pronounced SHAH-na An-TOON-ess), who joined The Post as deputy business editor in 1995, has been acting editor of The Post since October, when Kenneth Chandler, the editor in chief, assumed the title of publisher and stepped down from day-to-day newsroom management.

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; FRANCE; UNITED NATIONS; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 7 Killed and 9 Hurt in Kosovo Rampage, Worst Since War
column9: In the worst violence Kosovo has seen since the end of the war, seven Albanians were killed and at least nine wounded on Thursday night when about 500 people rampaged through the streets, bursting into apartments, firing guns and throwing grenades.  ...
column10: In the worst violence Kosovo has seen since the end of the war, seven Albanians were killed and at least nine wounded on Thursday night when about 500 people rampaged through the streets, bursting into apartments, firing guns and throwing grenades. The fierce fighting had subsided by daybreak, but the tension remained in this divided city as angry crowds of Serbs and Albanians gathered on either side of a bridge that spans the Ibar River, which runs through the heart of this industrial city 30 miles northwest of Kosovo's provincial capital, Pristina. The river separates the two communities; about 9,000 Serbs control the north bank, and 90,000 ethnic Albanians live on the south side.

column2: AUTOMOBILES; UTILITY VEHICLES AND OTHER LIGHT TRUCKS; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS
column3: The Way We Live Now: 2-6-00: Salient Facts: Armored S.U.V.'s; Gangsta on Board
column9: According to law-enforcement officials, Puffy Combs -- the rapper recently charged with throwing a 9-millimeter handgun out the window of his speeding Lincoln Navigator -- had installed a secret trap door to hide a weapon. The problem? The trap...
column10: According to law-enforcement officials, Puffy Combs -- the rapper recently charged with throwing a 9-millimeter handgun out the window of his speeding Lincoln Navigator -- had installed a secret trap door to hide a weapon. The problem? The trap door's security system was so elaborate that in the heat of the moment no one in the car could figure out how to get it open. According to a report in The New York Post, one witness told the grand jury that Combs yelled: ''Trap! Trap! Open the trap!'' (Combs has pleaded not guilty to charges of illegal gun possession.) Police say that secret gun vaults are increasingly common among certain high-risk drivers. And for those who have enough money and know the right auto-body mechanic, they are just one of the many options available. Trap Doors First used by drug gangs, these discreet compartments can keep illegal contraband (or legitimate cargo, should the need arise) safe and out of sight. As long as you can open them, that is: law-enforcement officials in New York have discovered traps -- inside dashboards, behind back seats, in door panels and floorboards -- that pop open only when the operator turns on the heat while the radio is set to a certain station, or when he inserts a hairpin into connections in the doorjamb while stepping on the brakes. More high-tech versions involve a series of microswitches that must be flipped in sequence. A few years ago, a drug gang in Washington Heights had a whole fleet of nondescript sedans whose traps could be opened only by inserting fuses into the second and fourth slots on the right column of the fuse box and then activating the rear-window defroster. ''Five years ago,'' one veteran New York City lawman said, ''these things were unusual. Now they're commonplace.'' Then again, he added, ''to some degree that's a function that we know to look for them now.'' Trap doors aren't actually illegal. Still, many alarm shops or auto detailers are leery of installing them. ''The police department frowns upon that kind of stuff,'' said the owner of a custom shop in the Bronx. ''If you start putting it in they give you a hard time. People ask me for safes, and I won't do it, because it's just too much to have in my head.'' Michael Trusio, a senior sales executive at Krystal Enterprises in Brea, Calif., agrees that it's business he'd rather not have. But, he added, ''we don't want to tell somebody no and then have someone come around and burn our plant down.'' Armor Car armor, which can include bulletproof glass in the windows, ballistic steel in the doors and body and Kevlar shields for the floorboards and gas tank, was once used for skittish billionaires and presidential motorcades. Today, it's just another accessory for the nation's wealthiest drivers. But all that security doesn't come cheap. Outfitting the family Mercedes in this bulletproof material can cost $100,000. And for some, that's just the beginning. ''I can think of 10 or 12 families who have armored cars for everyone,'' said Craig Fingold, the president of Beverly Hills Motoring, which has dubbed itself the Neiman Marcus of automotive accessories. Depending on the thickness, armor can add from 400 to 4,000 pounds to the weight of the car. Fingold said that a record mogul who had been threatened with death by a rapper had recently come in and had his Suburban outfitted with 4-inch metal -- enough to stop machine-gun fire. And Notorious B.I.G. stopped in to check out an armoring system but did not buy it. A few months later, he was shot to death in his Suburban. The Works Even drivers whose security concerns don't involve wielding or dodging heavy firepower have a number of self-defense toys to consider. Auto Taser ($200) delivers a powerful electric shock to anyone who lays an unwelcome hand on the steering wheel. Tiny video cameras ($800) that are installed with a clear view of the front seat can be useful for those who want evidence of police harassment; Fingold says they're especially popular with celebrities and sports figures. But for some wary drivers, the best defense is a good offense. Outfits like the Counter Spy Shops sell devices that spew oil, leaving a dangerous slick behind them ($1,300); they are reportedly popular in Russia, as are similar devices that spray a mist of oil on the windshield of the car behind ($1,300). Contraptions that scatter a large number of tacks in a car's wake -- first seen on countless Saturday-morning cartoons -- cost slightly more. (They start at $1,500.) Counter Spy claims it installed one for the Shah of Iran. Thankfully for the average American driver, however, most are available for export only. Finally, for those less afraid of fellow motorists than of airborne hazards, the smart choice is a tear-gas deterrent system that seals the car against unfiltered air ($5,000).

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; UNITED NATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
column3: In Kosovo, More Clashes Between Peacekeepers and Albanians
column9: Peacekeepers clashed with Kosovo Albanians for a second day today in this town, firing percussion grenades and tear gas to push back angry crowds from the bridge that divides the city.    Two Albanians and eight soldiers were reported wounded in the...
column10: Peacekeepers clashed with Kosovo Albanians for a second day today in this town, firing percussion grenades and tear gas to push back angry crowds from the bridge that divides the city. Two Albanians and eight soldiers were reported wounded in the clash as Albanian youths threw bottles and stones at troops guarding the bridge. Police in riot gear with helmets and shields reacted forcefully, advancing in formation, backed up by four Dutch armored vehicles.

column2: SANCHEZ, TOM; WEBB, WELLINGTON; DENVER (COLO); BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; POLICE; HISPANIC-AMERICANS
column3: Denver Police Chief Pushed Out After a Series of Problems
column9: Mayor Wellington Webb began a search today for a new police chief after a series of problems, including the accidental shooting death of a man in a botched drug raid, led him to seek the resignation of a 30-year veteran of the force who served less...
column10: Mayor Wellington Webb began a search today for a new police chief after a series of problems, including the accidental shooting death of a man in a botched drug raid, led him to seek the resignation of a 30-year veteran of the force who served less than 18 months as its chief. In announcing his request late Tuesday after meeting with the chief, Tom Sanchez, the city's first Hispanic police chief and one of the few Hispanics leading a big-city police force, Mayor Webb said, ''At certain times, due to a convergence of issues, a leadership change is necessary.''

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); GREAT BRITAIN; SERBIA; FRANCE
column3: British Troops Replace French in Riot-Torn Kosovo Town
column9: British peacekeeping forces took over guard duties on a bridge in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo today, replacing French troops that had been accused of failing to protect ethnic Albanians and Serbs.    The arrival of the...
column10: British peacekeeping forces took over guard duties on a bridge in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo today, replacing French troops that had been accused of failing to protect ethnic Albanians and Serbs. The arrival of the British -- about 150 men from the Royal Green Jackets who are based in central Kosovo -- is the latest effort by peacekeepers to ensure security and reduce tension in the area, which was the scene of riots last week. During an all-night rampage, angry Serbs took to the streets in retaliation for the deaths of two Serbs killed in a bus ambush.

column2: METROSTARS; SOCCER
column3: A New Striker Is Coming
column9: METROSTARS       The MetroStars, the worst team in Major League Soccer last season, made another move yesterday, trading away one Colombian striker for another. The MetroStars sent Henry Zambrano to the Colorado Rapids and replaced him with Alex...
column10: METROSTARS The MetroStars, the worst team in Major League Soccer last season, made another move yesterday, trading away one Colombian striker for another. The MetroStars sent Henry Zambrano to the Colorado Rapids and replaced him with Alex Comas, who played with Colombia's Atletico National for the past three years.

column2: NEW YORK STATE; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; ATTICA STATE PRISON (NY); CLASS-ACTION SUITS; SUITS AND CLAIMS AGAINST GOVERNMENT; GUARDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TORTURE
column3: Ex-Attica Inmates Recount Shattered Lives and Dreams
column9: Gary Haynes, Attica survivor, waited almost 30 years for this day.    Dressed in a weathered suit with his mother, Betty, at his side, Mr. Haynes showed up at the federal district courthouse here almost an hour early this morning. He wanted to talk...
column10: Gary Haynes, Attica survivor, waited almost 30 years for this day. Dressed in a weathered suit with his mother, Betty, at his side, Mr. Haynes showed up at the federal district courthouse here almost an hour early this morning. He wanted to talk about how the guards had beaten him and burned his chest with cigarettes. He wanted to tell people about the kidney transplant that he says was a result of the beating -- as well as the broken ankle, the broken feet, the broken hip and the thwarted dreams that ensued.

column2: CHERNOKOZOVO (RUSSIA); INGUSHETIA (RUSSIAN REPUBLIC); RUSSIA; CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; SEX CRIMES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; TORTURE
column3: Chechens Tell of Torture in Russian Camp
column9: Three men seized by Russian troops and imprisoned at a detention camp in northern Chechnya this winter have told human rights observers of beatings, torture and rapes they say took place there before they bribed their way to freedom this month.    ...
column10: Three men seized by Russian troops and imprisoned at a detention camp in northern Chechnya this winter have told human rights observers of beatings, torture and rapes they say took place there before they bribed their way to freedom this month. The three, who are now in the neighboring Russian province of Ingushetia, gave their accounts to researchers for Human Rights Watch, which relayed them to news organizations this week.

column2: LEBANON; AKUR (LEBANON); ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Army Breaks Up Beirut Demonstration at U.S. Embassy
column9: Popular anger erupted outside the United States Embassy today, a week after Israel retaliated against Lebanon for guerrilla attacks that killed several Israeli soldiers. Hundreds of Lebanese students joined with other protesters in throwing rocks and...
column10: Popular anger erupted outside the United States Embassy today, a week after Israel retaliated against Lebanon for guerrilla attacks that killed several Israeli soldiers. Hundreds of Lebanese students joined with other protesters in throwing rocks and tomatoes at Lebanese army and police detachments, which responded with batons, tear gas canisters and high-pressure water hoses. The protests appeared to have been organized with the help of Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Party of God, whose guerrillas have mounted an offensive in southern Lebanon that has killed seven Israeli soldiers in less than three weeks. In a fiery speech on Wednesday, the Hezbollah leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, citing official American statements that supported the Israeli bombing, called on this nation of 3.5 million people to boycott the United States ambassador, David Satterfield, whom he described as ''the U.S.-Israeli ambassador in Lebanon.''

column2: ISRAEL; CABLE NEWS NETWORK; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; TELEVISION; LEBANON-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
column3: Protests in Beirut Against U.S. and Israel Turn Wrath on CNN
column9: A second day of angry street protests against Israel and the United States turned today against the American cable network CNN, with Lebanese soldiers and policemen in riot gear firing tear gas to drive back about 3,000 demonstrators who tried to...
column10: A second day of angry street protests against Israel and the United States turned today against the American cable network CNN, with Lebanese soldiers and policemen in riot gear firing tear gas to drive back about 3,000 demonstrators who tried to reach CNN's Beirut offices. The demonstrators, mostly university students, dispersed after about an hour without breaking through barricades. Their anger at CNN, the only American television network with a news bureau here, appeared to be as much an outgrowth of resentment of the United States' support of Israel as an attack on CNN's Middle East coverage, although that, too, was widely condemned.

column2: KIM DAE JUNG; SOUTH KOREA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
column3: Korean Fights For Coalition And His Aims As a Reformer
column9: Two years into his five-year term as president, Kim Dae Jung is locked in a surprisingly ugly fight for his political life -- or at least to avoid having the remainder of his term turned into an ornamental presidency.     The depth of his predicament...
column10: Two years into his five-year term as president, Kim Dae Jung is locked in a surprisingly ugly fight for his political life -- or at least to avoid having the remainder of his term turned into an ornamental presidency. The depth of his predicament was driven home the other day when one of South Korea's leading politicians compared the president, who took office as a reformer with a long history of opposition dissent, to Mao Zedong.

column3: Rudolph Patzert, 88; Transported Jews to Palestine After War
column9: Rudolph W. Patzert, the captain of a rusty 1904 gunboat that carried more than 1,380 Jewish refugees from Europe to Palestine as part of a secret rescue operation after World War II, died on Jan. 21 in a nursing home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 88.  ...
column10: Rudolph W. Patzert, the captain of a rusty 1904 gunboat that carried more than 1,380 Jewish refugees from Europe to Palestine as part of a secret rescue operation after World War II, died on Jan. 21 in a nursing home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 88. The cause was cancer, said his son Bill.

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Albanians Rally to Oust Serbs From a City in Kosovo
column9: Thousands of ethnic Albanians from throughout Kosovo marched on this divided city today and clashed with a phalanx of NATO-led troops, who used tear gas and fists to keep them from reaching the Serbian district.    A throng of protesters -- some...
column10: Thousands of ethnic Albanians from throughout Kosovo marched on this divided city today and clashed with a phalanx of NATO-led troops, who used tear gas and fists to keep them from reaching the Serbian district. A throng of protesters -- some estimates put their number at 25,000, others at twice that -- tried to cross the main bridge that divides the Serbian and Albanian sections of this mining town. The crowd was turned back as thousands of Serbs stood on the other side, waving flags and playing nationalist songs.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-11    China Threatens Taiwan On Reunification Issue  Beijing issued the bluntest warning yet that it would not wait indefinitely for Taiwan to reunite with the mainland, saying that if Taiwan, which is to hold presidential...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 China Threatens Taiwan On Reunification Issue Beijing issued the bluntest warning yet that it would not wait indefinitely for Taiwan to reunite with the mainland, saying that if Taiwan, which is to hold presidential elections on March 18, indefinitely refused to pursue reunification, then China would ''adopt all drastic measures possible, including the use of force.'' A1 Gains for Iran Reformers An adviser to President Mohammad Khatami said reform candidates appeared to have won 73 percent of the parliamentary seats already decided and could control up to 90 percent after a runoff in April. column9: One inmate was killed today and 12 others were wounded in a riot at a maximum-security prison here  that guards quelled with gunfire.    The violence came on the same day that a federal indictment of two former guards for attacks on inmates at the...
column10: One inmate was killed today and 12 others were wounded in a riot at a maximum-security prison here that guards quelled with gunfire. The violence came on the same day that a federal indictment of two former guards for attacks on inmates at the prison was made public in San Francisco.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    RUSSIA: FUNERAL IN ST. PETERSBURG -- Under heavy security because of a rumored assassination plot, President Vladimir V. Putin, left, attended the St. Petersburg funeral of his mentor and that city's first elected mayor, Anatoly Sobchak....
column10: EUROPE RUSSIA: FUNERAL IN ST. PETERSBURG -- Under heavy security because of a rumored assassination plot, President Vladimir V. Putin, left, attended the St. Petersburg funeral of his mentor and that city's first elected mayor, Anatoly Sobchak. Mr. Putin said Mr. Sobchak, who fled Russia from 1997 to 1999 after being accused of corruption, was a democratic visionary destroyed by persecution. Mr. Sobchak died after a heart attack last weekend. Michael Wines (NYT) SERBIA: MORE POLICE FOR KOSOVO -- Responding to the need for more civilian police officers in Kosovo and for other peacekeeping missions, the United States said it would create a permanent reserve of 2,000 officers to be available without delay. ''The recent slowness in deploying desperately needed civilian police to Kosovo provides only the latest evidence that present international capabilities are not adequate,'' said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

column2: SOUTH KOREA; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; REFORM AND REORGANIZATION; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; LAW AND LEGISLATION; ELECTIONS; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET
column3: Internet Recharges Reformers In Korea
column9: With his one-day beard and tousled hair, Park Byung Ok retains a hint of the look of the student protesters who lobbed rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who replied with tear gas and rubber bullets, in the often turbulent 1980's here.    But...
column10: With his one-day beard and tousled hair, Park Byung Ok retains a hint of the look of the student protesters who lobbed rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who replied with tear gas and rubber bullets, in the often turbulent 1980's here. But these days, Mr. Park, 39, and his associates are launching nothing more lethal than e-mails -- many thousands -- to officials and political parties from civic groups that are sprouting around the country. The effects are rocking South Korea in ways never imagined by the radical opposition that many of the protesters belonged to a generation ago.

column2: CHERNOKOZOVO (RUSSIA); RUSSIA; CHECHNYA (RUSSIA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; INDEPENDENCE MOVEMENTS AND SECESSION; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
column3: At Russian Camp, 2 Views of Chechen Prisoners
column9: The heavy steel doors, freshly painted for visitors, swung open one by one along a 100-foot-long corridor to reveal cold cells, gauzy from cigarette smoke and poor ventilation, where the sallow faces of Chechen men and women peered out from the...
column10: The heavy steel doors, freshly painted for visitors, swung open one by one along a 100-foot-long corridor to reveal cold cells, gauzy from cigarette smoke and poor ventilation, where the sallow faces of Chechen men and women peered out from the shadows -- their eyes frozen by the flash of intruding cameras. Their guards barked orders at them to ''stand back from the door!'' or to ''turn around!'' or ''speak up!'' and to report to a group of visitors on the conditions in this notorious ''filtration'' camp. Some who have passed through here have alleged that brutal beatings and torture have taken place.

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Troops Open Path for Kosovars to Return Home
column9: Firing tear gas and stun grenades and using armored personnel carriers, security forces punched a corridor through a crowd of Serbian protesters today, returning dozens of ethnic Albanians to their homes in this divided city.    More than 30 people...
column10: Firing tear gas and stun grenades and using armored personnel carriers, security forces punched a corridor through a crowd of Serbian protesters today, returning dozens of ethnic Albanians to their homes in this divided city. More than 30 people crossed the three-foot-deep Ibar River in the personnel carriers, bypassing demonstrators on the main bridge nearby, United Nations officials said. Those who crossed included members of 24 families, mostly said to be in their 50's or 60's.

column2: CLINTON, BILL; SELMA (ALA); ALABAMA; BLACKS; DISCRIMINATION; ELECTIONS
column3: Looking Back at a Day in Selma, 35 Years On
column9: Thirty-five years after Alabama state troopers waged a bloody attack on civil rights demonstrators here, President Clinton renewed the call for racial equality today at an anniversary gathering that drew thousands to the site of the march.    So much...
column10: Thirty-five years after Alabama state troopers waged a bloody attack on civil rights demonstrators here, President Clinton renewed the call for racial equality today at an anniversary gathering that drew thousands to the site of the march. So much has changed, everyone agreed, since that day in 1965 when the brutal racism of the South flared up for all to see. But so many challenges remain.

column2: HAZING
column3: First, The Ordeal
column9: The incidents are notable for their brutality. A freshman football player on Long Island is badly beaten by his senior teammates; a high school wrestler in Trumbull, Conn., is hogtied, confined inside a gym locker and then sexually violated with a...
column10: The incidents are notable for their brutality. A freshman football player on Long Island is badly beaten by his senior teammates; a high school wrestler in Trumbull, Conn., is hogtied, confined inside a gym locker and then sexually violated with a knife handle; a freshman hockey player at the University of Vermont is forced to perform a series of homoerotic acts. Hazing incidents, which are more and more in the news, are thought to reflect a rising level of violent incidents in our society and, as such, they have been roundly denounced. Some critics take it further and say all hazing must stop. The recent acts are criminal and should be prosecuted. But the very pervasiveness of hazing should also alert people that something else is going on. Unlike most violence, hazings are, to some degree, elective, and they result in an increase in status on the part of the victim. Moreover, hazing practices can be found in virtually every culture in the world.

column2: FRANCE; MCDONALD'S CORP; RESTAURANTS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; FAST FOOD INDUSTRY
column3: Egalite, Fraternite et Burgers
column9: My grandmother was shocked when I went to work for McDonald's. She thought I was cooking fries on Boulevard St.-Michel. It was 1984. McDonald's had 17 restaurants in France. Its headquarters was in an apartment. But I thought if I wanted to get...
column10: My grandmother was shocked when I went to work for McDonald's. She thought I was cooking fries on Boulevard St.-Michel. It was 1984. McDonald's had 17 restaurants in France. Its headquarters was in an apartment. But I thought if I wanted to get ahead, I should join an American company. It would take me forever to run a French company: I'd have to know all the right people. I was 39 when I became McDonald's president two years ago -- very, very unusual for France. When I was invited to the World Cup, I sat in the box with French executives. I think they thought I was there to serve the drinks. Then one asked: ''Is your chauffeur waiting for you outside?'' I said: ''No, I have my subway ticket in my pocket.'' He couldn't believe it.

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); ITALY; MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; FRANCE; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: U.S. Troops Seize Weapons From Albanians in Kosovo
column9: American troops in Kosovo carried out raids on the strongholds of ethnic Albanian guerrillas on Wednesday, capturing bombs and other weapons in the largest effort to date by American forces there to end the guerrillas' threat to the NATO-led...
column10: American troops in Kosovo carried out raids on the strongholds of ethnic Albanian guerrillas on Wednesday, capturing bombs and other weapons in the largest effort to date by American forces there to end the guerrillas' threat to the NATO-led peacekeeping mission, American officials said. No one was reported injured in the raids, which were conducted in villages and guerrilla posts in the eastern sector of Kosovo, where the bulk of the nearly 6,000 American troops in the territory are stationed. It was unclear if the American troops fired their weapons.

column2: DANFORTH, JOHN C; KORESH, DAVID; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; RECORDINGS (VIDEO); RELIGIOUS CULTS; SUITS AND LITIGATION
column3: Seeking Clues By Simulating Davidian Siege
column9: Early this Sunday, a select group of government officials and private lawyers will meet at nearby Fort Hood, the nation's largest military base. For several hours, maybe longer, they will watch an extraordinary simulation intended to answer a...
column10: Early this Sunday, a select group of government officials and private lawyers will meet at nearby Fort Hood, the nation's largest military base. For several hours, maybe longer, they will watch an extraordinary simulation intended to answer a question that has raged from Internet chat rooms to the halls of Congress: Did federal agents fire gunshots into the Branch Davidian compound occupied by David Koresh and his followers shortly before it burned to the ground on April 19, 1993, claiming the lives of about 80 men, women and children?

column2: PALCZYNSKI, JOSEPH C; MARYLAND; HOSTAGES; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; MENTAL HEALTH AND DISORDERS
column3: Maryland Hostage Siege Drags on Into Third Night
column9: A former convict with a history of mental illness, hunted in a shooting spree that took four lives, maintained a standoff against the police today, crackling the air with warning gunfire as he held three hostages in this tense suburban neighborhood. ...
column10: A former convict with a history of mental illness, hunted in a shooting spree that took four lives, maintained a standoff against the police today, crackling the air with warning gunfire as he held three hostages in this tense suburban neighborhood. ''Come on, Joby, pick up the phone,'' police officers pleaded over a loudspeaker from an armored car parked near the building where the suspect, Joseph Palcyzinski, known as Joby, had been holed up almost three days.

column2: DORISMOND, PATRICK M; SHARPTON, AL; GIULIANI, RUDOLPH W; DORISMOND, MARIE; NEW YORK CITY; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ATTACKS ON POLICE; BLACKS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
column3: Angry Mourners and Police Clash At Funeral of Man Shot by Officer
column9: On a day of solemnity and outrage that degenerated into violence, Patrick M. Dorismond, the unarmed son of Haitian immigrants who was shot to death in a confrontation with the police on March 16, was carried across Brooklyn, eulogized as a martyr and...
column10: On a day of solemnity and outrage that degenerated into violence, Patrick M. Dorismond, the unarmed son of Haitian immigrants who was shot to death in a confrontation with the police on March 16, was carried across Brooklyn, eulogized as a martyr and laid to rest yesterday after a march and funeral that drew thousands of anguished mourners and angry protesters. Before and after his funeral, there were clashes between protesters and the police, and wild scenes and sounds of chaos: barricades tumbling under surging crowds, American flags burning, the clashing chords of car horns, and the crash of glass thrown from a height, all beneath the airborne staccato of police helicopters.

column3: World Briefing
column9: MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: TALIBAN FOE FLEES -- Iran's official news agency said Ismail Khan, the former governor of Herat Province in Afghanistan and a major figure in the opposition to the ruling Taliban, had crossed into Iran and reached the city of...
column10: MIDDLE EAST IRAN: TALIBAN FOE FLEES -- Iran's official news agency said Ismail Khan, the former governor of Herat Province in Afghanistan and a major figure in the opposition to the ruling Taliban, had crossed into Iran and reached the city of Meshed after escaping from a Taliban prison. Mr. Khan, a hero to many Afghans for his fight against Soviet forces in the 1980's, was said to have reached Iran with another anti-Taliban leader who escaped from prison with him, Hafiz Qadir. Iran strongly opposes the Taliban. John F. Burns (NYT)

column2: CHICAGO (ILL); GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; TRAVEL AND VACATIONS
column3: Big Shoulders, Buffed for Action
column9: When friends from abroad come to the United States, I always send them to Chicago, or try to. It is the quintessential American city: muscular, inventive, wonderfully diverse, worldly-wise (if a bit oafish at times) and as unpretentious as its...
column10: When friends from abroad come to the United States, I always send them to Chicago, or try to. It is the quintessential American city: muscular, inventive, wonderfully diverse, worldly-wise (if a bit oafish at times) and as unpretentious as its prairie-flat vowels. ''Chicago is American in every chitling and sparerib,'' H. L. Mencken wrote wickedly during the era when the city's stockyards, since demolished, were the biggest anywhere. ''It is alive from snout to tail.''

column3: Zimbabwe Protesters Are Beaten by Government Supporters
column9: A peaceful anti-government march in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, erupted in violence today as a group of armed men wielding machetes and clubs attacked the crowd of several thousand marchers, leaving several people seriously injured.    About 200...
column10: A peaceful anti-government march in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, erupted in violence today as a group of armed men wielding machetes and clubs attacked the crowd of several thousand marchers, leaving several people seriously injured. About 200 men, who were described by witnesses as supporters of President Robert Mugabe, hurled bricks and stones and beat several protesters bloody until riot policemen intervened with tear gas.

column2: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
column3: Seattle Police Admit Failure In '99 Protests
column9: Referring to protesters as a ''well-trained and equipped adversary,'' Seattle police officials issued a report today blaming inadequate financing and lack of preparation for the violence that marked the World Trade Organization's meeting here last...
column10: Referring to protesters as a ''well-trained and equipped adversary,'' Seattle police officials issued a report today blaming inadequate financing and lack of preparation for the violence that marked the World Trade Organization's meeting here last year. Even as it admitted its own organizational failures in preparing for the protests, which led to the resignation of the police chief, the report angered many protesters.

column2: ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DISCRIMINATION; ARABS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Israel Is Slowly Shedding Harsh Treatment of Arabs
column9: Justice Minister Yossi Beilin calls it a ''quiet revolution.''     Through the years, Israel has been consistently criticized by many human and civil rights organizations for invoking national security to explain practices that were considered...
column10: Justice Minister Yossi Beilin calls it a ''quiet revolution.'' Through the years, Israel has been consistently criticized by many human and civil rights organizations for invoking national security to explain practices that were considered exclusionary, discriminatory and coercive toward Israeli Arabs and Palestinians. But since the right-wing government was replaced last summer by a broad coalition including several leftists and human rights advocates, crucial policy changes have been made that, together with a spate of High Court decisions, point toward a sea change.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL  A3-6    Bosnia War Crimes Suspect  Is Charged by Tribunal  Momcilo Krajisnik, the most senior war crimes defendant so far from the Bosnian conflict, responded ''not guilty'' to each of nine charges, including genocide, made against...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Bosnia War Crimes Suspect Is Charged by Tribunal Momcilo Krajisnik, the most senior war crimes defendant so far from the Bosnian conflict, responded ''not guilty'' to each of nine charges, including genocide, made against him by the international war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia. A4 Bosnia votes in municipal elections today to decide whether to stay with ethnic parties that led them to war eight years ago. A4 New Japan Leader's Promise Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, in his first policy speech to Parliament, vowed to continue and expand the economic and other changes begun by his ailing predecessor, Keizo Obuchi, who remained in a coma. A5 I.M.F.'s New Chief in Russia Stanley Fischer said the fund was ready to pursue a new relationship with Russia as soon as President-elect Vladimir V. Putin acted on his promise to build a better foundation for the country's still shaky market economy. Mr. Fischer, the fund's acting director, met with Mr. Putin before making his remarks. A6 American Not Charged The United States said Russia had not formally charged an American arrested on suspicion of spying. The United States Embassy identified the American as Edmond Pope, 53, and said he had been visited by a consular officer. A6 Haiti Election Protest Two top officials have resigned at the urging of the center-left opposition coalition to protest the government's failure to schedule local and parliamentary elections. Environment Minister Yves Cadet and Jean Ronald Joseph, labor undersecretary at the Social Affairs Ministry, held their posts since March 1999. (AP) Bolivians Protest Water Rates The police fired tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannons to scatter crowds in Cochabamba, Bolivia's third-largest city, during protests against an increase in water rates. Chaos enveloped some streets of the city, which is 350 miles east of La Paz, as protesters threw rocks and firebombs at the police, who then stormed the rioters. Hundreds of police officers and soldiers have virtually taken control of the streets. (AP) World Briefing A6 NATIONAL A7-10, 14 Senate Adopts G.O.P. Plan For $1.8 Trillion Budget The Senate, voting 51 to 45 largely along party lines, approved a budget plan for next year that would raise spending on the military and education, cut or freeze spending in many domestic programs, reduce taxes by at least $150 billion over five years, add a $40 billion prescription drug benefit to Medicare and pay down publicly held debt with the surplus generated by Social Security. A1 Medicaid Rolls to Be Restored The Clinton administration ordered states to restore benefits to families improperly deprived of health insurance when they were left off the welfare rolls as an unintended consequence of the 1996 welfare law. A10 An Accuser Is Accused The Pentagon's inspector general opened a preliminary investigation of the Army's highest-ranking woman, Lt. Gen. Claudia J. Kennedy, who has accused another general of sexual misconduct in 1996, senior defense officials said. The inquiry began after the Pentagon's inspector general received an electronic message from a retired officer who accused General Kennedy of personal misconduct during the mid-1980's. A9 U.S. to Let Elian Return Attorney General Janet Reno said government lawyers would prepare an order as early as next week allowing Elian Gonzalez to return to Cuba with his father. She appealed to the boy's Miami relatives to promptly and peacefully turn him over. A1 Vice President Al Gore made a campaign swing through Florida but avoided discussion of the Gonzalez case, even though it has dominated media coverage there for weeks. A8 Meeting With Gay Republicans Gov. George W. Bush said he had invited a small group of gay Republicans to meet with him next week, a development that stood in contrast to his longstanding refusal to meet formally with the Log Cabin Republicans, a leading gay political organization. A9 Finding Against Big Tobacco A Miami jury found that the diseases of three smokers chosen to represent hundreds of thousands of Florida residents in a class-action lawsuit had been caused by cigarettes, setting the stage for a potentially huge blow to the tobacco industry. A7 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Ad Asked Welfare Workers To Fill In for Strikers The city distributed a flier offering welfare recipients who work for their benefits security jobs at residential buildings if doormen and other building workers went on strike. A Human Resources Administration official said the city had turned down a request to supply such workers, because it amounted to strike breaking, and she expressed puzzlement at the flier's distribution. B1 Operation Condor Cut Back A third of the overtime money earmarked for the ambitious but much-criticized anti-narcotics effort will instead be used for increased uniformed patrols that will pursue various other offenses, officials said. B1 No Plans to Change Mayor Giuliani said he would not alter his campaign style despite polls suggesting his candidacy was in difficulty, saying voters would ultimately judge him on his mayoral record. B4 Shake-Up at Jewish Weekly Seth Lipsky, founding editor of The Forward, is being forced out by owners who regard him as too right-wing for the paper's socialist traditions, editors and executives said. B3 Religion Journal B6 EDUCATION Merit Seen in Web Proposal The chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, Carl T. Hayden, said a proposal to create a New York City Board of Education site on the Internet that accepts corporate advertising in exchange for computer equipment and services deserved serious consideration. B3 SPORTS D1-8 Duval Moves Up in Masters David Duval shot a seven-under-par 65 that gave him a one-stroke lead after the second round. D1 U.S. Stays Even in Davis Cup Jiri Novak of the Czech Republic swept Pete Sampras, 7-6 (1), 6-3, 6-2, but Andre Agassi evened the quarterfinal match at 1-1 by beating Slava Dosedel, 6-3, 6-3, 6-3. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Demands for Perquisites Met Salomon Smith Barney, responding to demands compiled by a 23-year-old junior investment banker, is piling on perks to stem a flow of young employees to Internet companies. A1 No Dampening of Economy The economy rolled on in March, despite recent interest rate rises, creating 416,000 jobs. Unemployment held at about 4.1 percent. C1 The Nasdaq soared 178.89 points, or 4.2 percent, to 4,446.45, and the S.& P. 500 climbed 15.01 points, or 1 percent, to 1,516.35, but the Dow slipped 2.79 points, to 11,111.48. C1 A Royal Investment Queen Elizabeth II was rewarded for holding her $160,000, 1.5 percent stake in an Internet company, Getmapping .com. Its share price soared almost tenfold as the stock went public. The company plans to produce the first full aerial map of her realm. C1 Business Digest C1 OBITUARIES A11 ARTS & IDEAS B7-18 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: Pakistan's questionable verdict; don't victimize the Constitution; a cartel for doctors; peacekeeping in Sierra Leone. Columns: Bob Herbert, William Safire. Bridge B17 TV Listings B18 Crossword B16 Weather A10 Public Lives A7

column2: TUCKER, KEN; SUSOEFF, JOHN; SEX PISTOLS; MUSIC
column3: 'Mellow,' Not Fresh
column9: To the Editor:    Ken Tucker says the Sex Pistols existed to ''release an invigorating blast of poisonous gas into the clean, crisp air of the 70's pop-music industry'' [''This Time, the Sex Pistols' Point of View,'' April 2]. He should know better....
column10: To the Editor: Ken Tucker says the Sex Pistols existed to ''release an invigorating blast of poisonous gas into the clean, crisp air of the 70's pop-music industry'' [''This Time, the Sex Pistols' Point of View,'' April 2]. He should know better. That clean, crisp air he describes was nothing more than the combined flatulence of a herd of jaded, aging AOR or Album-Oriented Rock stars. I grew up in Los Angeles listening to not one, not two, but three horrible album rock stations that combined with the aforementioned rock stars to grind music into a droning, ''mellow,'' ''progressive'' haze. The fresh air was definitely delivered by the Pistols, the Ramones, the Clash and many others. It may have had remnants of tear gas in it, but it was definitely fresh. JOHN SUSOEFF Long Beach, Calif.

column2: BANZER, HUGO; BOLIVIA; UNEMPLOYMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Bolivia Calls An Emergency After Protest Over Water
column9: Bolivia's president declared a state of emergency today, fueling a week of widening unrest that left three people dead in fresh clashes between police and demonstrators.     The move came after a week of protests over rising water rates, unemployment...
column10: Bolivia's president declared a state of emergency today, fueling a week of widening unrest that left three people dead in fresh clashes between police and demonstrators. The move came after a week of protests over rising water rates, unemployment and other economic difficulties plaguing the Andean country of eight million people.

column2: COCHABAMBA (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: 5 More Die in Bolivia Protests After Emergency Is Declared
column9: Protests and police mutinies that have left eight people dead continued in cities around Bolivia today, after the government's declaration of a state of emergency this weekend inflamed anger over the country's worsening economic troubles.    ...
column10: Protests and police mutinies that have left eight people dead continued in cities around Bolivia today, after the government's declaration of a state of emergency this weekend inflamed anger over the country's worsening economic troubles. Tensions were centered in Cochabamba, the country's third largest city, where a wave of protests over government plans to raise rates for drinking water began a week ago.

column2: WASHINGTON (DC); SEATTLE (WASH); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Washington Braces to Handle Flood of Globalization Protesters
column9: A law enforcement armada from a half-dozen city and federal agencies is preparing for mass rallies here this week as organizers try to extend the protest against global economics that plunged Seattle into violent street confrontations in November.   ...
column10: A law enforcement armada from a half-dozen city and federal agencies is preparing for mass rallies here this week as organizers try to extend the protest against global economics that plunged Seattle into violent street confrontations in November. ''We're in the process of training drills with our mounted units and SWAT teams,'' said Sgt. Rob MacLean of the United States Park Police. ''If a situation occurs like the one in Seattle, we'll be prepared.''

column2: TOLEDO, ALEJANDRO; STEIN, EDUARDO; FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; PERU; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ELECTIONS; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET
column3: PERUVIAN'S LEAD IN VOTE PROMPTS CHARGE OF FRAUD
column9: Official returns today showed President Alberto K. Fujimori approaching a first-round victory in Peru's presidential election, prompting cries of fraud and threats of civil disturbance.     At the end of Sunday's voting, polls of voters and...
column10: Official returns today showed President Alberto K. Fujimori approaching a first-round victory in Peru's presidential election, prompting cries of fraud and threats of civil disturbance. At the end of Sunday's voting, polls of voters and independent counts suggested that neither Mr. Fujimori, running for a third five-year term, nor his challenger, Alejandro Toledo, would garner a majority.

column2: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CUBAN-AMERICANS
column3: For Reno, a Custody Case Is Now a Personal Crusade
column9: The custody battle over Elian Gonzalez has thrust Attorney General Janet Reno into what is most likely to be one of her last starring roles as she returned to her hometown, Miami, yesterday in a gesture that transformed a Justice Department legal...
column10: The custody battle over Elian Gonzalez has thrust Attorney General Janet Reno into what is most likely to be one of her last starring roles as she returned to her hometown, Miami, yesterday in a gesture that transformed a Justice Department legal fight into a one-woman crusade. The case has seemingly energized the 62-year-old Ms. Reno in the eighth and final year of her stewardship at the Justice Department. And today, at considerable risk to her credibility and reputation, she began a personal mission to reunite Elian with his father.

column2: ANWAR IBRAHIM; KUALA LUMPUR (MALAYSIA); MALAYSIA; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: Malaysian Police Break Up Opposition Protest and Arrest 46
column9: Defying tear gas and beatings by the police, hundreds of supporters of the jailed former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, marked the anniversary of his conviction today with a protest that led to 46 arrests.    The police cordoned off several...
column10: Defying tear gas and beatings by the police, hundreds of supporters of the jailed former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, marked the anniversary of his conviction today with a protest that led to 46 arrests. The police cordoned off several streets in downtown Kuala Lumpur, chased the demonstrators down alleys and beat them with canes in an attempt to disperse crowds that had gathered since late afternoon.

column2: WASHINGTON (DC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
column3: FINANCIAL LEADERS MEET AS PROTESTS CLOG WASHINGTON
column9: Thousands of protesters trying to shut down meetings of world financial leaders swarmed through the streets of the capital today, sealed off from their target by a virtual wall of police officers. A few brief clashes ensued, but for the most part, a...
column10: Thousands of protesters trying to shut down meetings of world financial leaders swarmed through the streets of the capital today, sealed off from their target by a virtual wall of police officers. A few brief clashes ensued, but for the most part, a day that some had feared would descend into chaos passed peacefully. The finance ministers and other delegates from around the world were loaded onto buses early this morning and escorted by the police so their meetings could take place as scheduled. This evening, they tacitly acknowledged the shouting on the streets by conceding in a communique issued by the International Monetary Fund that their role had become a matter ''of growing public debate.''

column2: WILLIAMS, ANTHONY; WOLFENSOHN, JAMES D; WASHINGTON (DC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CUSTOMS (TARIFF); CREDIT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FOREIGN AID
column3: World Trade Officials Pledging To Step Up Effort Against AIDS
column9: The world's top financial officials, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protesters braved a chilling rain and an impenetrable police force outside, pledged to pay more attention to globalization's victims and to commit ''unlimited money'' to...
column10: The world's top financial officials, trying to show sensitivity to poverty as protesters braved a chilling rain and an impenetrable police force outside, pledged to pay more attention to globalization's victims and to commit ''unlimited money'' to fight AIDS in poor countries. The finance ministers and central bank governors who oversee the World Bank said the bank should intensify its fight against AIDS because the disease is as much a problem of poverty as public health. More than 50 million people are infected with the virus that causes the disease, and it is spreading fastest in Africa, India, China and the Caribbean, all major World Bank clients. The bank has been active for more than a decade in fighting the disease.

column2: WASHINGTON (DC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: On a Day of Protests, K Street Takes the Day Off
column9: The protesters marching downtown today failed to disrupt the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its partner organization, the World Bank. But the protesters managed to halt the business of another influential Washington...
column10: The protesters marching downtown today failed to disrupt the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its partner organization, the World Bank. But the protesters managed to halt the business of another influential Washington institution: the law firms and lobbying shops of K Street. K Street, both as an address and a symbol of the capital's influence industry, was the spine of a 20-block area that the city police cordoned off from traffic early today. Demonstrators marched up and down the avenue in their bid to stop the world financial leaders from pursuing their agenda. They failed, but, in a sense, they might have accomplished more than they realized.

column2: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; ASYLUM (POLITICAL); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CUBAN-AMERICANS
column3: Justice Dept. Is Uncertain About Next Step
column9: The Federal appellate court ruling today preventing the return to Cuba of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez caught the Justice Department by surprise and left officials there uncertain about how to proceed in the highly politicized case.    Despite what the...
column10: The Federal appellate court ruling today preventing the return to Cuba of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez caught the Justice Department by surprise and left officials there uncertain about how to proceed in the highly politicized case. Despite what the officials acknowledged was a setback, they said they could still remove the child from the custody of his Miami relatives and turn him over to his father. Today's ruling only blocks the child from leaving the United States.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: TALKS CONTINUE  Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland will be in London today for the second round of talks in 48 hours with his British counterpart, Tony Blair. Mr. Blair visited Dublin, too, as part of a continuing...
column10: EUROPE NORTHERN IRELAND: TALKS CONTINUE Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland will be in London today for the second round of talks in 48 hours with his British counterpart, Tony Blair. Mr. Blair visited Dublin, too, as part of a continuing effort to resurrect the Protestant-Catholic coalition government suspended in February when the Irish Republican Army failed to make expected disarmament moves. Warren Hoge (NYT) BOSNIA: SERB DEFENDANTS FREED Two Bosnian Serbs facing war crimes charges were released until their trial begins because they have been in custody too long, the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague said. Miroslav Tadic, 62, and Simo Zaric, 51, surrendered in February 1998. Their trial has been delayed because of complaints by a co-defendant. (Reuters)

column2: NAIROBI (KENYA); KENYA; MALAWI; SOUTH AFRICA; NIGERIA; WORLD CUP (SOCCER); SOCCER; ARSON; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: Three African Teams Advance in Qualifiers
column9: Kenyan fans rioted, causing a World Cup qualifier to be abandoned with several minutes remaining yesterday, and Nigeria and South Africa advanced to the second round of African play.     At Nairobi, fans in the crowd of 20,000 threw bottles and...
column10: Kenyan fans rioted, causing a World Cup qualifier to be abandoned with several minutes remaining yesterday, and Nigeria and South Africa advanced to the second round of African play. At Nairobi, fans in the crowd of 20,000 threw bottles and stones on the field and ripped out seats in Moi International Stadium. Kenya, which lost the opener of the home-and-home, total-goals series by 2-0 April 8, was scoreless in injury time against Malawi, leaving little hope it would be one of 25 nations in Africa's second round.

column2: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; RENO, JANET; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; FLORIDA; IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CUBA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; SEARCH AND SEIZURE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CUBAN-AMERICANS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: CUBAN BOY SEIZED BY U.S. AGENTS AND REUNITED WITH HIS FATHER
column9: Armed United States immigration agents smashed their way into the Little Havana home of Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives before dawn today, took the sobbing 6-year-old boy from a bedroom closet and flew him to a reunion with his father outside...
column10: Armed United States immigration agents smashed their way into the Little Havana home of Elian Gonzalez's Miami relatives before dawn today, took the sobbing 6-year-old boy from a bedroom closet and flew him to a reunion with his father outside Washington. As demonstrators wept in rage and coughed from pepper spray and tear gas, the agents wrapped the child in a blanket and carried him to an airport to fly him to Washington. The action touched off a fury in the streets outside the home where Cuban exiles have kept a vigil since November.

column2: GONZALEZ, ELIAN; GONZALEZ, JUAN MIGUEL; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CUBA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; SEARCH AND SEIZURE; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CUBAN-AMERICANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Police Fire Tear Gas as Hundreds of Angry Protesters Take to the Streets in Miami
column9: Outraged that Elian Gonzalez was taken from them, hundreds of Cuban-American protesters took to a major road here today, burning tires and throwing rocks as police officers in riot gear moved in, firing tear gas and making hundreds of arrests.   ...
column10: Outraged that Elian Gonzalez was taken from them, hundreds of Cuban-American protesters took to a major road here today, burning tires and throwing rocks as police officers in riot gear moved in, firing tear gas and making hundreds of arrests. Roaming along Flagler Street, a four-lane avenue that cuts east-west through Little Havana not far from the house where 6-year-old Elian had stayed, the demonstrators overturned Dumpsters and threw old appliances and garbage into the street. The police initially appeared to fall back along the perimeter of the troubled streets, allowing the protesters, many of them young Cuban-Americans carrying Cuban flags and placards denouncing the Clinton Administration, to slow traffic.

column3: Raid in Miami Opens New Front In Struggle Over the Cuban Boy
column9: Both the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez and the federal government battled to sway public opinion today by mustering new details about the raid to return the boy to his father, focusing on the issues of tactics and trust during the 48 hours...
column10: Both the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez and the federal government battled to sway public opinion today by mustering new details about the raid to return the boy to his father, focusing on the issues of tactics and trust during the 48 hours leading up to the predawn operation. The Justice Department revealed that negotiators with close ties to Attorney General Janet Reno were on the phone with her when the raid occurred, having tried until the last minutes to broker a deal that would have resulted in a peaceful transfer of Elian to his father.

column2: PORTUGAL; PORTO SEGURO (BRAZIL); BRAZIL; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; HOLIDAYS AND SPECIAL OCCASIONS; HISTORY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 500 Years Later, Brazil Looks Its Past in the Face
column9: It was envisioned as a feel-good patriotic festival like the American Bicentennial. But the Brazilian government should have known that its plans to mark the 500th anniversary of the landing of the Portuguese were doomed when an irate Indian chief...
column10: It was envisioned as a feel-good patriotic festival like the American Bicentennial. But the Brazilian government should have known that its plans to mark the 500th anniversary of the landing of the Portuguese were doomed when an irate Indian chief marched into Congress earlier this month, drew his bow and arrow and threatened to kill the Senate president. Sure enough, the yearlong commemoration got off to a bumpy start on Saturday, when military police officers used tear gas, nightsticks and rubber bullets to disperse 2,000 Indian-led demonstrators taking part in a ''march of the excluded'' in Porto Seguro, the focal point of the official celebrations.

column3: SENATE WILL HOLD HEARINGS ON RAID ON HOUSE IN MIAMI
column9: The political storm over Elian Gonzalez grew fiercer today as the Republican leadership of the Senate called for hearings on the Justice Department's decision to use armed agents to seize the 6-year-old boy, and as Vice President Al Gore distanced...
column10: The political storm over Elian Gonzalez grew fiercer today as the Republican leadership of the Senate called for hearings on the Justice Department's decision to use armed agents to seize the 6-year-old boy, and as Vice President Al Gore distanced himself again from the government's handling of the case. Attorney General Janet Reno defended the raid in meetings today on Capitol Hill, but her answers did not satisfy Republican leaders.

column3: Castro Emerges as Conflict's Clear Winner
column9: At the corner of Flagler Street and 22nd Avenue, a procession of cars filled with teenagers, salsa music blaring, crawled slowly across the intersection with Cuban flags fluttering from radio antennas and a big American flag flying upside down, in...
column10: At the corner of Flagler Street and 22nd Avenue, a procession of cars filled with teenagers, salsa music blaring, crawled slowly across the intersection with Cuban flags fluttering from radio antennas and a big American flag flying upside down, in scorn. In Little Havana, in the days since Elian Gonzalez was taken from his Miami relatives' home in a blur of tear gas and armed federal agents, upside-down flags and disdain for the United States are fashionable.

column3: May Day Is Marked With Demonstrations On Right and Left
column9: Anti-capitalist protesters clashed with the police today in central London, tearing down the golden arches of a McDonald's and spray-painting a hammer and sickle on a statue of Winston Churchill in a May Day protest.    In Berlin, a march against...
column10: Anti-capitalist protesters clashed with the police today in central London, tearing down the golden arches of a McDonald's and spray-painting a hammer and sickle on a statue of Winston Churchill in a May Day protest. In Berlin, a march against ''capitalism and imperialism'' this evening erupted into violence in the Kreuzberg neighborhood, a stronghold of leftist activism. More than 100 police officers were injured as they used water cannons, tear gas and nightsticks against a crowd of 10,000 anarchists. At least three dozen leftists were arrested.

column3: Suspected Drug Trafficker Seized in Shootout in Mexico
column9: A major drug trafficker who officials said oversaw daily smuggling operations for the Tijuana drug cartel has been arrested and charged with racketeering and murder, Mexican authorities said today.    The trafficker, Ismael Higuera Guerrero, was...
column10: A major drug trafficker who officials said oversaw daily smuggling operations for the Tijuana drug cartel has been arrested and charged with racketeering and murder, Mexican authorities said today. The trafficker, Ismael Higuera Guerrero, was seized on Wednesday in what American officials called a major victory in the fight against drugs. He was captured after traffickers and soldiers exchanged gunfire and the soldiers lobbed tear gas grenades into a Pacific coast mansion at Ensenada, 60 miles south of Tijuana, the authorities said.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    U.S. and Britain Agree To Aid U.N. in Sierra Leone  The United States and Britain will help bail out a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone that appears to be overwhelmed, with rebels killing civilians in the...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 U.S. and Britain Agree To Aid U.N. in Sierra Leone The United States and Britain will help bail out a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone that appears to be overwhelmed, with rebels killing civilians in the capital, Freetown, and holding more than 500 peacekeepers hostage. Britain will send about 700 troops to secure the airport, so that Europeans can leave. The Clinton administration agreed to provide transport planes. A1

column9: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas today to break up a demonstration by students protesting a 17-year-old novel they said insulted Islam.    At the height of the protest this morning at Al Azhar University, the most prestigious Islamic...
column10: The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas today to break up a demonstration by students protesting a 17-year-old novel they said insulted Islam. At the height of the protest this morning at Al Azhar University, the most prestigious Islamic educational institution in the Middle East, about 2,000 students hurled rocks and insults at the police and chanted ''God is great!'' and ''Back to Islam!''

column2: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; UNITED NATIONS CONVENTION AGAINST TORTURE; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE
column3: Forum on Torture Hears of U.S. Efforts to End Police Brutality
column9: In its first report on its compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Torture, the United States today defended its efforts to eliminate any such practices, including police brutality and inmate abuse, which human rights advocates maintain...
column10: In its first report on its compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Torture, the United States today defended its efforts to eliminate any such practices, including police brutality and inmate abuse, which human rights advocates maintain are regular occurrences in America. The United States, like the 117 other countries that have signed the 1984 convention, is obliged to detail to the body's review committee every four years incidents of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment of its citizens and to describe the steps taken to stamp out such practices.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: ASIA    INDONESIA: ACEH TRUCE -- The government and representatives of separatist rebels from Aceh Province signed an agreement described as a ''humanitarian pause,'' resulting in the first cease-fire in more than two decades. While both sides...
column10: ASIA INDONESIA: ACEH TRUCE -- The government and representatives of separatist rebels from Aceh Province signed an agreement described as a ''humanitarian pause,'' resulting in the first cease-fire in more than two decades. While both sides welcomed the truce, signed at an undisclosed location in Geneva, as a milestone, both sides were quick to qualify it. The rebels pledged to continue pushing for independence, and Jakarta ruled out recognizing the insurgents. The cease-fire will begin June 2. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

column2: SEATTLE (WASH); GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; TRAVEL AND VACATIONS
column3: Seattle
column9: Seattle certainly made a name for itself last December as host to the World Trade Organization meeting. The boosters' idea of using the summit to show off their city as a world-class friend to free trade didn't exactly pan out, amid all the...
column10: Seattle certainly made a name for itself last December as host to the World Trade Organization meeting. The boosters' idea of using the summit to show off their city as a world-class friend to free trade didn't exactly pan out, amid all the demonstrations and the tear gas, but many residents think that the raucous protests against globalization amounted to a badge of honor for Seattle. Now the long-running tension here, between those who revel in the high-tech, high-wealth place Seattle has become and those who fret that the city is losing its quirky small-town charm, has a new focus: next month, a museum designed by Frank Gehry, known as the Experience Music Project, opens at the base of the Space Needle. Wildly curvy and colorful, built roughly in the shape of a guitar with the Seattle Center's monorail running through it, the museum is a celebration of modern music and includes a sound lab that, the museum says, lets you ''plug in, jam, dance, wail, scratch, learn, connect and, ultimately, experience the euphoria of making music.'' Some consider the building a brilliant addition to the architectural scene; some call it a curse on the civic landscape. Come and judge for yourself.

column3: New Arab-Israeli Strains Explode Into Street Clashes
column9: Thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza poured into the streets today for angry protests, some of which were marked by violent confrontations with Israeli troops that recalled scenes from the intifada, or uprising, of the late 1980's.    ...
column10: Thousands of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza poured into the streets today for angry protests, some of which were marked by violent confrontations with Israeli troops that recalled scenes from the intifada, or uprising, of the late 1980's. The Israelis soldiers used rubber-coated bullets and, according to witnesses, some live ammunition, and the Palestinians hurled stones and firebombs. In the northern west bank town of Qalqilya, one Palestinian man was killed by a rubber bullet to the chest.
