column3: 'Games' Turn Deadly as Clash Quickly Spirals Out of Control
column9: For nearly four hours, Palestinians were riveted today by the spectacle of Israeli troops on Ramallah's northern outskirts furiously trading automatic-weapon fire with gunmen -- many of them members of uniformed Palestinian security forces.   ...
column10: For nearly four hours, Palestinians were riveted today by the spectacle of Israeli troops on Ramallah's northern outskirts furiously trading automatic-weapon fire with gunmen -- many of them members of uniformed Palestinian security forces. ''Games,'' tersely commented a Palestinian officer in the red beret and camouflage of the military intelligence services. ''Games between them and us.''

column2: ARAFAT, YASIR; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); JERUSALEM; GAZA STRIP; PALESTINIANS; POLITICAL PRISONERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Palestinian Forces Exchange Gunfire With Israeli Troops
column9: For the first time in almost four years, Israelis and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank today as a wave of violent protest swept through the Palestinian territories. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won his...
column10: For the first time in almost four years, Israelis and Palestinian forces exchanged gunfire in the West Bank today as a wave of violent protest swept through the Palestinian territories. Despite the fighting, Prime Minister Ehud Barak won his Parliament's approval to cede three villages near Jerusalem to the Palestinian Authority in an effort to advance the peace talks. The gun battle, which broke out at a junction near the Palestinian city of Ramallah, accompanied chaotic confrontations throughout the West Bank and Gaza, in which Israeli forces suppressed unruly Palestinian demonstrators by shooting tear gas, rubber-coated bullets and, at some sites, live ammunition into crowds charging at them with stones and firebombs.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: MIDDLE EAST    PALESTINIANS: CLASHES CONTINUE -- Sporadic clashes between young Palestinians and Israeli troops continued in the West Bank and near Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets at...
column10: MIDDLE EAST PALESTINIANS: CLASHES CONTINUE -- Sporadic clashes between young Palestinians and Israeli troops continued in the West Bank and near Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip. Israeli soldiers fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters who threw stones and firebombs; they also reported that Israeli posts had been fired upon and that they responded with live fire. Deborah Sontag (NYT) ISRAEL: TYING UP BARAK -- Two opposition bills that could tie Prime Minister Ehud Barak's hands in negotiations with the Palestinians passed preliminary votes, although both require three more readings to become law. They would require absolute majority approval of the Parliament to change the municipal boundaries of Jerualem and to allow the right of return of Palestinian refugees to Israel. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

column9: Galatasaray became the first Turkish team to win the UEFA Cup when it beat Arsenal of England, 4-1, in a penalty shootout yesterday in Copenhagen after a day of fan violence.     The game ended 0-0 after regulation and extra time.
column10: Galatasaray became the first Turkish team to win the UEFA Cup when it beat Arsenal of England, 4-1, in a penalty shootout yesterday in Copenhagen after a day of fan violence. The game ended 0-0 after regulation and extra time.

column3: Protests Flare As Belgrade Takes Control Of TV Station
column9: About 20,000 people gathered again tonight to protest the Serbian government's seizure of the main opposition television station here, Studio B, but as they were dispersing, policemen in riot gear charged them.    There were clashes with the...
column10: About 20,000 people gathered again tonight to protest the Serbian government's seizure of the main opposition television station here, Studio B, but as they were dispersing, policemen in riot gear charged them. There were clashes with the demonstrators, some of whom then threw stones and homemade firebombs at the police, who responded in turn with truncheons and a lavish use of tear gas. At least 19 people were hurt, beaten by the police, and ambulances picked them up at City Hall, where once again opposition political leaders conferred with one another but did not address the crowd.

column2: ABDULLAH II; EGYPT; IRAQ; KUWAIT; MIDDLE EAST; JORDAN; UNITED ARAB EMIRATES; SAUDI ARABIA; FOREIGN INVESTMENTS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Jordan's Long Road To the Free-Trade Club
column9: MOHAMMED A. HALAIQAH'S trip to Seattle last November was to have been the culmination of his career. As Jordan's most experienced trade negotiator, he had spent five years arduously preparing for his country's entry into the World Trade Organization....
column10: MOHAMMED A. HALAIQAH'S trip to Seattle last November was to have been the culmination of his career. As Jordan's most experienced trade negotiator, he had spent five years arduously preparing for his country's entry into the World Trade Organization. After a thorough and painful overhaul of its tariffs and investment rules, putting domestic industries like pharmaceuticals at risk, Jordan was finally poised to become the W.T.O.'s next full member. As the only country scheduled to join the group at its Seattle summit meeting, it hoped to attract worldwide publicity -- and American investment in the high-technology industries it sees as the key to its future.

column2: BARAK, EHUD; JERICHO (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: ISRAEL SUMMONING NEGOTIATORS HOME AFTER NEW ATTACK
column9: Prime Minister Ehud Barak recalled his peace negotiators from Sweden today after a firebomb critically wounded a 2-year-old Israeli girl in a car passing through the sleepy Palestinian-ruled city of Jericho.    The attack prompted Israel to block...
column10: Prime Minister Ehud Barak recalled his peace negotiators from Sweden today after a firebomb critically wounded a 2-year-old Israeli girl in a car passing through the sleepy Palestinian-ruled city of Jericho. The attack prompted Israel to block entrance to the Palestinian territories, declaring them unsafe for Israelis and tourists, and temporarily undercut a year of normalization efforts. The incident also undermined Palestinian attempts to restore order, although the Palestinians did clamp down on street fighting for the first time in 10 days.

column3: As Protests Grow Violent, Peru Says Runoff Will Go On
column9: The government of President Alberto K. Fujimori said today that a runoff presidential election would be held on Sunday as scheduled despite nationwide protests and calls from Washington and other allies that it be postponed to ensure a clean ballot...
column10: The government of President Alberto K. Fujimori said today that a runoff presidential election would be held on Sunday as scheduled despite nationwide protests and calls from Washington and other allies that it be postponed to ensure a clean ballot count. The decision appeared to increase the possibility of economic sanctions against Peru after it ignored the recommendations of the Clinton administration, the Organization of American States and several European and Latin American governments.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: ASIA    JAPAN: PREMIER APOLOGIZES -- Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori apologized for remarks last week that seemed to endorse emperor worship. After several days of heavy criticism, Mr. Mori, left, expressed regret in a tense news conference that his...
column10: ASIA JAPAN: PREMIER APOLOGIZES -- Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori apologized for remarks last week that seemed to endorse emperor worship. After several days of heavy criticism, Mr. Mori, left, expressed regret in a tense news conference that his remarks had caused misunderstanding, but declined to retract his statement altogether. In his original remarks, which critics said echoed Japan's prewar militarism, Mr. Mori said Japan was ''a divine nation with the emperor at its core.'' Howard French (NYT) SRI LANKA: MILITARY PLEA -- The government asked retired officers and policemen to re-enlist in the armed forces in hopes of bolstering 30,000 troops under assault from separatist ethnic Tamils in the northern Jaffna Peninsula. Those who rejoined would take the noncombat positions of younger soldiers, who would then be shifted to the front lines. The rebels threatened a bloodbath for soldiers who failed to surrender by today. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

column3: Rocket Richard, Montreal's Goal-Scoring Hero, Dies at 78
column9: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal-scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died...
column10: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal-scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died yesterday in a hospital in Montreal. He was 78. He had been suffering from stomach cancer and Parkinson's disease, and he was hospitalized early this month.

column2: TOLEDO, ALEJANDRO; FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; MORALES BERMUDEZ, FRANCISCO; PERU; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTION RESULTS
column3: FUJIMORI IS VICTOR IN PERU'S RUNOFF AS PROTESTS GROW
column9: In a runoff vote long on protest but short on suspense, President Alberto K. Fujimori swept to victory today against an opponent who had urged his supporters to abstain because of what he called vote fraud and an array of campaign irregularities.    ...
column10: In a runoff vote long on protest but short on suspense, President Alberto K. Fujimori swept to victory today against an opponent who had urged his supporters to abstain because of what he called vote fraud and an array of campaign irregularities. Mr. Fujimori had hoped for a third landslide victory that would venerate his successes in defeating two terrorist groups and hyperinflation and making peace with Ecuador after decades of border tensions. Instead, the 61-year-old president won a hollow victory leaving the country badly polarized and facing possible economic sanctions just as it tries to emerge from recession.

column2: SPORTS OF THE TIMES (TIMES COLUMN); RICHARD, MAURICE; MONTREAL CANADIENS; HOCKEY, ICE
column3: Richard Is Real Rocket, the Only Rocket
column9: OTHER athletes are known today as the Rocket, notably pitcher Roger Clemens, the tennis legend Rod Laver and receiver Raghib Ismael, but they plagiarized the nickname. To anyone who saw Maurice Richard play hockey, he was not only the original...
column10: OTHER athletes are known today as the Rocket, notably pitcher Roger Clemens, the tennis legend Rod Laver and receiver Raghib Ismael, but they plagiarized the nickname. To anyone who saw Maurice Richard play hockey, he was not only the original Rocket, he also deserved to be remembered as the real Rocket, the only Rocket. Just as Babe defined George Herman Ruth, Rocket defined the Montreal Canadiens' folk hero who set all the National Hockey League goal-scoring records that Gordie Howe and Wayne Gretzky eventually shattered.

column10: Maurice Richard, the charismatic star of the Montreal Canadiens through the 1940's and 1950's known as the Rocket, one of the most electrifying goal scorers in National Hockey League history and a revered figure in French-speaking Canada, died Saturday in a hospital in Montreal. He was 78. He had been suffering from stomach cancer and Parkinson's disease, and he was hospitalized early this month.

column10: Responding to the unopposed election of Alberto Fujimori to a third term as president of Peru, foreign ministers at the annual assembly of the Organization of American States agreed tonight to send a mission to Lima to explore options for strengthening democracy in Peru. The team is to be led by Canada's foreign minister, Lloyd Axworthy, and Cesar Gaviria, secretary general of the Organization of the American States.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: FLAG DEBATE -- The Northern Ireland Assembly met for the first time since home rule was suspended by Britain in February and spent the day debating whether the Union Jack, the Irish tricolor, both flags or no flag should...
column10: EUROPE NORTHERN IRELAND: FLAG DEBATE -- The Northern Ireland Assembly met for the first time since home rule was suspended by Britain in February and spent the day debating whether the Union Jack, the Irish tricolor, both flags or no flag should fly over official buildings. The Rev. Ian Paisley, head of the hard-line Ulster Democratic Party that has vowed to disrupt the power-sharing government, protested the refusal of two ministers from Sinn Fein, political ally of the Irish Republican Army, to raise the British flag at their offices. Warren Hoge (NYT) SPAIN: THOUSANDS PROTEST KILLING -- Thousands of people held silent vigils across the country to protest the death of Jesus Maria Pedrosa, a town councilor in the Basque city of Durango shot to death by suspected Basque rebels. Mr, Pedrosa was a member of Spain's ruling center-right Popular Party and had received threats from radical Basque separatists. The armed Basque group E.T.A. has killed five people since ending a cease-fire last December. Benjamin Jones (NYT)

column3: Violence in Brussels After Euro 2000 Match
column9: Police officers in riot gear fired tear gas to disperse thousands of rowdy soccer fans in the center of Brussels today, hours after Belgium beat Sweden 2-1 in the opening match of the Euro 2000 soccer tournament.     Thousands of flag-waving, singing...
column10: Police officers in riot gear fired tear gas to disperse thousands of rowdy soccer fans in the center of Brussels today, hours after Belgium beat Sweden 2-1 in the opening match of the Euro 2000 soccer tournament. Thousands of flag-waving, singing soccer fans had filled the center of town after the Belgium-Sweden match in the Roi Baudouin Stadium on the northern outskirts of Brussels. But the celebration turned violent when bottles and glasses were thrown at police officers, who responded with volleys of tear gas.

column2: FRANCE; NETHERLANDS; VIOLENCE; SOCCER; EUROPEAN CHAMPIONSHIP (SOCCER)
column3: French and Dutch Reach Quarterfinals
column9: France, the World Cup champion, beat the Czech Republic, 2-1, and the Netherlands defeated Denmark, 3-0, to secure quarterfinal spots at the European soccer championship, which was marred yesterday by its first serious fan violence.     The police in...
column10: France, the World Cup champion, beat the Czech Republic, 2-1, and the Netherlands defeated Denmark, 3-0, to secure quarterfinal spots at the European soccer championship, which was marred yesterday by its first serious fan violence. The police in Brussels used tear gas and clubs to subdue rampaging English fans a day before the England-Germany game, which had sparked fears of hooliganism. The police said 137 were arrested and 21 were injured.

column2: WACO (TEX); BRANCH DAVIDIANS; SUITS AND LITIGATION
column3: Finally Taken Seriously, Waco Suit Goes to Trial
column9: For years, the Branch Davidian wrongful-death lawsuit seemed unlikely to amount to anything more than paper. The case file is about as thick as 25 metropolitan phone books, a tower of motions and countermotions once regarded as a monument to futility...
column10: For years, the Branch Davidian wrongful-death lawsuit seemed unlikely to amount to anything more than paper. The case file is about as thick as 25 metropolitan phone books, a tower of motions and countermotions once regarded as a monument to futility by those who doubted that the case would ever reach trial. But six years after the lawsuit was filed, the trial is scheduled to open on Monday in Federal District Court in Waco, Tex. Once criticized as a bundle of anti-government conspiracies, the lawsuit is now being taken very seriously. At its core lies the fundamental question of whether the government was negligent in the deaths of more than 80 Branch Davidians on April 19, 1993, when the sect's Mount Carmel compound near Waco burned to the ground.

column2: WACO (TEX); BRANCH DAVIDIANS; RELIGIOUS CULTS; SUITS AND LITIGATION
column3: 2 Sides Give 2 Versions Of Facts in Waco Suit
column9: Trial in a lawsuit filed against the government by survivors and relatives of those killed in the 1993 fire at the Branch Davidian compound began today with the two sides giving different interpretations of the same basic facts.    ''This case is...
column10: Trial in a lawsuit filed against the government by survivors and relatives of those killed in the 1993 fire at the Branch Davidian compound began today with the two sides giving different interpretations of the same basic facts. ''This case is about truth and responsibility,'' said Michael A. Caddell, lead attorney for the plaintiffs. ''We'll hear the truth about what happened at Mount Carmel and who bears the responsibility for what happened, including the death of 25 children.''

column2: RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; TEAR GAS
column3: National News Briefs; Waco Agents Authorized To Act, Reno Testifies
column9: During the final day of the Branch Davidian standoff, federal agents had the discretion to do what needed to be done to insert tear gas into the compound in order to force out sect members, Attorney General Janet Reno said in a videotaped deposition...
column10: During the final day of the Branch Davidian standoff, federal agents had the discretion to do what needed to be done to insert tear gas into the compound in order to force out sect members, Attorney General Janet Reno said in a videotaped deposition played for jurors today. ''But the discretion would have to be exercised within the limits of the plan,'' Ms. Reno said of the F.B.I. commanders at the Mount Carmel compound near Waco.

column2: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; UNITED NATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: In Mock Palestinian Hill Town, Israeli Troops Prepare for Worst
column9: Near the ancient caves of Bet Guvrin in Israel, army officials say, there is a secret Palestinian village on a hill. It consists of about 15 houses and a mosque. It is for Israelis only.    The village is a simulation, a three-dimensional stage set...
column10: Near the ancient caves of Bet Guvrin in Israel, army officials say, there is a secret Palestinian village on a hill. It consists of about 15 houses and a mosque. It is for Israelis only. The village is a simulation, a three-dimensional stage set that the Israeli Army uses to train its troops in occupation techniques, riot control and all-out battle. It is populated by soldiers playing the roles of what an army official called ''the enemy'': Palestinian stone throwers and police officers, even journalists and homemakers. In the year-old mock village, the army experiments with techniques for controlling and reacting to violence in a way that is meant to minimize the risk to Palestinian civilians.

column2: RENO, JANET; CONRAD, ROBERT J JR; GORE, AL; UNITED STATES; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; SPECIAL PROSECUTORS (INDEPENDENT COUNSEL); FINANCES; ELECTION ISSUES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ETHICS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2000; ELECTIONS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 1996
column3: An Old Issue Returns To Haunt Reno Again
column9: In the coming weeks, Attorney General Janet Reno must decide whether to name a special counsel to investigate Vice President Al Gore's political fund-raising in the 1996 presidential campaign. The issue has haunted Ms. Reno, threatening her chances...
column10: In the coming weeks, Attorney General Janet Reno must decide whether to name a special counsel to investigate Vice President Al Gore's political fund-raising in the 1996 presidential campaign. The issue has haunted Ms. Reno, threatening her chances of leaving a legacy of nonpolitical stewardship of the Justice Department. She has struggled to bring an end to the fund-raising case, having twice refused to submit Mr. Gore to the scrutiny of an independent counsel. But the issue arose again last week when Justice Department officials said the chief of her campaign finance unit, Robert J. Conrad Jr., had recommended that she refer Mr. Gore's case to an outside prosecutor.

column2: IRAN; TEHRAN (IRAN); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Tehran Police And Vigilantes Fight Students
column9: Students fought street battles with riot policemen and hard-line vigilantes today, snapping a truce that had lasted since the violent suppression of a pro-democracy rally one year ago.    The policemen moved against thousands of demonstrators in...
column10: Students fought street battles with riot policemen and hard-line vigilantes today, snapping a truce that had lasted since the violent suppression of a pro-democracy rally one year ago. The policemen moved against thousands of demonstrators in Tehran during a rally marking the first anniversary of an assault by security forces on a campus demonstration that left at least one student dead. That incident touched off some of the worst unrest in Iran since the aftermath of the Islamic revolution.

column2: HARARE (ZIMBABWE); ZIMBABWE; SOUTH AFRICA; SOCCER; WORLD CUP; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Zimbabwe Soccer Deaths
column9: Twelve people died in a soccer stampede today after the police fired tear gas at bottle-throwing fans during a World Cup qualifier between Zimbabwe and South Africa.    Players from both teams choked and writhed on the field, covering their faces as...
column10: Twelve people died in a soccer stampede today after the police fired tear gas at bottle-throwing fans during a World Cup qualifier between Zimbabwe and South Africa. Players from both teams choked and writhed on the field, covering their faces as tear gas spread through the stadium.

column2: WORLD CUP (SOCCER); SOCCER
column3: Americans Set for Cup Qualifiers
column9: The games in Guatemala next Sunday and Costa Rica a week later may determine whether the United States qualifies for the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea. The Americans convened in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., yesterday to prepare for the first two...
column10: The games in Guatemala next Sunday and Costa Rica a week later may determine whether the United States qualifies for the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea. The Americans convened in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., yesterday to prepare for the first two World Cup qualifying games on the road before they return home to play Barbados Aug. 16 at Foxboro Stadium outside Boston. Home games will follow against Guatemala (Sept. 3 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington) and Costa Rica (Oct. 11 at Columbus Crew Stadium in Columbus, Ohio). The Americans will complete the qualifying round with a game Nov. 15 in Barbados, the weakest team in the group.

column2: HARARE (ZIMBABWE); ZIMBABWE; FIFA; ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY; SOCCER
column3: Zimbabwe Loses Hosting Privileges
column9: Soccer's governing body ruled yesterday in Zurich that National Stadium in Harare, Zimbabwe, may not play host to international soccer matches for an indefinite period after 13 people were killed there Sunday in a stampede.   ''FIFA has studied the...
column10: Soccer's governing body ruled yesterday in Zurich that National Stadium in Harare, Zimbabwe, may not play host to international soccer matches for an indefinite period after 13 people were killed there Sunday in a stampede. ''FIFA has studied the reports of the match commissioner and referee in detail and is now launching a formal investigation into the incident,'' a statement said. ''In the meantime, FIFA has taken the decision that the National Stadium in Harare may not be used for international football matches until further notice.''

column2: SMITH, WALTER S; WACO (TEX); BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO AND FIREARMS; FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; SUITS AND LITIGATION
column3: JURY FINDS FOR U.S. IN DEATHS AT WACO
column9: In a striking victory for the government, an advisory panel of five jurors took slightly more than an hour today to find that federal officials were not liable in the deaths of nearly 80 Branch Davidians who were killed in the 1993 raid and standoff...
column10: In a striking victory for the government, an advisory panel of five jurors took slightly more than an hour today to find that federal officials were not liable in the deaths of nearly 80 Branch Davidians who were killed in the 1993 raid and standoff at the sect's compound near Waco. Federal officials portrayed the jury's finding as a vindication for them in an episode that provided one of the darkest chapters in the history of federal law enforcement, threatened the career of Attorney General Janet Reno and continues to generate criticism. The lawsuit itself represents a six-year legal struggle that ultimately became a highly publicized test of the government's credibility.

column2: VUKOVIC, DALIBOR; KOSOVO (SERBIA); MITROVICA (SERBIA); SERBIA; FRANCE; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED NATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; TEAR GAS
column3: Arrest Spurs a Protest in a Divided City in Kosovo
column9: Angry over the arrest of a Serb accused of attacking Kosovo Albanians, thousands of Serbs blocked roads into their part of this ethnically divided city today and staged rallies to demand the suspect's release.    French soldiers backed by six armored...
column10: Angry over the arrest of a Serb accused of attacking Kosovo Albanians, thousands of Serbs blocked roads into their part of this ethnically divided city today and staged rallies to demand the suspect's release. French soldiers backed by six armored personnel carriers blocked the main bridge over the Ibar River, which divides the Serbian and Albanian areas, refusing to allow even United Nations employees to cross.

column2: DANFORTH, JOHN C; KORESH, DAVID; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO AND FIREARMS; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; RELIGIOUS CULTS
column3: A SPECIAL COUNSEL FINDS GOVERNMENT FAULTLESS AT WACO
column9: John C. Danforth, the special counsel investigating the 1993 tear-gas assault by federal agents on the Branch Davidian compound, today issued a sweeping report that cleared Attorney General Janet Reno and the government of any wrongdoing in the...
column10: John C. Danforth, the special counsel investigating the 1993 tear-gas assault by federal agents on the Branch Davidian compound, today issued a sweeping report that cleared Attorney General Janet Reno and the government of any wrongdoing in the deadly episode. Reminding a crowded news conference of his initial pledge to answer the ''dark questions'' surrounding the case, Mr. Danforth, a former Republican senator from Missouri, did not mince words. He declared that agents did not shoot at the Branch Davidians and did not start the fire that destroyed the compound on April 19, 1993, claiming the lives of about 80 people.

column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-7    Israeli Hopes Rise At Mideast Peace Talks  The Israeli peace delegation's mood shifted from dire to hopeful as officials outside Camp David said Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel believed the chances for the summit...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Israeli Hopes Rise At Mideast Peace Talks The Israeli peace delegation's mood shifted from dire to hopeful as officials outside Camp David said Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel believed the chances for the summit meeting's success had improved. President Clinton, who is attending an economic meeting of the leading industrial nations in Okinawa, also sounded upbeat. A1 Clinton Meets With Putin President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met with President Clinton to argue against American deployment of a national missile shield. They met during a break in the Group of 8 meeting in Okinawa. A6

column2: DANFORTH, JOHN C; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; EDITORIALS; SUITS AND LITIGATION
column3: Mr. Danforth's Verdict on Waco
column9: John Danforth noted last Friday that his inquiry into the 1993 Waco disaster had been limited to ''whether government agents had engaged in bad acts, not whether they exercised bad judgment.''    This is an important distinction. The report by Mr....
column10: John Danforth noted last Friday that his inquiry into the 1993 Waco disaster had been limited to ''whether government agents had engaged in bad acts, not whether they exercised bad judgment.'' This is an important distinction. The report by Mr. Danforth, the special counsel, cleared Attorney General Janet Reno of any wrongdoing in the federal raid on the compound near Waco, Tex., occupied by a sect called the Branch Davidians. After a 51-day standoff, tanks driven by F.B.I. agents pumped tear gas into the compound, after which a fire broke out, claiming about 80 lives.

column2: SPEIGHT, GEORGE; FIJI; SAVUSAVU (FIJI); AIR FIJI; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; HOSTAGES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; TEAR GAS
column3: Coup Leader in Fiji Is Arrested by the Military
column9: George Speight, who toppled Fiji's elected government in a two-month hostage standoff, was arrested tonight by the military, which then stormed his stronghold, leaving one supporter dead and dozens injured, officials said.    Troops firing tear gas...
column10: George Speight, who toppled Fiji's elected government in a two-month hostage standoff, was arrested tonight by the military, which then stormed his stronghold, leaving one supporter dead and dozens injured, officials said. Troops firing tear gas moved on a school in a suburb of Suva, Fiji's capital, where more than 350 Speight supporters had been camped for more than a week, said a military spokesman, Lt. Col. Filipo Tarakinikini. Hundreds were arrested.

column2: FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; LIMA (PERU); PERU; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Fujimori Takes Oath as Protests Blanket Area in Smoke
column9: President Alberto K. Fujimori was inaugurated to a third term today as the police and demonstrators engaged in running battles that engulfed the downtown area in tear gas and smoke.    Mr. Fujimori, on his 62nd birthday, enjoyed the pomp of military...
column10: President Alberto K. Fujimori was inaugurated to a third term today as the police and demonstrators engaged in running battles that engulfed the downtown area in tear gas and smoke. Mr. Fujimori, on his 62nd birthday, enjoyed the pomp of military marches and a special Mass. But waves of demonstrators, angered by their belief that he was elected in a fraudulent vote, tried to interrupt the proceedings, only to be turned back by police officers firing water cannon, tear gas and bullets.

column2: DAVILA, WILLIAM; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; MERIDA (VENEZUELA); FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Chavez Says He Will Crush Political Foes In Venezuela
column9: President Hugo Chavez said today that he would use troops to crush  street protests and to remove an opposition party governor who has accused the governing party of fraudulently altering the outcome of  elections last weekend.    ''This is going to...
column10: President Hugo Chavez said today that he would use troops to crush street protests and to remove an opposition party governor who has accused the governing party of fraudulently altering the outcome of elections last weekend. ''This is going to be nothing more than a little spat, but we are obliged to guarantee order and prevent these groups from spoiling the beautiful process that we have concluded,'' Mr. Chavez said this afternoon, referring to the vote held across Venezuela on Sunday. ''If they lost, they lost,'' he added dismissively.

column2: TOKAJI, DAN; LOS ANGELES (CALIF); PHILADELPHIA (PA); AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; CONVENTIONS, NATIONAL (US); SUITS AND LITIGATION; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2000; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Police and Protesters Ready; Politicians Hope for the Best
column9: The police say they are ready. They've chopped down trees that could be set on fire, uprooted newspaper racks that could be used as battering rams and fenced off a good-size patch of downtown Los Angeles with tall silver swaths of chain-link in an...
column10: The police say they are ready. They've chopped down trees that could be set on fire, uprooted newspaper racks that could be used as battering rams and fenced off a good-size patch of downtown Los Angeles with tall silver swaths of chain-link in an effort to keep any protests at the Democratic National Convention from getting out of hand. The demonstrators say they are ready, too. They're building puppets to protest corporate greed, practicing passive resistance and media techniques, sharing organizing tips over the Internet and warily watching the police cars that circle their ''convergence center'' near MacArthur Park. They pledge, as one of their Web sites puts it, to ''celebrate and renew our resistance to corporate globalization, militarism, poverty, starvation, campaign finance corruption, sexism, racism, homo/trans-phobia, criminalization of youth, environmental destruction, prison industrial complex, genocide,'' and that's just for starters.

column2: LOS ANGELES (CALIF); CONVENTIONS, NATIONAL (US); PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2000; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Police and Demonstrators Clash Outside Convention Hall
column9: The long-awaited dance between protesters and the police turned into a violent confrontation tonight when some in the audience at a concert  outside the Staples Center threw rocks and bottles at officers, who responded by firing rubber-coated bullets...
column10: The long-awaited dance between protesters and the police turned into a violent confrontation tonight when some in the audience at a concert outside the Staples Center threw rocks and bottles at officers, who responded by firing rubber-coated bullets and pepper spray at the demonstrators and moved in on horseback to disperse them. The concert of protest itself, by the hard-rock, hip-hop band Rage Against the Machine, was peaceful enough, staged just outside the center in a fenced-off spot from which the authorities had tried to bar demonstrators until a federal judge intervened. But once the concert was over, some in the crowd threw the bottles and rocks over a high-security fence at police officers on the other side.

column2: TELESCA, MICHAEL A; NEW YORK STATE; ATTICA STATE PRISON; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
column3: COMPENSATION SET ON ATTICA UPRISING
column8: Front Page; New York and Region
column9: Declaring that inmates beaten in the 1971 Attica prison uprising were treated ''like garbage,'' a federal judge divided an $8 million settlement today to compensate more than 500 inmates and relatives for the abuse that the prisoners suffered.    The...
column10: Declaring that inmates beaten in the 1971 Attica prison uprising were treated ''like garbage,'' a federal judge divided an $8 million settlement today to compensate more than 500 inmates and relatives for the abuse that the prisoners suffered. The allotment of the landmark settlement caps one of the longest and most ignominious chapters in American criminal justice history, fleshing out a deal reached in January between New York State and lawyers representing 1,281 former inmates.

column2: JAHN, LEROY; JAHN, RAY; WACO (TEX); BRANCH DAVIDIANS; RELIGIOUS CULTS; ETHICS
column3: 2 More Waco Prosecutors Said to Be at Risk of Charges
column9: Two federal prosecutors who helped send several Branch Davidians to prison may face prosecution themselves on charges that they withheld information about government actions in the siege at the group's compound near Waco, a lawyer involved in the...
column10: Two federal prosecutors who helped send several Branch Davidians to prison may face prosecution themselves on charges that they withheld information about government actions in the siege at the group's compound near Waco, a lawyer involved in the case said today. The prosecutors, Ray Jahn and his wife, LeRoy Jahn, assistant United States attorneys in San Antonio who in 1994 won convictions against eight Branch Davidians in the group's deadly 1993 standoff with federal agents, have been told that they may be indicted by John C. Danforth, the special counsel investigating the government's actions, the lawyer said.

column10: If the 150 or so national leaders assembled at the United Nations yesterday were curious about where globalization was really taking the world, they could have ambled over to Town Hall, the concert auditorium on West 43rd Street. There, opinions abounded:

column2: FREEH, LOUIS J; SMITH, WALTER S; HOLDER, ERIC H JR; WACO (TEX); BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO AND FIREARMS; FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); SUITS AND LITIGATION; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
column3: Government Cleared in Deaths at Waco
column9: A federal judge today dismissed the wrongful death civil lawsuit brought by Branch Davidians, clearing the government of any wrongdoing in the deaths of about 80 members of the religious sect during the disastrous 1993 standoff at the group's...
column10: A federal judge today dismissed the wrongful death civil lawsuit brought by Branch Davidians, clearing the government of any wrongdoing in the deaths of about 80 members of the religious sect during the disastrous 1993 standoff at the group's compound near Waco, Tex. The judge, Walter Smith Jr. of Federal District Court in Waco, issued an order that found that federal agents had acted legally and could not be held liable for the deaths. His ruling ended a legal battle that lasted nearly seven years and came after an advisory jury in the case and a special counsel, former Senator John C. Danforth, both issued similar findings in July.

column3: World Briefing
column9: MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: CONTENTIOUS ROADWAY -- The Jerusalem municipality is starting to expropriate land from Palestinians in southeast Jerusalem to build an eastern road that circumnavigates the congested city. Palestinian officials in East...
column10: MIDDLE EAST ISRAEL: CONTENTIOUS ROADWAY -- The Jerusalem municipality is starting to expropriate land from Palestinians in southeast Jerusalem to build an eastern road that circumnavigates the congested city. Palestinian officials in East Jerusalem said the project was an obstacle to peace that aimed to separate Palestinian neighborhoods in East Jerusalem from the West Bank, and Israel's Peace Now group called on the city to freeze the roadwork to await the outcome of peace talks. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

column2: WOLFENSOHN, JAMES D; PRAGUE (CZECH REPUBLIC); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Protests Distract Global Finance Meeting
column9: Black-masked protesters hurled cobblestones ripped from Prague's medieval streets and attacked the police with homemade gasoline bombs today, trying desperately -- but unsuccessfully -- to shut down the global finance meeting here.    The riot police...
column10: Black-masked protesters hurled cobblestones ripped from Prague's medieval streets and attacked the police with homemade gasoline bombs today, trying desperately -- but unsuccessfully -- to shut down the global finance meeting here. The riot police had to escort government ministers attending the annual conference of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank into special subways cars to whisk them away from their meeting at the end of the session, though by evening, normal access had been fully restored.

column2: SUHARTO; INDONESIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
column3: Jakarta Court Drops Charges Against Ailing Suharto
column9: An Indonesian court dismissed the government's corruption case against former President Suharto today after court-appointed doctors declared him medically unfit to stand trial.     The ruling immediately touched off violent clashes outside the...
column10: An Indonesian court dismissed the government's corruption case against former President Suharto today after court-appointed doctors declared him medically unfit to stand trial. The ruling immediately touched off violent clashes outside the auditorium where the trial was being conducted between hundreds of supporters and opponents of Mr. Suharto, whose 32-year rule ended in 1998.

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; GAZA; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: DEATH TOLL RISES
column9: Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli troops left at least 12 Palestinians dead and hundreds wounded in the third day of fierce fighting set off by the defiant visit on Thursday of a right-wing Israeli leader, Ariel Sharon, to the steps of...
column10: Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli troops left at least 12 Palestinians dead and hundreds wounded in the third day of fierce fighting set off by the defiant visit on Thursday of a right-wing Israeli leader, Ariel Sharon, to the steps of the ancient mosques atop Jerusalem's Old City. The fighting today, on the first day of the Jewish New Year, an Israeli national holiday that is commemorated as a time for quiet reflection and prayer, was among the bloodiest confrontations between Israelis and Palestinians in recent years.

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Old Anger of Israeli Arabs Finds Vent
column9: Ferrying wounded from the rubble-strewn battleground at the entrance to this Israeli Arab town today, honking cars sped up a road to a clinic besieged by an angry crowd.    Frantic youths shouted for people to make way as the casualties, arriving by...
column10: Ferrying wounded from the rubble-strewn battleground at the entrance to this Israeli Arab town today, honking cars sped up a road to a clinic besieged by an angry crowd. Frantic youths shouted for people to make way as the casualties, arriving by the minute, were rushed inside. As word spread that one of the wounded had died, a man said, ''The state has declared war on its citizens.''

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; GAZA STRIP; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: As Truce Fails, Fighting Rages In Middle East
column9: A cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians crumbled within hours today when intense rioting and gun battles flared once more throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Arab towns inside Israel.    Israeli television reported that Prime...
column10: A cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians crumbled within hours today when intense rioting and gun battles flared once more throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Arab towns inside Israel. Israeli television reported that Prime Minister Ehud Barak believed that the conflict was waning, and he was scheduled to travel to Paris on Wednesday to meet with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in a bid to end the bloodshed.

column2: ALBRIGHT, MADELEINE K; CHIRAC, JACQUES; MUBARAK, HOSNI; ARAFAT, YASIR; BARAK, EHUD; ANNAN, KOFI; EGYPT; SYRIA; FRANCE; ISRAEL; CAIRO (EGYPT); AMMAN (JORDAN); JORDAN; DAMASCUS (SYRIA); UNITED NATIONS; FRANCE-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; JEWS; PALESTINIANS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; ANTI-SEMITISM; ISRAEL-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: NO DEAL REACHED IN TALKS TO QUELL MIDEAST FIGHTING
column9: After more than 12 hours of stormy talks and with clashes continuing in the Middle East, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright struggled into the early morning today to find a way to stop the violence, but...
column10: After more than 12 hours of stormy talks and with clashes continuing in the Middle East, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright struggled into the early morning today to find a way to stop the violence, but failed to reach an overall agreement, a senior Clinton administration official said. Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel headed home from Paris this morning, declining an invitation from President Hosni Mubarak to hold further negotiations in Egypt. An American official said Dr. Albright was going to the meeting with Mr. Mubarak and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to ''lock things down'' and pin down Mr. Arafat.

column2: MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; KOSTUNICA, VOJISLAV; BELGRADE (SERBIA); SERBIA; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA; TEAR GAS
column3: Yugoslavs Claim Belgrade for New Leader
column9: As the federal Parliament burned and tear gas wafted through chaotic streets, vast throngs of Serbs wrested their capital and key levers of power away from Slobodan Milosevic today, bringing his 13-year reign to the edge of collapse.    Vojislav...
column10: As the federal Parliament burned and tear gas wafted through chaotic streets, vast throngs of Serbs wrested their capital and key levers of power away from Slobodan Milosevic today, bringing his 13-year reign to the edge of collapse. Vojislav Kostunica, the opposition leader who claimed victory in the presidential election on Sept. 24, moved through an ecstatic crowd of several hundred thousand and proclaimed, ''Good evening, dear liberated Serbia!''

column2: ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS
column3: In Bethlehem, New Generation of Teenage Foes Renews Ritual of Bloodshed
column9: Juggling stones in his hands, Muhammad Ibrahim, 17, reported for his afternoon shift in the seven-day-old street war of what he thinks of as the second, and final, Palestinian uprising.    His white T-shirt, the sleeves cut off to reveal biceps that...
column10: Juggling stones in his hands, Muhammad Ibrahim, 17, reported for his afternoon shift in the seven-day-old street war of what he thinks of as the second, and final, Palestinian uprising. His white T-shirt, the sleeves cut off to reveal biceps that have had a stone-throwing workout in the last week, was stained with the blood of a friend shot this morning.

column2: WEST BANK; GAZA; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; AL AKSA MOSQUE (JERUSALEM); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: In Israel, Brief Calm Gives Way to Chaos
column9: After a week of rioting and gun battles, Israeli and Palestinian authorities today struggled mutually, with limited success, to keep the Friday Prayers at Al Aksa Mosque in the Old City from ending in a bloodbath and further inflaming an already...
column10: After a week of rioting and gun battles, Israeli and Palestinian authorities today struggled mutually, with limited success, to keep the Friday Prayers at Al Aksa Mosque in the Old City from ending in a bloodbath and further inflaming an already explosive Israeli-Arab conflict. Unlike last week, when Israeli police stormed the mosque compound, killing 5 and wounding 200 Palestinians, Israeli officers kept to the perimeter after Prayers. Inside, Palestinian security officials with megaphones urged restraint, while frail Muslim clerics wrestled chunks of concrete from young men trying to throw them over the wall onto the plaza facing the Western Wall, Judaism's most sacred site.

column2: MILOSEVIC, MARKO; MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; KOSTUNICA, VOJISLAV; BELGRADE (SERBIA); SERBIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
column3: Touring Belgrade Ruins, in Pride and Sorrow
column9: A perfume shop on one of Belgrade's main shopping streets, Terazije, is called Scandal, and it is owned by Marko Milosevic, son of Slobodan.    It was trashed and looted last night by some of the hundreds of thousands who thronged through Belgrade to...
column10: A perfume shop on one of Belgrade's main shopping streets, Terazije, is called Scandal, and it is owned by Marko Milosevic, son of Slobodan. It was trashed and looted last night by some of the hundreds of thousands who thronged through Belgrade to take back their government from Mr. Milosevic and his family.

column2: MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; SERBIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
column3: The World: Stare Down; Serbs Shed Their Fear and Make a Revolution
column9: THE black plumes of smoke rising from Yugoslavia's federal Parliament building as a flag-waving throng storms the building will forever define the Serbian revolution that toppled Slobodan Milosevic. In its way, the image has the force of the...
column10: THE black plumes of smoke rising from Yugoslavia's federal Parliament building as a flag-waving throng storms the building will forever define the Serbian revolution that toppled Slobodan Milosevic. In its way, the image has the force of the photograph of a soldier planting the Soviet flag atop the Reichstag in Berlin in 1945. Both images are overwhelming in their glorious finality. But Yevgeny Khaldei's Reichstag photograph was a perfect representation of victory in a bloody war, whereas the iconic images of the end of Mr. Milosevic's 13-year rule seem to offer a partial truth. Without the critical injection of force at a pivotal moment -- the hard men from central Serbia storming past the hesitant police and their tear gas -- the opposition's protests might have proved as ineffectual as they so often had in the past. But Mr. Milosevic was downed less by violent upheaval than by the broad, massive, nonviolent protest that has characterized the fall of so many authoritarian regimes in recent years.

column3: CLINTON IS ASKING EGYPT TO CONVENE A MIDEAST MEETING
column9: Faced with the worst assault on Middle East peace since he entered the White House, President Clinton asked the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, to convene an urgent summit meeting where Mr. Clinton could meet the leaders of Israel, the...
column10: Faced with the worst assault on Middle East peace since he entered the White House, President Clinton asked the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, to convene an urgent summit meeting where Mr. Clinton could meet the leaders of Israel, the Palestinians and Jordan, a senior administration official said today. Mr. Mubarak did not immediately agree to the idea of a midweek regional summit meeting in Egypt, but said he would discuss it with Yasir Arafat when the Palestinian leader arrived in Cairo on Monday, officials said.

column3: How Small Town Turned Out For Kostunica at a Key Time
column9: Townspeople here cheered their mayor today in the street and paraded a yellow bulldozer around the main square for the television cameras in celebration of their part in the revolt in Belgrade that secured their election victory and forced Slobodan...
column10: Townspeople here cheered their mayor today in the street and paraded a yellow bulldozer around the main square for the television cameras in celebration of their part in the revolt in Belgrade that secured their election victory and forced Slobodan Milosevic from power. People from Cacak, one of the most determinedly anti-Milosevic places in Serbia, were at the core of the tide of people who gathered in the capital, Belgrade, on Thursday and overran the federal Parliament and state television station.

column3: Israelis Extend Deadline for Arafat to Quell Violence
column9: After the deadline set by Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel for the Palestinians to quell violence expired with riots still raging, the Israeli cabinet decided early this morning to avoid exploding a tense situation and gave Yasir Arafat a ''last...
column10: After the deadline set by Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel for the Palestinians to quell violence expired with riots still raging, the Israeli cabinet decided early this morning to avoid exploding a tense situation and gave Yasir Arafat a ''last chance'' to quiet protests. In the face of a concerted international effort to prevent the conflict from escalating and spreading, the government also said that it would agree, if invited, to attend an American-sponsored summit meeting in the region this week.

column2: MUGABE, ROBERT; TSVANGIRAI, MORGAN; HARARE (ZIMBABWE); ZIMBABWE; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; TEAR GAS
column3: Zimbabwe Authorities Crack Down on Political Opposition
column9: Two months after President Robert Mugabe bowed to election results and welcomed an opposition into the Parliament for the first time with promises of cooperation, relations have soured. The opposition leader 10 days ago warned Mr. Mugabe that if he...
column10: Two months after President Robert Mugabe bowed to election results and welcomed an opposition into the Parliament for the first time with promises of cooperation, relations have soured. The opposition leader 10 days ago warned Mr. Mugabe that if he didn't step aside, he would be ousted ''violently.'' Today, the government arrested three opposition members of Parliament on charges of inciting violence and sprayed tear gas on scores of their supporters, who sang and chanted outside the courthouse before scattering through clouds of choking smoke.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-17    Israel Extends Ultimatum, As Cabinet Weighs Options  Prime Minister Ehud Barak's deadline for the Palestinians to end violent protests expired with riots still raging, but the Israeli cabinet said it would give the...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Israel Extends Ultimatum, As Cabinet Weighs Options Prime Minister Ehud Barak's deadline for the Palestinians to end violent protests expired with riots still raging, but the Israeli cabinet said it would give the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, more time. As anxiety rose that the conflict might escalate and spread, an international intervention effort intensified with the arrival of the United Nations secretary general and Russia's foreign minister. President Clinton was expected to decide soon whether to call an emergency summit meeting. A1 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt held a two-hour meeting in Cairo with Mr. Arafat. A17

column2: LEBANON; ISRAEL; HEZBOLLAH; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 3 Israelis Are Now Pawns in a Growing Deal
column9: Hezbollah's capture of three Israeli soldiers along the Lebanese border on Saturday was a well-planned operation intended to coincide with the outburst of Palestinian protests over control of a Jerusalem site sacred to both Muslims and Jews,...
column10: Hezbollah's capture of three Israeli soldiers along the Lebanese border on Saturday was a well-planned operation intended to coincide with the outburst of Palestinian protests over control of a Jerusalem site sacred to both Muslims and Jews, according to leaders of the guerrilla group and military experts. Hezbollah's immediate goal, they say, was to swap the three sergeants for 19 Islamic militants in Israeli jails, although in the bargaining the total may go as high as 49. Israel has said that it is holding the 19 Lebanese prisoners without trial as bargaining chips for information on three of its soldiers missing in Lebanon since 1982 and an airman, Ron Arad, whose fighter-bomber crashed in Lebanon in 1987.

column2: ISRAEL; NAZARETH (ISRAEL); PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Crowds of Jews Rampage in Nazareth
column9: Several hundred Jews, apparently tired of feeling trapped for 12 days in this predominantly Arab city, rampaged on Sunday night, attacking Arab homes and touching off a melee in which the Israeli police killed two Arabs, more than a dozen Arab...
column10: Several hundred Jews, apparently tired of feeling trapped for 12 days in this predominantly Arab city, rampaged on Sunday night, attacking Arab homes and touching off a melee in which the Israeli police killed two Arabs, more than a dozen Arab witnesses said. The troubles began shortly after evening religious services for Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, when Jews swept through Arab neighborhoods shouting, ''Death to Arabs!'' hurling stones through windows and attacking Arabs.

column10: The authorities questioned Zimbabwe's main opposition leader for two hours today at police headquarters but delayed a decision about whether to arrest him, sidestepping a showdown that many feared would touch off violent protests. The police insisted that they still had enough evidence to arrest the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, for making a speech in which he told President Robert Mugabe, ''If you don't want to go peacefully, we will remove you violently.''

column3: Seattle Journal; In a Turbulent Year, a City Is Cheered by Baseball
column9: It's being  called  what else to call it? -- ''the Battle in Seattle.''     Powerful, important visitors have just arrived in the Pacific Northwest, vilified here as big shots bent on global domination (in three of the last four years, anyway). In...
column10: It's being called what else to call it? -- ''the Battle in Seattle.'' Powerful, important visitors have just arrived in the Pacific Northwest, vilified here as big shots bent on global domination (in three of the last four years, anyway). In outbursts and raucous demonstrations, Seattleites have made it clear: they do not want these visitors to achieve what they have come here to do.

column2: MUGABE, ROBERT; ZIMBABWE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Mugabe's Foes in Zimbabwe, Stymied, Talk of Violence
column9: The opposition legislators now speak the language of ayes and nays, motions and resolutions and their names appear in neat black type on white government doors. But the jubilation over their sweep in June elections of more than a third of...
column10: The opposition legislators now speak the language of ayes and nays, motions and resolutions and their names appear in neat black type on white government doors. But the jubilation over their sweep in June elections of more than a third of parliamentary seats has quickly dissolved into discontent. In recent weeks, the opposition has watched helplessly as the government has pardoned the perpetrators of political violence, drafted governing party militants into a militia and allocated millions of dollars more to the costly war in Congo while shabby hospitals here run short of syringes.

column2: MILOSEVIC, SLOBODAN; PAVKOVIC, NEBOJSA; SERBIA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; SERBIA-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US
column3: From a Summons to a Slap: How the Fight in Yugoslavia Was Won
column9: Early in the day of the uprising that overthrew Slobodan Milosevic, Ljubisav Djokic received a call requesting special assistance from organizers of the opposition. Mr. Djokic, a construction worker, drives a large bulldozer, and he was asked to...
column10: Early in the day of the uprising that overthrew Slobodan Milosevic, Ljubisav Djokic received a call requesting special assistance from organizers of the opposition. Mr. Djokic, a construction worker, drives a large bulldozer, and he was asked to bring it along to a mass demonstration in central Belgrade. Arriving in front of the federal Parliament shortly before 3 p.m. that Thursday, Oct. 5, he was confronted by riot police officers. ''I thought it was going to be peaceful,'' he said. ''But when the tear gas started and people fled, I came eye-to-eye with the police. Then I asked myself, 'Why did you come? What are you waiting for? Did you come to a parade or do you want to finish something?' ''

column3: Palestinian Militias: Motley but Armed
column9: Yasid Abu Abed, a veteran fighter in Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, stepped over the chunks of concrete, broken beams, twisted iron reinforcing rods and mangled furniture strewn about his headquarters in Gaza City.   ...
column10: Yasid Abu Abed, a veteran fighter in Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, stepped over the chunks of concrete, broken beams, twisted iron reinforcing rods and mangled furniture strewn about his headquarters in Gaza City. As he surveyed the wreckage, caused by Israeli missile attacks last week, bodyguards who clutched an eclectic collection of weapons, including American-made M-16 assault rifles and outdated black snub-nosed Russian machine guns, clustered around him.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    ITALY: VOTING ABROAD -- A constitutional amendment was approved to allow Italians overseas to elect their own legislators, including candidates who live abroad. Twelve seats in the 630-seat lower house and six in the 315-seat Senate are to...
column10: EUROPE ITALY: VOTING ABROAD -- A constitutional amendment was approved to allow Italians overseas to elect their own legislators, including candidates who live abroad. Twelve seats in the 630-seat lower house and six in the 315-seat Senate are to be allocated to representatives of Italians abroad, of whom there are about 4 million, with more than 300,000 in the United States and Canada. First, however, a law must be passed setting up candidates' procedural rules. Voting by absentee ballot is not allowed. Alessandra Stanley (NYT) FRANCE: CABINET RESIGNATION -- Martine Aubry, the cabinet minister who shepherded the introduction of the government's 35-hour workweek policy, has quit her cabinet post to run for mayor of Lille. The widely expected move is seen as a steppingstone to run for higher office in 2002. If Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, who is expected to run for president in 2002, were to win, Mrs. Aubry could well replace him as prime minister. Mr. Jospin named his justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, to take over Mrs. Aubry's portfolio. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

column2: ARAFAT, YASIR; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Barak May Halt Peace Moves To Revamp His Government
column9: Prime Minister Ehud Barak, elected on a platform of peacemaking, announced tonight that he was prepared to take an indefinite ''timeout'' from the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. That would pave the way for him to forge a national emergency...
column10: Prime Minister Ehud Barak, elected on a platform of peacemaking, announced tonight that he was prepared to take an indefinite ''timeout'' from the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. That would pave the way for him to forge a national emergency government with the right-wing opposition next week. Mr. Barak's announcement came at the end of one of the worst days of violence since the current conflict began raging three weeks ago, and on the eve of a weekend summit meeting of Arab leaders. After Palestinians confronted Israeli soldiers at checkpoints throughout the West Bank, 10 Palestinians were killed in clashes that defied the truce agreement forged early this week in Sharm el Sheik, Egypt.

column2: BARAK, EHUD; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Barak Seeks To Heal Rift With Inquiry And New Aid
column9: Trying to heal a rift with Israel's Arab citizens, Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced an inquiry today into the deaths of 13 Israeli Arabs in the current unrest and unveiled a four-year development plan for Arab communities.    The moves were met...
column10: Trying to heal a rift with Israel's Arab citizens, Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced an inquiry today into the deaths of 13 Israeli Arabs in the current unrest and unveiled a four-year development plan for Arab communities. The moves were met with skepticism by Israeli Arab leaders, who said that the inquiry, by a committee of experts and retired judges instead of an official state commission, would lack binding authority. The development plan, they said, failed to address the roots of inequality of Israel's one million Arab citizens.

column3: Intelligence Chief Returns, Sending Peru Into Disarray
column9: A month after fleeing, the former intelligence chief returned here today, plunging the government of President Alberto K. Fujimori into disarray.    First Vice President Francisco Tudela, a close ally of Mr. Fujimori, resigned, saying of the...
column10: A month after fleeing, the former intelligence chief returned here today, plunging the government of President Alberto K. Fujimori into disarray. First Vice President Francisco Tudela, a close ally of Mr. Fujimori, resigned, saying of the intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, who fled to escape allegations of corruption, ''The game he is playing with the country outrages me.''

column3: World Briefing
column9: EUROPE    FRANCE: MAD COW CONCERN -- Concern about the spread of mad cow disease has been growing as the number of new cases recorded this year has more than doubled since last year. Authorities announced over the weekend that 1,000 tons of...
column10: EUROPE FRANCE: MAD COW CONCERN -- Concern about the spread of mad cow disease has been growing as the number of new cases recorded this year has more than doubled since last year. Authorities announced over the weekend that 1,000 tons of potentially contaminated meat had been put on the market as of Oct. 10. The Carrefour supermarket chain said the meat was distributed to 39 stores, mostly in northern France. The latest case brought to 73 the number of affected animals found in 2000, compared with 31 in 1999. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

column2: CLINTON, BILL; ABDULLAH; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; JORDAN; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ISRAEL-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-JORDAN; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; JORDAN-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US
column3: Anti-U.S. Fury in Jordan's Streets Overshadows a Trade Pact
column9: On the day that Bill Clinton held a White House ceremony with Jordan's king to sign a trade pact, Muhammad Nubeni and his friends paraded through the streets here today denouncing the American president.     Tens of thousands of Jordanians -- most of...
column10: On the day that Bill Clinton held a White House ceremony with Jordan's king to sign a trade pact, Muhammad Nubeni and his friends paraded through the streets here today denouncing the American president. Tens of thousands of Jordanians -- most of Palestinian origin, like Mr. Nubeni -- marched toward the border with Israel, demanding an end to Jordan's diplomatic and economic relations with Israel and condemning American support for Israel.

column3: Gun Lessons Are Suddenly All the Rage in Israel
column9: At the Battle Shooting Range, Kady Harari, 36, stood with her feet planted wide, raised a semiautomatic weapon, set her sights on the target's heart and trembled. Then, feeling sick, she later said, she squeezed the trigger of a pistol for the first...
column10: At the Battle Shooting Range, Kady Harari, 36, stood with her feet planted wide, raised a semiautomatic weapon, set her sights on the target's heart and trembled. Then, feeling sick, she later said, she squeezed the trigger of a pistol for the first time in her life and sent a bullet ricocheting off the padded ceiling. Wearing a long khaki skirt and a baseball cap -- a uniform of the modern religious woman here -- she looked like an unlikely sharpshooter. But several spent magazines later, she had considerably improved.

column2: GBAGBO, LAURENT; GUEI, ROBERT; ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; FRANCE; EUROPEAN UNION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; IVORY COAST-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; CURFEWS; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Ivory Coast Ruler Declares Himself Winner
column9: The military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, declared himself winner of Sunday's presidential election today, dissolving the electoral commission that had shown him trailing his main opponent and dashing hopes that the vote would reverse this West African...
column10: The military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, declared himself winner of Sunday's presidential election today, dissolving the electoral commission that had shown him trailing his main opponent and dashing hopes that the vote would reverse this West African country's yearlong slide into political instability. The announcement set off immediate and widespread protests here and in several other cities. On Monday, after preliminary results indicated that the main opposition leader, Laurent Gbagbo, had an 11-point lead, soldiers invaded the offices of the National Electoral Commission and halted the vote-counting.

column10: A day after toppling the military dictator in a popular uprising, residents of Ivory Coast furiously turned against one another today, and the deadly clashes quickly took on religious and ethnic overtones and spread to smaller cities. Supporters of two of the main political parties, unified the day before in their opposition to the officer, Gen. Robert Guei, were thrust apart today by religion, ethnicity and their leaders' ambitions.

column10: Israeli soldiers shot four Palestinians dead today as violence flared across the West Bank and Gaza Strip after several days of relative calm. In Ramallah, ambulances screamed in constant rotation as hundreds of Palestinians gathered on a hill to watch squads of young men hurl rocks at Israeli jeeps parked across from their barrier of burned-out cars.

column10: An uneasy calm returned to the Ivory Coast today as the new president and his opponents held meetings suggesting a truce in the political crisis that has shaken this corner of West Africa for a week. A day after politically fueled religious tensions exploded in deadly clashes in the slums and working-class quarters of Abidjan, the president and his main opponent met in an air-conditioned room here, sat on a beige sofa and, as flashbulbs exploded, shook hands.

column2: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Foreign Affairs; Ritual Sacrifice
column9: Here's a day in the life of Israel and Palestine: I arrive in Jerusalem from Hong Kong at 5 a.m. The taxi drops me at the door of the King David Hotel. I walk in. The lobby is completely dark and empty. Not a soul, not a bellhop, is stirring, not...
column10: Here's a day in the life of Israel and Palestine: I arrive in Jerusalem from Hong Kong at 5 a.m. The taxi drops me at the door of the King David Hotel. I walk in. The lobby is completely dark and empty. Not a soul, not a bellhop, is stirring, not even a mouse. ''Hello,'' I shout into the dark, wondering if my travel agent has made a mistake and the hotel has been closed. ''Is anybody home? Hello!'' Finally a desk clerk emerges from a dark corner, where he has been sleeping on a couch. The hotel has laid off most of its employees, because tourism is dead. ''Am I the only one staying here?'' I ask. The clerk just chuckles. The following morning I drive to Ramallah with a Palestinian journalist friend. When we arrive at the back entrance to the city, a ''clash'' is underway. There is a long, wide street. The Israeli soldiers are on our end hiding behind three armored cars, popping out to fire tear gas, rubber bullets and real bullets at the Palestinian youths, who are pelting the soldiers with rocks and marbles from behind a pile of burned-out cars. Behind the Palestinians, five Palestinian ambulances are parked. When a Palestinian youth goes down, an ambulance races out, siren screaming, and the wounded boy is bundled off to the hospital, like a Roman gladiator scraped up off the ring. Behind them, a crowd of 300 Palestinians, of various ages, are simply watching the scene. A vendor is selling kebabs.

column2: SHALAH, BILAL; SHALAH, HILAL; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Arabs See Brothers' Deaths as Israeli Escalation
column9: For the Palestinian residents of this hardscrabble village, the shooting deaths here of two brothers in a confrontation with Israeli soldiers was proof that Israelis no longer hesitate to pull the trigger on unarmed civilians.     For the Israeli...
column10: For the Palestinian residents of this hardscrabble village, the shooting deaths here of two brothers in a confrontation with Israeli soldiers was proof that Israelis no longer hesitate to pull the trigger on unarmed civilians. For the Israeli Army, the killings were an aberration, caused by the reckless provocation of two young men, but turned into tragedy by what a military spokesman suggested may have been an inappropriate use of live ammunition.

column2: BAKIR, OSCAR; SHINAHOTA (BOLIVIA); BRAZIL; COCAINE AND CRACK COCAINE; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC
column3: Shinahota Journal; Where the Coca Trade Withers, Tourism Sprouts
column9: Drug smuggling planes used to land in the middle of the street in this farming town at the height of the cocaine boom in the mid-1980's. Roberto Suarez, the local kingpin, was so rich he offered to pay off Bolivia's entire national debt.    But after...
column10: Drug smuggling planes used to land in the middle of the street in this farming town at the height of the cocaine boom in the mid-1980's. Roberto Suarez, the local kingpin, was so rich he offered to pay off Bolivia's entire national debt. But after three years of a government coca eradication campaign, cocaine is virtually a thing of the past here. Now the future is full of suntan lotion and long drives off the tee. At least that is the idea of Oscar Bakir, a telecommunications executive who thinks Shinahota could be the next Disney World or Riviera.

column9: Efforts by Palestinians and Israelis to tamp down their clashes were interrupted by new violence today, but they stayed alive with reports that both sides would meet with President Clinton next week.     A White House spokeswoman, Nanda Chitre, said...
column10: Efforts by Palestinians and Israelis to tamp down their clashes were interrupted by new violence today, but they stayed alive with reports that both sides would meet with President Clinton next week. A White House spokeswoman, Nanda Chitre, said in Washington, ''The president hopes to see the leaders toward the end of next week,'' after Election Day. A senior administration official said the proposal was for Mr. Clinton to hold separate meetings at the White House with Prime Minister Ehud Barak and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, to cull ideas about getting back to peace negotiations.
