column3: 4 Die in Election Violence in Northern Egypt
column9: The police fired live ammunition and tear gas today in clashes with voters in three northern villages. Elsewhere, fistfights between supporters of rival candidates in the parliamentary elections turned to gunfire.     As night fell, 4 people were...
column10: The police fired live ammunition and tear gas today in clashes with voters in three northern villages. Elsewhere, fistfights between supporters of rival candidates in the parliamentary elections turned to gunfire. As night fell, 4 people were dead and more than 60 people injured.

column2: IVORY COAST; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY; ISLAM
column3: 2 Religions Clashing in Ivory Coast
column9: Up a winding street here in a sprawling, working-class neighborhood, a mosque, a Roman Catholic church and a Protestant church have long stood close to one another -- symbols of the religious and ethnic tolerance that made this country the envy of...
column10: Up a winding street here in a sprawling, working-class neighborhood, a mosque, a Roman Catholic church and a Protestant church have long stood close to one another -- symbols of the religious and ethnic tolerance that made this country the envy of other Africans. But after a popular revolt that began against a military dictator on Oct. 24 quickly degenerated into deadly political clashes, Christians attacked the Aisha Niangon Mosque, in this neighborhood, Yopougon. The walls surrounding the building are pockmarked with holes the assailants used as toeholds to clamber over. In the courtyard, the burned-out skeleton of the imam's car lay not too far from a palm tree that had also been set on fire.

column2: DANFORTH, JOHN C; JOHNSTON, BILL; RENO, JANET; WACO (TEX); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT; BRANCH DAVIDIANS; ETHICS
column3: Prosecutor Is Indicted in Davidian Inquiry
column9: A federal prosecutor who warned Attorney General Janet Reno last year that Justice Department officials might have withheld evidence in the investigation of the 1993 standoff with the Branch Davidians outside Waco, Tex., was indicted today on charges...
column10: A federal prosecutor who warned Attorney General Janet Reno last year that Justice Department officials might have withheld evidence in the investigation of the 1993 standoff with the Branch Davidians outside Waco, Tex., was indicted today on charges of obstructing justice and making false statements to investigators. The five-count federal indictment of the prosecutor, Bill Johnston, was initiated by John C. Danforth, the special counsel looking into the standoff.

column2: OBAIYAT, HUSSEIN; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; BETHLEHEM (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; FATAH, AL; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; PALESTINIANS
column3: After Funeral for a Slain Palestinian Paramilitary Leader, More Death for Both Sides
column9: In Manger Square, spiffed up just last Christmas for what was supposed to be a banner year for the now-dead Palestinian tourism industry, thousands of Muslims bowed in prayer today to mourn a paramilitary leader assassinated by the Israelis.    The...
column10: In Manger Square, spiffed up just last Christmas for what was supposed to be a banner year for the now-dead Palestinian tourism industry, thousands of Muslims bowed in prayer today to mourn a paramilitary leader assassinated by the Israelis. The dead man, Hussein Obaiyat, 34, a baker by trade, a gun collector by avocation, was not well known here beyond his clan and the paramilitary unit that he ran for Yasir Arafat's Fatah organization. But when Israel used helicopter gunships to kill him on Thursday, and killing two middle-aged women as well, it instantly secured him a place in the pantheon of Palestinian heroes.

column2: MARCENARO, RICARDO; PANIAGUA, VALENTIN; FUJIMORI, ALBERTO K; HILDEBRANDT, MARTHA; PERU; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
column3: Peru Opposition Picks Successor for Fujimori's Ally in Congress
column9: Two days after ousting a head of Congress loyal to President Alberto K. Fujimori, opposition lawmakers named their candidate today to lead the legislature, threatening to undermine further Mr. Fujimori's fading hold on power.    Also today, the...
column10: Two days after ousting a head of Congress loyal to President Alberto K. Fujimori, opposition lawmakers named their candidate today to lead the legislature, threatening to undermine further Mr. Fujimori's fading hold on power. Also today, the police used tear gas to disperse hundreds of leftist-led construction workers who were demonstrating outside the Government Palace. The protesters carried an effigy with two heads, Mr. Fujimori's and that of the former spy chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, in a cage. Tear gas canisters flew after some protesters, carrying wood poles and shouting, ''There is no president!'' charged at the police.

column2: GANTZ, BENJAMIN; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS
column3: Resolute Commander of Israeli Forces in the West Bank
column9: It is Wednesday, and just another day at the office for Brig. Gen. Benjamin Gantz, commander of Israel's forces throughout the West Bank.     In the morning, undercover commando units abducted 15 Palestinians who Israel said were Fatah militia...
column10: It is Wednesday, and just another day at the office for Brig. Gen. Benjamin Gantz, commander of Israel's forces throughout the West Bank. In the morning, undercover commando units abducted 15 Palestinians who Israel said were Fatah militia members responsible for the shooting deaths of two soldiers and a teacher. In the evening, a few hundred yards from his fortress headquarters, General Gantz's troops battled rioters, firing tear gas, rubber-coated bullets and sporadic bursts of live ammunition.

column2: WILLIAMS, HOSEA; KING, MARTIN LUTHER JR; BLACKS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
column3: Hosea Williams, 74, Rights Crusader, Dies
column9: Hosea Williams, a field general for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in civil rights clashes of the 1960's, and more recently an Atlanta politician with a talent for confounding friends and enemies alike, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 74 and...
column10: Hosea Williams, a field general for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in civil rights clashes of the 1960's, and more recently an Atlanta politician with a talent for confounding friends and enemies alike, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 74 and had been suffering from cancer. Rambunctious, fearless and blunt, Mr. Williams was just the man for a certain kind of work in Dr. King's efforts to desegregate the South. Dr. King called him ''my wild man, my Castro,'' and deployed him as heavy artillery to soften up resistance.

column3: The Endgame in Peru
column9: Pressure mounted on Alberto Fujimori, president of Peru, to leave office before his announced July resignation date.     First, the state prosecutor asked the attorney general to investigate a Colombian news magazine article that in 1989 Mr. Fujimori...
column10: Pressure mounted on Alberto Fujimori, president of Peru, to leave office before his announced July resignation date. First, the state prosecutor asked the attorney general to investigate a Colombian news magazine article that in 1989 Mr. Fujimori received money from Pablo Escobar, the Colombian drug baron who was later killed.

column2: HAVIVIAN, YORAM; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; JORDAN; GAZA STRIP; JORDANIAN ISLAMIC RESISTANCE MOVEMENT; AHMED DAKAMSHE UNIT; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Israeli Diplomat Wounded in Jordan, but Fighting Tapers Off
column9: An Israeli diplomat was shot and slightly wounded outside his home in Jordan today, raising fresh concerns that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is affecting neighboring countries that have already made peace with Israel.    But the conflict...
column10: An Israeli diplomat was shot and slightly wounded outside his home in Jordan today, raising fresh concerns that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is affecting neighboring countries that have already made peace with Israel. But the conflict continued to taper off here, with Israel's senior security officials reporting a decline in stone-throwing and shooting incidents in the West Bank and Gaza. The Israelis also said the Palestinian police were making a visible effort to prevent shooting for the first time since the violence began in late September.

column2: FOX QUESADA, VICENTE; MEXICO CITY (MEXICO); MEXICO; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
column3: In Mexico, a Man With a Badge Isn't the Good Guy
column9: Ramiro Ayala Zambrano and his wife, Edith, have raised four children in a gritty barrio brimming with violence and corruption, so they know an outlaw when they see one.    In their eyes, the worst criminals here in a neighborhood called Tepito are...
column10: Ramiro Ayala Zambrano and his wife, Edith, have raised four children in a gritty barrio brimming with violence and corruption, so they know an outlaw when they see one. In their eyes, the worst criminals here in a neighborhood called Tepito are not the thousands who sell stolen stereos, handguns, endangered birds or pirated videocassettes from the maze of concession stands that crowd the sidewalks. The couple is most afraid of the few dozen bad guys who prowl in police uniforms.

column2: SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: An Orderly Anniversary for a Great Global Trade Protest
column9: For the people in sea turtle costumes, for the masked anarchists, for the protesters on stilts who took a rubber bullet with pride, the Battle of Seattle one year ago today has become the Alamo in their fight against corporate globalization.     But...
column10: For the people in sea turtle costumes, for the masked anarchists, for the protesters on stilts who took a rubber bullet with pride, the Battle of Seattle one year ago today has become the Alamo in their fight against corporate globalization. But as they gathered today on the anniversary of the ruckus that led to more than 600 arrests, and nearly shut down the World Trade Organization's ministerial meetings in Seattle, protesters could do little more than recall the near-legendary days of tear gas and smashed windows, and shout at Christmas shoppers to holster their credit cards.

column3: World Briefing
column9: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: HUME STEPS DOWN  John Hume, the Nobel Prize-winning architect of the Northern Ireland peace accord, resigned from the new power-sharing assembly that the settlement created, citing the workload involved with being a...
column10: EUROPE NORTHERN IRELAND: HUME STEPS DOWN John Hume, the Nobel Prize-winning architect of the Northern Ireland peace accord, resigned from the new power-sharing assembly that the settlement created, citing the workload involved with being a member of the British and European Parliaments and leader of the Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party. Mr. Hume, 63, who announced his decision this fall, will be replaced by a party member without the need for a by-election. Warren Hoge (NYT) BRITAIN: PARATROOPERS CHARGED Three British paratroopers have been charged in connection with the July 3 shooting deaths in Pristina of two Kosovo Liberation Army fighters who were firing celebratory shots into the air from the roof of a car. The Ministry of Defense did not identify the soldiers, who were members of the NATO peacekeeping force, or specify what the charges were. They remain in service pending court-martial. Warren Hoge (NYT)

column2: EUROPE; NICE (FRANCE); EUROPEAN UNION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Europeans, and Protesters, Meet on the Riviera
column9: As protesters clashed violently with the police in the streets, European Union leaders began a crucial three-day summit meeting today by promising to come up with a new decision-making structure that would allow them to accept new countries as...
column10: As protesters clashed violently with the police in the streets, European Union leaders began a crucial three-day summit meeting today by promising to come up with a new decision-making structure that would allow them to accept new countries as members. When the leaders arrived today at this Riviera city, so much tear gas filled the streets that it seeped into the convention hall's air conditioning system. At one point, the fumes forced the French president, Jacques Chirac, to sneeze and blow his nose as he waited to have his picture taken.

column9: As the new year passed through various time zones last Dec. 31, television cameras captured the glow and dazzle of one millennium celebration after another: jubilant, confetti-covered masses in rolling moments of shared euphoria.    Then there was...
column10: As the new year passed through various time zones last Dec. 31, television cameras captured the glow and dazzle of one millennium celebration after another: jubilant, confetti-covered masses in rolling moments of shared euphoria. Then there was Denver.

column2: CLINTON, BILL; PELTIER, LEONARD; WILLIAMS, RONALD ADOLPHUS; COLER, JACK; PINE RIDGE INDIAN RESERVATION (SD); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; INDIANS, AMERICAN; UNITED STATES POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; AMNESTIES AND PARDONS
column3: F.B.I. Agents Rally Against Possible Clemency
column9: About 500 active and retired F.B.I. agents and employees marched to the White House today in a highly unusual protest, angered that President Clinton might commute the life sentence of an American Indian activist convicted of killing two F.B.I....
column10: About 500 active and retired F.B.I. agents and employees marched to the White House today in a highly unusual protest, angered that President Clinton might commute the life sentence of an American Indian activist convicted of killing two F.B.I. agents 25 years ago. Many agents wore their F.B.I. badges pinned to their coats as they walked two-by-two in a long, silent protest around the Ellipse, the park immediately south of the White House, to the presidential mansion. A banner held by agents at the front of the line said, ''Never Forget.''

column2: JOHN PAUL II; HAIDER, JORG; ITALY; AUSTRIA; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Right-Winger From Austria Meets Pope Amid Clamor
column9: In an encounter bracketed by political clashes and public protest, Pope John Paul II met briefly today at the Vatican with Jorg Haider, the far-right Austrian politician, who is persona non grata to many European leaders.     Mr. Haider, leading a...
column10: In an encounter bracketed by political clashes and public protest, Pope John Paul II met briefly today at the Vatican with Jorg Haider, the far-right Austrian politician, who is persona non grata to many European leaders. Mr. Haider, leading a group of 250 Austrians and presenting a gift of an 80-foot Christmas tree from Carinthia, the state of which he is governor, did not receive a private audience with the pope. The Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, said Mr. Haider and Bishop Egon Kapellari of Carinthia spoke with the pope for a few minutes before the meeting only to exchange greetings.

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); RUSSIA; SERBIA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: 2 Serbs Die in Weekend Clashes In Tense Kosovo Border Region
column9: Violence continued over the weekend in the tense border area between Kosovo and the rest of Serbia. On Saturday, two Serbs died and one was wounded in a melee with peacekeepers in the town of Leposavic.    Today, gunmen fired on a joint...
column10: Violence continued over the weekend in the tense border area between Kosovo and the rest of Serbia. On Saturday, two Serbs died and one was wounded in a melee with peacekeepers in the town of Leposavic. Today, gunmen fired on a joint American-Russian patrol as it tried to seal the boundary between Kosovo and part of southern Serbia where Albanian rebels have been challenging Yugoslav forces, the United States Army said. Kosovo is a province of Serbia, which is the dominant republic remaining in Yugoslavia.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    TURKEY: PRISON SIEGE ENDS -- Soldiers used tear gas to subdue about 400 inmates at a prison in Istanbul, ending five days of raids to reassert government control over 20 prisons across the country. At least 27 people died. The raids were...
column10: EUROPE TURKEY: PRISON SIEGE ENDS -- Soldiers used tear gas to subdue about 400 inmates at a prison in Istanbul, ending five days of raids to reassert government control over 20 prisons across the country. At least 27 people died. The raids were made after hunger strikers refused to end fasts protesting transfers from prisons where up to 100 inmates shared a dormitory-style room to prisons with small cells. Inmates say they fear torture and isolation in the new cells. Douglas Frantz (NYT) SPAIN: RUSSIAN GETS BAIL -- A judge ordered Vladimir Gusinsky, left, to be released from jail and confined to his luxury villa in southern Spain under police guard while the Russian media magnate fought Moscow's efforts to extradite him. Judge Baltasar Garzon ruled Mr. Gusinsky must pay $5.55 million in bail to secure his freedom after being detained 10 days ago on an international arrest warrant sought by Russia, where he faces fraud charges. (Reuters)

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; GORE, AL; FLORIDA; VOTING MACHINES; SUITS AND LITIGATION; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2000; ELECTIONS
column3: THE 43rd PRESIDENT; Excerpts From Florida Supreme Court Ruling on Ballot-Counting Methods
column9: Following are excerpts from the Florida Supreme Court's decision yesterday that said the State Legislature should develop a standard for counting ballots. The court issued a per curiam or unsigned decision in the case of Albert Gore Jr. and Joseph I....
column10: Following are excerpts from the Florida Supreme Court's decision yesterday that said the State Legislature should develop a standard for counting ballots. The court issued a per curiam or unsigned decision in the case of Albert Gore Jr. and Joseph I. Lieberman v. Katherine Harris as Secretary of State. Justices Leander B. Shaw, Harry Lee Anstead, R. Fred Lewis, Barbara J. Pariente and Peggy A. Quince concurred, with Justices Shaw and Pariente filing separate opinions. Justice Major B. Harding and Chief Justice Charles T. Wells concurred in result only, with the chief justice filing a separate one-sentence opinion. FROM THE OPINION This case is before the court on remand from the United States Supreme Court. In our previous opinion, we ordered the Circuit Court of Leon County to tabulate by hand 9,000 contested Dade County ballots. This court further held that relief would require manual recounts in all Florida counties where undervotes existed which had not previously been subject to manual tabulation.

column2: SAMAN, MUHAMMAD; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; NETZARIM (ISRAEL); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
column3: Playing War
column9: A little before noon on the last day of his life, 15-year-old Ahmed Abutayeh invented a toothache. This was the first time he had ever complained of a health problem in school, so his science teacher wrote him a permission slip to visit a nearby...
column10: A little before noon on the last day of his life, 15-year-old Ahmed Abutayeh invented a toothache. This was the first time he had ever complained of a health problem in school, so his science teacher wrote him a permission slip to visit a nearby clinic. Ahmed shouldered his plaid-patterned book bag and walked out of the Rimal Boys' School and onto the chaotic streets of Beach Camp, where 75,000 Palestinian refugees are corralled into a half-square-mile block, at the northern end of the Gaza Strip. It was Nov. 1 of this year. The previous day, Ahmed had sold his pet nightingale for a few shekels, and now, carrying this money, he caught a taxi and asked to be driven to a place called Karni crossing. He was wearing the nicest shirt he owned, a light blue button-down, and a few dabs of his father's cologne. On the outside of his book bag, in blue ink, he had inscribed a four-word epitaph: ''The Martyr Ahmed Abutayeh.'' Karni crossing, as its name implies, is an intersection. It's where the Karni Road crosses the so-called Green Line, the razor-wire border dividing the occupied territory of Gaza from Israel proper. The Gaza Strip is a place small enough to be easily fenced. It pokes from the northern end of the Egypt-Israel border and follows the shoreline of the Mediterranean Sea; its silhouette is roughly that of a pistol, aimed just west of Jerusalem. Karni crossing is at a point about midway along the pistol's barrel.

column2: THABET, THABET; KAHANE, TALIA; CLINTON, BILL; KAHANE, BINYAMIN; KAHANE, MEIR; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS
column3: Son of Slain Rabbi Kahane Dies With Wife in West Bank Ambush
column9: Binyamin Kahane, a radical right-wing settler and son of the late Rabbi Meir Kahane, was killed today along with his wife in an ambush shooting in the West Bank.     Hours after the attack, which came a decade after the Brooklyn-born Meir Kahane was...
column10: Binyamin Kahane, a radical right-wing settler and son of the late Rabbi Meir Kahane, was killed today along with his wife in an ambush shooting in the West Bank. Hours after the attack, which came a decade after the Brooklyn-born Meir Kahane was assassinated in New York City, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a senior Palestinian health official, Dr. Thabet Thabet, near his West Bank home.

column2: GREAT BRITAIN; SOCCER
column3: Manchester United Extends Lead
column9: Arsenal suffered a damaging blow to its Premier League title aspirations yesterday in a 1-0 loss to Charlton Athletic. Jonatan Johansson's first-half header gave Charlton the victory, and enabled Manchester United to widen its lead over Arsenal to 11...
column10: Arsenal suffered a damaging blow to its Premier League title aspirations yesterday in a 1-0 loss to Charlton Athletic. Jonatan Johansson's first-half header gave Charlton the victory, and enabled Manchester United to widen its lead over Arsenal to 11 points after it beat West Ham, 3-1. Nelson Vivas's penalty kick in the 75th minute was saved by Charlton goalkeeper Dean Kiely to conclude a dismal start to the new year for the Gunners. Arsenal also lost two points on Saturday when it wasted a 2-0 lead and settled for a 2-2 tie against Sunderland.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: THE AMERICAS    CHILE: PINOCHET STARTS TESTS  Gen. Augusto Pinochet obeyed a judicial order by entering a military hospital to begin several days of psychological and neurological examinations to test whether he is fit to stand trial on possible...
column10: THE AMERICAS CHILE: PINOCHET STARTS TESTS Gen. Augusto Pinochet obeyed a judicial order by entering a military hospital to begin several days of psychological and neurological examinations to test whether he is fit to stand trial on possible murder and kidnapping charges. The start of the examinations culminated nearly a week of legal maneuvering during which the former dicatator's lawyers tried to block the tests as well as an interrogation scheduled for next week. A finding that General Pinochet is mentally impaired could end any future prosecution, but it could also be open to appeal. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

column2: ARONOFF, MURRAY; FRANCE; MIDDLE EAST; JEWS; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
column3: Murray Aronoff, 75; Defended Jews at Sea
column9: Murray Aronoff, a crew member of a retired steamship, the Exodus 1947, on its aborted voyage to transport 4,500 Jewish refugees from France to Palestine in 1947, died on Dec. 30 at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in...
column10: Murray Aronoff, a crew member of a retired steamship, the Exodus 1947, on its aborted voyage to transport 4,500 Jewish refugees from France to Palestine in 1947, died on Dec. 30 at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in Plainview. He was 75. The cause was complications resulting from Alzheimer's disease, said his son, Aaron.

column2: RENO, JANET; JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
column3: Reno Ponders the Future And Reflects on the Past
column9: For now, at least, the mood seems placidly subdued in the office of the attorney general after nearly eight years of trouble, strife and controversy. At last, the spotlight has shifted away from Janet Reno.    One morning this week, Ms. Reno seemed...
column10: For now, at least, the mood seems placidly subdued in the office of the attorney general after nearly eight years of trouble, strife and controversy. At last, the spotlight has shifted away from Janet Reno. One morning this week, Ms. Reno seemed buoyant and jaunty -- in contrast to the grim visage she often displayed at Congressional hearings -- as she contemplated her future outside the government and her return to her home in Miami.

column2: AMERICA'S MOST WANTED (TV PROGRAM); HALPRIN, RANDY ETHAN; RIVAS, GEORGE; GARCIA, JOSEPH C; NEWBURY, DONALD KEITH; HARPER, LARRY JAMES; MURPHY, PATRICK HENRY JR; RODRIGUEZ, MICHAEL ANTHONY; WOODLAND PARK (COLO); TEXAS; COLORADO; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; TELEVISION; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; PRISON ESCAPES; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
column3: 4 of 7 Texas Fugitives Captured In Colorado as 5th Kills Himself
column9: For nearly six frantic weeks until today, the search for seven heavily armed escapees from a maximum-security prison in Texas had gone nowhere, an endless trail of useless tips and fruitless leads that led investigators from Mexico to Mississippi to...
column10: For nearly six frantic weeks until today, the search for seven heavily armed escapees from a maximum-security prison in Texas had gone nowhere, an endless trail of useless tips and fruitless leads that led investigators from Mexico to Mississippi to New York City. But acting on a tip from local residents, the manhunt today led to a trailer park in this small, rural community about 20 miles west of Colorado Springs, where the fugitives deemed the most dangerous men in America had been quietly hiding since about New Year's Day.

column2: FISCHER, STANLEY; GATES, WILLIAM H; FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM; DAVOS WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND; GATES, BILL AND MELINDA, FOUNDATION; INTERNATIONAL AIDS VACCINE INITIATIVE; ACQUIRED IMMUNE DEFICIENCY SYNDROME; VACCINATION AND IMMUNIZATION; GRANTS (CORPORATE AND FOUNDATION); PHILANTHROPY; UNITED STATES ECONOMY; INTEREST RATES; CREDIT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Forum in Switzerland Focuses on U.S. Economic Slowdown
column9: The slowdown in the American economy will cut the global growth rate but will probably not drag the world into recession, a top International Monetary Fund official told world business and political leaders at an annual economic forum here today.    ...
column10: The slowdown in the American economy will cut the global growth rate but will probably not drag the world into recession, a top International Monetary Fund official told world business and political leaders at an annual economic forum here today. The I.M.F.'s deputy director, Stanley Fischer, said the slowdown was causing the fund to predict that growth in the global economy would be considerably lower, ''possibly in the range of 3.5 percent.'' That was scaled back from its prediction of 4.2 percent in September.

column2: DOHA (QATAR); SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
column3: Ideas & Trends; The Next Center of the World
column9: WHEN the World Trade Organization invited bids to host its next global trade summit, it promised a convention marketer's dream: 6,000 delegates and lobbyists; reels of media attention; the chance to make history.    But just as Geneva-based...
column10: WHEN the World Trade Organization invited bids to host its next global trade summit, it promised a convention marketer's dream: 6,000 delegates and lobbyists; reels of media attention; the chance to make history. But just as Geneva-based bureaucrats were preparing to cull applications, the trade body held its 1999 ministerial meeting in Seattle, which became synonymous with tear gas and gridlock.

column2: LONDONDERRY (NORTHERN IRELAND); NORTHERN IRELAND
column3: Lives; An Unreliable Witness
column9: No one expected it to end with killing. In 1972, I was a junior TV journalist assigned to watch events in Northern Ireland, which that weekend happened to include a protest march in Derry. At most, I figured there would be the customary low-level...
column10: No one expected it to end with killing. In 1972, I was a junior TV journalist assigned to watch events in Northern Ireland, which that weekend happened to include a protest march in Derry. At most, I figured there would be the customary low-level standoff between protesters and the army, some stone-throwing and tear gas. But once the shooting started, that day was destined to be known as Bloody Sunday. My nationalist sources and the police had forecast no real trouble, so I told my bosses at the London network that I would not need a film crew. Like everyone else, I was taken completely by surprise when paratroops burst through barriers, ran toward the crowd and almost instantly began firing. This is the last damn straw! I remember thinking as I crushed my nose into the roadway's asphalt with high-velocity bullets cracking and whining over me. I was 23 and scared witless, but my thoughts came embroidered with bravado. I had covered enough of ''the troubles'' to have been threatened at gunpoint by Protestant paramilitaries and another time been forced to run from I.R.A. sniper fire. Now, I blustered to myself, it is my own national army who's firing at me.

column2: ZANZIBAR (TANZANIA); TANZANIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Voting Dispute Turns Violent in Zanzibar
column9: Protesters seeking new elections fought running battles with the police today as violence spread across Tanzania and left as many as 17 people dead.     Opposition officials and doctors said 16 protesters had been killed on Zanzibar's main islands of...
column10: Protesters seeking new elections fought running battles with the police today as violence spread across Tanzania and left as many as 17 people dead. Opposition officials and doctors said 16 protesters had been killed on Zanzibar's main islands of Unguja and Pemba as demonstrations across the archipelago calling for a rerun of disputed elections turned violent. One member of the security forces was decapitated, a police official said.

column2: CHINA; FALUN GONG; AGRICULTURE; LABOR; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Chinese Officials Order Cities To Bolster Riot Police Forces
column9: The Chinese authorities, facing constant protests by aggrieved workers and farmers and a prospect of unending defiance by die-hard Falun Gong believers,  have ordered cities across the country to augment their anti-riot police.     Reflecting the...
column10: The Chinese authorities, facing constant protests by aggrieved workers and farmers and a prospect of unending defiance by die-hard Falun Gong believers, have ordered cities across the country to augment their anti-riot police. Reflecting the leadership's obsession with ''social stability,'' which has reached a new pitch as China seeks to be awarded the 2008 Olympic Games, the Ministry of Public Security has ordered ''intensive efforts'' to build up anti-riot squads and said they are ''expected to play key roles in handling group violence and terrorism cases.''

column2: WAHID, ABDURRAHMAN; JAKARTA (INDONESIA); BRUNEI; INDONESIA; EMBEZZLEMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Hints of Graft by Indonesian President
column9: As protests against President Abdurrahman Wahid erupted into violence outside Parliament today, an investigative committee inside submitted a report to lawmakers that suggested that Mr. Wahid acted improperly in two multimillion-dollar corruption...
column10: As protests against President Abdurrahman Wahid erupted into violence outside Parliament today, an investigative committee inside submitted a report to lawmakers that suggested that Mr. Wahid acted improperly in two multimillion-dollar corruption scandals. In a closed-door session, the 50-member committee presented the findings of its six-month inquiry into accusations that Mr. Wahid may have been involved in the embezzlement of $3.7 million from a government agency and that he improperly accepted $2 million from the sultan of Brunei.

column2: CHINA; BEIJING (CHINA); TIANANMEN SQUARE (BEIJING); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Tiananmen's Shadow
column9: Throughout the spring of 1989, Tiananmen Square, the political heart of Beijing, was engulfed in protests. By June, many of the people filling the square and surrounding streets were spectators with only the vaguest political motives. It was into...
column10: Throughout the spring of 1989, Tiananmen Square, the political heart of Beijing, was engulfed in protests. By June, many of the people filling the square and surrounding streets were spectators with only the vaguest political motives. It was into these crowds that the People's Liberation Army opened fire in the early hours of June 4, killing hundreds or even thousands of civilians. No one outside the inner councils of the Chinese government knows for certain how many people died or why. The recently published ''Tiananmen Papers,'' transcripts of government documents reportedly smuggled out of the country by a disaffected Chinese official, claim to tell what happened behind the high red walls of China's leadership compound in the weeks before the massacre. Their appearance suggests that, even within the government, the wounds of Tiananmen still fester, and that some insiders are ready to reassess the wisdom of the decisions that led to the shooting that night.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    BRITAIN, FRANCE: ASYLUM ACCORD -- The two countries agreed to impose tighter controls on their cross-Channel rail link to try to stem record numbers of asylum seekers slipping into Britain. President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Tony...
column10: EUROPE BRITAIN, FRANCE: ASYLUM ACCORD -- The two countries agreed to impose tighter controls on their cross-Channel rail link to try to stem record numbers of asylum seekers slipping into Britain. President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Tony Blair, after a day of talks, also called for wider European efforts to tackle the trafficking. France said it would try to ratify by June a pact allowing French and British immigration officers to check passengers boarding the Eurostar train in Paris. (Reuters) NORTHERN IRELAND: FIRM AGAINST SINN FEIN -- David Trimble, first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly and leader of the province's largest Protestant party, said he would continue to bar ministers from Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from attending cross-border meetings with their counterparts in the Irish government because of the I.R.A.'s refusal to begin disarming. A Belfast High Court judge ruled the ban unlawful last month, but Mr. Trimble is appealing the decision. Warren Hoge (NYT)

column3: World Briefing
column9: EUROPE    POLICY ON MAD COW DISEASE -- The director of farm policy for the European Union proposed far-reaching changes to deal with the financial and biological consequences of mad cow disease, which has caused a crisis across Western Europe. Franz...
column10: EUROPE POLICY ON MAD COW DISEASE -- The director of farm policy for the European Union proposed far-reaching changes to deal with the financial and biological consequences of mad cow disease, which has caused a crisis across Western Europe. Franz Fischler, left, outlined incentives that would cut back beef production and encourage organic farming to grow crops for animal feed. Contaminated bone meal is believed to be the cause of the epidemic. The proposals will cost about $1 billion next year alone. Marlise Simons (NYT)

column2: ACUNA (MEXICO); MEXICO; ALCOA INC; FOREIGN INVESTMENTS; LABOR; SURVEYS AND SERIES; ENVIRONMENT; WAGES AND SALARIES; WORKING HOURS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS
column3: Profits Raise Pressures On U.S.-Owned Factories In Mexican Border Zone
column9: Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly-line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here.    After...
column10: Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly-line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here. After Paul H. O'Neill, the Alcoa chief executive who became President Bush's treasury secretary last month, trumpeted the company's growing profits, Mr. Tovar stepped to a microphone. At the time Mr. Tovar, who was earning about $6 a day, described Alcoa managers so stingy that they stationed a janitor at bathroom doors to limit workers to just three pieces of toilet paper. He also recounted an incident in which more than 100 workers had been overcome by fumes from a gas leak and taken to hospitals.

column2: ABU ELBA, KHALIL; BARAK, EHUD; WEST BANK; AZUR (ISRAEL); ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; BUSES; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
column3: Arab Drives Bus Into Crowd, Killing 8 Israelis
column9: After years of shuttling Gazan laborers into Israel without incident, a Palestinian bus driver who passed a strict Israeli security clearance just two weeks ago veered wildly off course today with deadly consequences.    Plowing into a crowd of...
column10: After years of shuttling Gazan laborers into Israel without incident, a Palestinian bus driver who passed a strict Israeli security clearance just two weeks ago veered wildly off course today with deadly consequences. Plowing into a crowd of soldiers and commuters at a bus stop here, the Palestinian driver killed eight Israelis during the morning rush hour. His hit-and-run assault, which was presumed to be an unorthodox terror attack by an unlikely terrorist, caused the highest single-day Israeli death toll since the Palestinian uprising erupted early last fall.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: EUROPE    SERBIA: BUFFER WITH KOSOVO  NATO told Serbian officials that it was prepared as part of an overall peace plan to consider changes to the buffer zone on Kosovo's eastern boundary, which ethnic Albanian separatists are using as a safe haven....
column10: EUROPE SERBIA: BUFFER WITH KOSOVO NATO told Serbian officials that it was prepared as part of an overall peace plan to consider changes to the buffer zone on Kosovo's eastern boundary, which ethnic Albanian separatists are using as a safe haven. But while welcoming a plan by Belgrade to stabilize the region, NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, above, said any ultimatum or use of force by Serbian forces to regain control of the zone would be unacceptable. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

column2: ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DISCRIMINATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Emotions Escalate at Hearing on Killings of Israeli Arabs
column9: An Israeli Arab couple lost control today as a border police officer suspected of fatally shooting their son took the witness stand a few feet from them.     Attending the first public hearing into police killings of 13 people during a wave of...
column10: An Israeli Arab couple lost control today as a border police officer suspected of fatally shooting their son took the witness stand a few feet from them. Attending the first public hearing into police killings of 13 people during a wave of violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October, the grief-stricken parents, Hatem and Rushdiyeh Gara, erupted.

column3: The Peruvian Revolution Is Being Televised
column9: In media-crazy Peru, it's no surprise that the government would be toppled by a wall-to-wall outpouring of raunchy and scandalous videos.
column10: In media-crazy Peru, it's no surprise that the government would be toppled by a wall-to-wall outpouring of raunchy and scandalous videos.
