column3: National Briefs; Festivities Turn Violent In Austin and Seattle
column9: Some participants in weekend Mardi Gras festivities here threw beer bottles and punches and smashed windows, injuring about 30 people. More than 50 people were arrested.    The Austin police arrested 35 people early today and an additional 21 early...
column10: Some participants in weekend Mardi Gras festivities here threw beer bottles and punches and smashed windows, injuring about 30 people. More than 50 people were arrested. The Austin police arrested 35 people early today and an additional 21 early Saturday on charges including indecent exposure and public intoxication. Police used tear gas and shot rubber pellets this morning to disperse the crowd , estimated at about 100,000 people.

column2: TACOMA (WASH); OLYMPIA (WASH); SEATTLE (WASH); WASHINGTON (STATE); EARTHQUAKES
column3: Big Quake Jolts Northwest; Damage Estimated in Billions
column9: The Pacific Northwest was rocked today by the most powerful earthquake to hit the area in 52 years, a 40-second tremor that shattered windows, crumbled bricks and buckled pavement across Seattle and cracked the Capitol dome in Olympia, Wash., a dozen...
column10: The Pacific Northwest was rocked today by the most powerful earthquake to hit the area in 52 years, a 40-second tremor that shattered windows, crumbled bricks and buckled pavement across Seattle and cracked the Capitol dome in Olympia, Wash., a dozen miles from the quake's epicenter. At least 215 people were injured, at least 8 seriously, and officials said property damage would easily run into the billions of dollars. And there was a report of a fatal heart attack related to the quake, which struck at 10:54 a.m. Pacific time and sent a wave of fright through schools and offices.

column2: ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: Pentagon Unveils Plans for a New Crowd-Dispersal Weapon
column9: The Pentagon today unveiled what some military officials hope will become the rubber bullet of the 21st century: a weapon that uses electromagnetic waves to disperse crowds without killing, maiming or, military officials say, even injuring anyone...
column10: The Pentagon today unveiled what some military officials hope will become the rubber bullet of the 21st century: a weapon that uses electromagnetic waves to disperse crowds without killing, maiming or, military officials say, even injuring anyone slightly. Known in Pentagon patois as an ''active denial system,'' the weapon is the fruit of 10 years of research and is intended to help American soldiers in the quasi-military roles they have increasingly been asked to play as peacekeepers or police in places like Kosovo and Ethiopia.

column2: SCHELL, PAUL; SEATTLE (WASH); WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; MAYORS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; EARTHQUAKES; ELECTION ISSUES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: An Earthquake Puts a Political Career on Firmer Ground
column9: AT 10:56 a.m. on Wednesday, Paul SchellPaul Schell was precisely four minutes away from starting a difficult news  conference, this one in response to Mardi Gras mayhem on the Seattle streets that had left a  young man dead, dozens of people injured...
column10: AT 10:56 a.m. on Wednesday, Paul SchellPaul Schell was precisely four minutes away from starting a difficult news conference, this one in response to Mardi Gras mayhem on the Seattle streets that had left a young man dead, dozens of people injured and the sort of disturbing image that he never thought would be an emblem of his mayoralty: the police firing tear gas and rubber pellets to disperse a crowd. The same police scenes played out in the raucous December 1999 protests against a World Trade Organization meeting here. And now Mr. Schell was moments from once again having to explain what happened.

column3: 'Dogeaters': Memories of Manila Under the Marcoses
column9: HINAYON mo ang tingog mo!" my Lola Adela exclaimed, cautioning us to lower our voices. Growing up a martial-law baby in the slums of 1970's Old Manila, I had become somewhat inured to my grandma's frequent exhortations to watch what we said in...
column10: HINAYON mo ang tingog mo!" my Lola Adela exclaimed, cautioning us to lower our voices. Growing up a martial-law baby in the slums of 1970's Old Manila, I had become somewhat inured to my grandma's frequent exhortations to watch what we said in public. She warned us of unseen goons who roamed the streets and countryside with concealed guns and a mandate to shoot on the spot any subversive caught criticizing Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos.

column2: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; POLICE; TORTURE
column3: The Way We Live Now: 3-11-01: The Old Economy; Pain and Gain
column9: A new study from Amnesty International, titled ''Stopping the Torture Trade,'' reports that over the last 10 years the United States has been the world's biggest exporter of high-tech restraint devices. The market is now dominated by electronic...
column10: A new study from Amnesty International, titled ''Stopping the Torture Trade,'' reports that over the last 10 years the United States has been the world's biggest exporter of high-tech restraint devices. The market is now dominated by electronic devices like stun guns, stun batons, stun shields and stun belts -- nonlethal devices that are used by law-enforcement officials all across this country. Amnesty International has provided the following sample of recent products and manufacturers or exporters. The human rights group is careful to note that none of these companies are involved in the production or export of torture equipment -- merely that this type of equipment has been used for torture, and that its trade should be more closely regulated. Arianne International, Palm Beach, Fla. Produces Myotron ''Checkmate'' pulse weapon.

column2: BEN-ELIEZER, BINYAMIN; SHARON, ARIEL; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
column3: Sharon Blockades a Palestinian Center in the West Bank
column9: The Israeli Army today sealed off this city, the unofficial seat of government of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank, blocking roads with trenches, mounds of earth  and checkpoints backed by tanks and armored troop carriers.    It was the...
column10: The Israeli Army today sealed off this city, the unofficial seat of government of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank, blocking roads with trenches, mounds of earth and checkpoints backed by tanks and armored troop carriers. It was the first action against the Palestinians by the newly inaugurated government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and the most severe blockade imposed by the Israelis on this community of 60,000, a major commercial and cultural center.

column2: MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); TETOVO (MACEDONIA); UNIVERSITY OF TETOVO; MINORITIES (US); COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; ALBANIAN LANGUAGE
column3: Another Balkan Battle: Higher Learning
column9: A new Albanian-language university, sponsored and financed by the international community, was supposed to be a significant response to the grievances that have underpinned the Albanian rebellion now building in the hills above Tetovo and threatening...
column10: A new Albanian-language university, sponsored and financed by the international community, was supposed to be a significant response to the grievances that have underpinned the Albanian rebellion now building in the hills above Tetovo and threatening the cohesion of the Macedonian state. But the new private university, due to open in October on land donated by the government, has instead created a political storm that shows the fissures in this fragile, multi-ethnic state and the complications that surround the good intentions of foreigners.

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; HAMAS; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES
column3: Sharon Orders His First Raid After Bombing
column9: Israeli helicopter gunships bombarded bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces tonight after a Palestinian suicide bombing this morning killed two Israeli teenagers in central Israel.    It was Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's...
column10: Israeli helicopter gunships bombarded bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces tonight after a Palestinian suicide bombing this morning killed two Israeli teenagers in central Israel. It was Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's first military response since he took office three weeks ago to a spate of Palestinian attacks that escalated this week. Pressure inside Israel had been mounting on Mr. Sharon, who was elected largely because of his iron-fisted image, to take decisive action.

column3: National Briefing
column9: SOUTHWEST    TEXAS: EXPANDED USE OF DNA TESTS -- A bill making it easier for inmates to use DNA tests to try to prove their innocence received final approval from the Legislature, and Gov. Rick Perry is expected to sign it into law. The legislation...
column10: SOUTHWEST TEXAS: EXPANDED USE OF DNA TESTS -- A bill making it easier for inmates to use DNA tests to try to prove their innocence received final approval from the Legislature, and Gov. Rick Perry is expected to sign it into law. The legislation requires prosecutors to preserve biological evidence and provides state-paid DNA testing if it was not available at trial and could clear an inmate. One amendment to the bill requires courts to provide lawyers for indigent inmates; another allows inmates who pleaded guilty to request testing. AP

column2: THOMAS, TIMOTHY; LUKEN, CHARLIE; REECE, ALICIA; ROACH, STEVEN; CINCINNATI (OHIO); AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
column3: Appeals for Peace in Ohio After Two Days of Protests
column9: This city's clergy and political leaders pleaded for peace on the streets today after two days of sporadic protests and vandalism that followed the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white policeman.    ''This situation has been...
column10: This city's clergy and political leaders pleaded for peace on the streets today after two days of sporadic protests and vandalism that followed the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white policeman. ''This situation has been festering for over five years,'' City Councilwoman Alicia Reece said. She surveyed the 66 arrests and damage to dozens of city stores as evidence of deepening tensions between the police and black residents who have long complained of racial profiling by officers.

column2: ECEVIT, BULENT; ANKARA (TURKEY); TURKEY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; TEAR GAS
column3: Economic Protest in Turkey Turns Into a Melee
column9: An estimated 50,000 people, mostly tradesmen and owners of small businesses , tried to march to Parliament in Ankara today to press demands that Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit resign over his handling of the two-month-old economic crisis, but the...
column10: An estimated 50,000 people, mostly tradesmen and owners of small businesses , tried to march to Parliament in Ankara today to press demands that Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit resign over his handling of the two-month-old economic crisis, but the police used tear gas, water cannon and riot sticks to beat them back. Scores of demonstrators and police officers were injured in the melee. On the eighth day of protests, and the most violent, the demonstrators chanted ''Ecevit, quit!'' and ''Government, resign!'' to protest soaring prices and the collapse of the lira.

column2: THOMAS, TIMOTHY; LUKEN, CHARLIE; ROACH, STEVEN; CINCINNATI (OHIO); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; DISCRIMINATION; CURFEWS; POLICE
column3: Cincinnati Mayor Imposes Curfew to Quell Violence
column9: This racially tense city was placed under a strict nightlong curfew today as the authorities struggled to stop sporadic vandalism and the confrontations with police officers that followed the fatal shooting of a black teenager by the police.   ...
column10: This racially tense city was placed under a strict nightlong curfew today as the authorities struggled to stop sporadic vandalism and the confrontations with police officers that followed the fatal shooting of a black teenager by the police. ''Despite the best efforts of the good citizens of our city, the violence on our streets is uncontrolled and it runs rampant,'' Mayor Charlie Luken declared as he announced a state of emergency and ordered that the streets be kept clear of most people from 8 p.m. until 6 a.m. until further notice.

column2: BLACKWELL, J KENNETH; THOMAS, TIMOTHY; CINCINNATI (OHIO); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; BLACKS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
column3: Blacks in Cincinnati Hear Echoes Amid the Violence
column9: Charles Wimms looked back today from some fresh scars on storefronts in the black Avondale neighborhood to the old, still chilling memories of the last time local youths erupted in violent protest, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was...
column10: Charles Wimms looked back today from some fresh scars on storefronts in the black Avondale neighborhood to the old, still chilling memories of the last time local youths erupted in violent protest, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated more than three decades ago. ''This wouldn't have happened if they had listened to us in those years back then,'' said Mr. Wimms, a 39-year-old construction worker, recalling that police treatment of black Cincinnatians -- the issue that drove the wave of protest and vandalism by clusters of angry blacks this week -- was also a principal issue in the 1968 violence.

column3: April 8-14; Riots in Cincinnati
column9: The scene in Cincinnati seemed a time-warp from the 1960's as protests over alleged racial profiling by police degenerated into hit-and-run vandalism, centered in black neighborhoods. The city declared a state of emergency and a curfew after four...
column10: The scene in Cincinnati seemed a time-warp from the 1960's as protests over alleged racial profiling by police degenerated into hit-and-run vandalism, centered in black neighborhoods. The city declared a state of emergency and a curfew after four nights in which the police used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop clusters of young black men who looted stores and intimidated whites. ''Knock it off,'' demanded Mayor Charlie Luken, even as he conceded there were ''very legitimate'' concerns over police killings of 15 black male suspects in six years. Francis X. Clines

column3: Grief and Fury at Funeral for Slain Youth
column9: Inside a packed church today, the black community's grief reached a crescendo with the singing of a hymn about suffering and resolve addressed to Jesus: ''I've been up and I've been down, but I'm not going to turn around because I'm fighting.''   ...
column10: Inside a packed church today, the black community's grief reached a crescendo with the singing of a hymn about suffering and resolve addressed to Jesus: ''I've been up and I've been down, but I'm not going to turn around because I'm fighting.'' Minutes later, the shiny metallic coffin containing the body of 19-year-old Timothy Thomas was carried out and down the steps, where a phalanx of Black Panthers raised clenched fists in bidding an angry farewell.

column3: WORLD BRIEFING
column9: AMERICAS    MEXICO: PRAISE FROM HELMS  Senator Jesse Helms, leading a delegation from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, concluded a three-day goodwill visit after meeting with Mexican officials. In a speech before his committee's Mexican...
column10: AMERICAS MEXICO: PRAISE FROM HELMS Senator Jesse Helms, leading a delegation from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, concluded a three-day goodwill visit after meeting with Mexican officials. In a speech before his committee's Mexican counterparts, the North Carolina Republican praised the new government for economic and democratic reforms. Graham Gori (NYT)

column3: BUSH WILL PRESS FREE-TRADE ISSUE AT QUEBEC TALKS
column9: President Bush arrived at his first summit meeting today declaring that he would make the expansion of economic and political ties with Latin America his first foreign policy priority.     But before Mr. Bush and other leaders could get down to work,...
column10: President Bush arrived at his first summit meeting today declaring that he would make the expansion of economic and political ties with Latin America his first foreign policy priority. But before Mr. Bush and other leaders could get down to work, tonight's opening ceremony of the Summit of the Americas was delayed for an hour, to about 7:30, as thousands of mostly young protesters clogged the narrow streets of this walled city seeking to block talks over a Free Trade Area of the Americas.

column3: Demonstrators At the Summit Are Greeted With Tear Gas
column9: The Summit of the Americas got under way in this fortified city today with 34 leaders passing through color guards and red-coated Mounties inside the delegates' hall, while outside hooded protesters tangled with riot policemen under billowing clouds...
column10: The Summit of the Americas got under way in this fortified city today with 34 leaders passing through color guards and red-coated Mounties inside the delegates' hall, while outside hooded protesters tangled with riot policemen under billowing clouds of tear gas. A crowd that the police estimated at 2,000 tore down about 150 feet of a chain-link fence atop concrete barricades that had been erected near the convention center where President Bush and the other leaders of the Western Hemisphere gathered this afternoon.

column2: QUEBEC CITY (QUEBEC); SUMMIT OF THE AMERICAS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: In the Streets, Fervor, Fears and a Gamut of Issues
column9: For a second day, the old streets of this historic city were mobbed today with people protesting the proceedings of the third Summit of the Americas. The biggest crowd -- a good mile long and a boulevard wide -- marched for hours without incident or...
column10: For a second day, the old streets of this historic city were mobbed today with people protesting the proceedings of the third Summit of the Americas. The biggest crowd -- a good mile long and a boulevard wide -- marched for hours without incident or trouble yet with evident concern for the panoply of issues that angered, frightened or frustrated them enough to come here. But on the other side of Quebec, police officers used a water cannon, rubber bullets and a continual shower of tear gas to repeatedly push back the front ranks of more than 6,000 protesters at a few key points not far from the meeting site. One of the most prolonged confrontations took place at a weak point in the concrete and chain-link fence around the official summit meeting area that had been breached briefly during protests on Friday afternoon.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; FOX QUESADA, VICENTE; WESTERN HEMISPHERE; QUEBEC CITY (QUEBEC); SUMMIT OF THE AMERICAS; LABOR; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; ENVIRONMENT
column3: BUSH LINKS TRADE WITH DEMOCRACY AT QUEBEC TALKS
column9: President Bush told the leaders of the Western Hemisphere today that after almost a decade of delays in creating a single market from the Arctic to the tip of South America, the time had come to ''build an age of prosperity in a hemisphere of...
column10: President Bush told the leaders of the Western Hemisphere today that after almost a decade of delays in creating a single market from the Arctic to the tip of South America, the time had come to ''build an age of prosperity in a hemisphere of liberty.'' At the same time, Mr. Bush cautiously reached out to the thousands here who were protesting his drive to expand the Nafta accord throughout Central and South America. He sent members of his administration to meet a variety of labor, environmental and human rights groups that Republicans have previously dismissed as protectionists and the enemy of trade accords.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; LATIN AMERICA; CARIBBEAN AREA; QUEBEC PROVINCE (CANADA); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
column3: Biggest Obstacle to Selling Trade Pact: Sovereignty
column9: Midway through President Bush's first summit meeting, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he was unfazed by the raucous demonstrations that greeted the 34 leaders trying to turn the Western Hemisphere into a single market.    ''An old infantryman...
column10: Midway through President Bush's first summit meeting, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he was unfazed by the raucous demonstrations that greeted the 34 leaders trying to turn the Western Hemisphere into a single market. ''An old infantryman always remembers what tear gas and pot smell like when you walk in the barracks,'' he joked with reporters, recalling his days as a young Army officer.

column2: LUKEN, CHARLIE; CINCINNATI (OHIO); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION; BLACKS; SUITS AND LITIGATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; POLICE
column3: In Aftershock of Unrest, Cincinnati Seeks Answers
column9: Amid the aftershocks of three days of racial protest and vandalism, this proud but careworn city is seeking to right itself by moving quickly toward mediation of a federal lawsuit that accuses the police of abusing black citizens.    ''In terms of...
column10: Amid the aftershocks of three days of racial protest and vandalism, this proud but careworn city is seeking to right itself by moving quickly toward mediation of a federal lawsuit that accuses the police of abusing black citizens. ''In terms of achieving improvement and restoring some trust, I view the racial profiling lawsuit as an important vehicle to do that,'' said Mayor Charlie Luken, who presides over a racially divided city facing an uphill recovery from street disruptions that drew national attention to the anger of blacks here.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; LATIN AMERICA; CANADA; CARIBBEAN AREA; QUEBEC PROVINCE (CANADA); INTER-AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK; INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Talks Tie Trade In the Americas To Democracy
column9: Pledging equal support to democracy and free trade, 34 leaders of the Western Hemisphere closed a summit meeting today by reinforcing their commitment to a vast Free Trade Area of the Americas, vowing to ensure that its benefits are shared by the...
column10: Pledging equal support to democracy and free trade, 34 leaders of the Western Hemisphere closed a summit meeting today by reinforcing their commitment to a vast Free Trade Area of the Americas, vowing to ensure that its benefits are shared by the hemisphere's 800 million people. ''There's no question in my mind that we have challenges ahead of us, but there's also no question in my mind that we can meet those challenges,'' President Bush said after he and the other leaders signed a closing declaration.

column2: JERSEY CITY (NJ); FIRES AND FIREMEN; TEAR GAS
column3: 50 Hurt After Tear-Gas Can Is Tossed Into Building Lobby
column9: About 50 people, most of them firefighters, were injured late Monday when someone threw a canister of military-strength tear gas into the lobby of an apartment building here, spreading a thick white smoke that burned the skin and eyes.    ''It was...
column10: About 50 people, most of them firefighters, were injured late Monday when someone threw a canister of military-strength tear gas into the lobby of an apartment building here, spreading a thick white smoke that burned the skin and eyes. ''It was the most horrifying, terrifying experience of my life,'' said Minda Manalac, 39, who fled her second-floor apartment to the lobby. ''I didn't think I could make it because I couldn't see at all, and I was gagging and vomiting, and I kept tripping and falling. I thought I was going to die.''

column2: CONGO REPUBLIC; SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: At Least 7 Killed In Lubumbashi Riot
column9: Panicked crowds crushed at least seven people to death yesterday in a riot at a game between two of Congo's top teams in Lubumbashi.     Another 51 people were injured, Congo's information minister, Kikaya Bin Karubi, said.
column10: Panicked crowds crushed at least seven people to death yesterday in a riot at a game between two of Congo's top teams in Lubumbashi. Another 51 people were injured, Congo's information minister, Kikaya Bin Karubi, said.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Germany Proposes Union In a European Federation  Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's governing party proposed a far-reaching plan to turn the European Union into a more centralized federal system. The plan, modeled after the...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Germany Proposes Union In a European Federation Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's governing party proposed a far-reaching plan to turn the European Union into a more centralized federal system. The plan, modeled after the structure of Germany, would give much more power to the European Parliament, but it is expected to cause national anxiety in Britain and France. A1

column2: ESTRADA, JOSEPH; ARROYO, GLORIA MACAPAGAL; PHILIPPINES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ETHICS; BRIBERY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 4 in Manila Die in Protest for Ousted President
column9: Security forces fired warning shots, tear gas and water cannons early today to fend off supporters of the ousted former president, Joseph Estrada, as they tried to storm the presidential palace, demanding that his successor quit. At least four people...
column10: Security forces fired warning shots, tear gas and water cannons early today to fend off supporters of the ousted former president, Joseph Estrada, as they tried to storm the presidential palace, demanding that his successor quit. At least four people were reported dead. It was the second time in as many nights that President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo survived an attempt to force her from office. She said Mr. Estrada and his allies had incited the protest in an effort to seize power.

column2: ALGERIA; KABYLIA (ALGERIA); BERBERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Ethnic Anger Erupts Again in Algeria
column9: Clashes between protesters and security forces resumed today in the Berber region around Kabylia. Anger over reports that 40 people had died in ethnic-based rioting spread to the capital, Algiers.    This city of 600,000 remained paralyzed as...
column10: Clashes between protesters and security forces resumed today in the Berber region around Kabylia. Anger over reports that 40 people had died in ethnic-based rioting spread to the capital, Algiers. This city of 600,000 remained paralyzed as stone-throwing rioters fought battles with police officers who fired tear-gas canisters. Gunshots wounded two people, medical sources said. Some calm returned in the afternoon to streets strewn with debris, burned tires and felled trees.

column2: ESTRADA, JOSEPH; ARROYO, GLORIA MACAPAGAL; MANILA (PHILIPPINES); PHILIPPINES; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 'State of Rebellion' Declared After Siege at Manila Palace
column9: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a ''state of rebellion'' in the Philippine capital today and ordered the arrests of opposition leaders whom she accused of conspiring to topple her fledgling government.    Her move came hours after a mob of...
column10: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a ''state of rebellion'' in the Philippine capital today and ordered the arrests of opposition leaders whom she accused of conspiring to topple her fledgling government. Her move came hours after a mob of protesters loyal to her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, stormed the gates of the presidential palace, resulting in three deaths and more than a hundred injuries.

column2: FREEH, LOUIS J; CLINTON, BILL; BUSH, GEORGE W; FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS
column3: DIRECTOR OF F.B.I. SAYS HE'LL RESIGN AFTER EIGHT YEARS
column9: Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. said today that he would resign in June after an eight-year tenure in which he energetically expanded the bureau's reach around the world but warred almost continuously with Bill Clinton, the president who...
column10: Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I. said today that he would resign in June after an eight-year tenure in which he energetically expanded the bureau's reach around the world but warred almost continuously with Bill Clinton, the president who appointed him. Mr. Freeh, who had long told aides that he planned to step down after the November elections, agreed instead to President Bush's request to stay on through the transition. But while visiting the White House on Monday, Mr. Freeh informed the president of his decision to resign, two years short of completing his 10-year term.

column2: ACCRA (GHANA); AFRICA; SOCCER; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Death Toll Thought to Top 100 In a Soccer Stampede in Ghana
column9: More than 100 people were feared dead in a soccer stadium stampede here in the capital tonight, state television and private radio said. It was the third soccer disaster in Africa in a month.     A state television official said the unconfirmed death...
column10: More than 100 people were feared dead in a soccer stadium stampede here in the capital tonight, state television and private radio said. It was the third soccer disaster in Africa in a month. A state television official said the unconfirmed death toll was 120. A private radio broadcaster said he had counted more than 100 bodies in a hospital and a senior government official said he had seen 50 to 60.

column2: ACCRA (GHANA); CONGO (FORMERLY ZAIRE); IVORY COAST; SOUTH AFRICA; GHANA; SOCCER; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: Soccer in Africa Once More Turns Deadly
column9: The official toll issued by Ghana to day  at least 123 deaths and 93 injuries -- turned a stampede at a soccer match on Wednesday into the worst sporting disaster in Africa's history and pushed to nearly 180 the number of spectators killed across the...
column10: The official toll issued by Ghana to day at least 123 deaths and 93 injuries -- turned a stampede at a soccer match on Wednesday into the worst sporting disaster in Africa's history and pushed to nearly 180 the number of spectators killed across the continent in the last month. The deaths in a stadium in Accra, the capital of the West African nation, followed similar incidents in Ivory Coast, in Congo and in South Africa. In all cases, many have accused the police of having failed to control the unruly crowds and, in at least two incidents, of making the stampedes worse by firing excessive amounts of tear gas.

column3: May 6-12; Soccer Stampede in Ghana
column9: Africa's fourth soccer tragedy in a month became its deadliest, as 123 fans were killed in a soccer stampede in Accra, Ghana, during a match between two of the country's top teams. It raised to about 180 the total number of spectators killed across...
column10: Africa's fourth soccer tragedy in a month became its deadliest, as 123 fans were killed in a soccer stampede in Accra, Ghana, during a match between two of the country's top teams. It raised to about 180 the total number of spectators killed across the continent, since 43 fans died trying to get into a packed stadium in South Africa last month. The incident also highlighted the poor security in most of Africa's stadiums. Few have security personnel managing crowds and rely instead on police officers who tend to overreact in riots by indiscriminately firing tear gas. Norimitsu Onishi

column2: MCVEIGH, TIMOTHY; OKLAHOMA CITY (OKLA); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
column3: The Nation: A Conspiracy So Vast; How Crimes Become Obsessions
column9: THE disclosure that the Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld documents from Timothy McVeigh's lawyers seems certain to ignite a controversy that will burn for years, perhaps decades.    ''If any questions or doubts remain about this case, it...
column10: THE disclosure that the Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld documents from Timothy McVeigh's lawyers seems certain to ignite a controversy that will burn for years, perhaps decades. ''If any questions or doubts remain about this case, it would cast a permanent cloud over justice,'' said Attorney General John D. Ashcroft in delaying Mr. McVeigh's execution until at least June 11.

column2: PYDYSZEWSKI, KURT; UNIVERSITY OF NORTHERN COLORADO; ALCOHOL ABUSE; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
column3: A Suicide Draws Attention to Campus Melees
column9: The little house on Ninth Avenue stands as a shrine to what happened here on the last Saturday of April. The front lawn has a small cross, adorned with flowers and a poem, in memory of Kurt Pydyszewski, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of...
column10: The little house on Ninth Avenue stands as a shrine to what happened here on the last Saturday of April. The front lawn has a small cross, adorned with flowers and a poem, in memory of Kurt Pydyszewski, a 20-year-old sophomore at the University of Northern Colorado who lived inside. Mr. Pydyszewski killed himself with a gunshot to the head on May 4, the result, friends said, of his participation in a showdown with the police that grew out of a block party where many of the 1,000 students became drunk. The Greeley police arrested Mr. Pydyszewski and more than two dozen other students, most of whom were also facing disciplinary action by the school.

column2: FRANCE; TELEVISION
column3: Reality TV in France: A Smash Hit With Dialectics
column9: So the truth is out. With the arrival of the reality show ''Big Brother'' here this month, the French are proving to be no more highbrow than Spaniards, Italians, Britons, Americans and others before them. Overnight the French have become hooked,...
column10: So the truth is out. With the arrival of the reality show ''Big Brother'' here this month, the French are proving to be no more highbrow than Spaniards, Italians, Britons, Americans and others before them. Overnight the French have become hooked, tuning in by the millions every evening to watch five men and five woman engaged in an elimination contest in an enclosed space under the eyes of 26 cameras. But wait. Perhaps the French are different after all. ''Loft Story'' (the show's title is in English) may be as hypnotically banal as earlier versions of ''Big Brother'' elsewhere, but at least here there is the additional entertainment of an immense furor stirred by the show off screen. The question is even being posed: Should the land of Molière, Montaigne and Voltaire be allowed to watch ''trash TV,'' as reality shows have been tagged here?

column2: WAHID, ABDURRAHMAN; INDONESIA; IMPEACHMENT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Parliament In Indonesia Votes to Start Impeachment
column9: Parliament voted today to begin impeachment proceedings against President Abdurrahman Wahid, raising the prospect of another turbulent change of power in this restive archipelago.    Mr. Wahid, the 60-year-old Muslim leader, now seems likely to...
column10: Parliament voted today to begin impeachment proceedings against President Abdurrahman Wahid, raising the prospect of another turbulent change of power in this restive archipelago. Mr. Wahid, the 60-year-old Muslim leader, now seems likely to become the latest casualty of a wave of upheaval that has swept across Asia from Indonesia and Thailand to the Philippines and Taiwan.

column2: HUSSEINI, FAISAL; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; PALESTINIANS; DOME OF THE ROCK (SHRINE); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: A Funeral in Jerusalem Arouses Palestinian Nationalism
column9: Tens of thousands of Palestinians waving Palestinian flags marched through East Jerusalem today as the Israeli police stood back and watched the most fervent, open display of Palestinian nationalism in the heart of this city in more than three...
column10: Tens of thousands of Palestinians waving Palestinian flags marched through East Jerusalem today as the Israeli police stood back and watched the most fervent, open display of Palestinian nationalism in the heart of this city in more than three decades. The Palestinians were accompanying the coffin of Faisal Husseini, the senior Palestinian official in Jerusalem, to the Aksa mosque in the Old City. As the Israeli police kept to the edges, Palestinian officials directed the crowds in what Israelis called a singular moment of security cooperation in these tense times.

column2: TEL AVIV (ISRAEL); ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
column3: Victims' Accounts of a Night of Horror
column9: Ana Sinichkin lay sobbing in a hospital bed in a suburb of this city today, shrapnel in her leg and her hand cradled by a friend who tried to comfort her.    A 16-year-old who moved to Israel a year and a half ago from Russia with her widowed mother...
column10: Ana Sinichkin lay sobbing in a hospital bed in a suburb of this city today, shrapnel in her leg and her hand cradled by a friend who tried to comfort her. A 16-year-old who moved to Israel a year and a half ago from Russia with her widowed mother and sister, Ms. Sinichkin was just starting to come to grips with the devastation of Friday night's suicide bombing that killed 18 young people and wounded scores outside a beach-front disco in Tel Aviv.

column2: GYANENDRA; AISWARYA; BIRENDRA; DIPENDRA; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; ROYAL FAMILY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CURFEWS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
column3: Riots Break Out as Nepal Gets 3rd King in 4 Days
column9: Rioting erupted here in Nepal's capital today, just hours after the enthronement of a new king, this Himalayan nation's third monarch in the last four wrenching days.    After the death of King Dipendra before dawn today, his uncle, Gyanendra Bir...
column10: Rioting erupted here in Nepal's capital today, just hours after the enthronement of a new king, this Himalayan nation's third monarch in the last four wrenching days. After the death of King Dipendra before dawn today, his uncle, Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah, was proclaimed king.

column2: QUEVEDO, HUGO; ECUADOR; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: More Turmoil In Congress
column9: After a failed attempt to declare a monthlong recess, the president of the country's one-chamber congress, Hugo Quevedo, has resigned rather than face a vote intended to replace him on charges of corruption and administrative incompetence. The action...
column10: After a failed attempt to declare a monthlong recess, the president of the country's one-chamber congress, Hugo Quevedo, has resigned rather than face a vote intended to replace him on charges of corruption and administrative incompetence. The action comes with Congress's approval rating at an all-time low and follows recent incidents in which fistfights broke out during legislative sessions and tear gas was released during a debate on a disputed tax measure. Larry Rohter (NYT)

column2: JOHNSTON, BILL; WACO (TEX); BRANCH DAVIDIANS; SENTENCES (CRIMINAL)
column3: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Probation In A Waco Case
column9: Bill Johnston, a former federal prosecutor, was sentenced by a federal court in St. Louis to two years of probation for withholding evidence in connection with the 1993 standoff and fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. Mr. Johnston...
column10: Bill Johnston, a former federal prosecutor, was sentenced by a federal court in St. Louis to two years of probation for withholding evidence in connection with the 1993 standoff and fire at the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex. Mr. Johnston admitted in February that he had withheld from investigators one page of notes involving F.B.I. agents' use of pyrotechnic tear gas canisters during the 51-day siege. In return for his plea, prosecutors dropped charges of obstructing justice and lying to investigators and a federal grand jury. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

column2: TRAJKOVSKI, BORIS; GEORGIEVSKI, LJUBCO; MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; AMNESTIES AND PARDONS
column3: Macedonia Expands Attacks Against Rebels
column9: The Macedonian government intensified its attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels today, despite a rebel offer of a cease-fire, pounding rebel-held villages north of the capital with heavy artillery and fire from helicopter gunships.     The rebels...
column10: The Macedonian government intensified its attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels today, despite a rebel offer of a cease-fire, pounding rebel-held villages north of the capital with heavy artillery and fire from helicopter gunships. The rebels seemed undeterred, holding their positions under the assault and even appearing in uniform in a suburb Aracinovo, less than four miles from the capital, Skopje.

column2: DOYLE, CLIVE; MARTIN, SHEILA; MCVEIGH, TIMOTHY JAMES; WACO (TEX); OKLAHOMA CITY (OKLA); BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; BRANCH DAVIDIANS (RELIGIOUS SECT); CAPITAL PUNISHMENT; RELIGIOUS CULTS; TERRORISM
column3: Branch Davidians Shed No Tears for McVeigh
column9: Their ranks are small these days, outnumbered by the 80 crape myrtles planted at the Mount Carmel compound to commemorate each of the Branch Davidians who died here eight years ago.     Their arguments are fierce, for no fewer than three factions of...
column10: Their ranks are small these days, outnumbered by the 80 crape myrtles planted at the Mount Carmel compound to commemorate each of the Branch Davidians who died here eight years ago. Their arguments are fierce, for no fewer than three factions of Branch Davidians have laid legal claim to the 77-acre property outside the city, producing yet another bizarre standoff, with separate churches for two factions and a histrionic display by the third, which dismisses the entire 51-day siege by federal agents at the compound as a diversion.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    China Is Said to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions  China has greatly slowed emissions of carbon dioxide in the last decade, Chinese and Western energy experts say, pushing back the day that China will presumably pass the...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 China Is Said to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions China has greatly slowed emissions of carbon dioxide in the last decade, Chinese and Western energy experts say, pushing back the day that China will presumably pass the United States as the biggest source of the air pollution that scientists believe is warming the planet. The specter of runaway Chinese emissions has been cited by President Bush as a major reason for why the Kyoto climate accord is ''fatally flawed.'' A1 At a European Union meeting, President Bush and European leaders expressed differences and conflicting intentions on global warming. A6

column2: ALGIERS (ALGERIA); ALGERIA; BERBERS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 2 Die in Big Berber Rally in Algiers
column9: The police fired water cannon and tear gas at rioters today as hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on Algeria's presidential palace demanding greater democracy. Two  people died and more than 400 were injured in the turmoil.    Ethnic Berbers...
column10: The police fired water cannon and tear gas at rioters today as hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on Algeria's presidential palace demanding greater democracy. Two people died and more than 400 were injured in the turmoil. Ethnic Berbers organized the mass protest against discrimination and they were joined by opposition parties demanding greater freedom, presenting Algeria's military-backed government with a growing challenge even as it battles the separate threat of an Islamic insurgency.

column2: ISRAEL; ARABS
column3: Police Killings of Israeli Arabs Being Questioned by Inquiry
column9: A formal inquiry this month into the police killing of 13 people in violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October has raised questions about several of the shootings, particularly whether the police needed to fire live ammunition. It has also served...
column10: A formal inquiry this month into the police killing of 13 people in violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October has raised questions about several of the shootings, particularly whether the police needed to fire live ammunition. It has also served as a platform to air what Israeli Arabs say is discrimination that has gone on for decades. The three-member commission, headed by a Supreme Court judge, Theodor Or, drew attention last week during its inquiry into the death of Asel Asleh, a 17-year-old Israeli Arab peace advocate killed by police gunfire during a stone-throwing protest, part of a wave of Israeli Arab protests last fall in support of the Palestinian uprising.

column2: ALGERIA; BERBERS; MINORITIES (US); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Berber Unrest Threatens Algeria's Government
column9: Two months of slowly mounting protests by the Berber minority exploded last week into the biggest popular outpouring since independence in 1962 when thousands of Algerians seized the chance to vent their own grievances against the government.   ...
column10: Two months of slowly mounting protests by the Berber minority exploded last week into the biggest popular outpouring since independence in 1962 when thousands of Algerians seized the chance to vent their own grievances against the government. While the hundreds of thousands of Berbers who descended on the capital have since returned to their home provinces, the challenge they have opened to a government widely seen as repressive and ineffective is far from dissipated.

column2: NEW YORK CITY; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; MACE (CHEMICAL)
column3: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Spray Sickens 13 In School
column9: Two adults and 11 children at Public School 191 on the Upper West Side were sickened yesterday when a student discharged a canister of Mace, a form of tear gas, the police said. The student, an 11-year-old girl in special education, reached into her...
column10: Two adults and 11 children at Public School 191 on the Upper West Side were sickened yesterday when a student discharged a canister of Mace, a form of tear gas, the police said. The student, an 11-year-old girl in special education, reached into her purse at 10:30 a.m., when she uncapped the irritant, apparently by accident, the police said. It was unclear why the girl carried the canister. The students, a teacher and a parent were taken to St. Mary's Hospital, where they were treated for inflamed eyes and throat and released. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

column2: BEATTY, RUSSELL A; SAN FRANCISCO (CALIF); ALCATRAZ (SAN FRANCISCO); GARDENS AND GARDENING
column3: The Plant Men of Alcatraz
column9: PLANTS, like buildings, hold memories. They are flourishing beneath the cellblock here on Alcatraz, this famously foreboding rock, as they have since military days, when this island -- buffeted by winds and currents -- was a fortress defending San...
column10: PLANTS, like buildings, hold memories. They are flourishing beneath the cellblock here on Alcatraz, this famously foreboding rock, as they have since military days, when this island -- buffeted by winds and currents -- was a fortress defending San Francisco Bay. The sweet scent of honeysuckle mingles with the salty air. The old warden's house, now a ruin overtaken by a fugitive garden, looks like an Aubusson carpet of roses and nasturtiums. Flowers are everywhere on Alcatraz at this time of year -- snaking up barbed wire fences, threatening to subsume the hillside where Al Capone traveled from his cell to laundry detail. Some ancient roses are holdovers from the 19th-century military era, when officers' wives sipped iced tea in cottage gardens. Others were planted and tended by inmates like Elliott Michener, who arrived in 1941, a convicted counterfeiter who couldn't resist a geranium.

column2: JAPAN; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; EDUCATION AND SCHOOLS; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TEAR GAS
column3: Japanese Children Get Scary Lessons in Fighting Violence
column9: Ever since a knife-wielding man killed eight children at an elementary school near Osaka on June 8, schools across Japan have wasted little time adopting security measures that until the stabbing would have been unthinkable in a country of little...
column10: Ever since a knife-wielding man killed eight children at an elementary school near Osaka on June 8, schools across Japan have wasted little time adopting security measures that until the stabbing would have been unthinkable in a country of little violence. School officials have locked gates, posted guards, organized parent patrols, installed cameras and enrolled teachers in self-defense courses.

column2: MORRISON, JIM; PARIS (FRANCE); MUSIC; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
column3: 30 Years Later, He Still Lights His Fans' Fire
column9: In the decades since Jim Morrison died, his grave, with his name on a simple bronze tablet and the words, in Greek, ''True to his own spirit,'' has attracted crowds of pilgrims that have made it a special place of homage for the international rock...
column10: In the decades since Jim Morrison died, his grave, with his name on a simple bronze tablet and the words, in Greek, ''True to his own spirit,'' has attracted crowds of pilgrims that have made it a special place of homage for the international rock scene and the principal attraction in the big Père-Lachaise cemetery in eastern Paris. So today, on the 30th anniversary of Morrison's death in a Paris apartment of an overdose of alcohol and drugs, the crowds were heavy. Le Monde, the arbiter of French tastes, said that he had become a cult object with Père-Lachaise as its Lourdes.

column2: GREAT BRITAIN; BRADFORD (ENG); ATTACKS ON POLICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Race Riot in Another City in Northern England Is Worst So Far
column9: It was the worst race riot so far in what has been a tense summer in Britain's restive north. And today, hours after the end of a rampage in Bradford that injured 120 police officers, community leaders and government officials said they were bracing...
column10: It was the worst race riot so far in what has been a tense summer in Britain's restive north. And today, hours after the end of a rampage in Bradford that injured 120 police officers, community leaders and government officials said they were bracing for further unrest. Thirty-six people were arrested today after pitched battles with the police during nine hours of violence. Shop windows were broken and cars were set on fire as rioters used bricks, bats, hammers, fireworks and firebombs against the police and against local businesses.

column2: MCVEIGH, TIMOTHY JAMES; ASHCROFT, JOHN; OKLAHOMA CITY (OKLA); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES
column3: Ashcroft Says F.B.I.'s Failings Have Led Public to Lose Trust
column9: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today in a speech at F.B.I. headquarters that public trust in the agency had been eroded by recent humiliations, among them a case in which an  agent pleaded guilty to spying for Russia and another in which the...
column10: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today in a speech at F.B.I. headquarters that public trust in the agency had been eroded by recent humiliations, among them a case in which an agent pleaded guilty to spying for Russia and another in which the bureau failed to turn over thousands of pages of investigative reports to defense lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case. ''All institutions -- even great ones like the Federal Bureau of Investigation -- have problems,'' Mr. Ashcroft said in his speech to about 500 F.B.I. employees, among them supervisors, agents and technical analysts. ''Our challenge is how we respond to these problems, how we, working together, answer the call to protect the people's trust, reinforce freedom and preserve justice.''

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; GENOA (ITALY); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Protesters at Bay, Rich Nations' Chiefs to Meet in Genoa
column9: Multiple checkpoints, bomb-sniffing dogs and 13-foot iron gratings put up across cobbled alleys to seal off secure zones have given the medieval port city of Genoa the look of pre-1989 East Berlin.     On Friday, a summit meeting for the world's...
column10: Multiple checkpoints, bomb-sniffing dogs and 13-foot iron gratings put up across cobbled alleys to seal off secure zones have given the medieval port city of Genoa the look of pre-1989 East Berlin. On Friday, a summit meeting for the world's major industrial nations will begin here and is expected to draw more than 100,000 antiglobalization protesters. Tension and security fears are already high.

column2: SRI LANKA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Protesters Defy Ban
column9: More than 10,000 people in the political opposition defied a government ban on a rally in Colombo and assembled to protest President Chandrika Kumaratunga's suspension of Parliament. The police used tear gas, rubber bullets and riot sticks to...
column10: More than 10,000 people in the political opposition defied a government ban on a rally in Colombo and assembled to protest President Chandrika Kumaratunga's suspension of Parliament. The police used tear gas, rubber bullets and riot sticks to disperse the crowds. Parliament, which was to take a no-confidence vote on the government that Mrs. Kumaratunga feared losing, is to remain suspended until Sept. 7. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

column2: CIAMPI, CARLO AZEGLIO; AGNOLETTI, VITTORIO; BERLUSCONI, SILVIO; GIULIANI, CARLO; GENOA (ITALY); GENOA SOCIAL FORUM; GROUP OF EIGHT; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: ITALIAN PROTESTER IS KILLED BY POLICE AT GENOA MEETING
column9: A 23-year-old Italian protester was shot and killed today by a police officer during a riot less than two miles from a gathering of leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations, who were protected by a 13-foot fence that anti-globalization...
column10: A 23-year-old Italian protester was shot and killed today by a police officer during a riot less than two miles from a gathering of leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations, who were protected by a 13-foot fence that anti-globalization demonstrators had vowed to breach. The killing in Genoa, a medieval seaport converted into a 21st-century citadel, is the first death during an anti-globalization demonstration since the movement tempestuously surfaced at a World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in 1999. Today's grim milestone deepened an already widespread feeling that these kinds of international conferences -- and the vast and often violent protests they inspire -- cannot go on unchanged any longer.

column2: CHRETIEN, JEAN; BUSH, GEORGE W; JAPAN; GERMANY; CANADA; FRANCE; GENOA (ITALY); KYOTO PROTOCOL; WEATHER; GLOBAL WARMING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: ALLIES TELL BUSH THEY'LL ACT ALONE ON CLIMATE ACCORD
column9: As tens of thousands of demonstrators marched toward the center of this ancient city and occasionally clashed with the police, the United States' leading allies told President Bush today that they intended to move ahead and ratify the Kyoto Protocol...
column10: As tens of thousands of demonstrators marched toward the center of this ancient city and occasionally clashed with the police, the United States' leading allies told President Bush today that they intended to move ahead and ratify the Kyoto Protocol on global warming by next year, even without American participation. At the summit meeting of top industrial nations, protesters and riot police clashed anew, one day after a protester was killed. Today as many as 50,000 demonstrators flowed through the streets of Genoa, but outside the center of the city, where the leaders were sequestered.

column2: GENOA (ITALY); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: G-8 and Main Protest Groups Concur on Stopping Violence
column9: As both sides left Genoa, the leaders of the major industrialized nations who met here and the mainstream protest leaders began reflecting today on how to carry out their goals while avoiding the fatal violence that marred this year's meeting.   ...
column10: As both sides left Genoa, the leaders of the major industrialized nations who met here and the mainstream protest leaders began reflecting today on how to carry out their goals while avoiding the fatal violence that marred this year's meeting. About all they agreed upon was: never again.

column3: A Day After Seeing Putin, a Harder-Line Bush Emerges
column9: President Bush said today that ''time is of the essence'' in his new arms talks with Moscow and warned that he would move ahead with testing missile shield technology even if he did not reach an agreement that would scrap the Antiballistic Missile...
column10: President Bush said today that ''time is of the essence'' in his new arms talks with Moscow and warned that he would move ahead with testing missile shield technology even if he did not reach an agreement that would scrap the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. Mr. Bush's comments came only a day after he and President Vladimir V. Putin agreed to begin ''consultations'' that would tie deep cuts in the nuclear arsenals of both nations to the discussions on new defensive technologies. They were much more toughly worded than anything he had said publicly in Mr. Putin's presence in Genoa, Italy.

column2: IBRAHIM-NEJAD, EZAT; IRAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; DECISIONS AND VERDICTS
column3: Iran Court Won't Pursue Slain Protester's Case
column9: A court has ruled that it has no authority to pursue a murder prosecution in the case of a man who was killed two years ago in a clash between pro-reform students and hard-line vigilantes. The court found that the man brought on the attack by taking...
column10: A court has ruled that it has no authority to pursue a murder prosecution in the case of a man who was killed two years ago in a clash between pro-reform students and hard-line vigilantes. The court found that the man brought on the attack by taking part in the protest. The Revolution Court, in a decision published a week ago in a daily, Norouz, said the victim, Ezat Ibrahim-nejad, 25, had provoked the students to violence by chanting songs that urged them to defend themselves in their demonstration on July 8, 1999, in support of President Mohammad Khatami. Mr. Ibrahim-nejad had been visiting friends at the dormitory on the day of the protest.

column3: Melee at Jerusalem's Most Sacred, and Explosive, Site
column9: Jerusalem and its sacred places returned to the center of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today when Palestinians on an elevated Muslim compound hurled stones at Jews praying below, provoking a battle with the Israeli police.    Hundreds of Israeli...
column10: Jerusalem and its sacred places returned to the center of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today when Palestinians on an elevated Muslim compound hurled stones at Jews praying below, provoking a battle with the Israeli police. Hundreds of Israeli officers in riot gear rushed into the Aksa compound after a barrage of rocks, some quite large, sent Jewish worshipers fleeing from the Western Wall. The attack came on a day when Jews traditionally gather there to mourn the destruction of two ancient temples.

column3: Outcry Grows Over Police Use of Force in Genoa
column9: More than two weeks ago, Susan Hager received a telephone call in Portland, Ore., about her daughter, a student who had stopped off in Genoa to join protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting on her way to a junior year abroad program in Siena.   ...
column10: More than two weeks ago, Susan Hager received a telephone call in Portland, Ore., about her daughter, a student who had stopped off in Genoa to join protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting on her way to a junior year abroad program in Siena. ''Her friend had found her bloody belongings'' at the Armando Diaz school complex in Genoa where protesters had been staying, Mrs. Hager said. There, in the early hours of July 22, 92 young people were dragged from their beds by squads of Italian anti-riot police officers who beat and jailed them.

column10: ''Do you want to see my boy?'' Sabir Veseli asked. He climbed up to the porch where, on muggy nights like last night, his three children go out to sleep. Last night, after 11 p.m., two bullets were fired from the road. The children scattered. A dozen more shots hit the porch, one of which passed through his oldest son, Tafil, 11. The bullet went in at the small of his back and out just below his navel.

column2: FISHER, PETE; COACHES AND MANAGERS; SEX CRIMES; TENNIS
column3: Paroled Ex-Coach Is Upbeat
column9: On the bus trip toward a prison in the California desert three years ago, Pete Fischer sat motionless, with his eyes fixed straight ahead and his mouth shut tight.    He wanted to blend in, not create a stir. And yet, his camouflage as an...
column10: On the bus trip toward a prison in the California desert three years ago, Pete Fischer sat motionless, with his eyes fixed straight ahead and his mouth shut tight. He wanted to blend in, not create a stir. And yet, his camouflage as an inconspicuous inmate vanished. A seat away, another prisoner recognized Fischer's face from the news as the prominent Los Angeles pediatrician who drew up the blueprint for Pete Sampras's career but had been convicted of molesting some of his young patients.

column3: Gunman Kills Deputy and Is Believed to Die in Fire
column9: A man sought by federal agents shot and killed a sheriff's deputy today, the authorities said, then barricaded himself inside his home, which caught fire after officers lobbed tear gas inside.    The authorities said they believed that the gunman...
column10: A man sought by federal agents shot and killed a sheriff's deputy today, the authorities said, then barricaded himself inside his home, which caught fire after officers lobbed tear gas inside. The authorities said they believed that the gunman remained inside as the blaze gutted the house. A search of the rubble was under way this evening, but officers said that although the man was probably dead, they had not yet found his body.

column10: For the first time in 65 years, voters here have thrown out an incumbent mayor in a primary election, ousting the one-term mayor, Paul Schell, on Tuesday after a turbulent four years in which the city's image took a battering and its economy stumbled. Two veteran city leaders will now face each other in the November election.

column10: RICHARD R. WACKENHUT grew up in the security business. He is the son of an F.B.I. special agent who started his own company 47 years ago. It provided Mr. Wackenhut's first employment. He started as a guard, then graduated to investigator, then sales representative, then management. Today the Wackenhut Corporation, which he took over in 1986 from his father, George R. Wackenhut, is one of the largest independent security companies in the United States, a leading provider of private security overseas and a major operator of privatized prisons. It has contracts with the government to protect many of the nation's nuclear sites, Defense Department installations and some American embassies..

column9: Here is what a quiet day looks like during the nominal ceasefire in Israel: today, just one car, packed with explosives, nails, and ammunition, blew up along a busy street here, and it did not hurt anybody.     The Bush administration has urgently...
column10: Here is what a quiet day looks like during the nominal ceasefire in Israel: today, just one car, packed with explosives, nails, and ammunition, blew up along a busy street here, and it did not hurt anybody. The Bush administration has urgently sought a truce between Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's coalition government and Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority. But so far the antagonists' mincing steps toward peace have yielded what is, even by this region's standards, a most unstable situation: a cease-fire that won't, a unity government that isn't, and a Palestinian Authority that doesn't have much, or at least won't exercise it to the Israelis' satisfaction.

column9: Chaudary Umadali stood in the blackened ruins of his movie theater this afternoon, a dignified man trying to make sense of the rage that led to its destruction.    ''They broke the windows and came inside with petrol bottles,'' he said, gazing at...
column10: Chaudary Umadali stood in the blackened ruins of his movie theater this afternoon, a dignified man trying to make sense of the rage that led to its destruction. ''They broke the windows and came inside with petrol bottles,'' he said, gazing at puddles of sooty water and shards of glass. ''There were a thousand people. They set fire to my cinema'' -- because it was playing an American film, ''Desperado.''

column10: Protests against the airstrikes in Afghanistan erupted into extraordinary confrontations today in the Gaza Strip, when Palestinian security forces opened fire on Palestinian student demonstrators and killed at least two people, including a 13-year-old boy. In sending his own police against a crowd of some 2,000 Palestinians, Yasir Arafat appeared to make a clear choice in the international battle against terror: he is with the United States, and against Osama bin Laden. But, on a day when Mr. Arafat, like many other Arab leaders, enveloped himself in silence, it was not clear why he had decided to act as he did.

column9: Today, Yasir Arafat took a gamble, confronting a radical Palestinian crowd in a bid to shore up his own position and assert his international credibility as the possible leader of a Palestinian state.     For the first time in years, Mr. Arafat's...
column10: Today, Yasir Arafat took a gamble, confronting a radical Palestinian crowd in a bid to shore up his own position and assert his international credibility as the possible leader of a Palestinian state. For the first time in years, Mr. Arafat's security forces used deadly force against Palestinians to suppress a demonstration in support of Osama bin Laden. In a cloud of tear gas and a hail of bullets, two Palestinians -- one of them only 13 -- were slain. Another was close to death.

The protests, in at least four cities, remained relatively small, but radical Muslim groups said they were preparing larger demonstrations and repeated their warnings that they might attack foreigners here.

column9: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets across Pakistan today to protest American attacks on Afghanistan and their country's support for the American-led alliance.    But a bristling display of troops and weaponry kept violence to a minimum in...
column10: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets across Pakistan today to protest American attacks on Afghanistan and their country's support for the American-led alliance. But a bristling display of troops and weaponry kept violence to a minimum in what appeared to be a victory for President Pervez Musharraf's get-tough policy with protesters.

column3: Shaping Young Islamic Hearts and Hatreds
column9: A thousand years ago, in the days of the camel caravans, storytellers gathered here in the tea shops and brought the outside world and all its thoughts and ideas to the bazaar. As the vendors hawked silk, spice and rich tapestries and traders herded...
column10: A thousand years ago, in the days of the camel caravans, storytellers gathered here in the tea shops and brought the outside world and all its thoughts and ideas to the bazaar. As the vendors hawked silk, spice and rich tapestries and traders herded beasts through streets thick with smoke from cooking fires, travelers from distant lands and differing religions told stories about moguls, magic, wit and wisdom. In time, the bazaar came to be known as Qissa Khwani -- the Bazaar of the Storytellers. Now, the streets are still choked with donkey carts, and meat still sizzles on open pits, but the vendors are poor men selling simple things. Blaring car horns drown out all other sound, just as the teachers and students in the Islamic seminaries that surround this bazaar have drowned out all conflicting ideas, all unacceptable thoughts.

column10: Two demonstrators were killed and at least six were wounded today when the police fired on a stone-throwing crowd trying to block entrances to an airport where American aircraft are based to provide logistical support for airstrikes on Afghanistan. Several thousand protesters evaded a security cordon set up around the city of Jacobabad in southern Pakistan and tried to reach the airport, prompting police officers and paramilitary rangers to open fire with live ammunition and tear gas.

column3: Reporter's Notebook; In Quiet Corners, the Roots of Afghan Rebellion
column9: While bombs fall in Afghanistan, a quieter war is being waged in the dusty border city of Quetta and, farther north, in the mud-brick city of Peshawar. It is a clandestine affair, intended to win converts for an attempt to overthrow the Taliban.   ...
column10: While bombs fall in Afghanistan, a quieter war is being waged in the dusty border city of Quetta and, farther north, in the mud-brick city of Peshawar. It is a clandestine affair, intended to win converts for an attempt to overthrow the Taliban. Mujahedeen commanders, tribal chiefs and other prominent Afghans opposed to the ruling Taliban gather in carpet shops, in coffee houses and behind closed doors in both cities to discuss shifting alliances and strategies for exploiting a schism among Taliban leaders. Some travel from Afghanistan, crossing the mountains for talks that could shape the future of their country and the outcome of the American war.

column2: NEW YORK CITY; FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION; ANIMALS; WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; HIJACKING; TERRORISM
column3: Carry-On Rules: List Grows Long
column9: DO not try flying US Airways with a pinned-up hem, or for that matter, with a red, white and blue ribbon affixed to your shirt. Because a safety pin -- along with all sharp objects and anything else that could be used as a weapon -- will be...
column10: DO not try flying US Airways with a pinned-up hem, or for that matter, with a red, white and blue ribbon affixed to your shirt. Because a safety pin -- along with all sharp objects and anything else that could be used as a weapon -- will be confiscated if you try to take it aboard, according to signs posted throughout La Guardia's US Airways terminal. Cigarette lighters and hockey sticks are also on the carrier's list of prohibited objects. The list was taken from an Federal Aviation Administration directive issued after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and has inspired just some of the adjustments passengers will have to accept as part of the attempt by the United States to make the skies safe.

column2: KENYA; POLITICAL PRISONERS
column3: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Prisoners' Advocates Are Imprisoned
column9: The police in Nairobi have arrested 70 people who were campaigning on behalf of political prisoners for holding what the authorities called an illegal political meeting. Using tear gas, the police raided the offices of Release Political Prisoners on...
column10: The police in Nairobi have arrested 70 people who were campaigning on behalf of political prisoners for holding what the authorities called an illegal political meeting. Using tear gas, the police raided the offices of Release Political Prisoners on Saturday and made the arrests. Willy Mutunga, executive director of the Kenya Human Rights Commission, said the detainees had now become political prisoners themselves. Marc Lacey (NYT)

column2: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN; MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY; FOOTBALL
column3: In Michigan, Very Different States of Mind
column9: Although the skies were overcast, the man who called himself John Spirit wore sunglasses as he scanned the perimeter of the traffic island for potential vandals. He was protecting ''The Spartan,'' a 10-foot ceramic statue of a barely clothed warrior...
column10: Although the skies were overcast, the man who called himself John Spirit wore sunglasses as he scanned the perimeter of the traffic island for potential vandals. He was protecting ''The Spartan,'' a 10-foot ceramic statue of a barely clothed warrior near the football stadium of the Michigan State Spartans. The autumn wind swirled dead leaves around the feet of both ''The Spartan'' and John Spirit. Both stood strong and vigilant. In the past, before the big game between Michigan State and Michigan, students drove 60 miles from the Michigan campus in Ann Arbor to splash the big icon with maize and blue paint, the colors of the Michigan Wolverines.

column10: Sayira Marín's hands still tremble as she recalls the Americans' invasion of Panama in 1989 and how her impoverished neighborhood, El Chorrillo, was caught in the cross-fire. Ms. Marín, now 25, wonders how Afghan civilians will emerge after weeks of bombing, which, no matter how precise, has already claimed some innocent lives.

column10: A Nepalese man was indicted today on a federal charge of trying to carry weapons onto an airplane, after the authorities said airline workers caught him boarding a flight to Omaha this weekend with several knives, a stun gun and a can of pepper spray. Eight employees of a private security company have been suspended for failing to detect the weapons in the man's carry-on bags at an earlier security checkpoint, although they did find two other knives in his pockets.

column3: Business Travel; The nation's airline security system continues to come up short in its basic responsibility.
column9: ANYONE gathering evidence to support growing suspicions that the airport security system is pretty much out of control has to be looking this week at Subash Bahadur Gurung as Exhibit A.    Mr. Gurung, 27, a Napalese national living in Chicago on a...
column10: ANYONE gathering evidence to support growing suspicions that the airport security system is pretty much out of control has to be looking this week at Subash Bahadur Gurung as Exhibit A. Mr. Gurung, 27, a Napalese national living in Chicago on a student visa that expired in 1999, was at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago for a flight to Omaha, late Saturday afternoon when he set off the metal detector at the security gate. Security guards found two knives in his pocket.

column10: Three security workers who let a man carrying knives, a stun gun and tear gas through a checkpoint at O'Hare International Airport were fired, and a fourth resigned, according to Argenbright Security, the company that employed them. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating Saturday's lapse at the United Airlines checkpoint. The weapons were found by United employees during a hand search at the gate. Subash Gurang, 27, of Chicago, a Nepal native in the United States on an expired student visa, was arrested by Chicago police. He was scheduled to appear today at a hearing before United States Magistrate Judge Morton Denlow.

column2: QATAR; DOHA (QATAR); SEATTLE (WASH); INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; EDITORIALS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
column3: Up From Seattle
column9: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and...
column10: Trade ministers from 142 nations will meet in Doha, Qatar, today for a conference of the World Trade Organization. Their agenda is much the same as the ill-fated ministerial meeting in Seattle in 1999, when attempts to bridge the gap between poor and wealthy countries' priorities blew up in a cloud of tear gas. The whole world has an interest in seeing this gathering turn out better. With the world's terrorized economy stuck at a standstill, the time is ripe for a cooperative, international push for growth through trade. The ministers' goal in Qatar is to launch a new set of comprehensive trade negotiations. During the original Uruguay Round, which led to the creation of the W.T.O., rich countries pledged to open their markets to textiles, crops and other basic exports from the developing world. There has been some progress in that area, but arcane customs rules, unnecessary red tape, stingy quotas and anti-dumping programs still keep poor nations' exports out of wealthy markets. Now protectionist politicians are trying to erect more barriers by exploiting concerns about border security and food safety.

column10: Thousands of supporters of Pakistan's Islamic parties marched in several cities today, blocking roads, burning tires and clashing with police officers who lobbed tear gas canisters and, in one case, killed at least three protesters. But the protests fell short of the parties' goal of paralyzing the country. A significant number of shops remained open and cars moved freely here just south of the capital, Islamabad, and elsewhere.

column10: Organized labor and students come together. 1940-50 As interest in Communism and Socialism flourishes, the party forms many youth adjuncts on campuses. Labor unions also recruit heavily and openly, mobilizing labor-led student groups like the American Youth for Democracy, the American Student Union and the American Student Congress to fight, among other issues, low pay and racial discrimination in the workplace.
