column3: Nathan Pusey, Harvard President Through Growth and Turmoil Alike, Dies at 94
column9: Nathan M. Pusey, who led Harvard University through tremendous growth and liberalization only to be swept away in a storm over Vietnam-era protests, died yesterday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 94 and lived on the East Side.  ...
column10: Nathan M. Pusey, who led Harvard University through tremendous growth and liberalization only to be swept away in a storm over Vietnam-era protests, died yesterday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 94 and lived on the East Side. In Dr. Pusey's tenure as Harvard's 24th president, from 1953 to 1971, the university's budget quadrupled, as did its endowments. The campus was transformed by the construction of more than 30 buildings, which almost doubled its floor space. The permanent population of teachers and administrators swelled to 8,500 from 3,000, and Dr. Pusey made higher salaries and improved benefits a priority.

column3: I.M.F. Plans For Recovery, But Avoids Terror Issue
column9: The International Monetary Fund pressed the world's leading nations today to cut interest rates further if needed to shore up a bleak world economy, while outside the meeting globalization protesters braved the Canadian chill.    Finance ministers...
column10: The International Monetary Fund pressed the world's leading nations today to cut interest rates further if needed to shore up a bleak world economy, while outside the meeting globalization protesters braved the Canadian chill. Finance ministers and central bankers from around the world met to chart the actions the fund would take in the months ahead to try to counter an increasingly dour and uncertain global economic outlook.

column9: Riot police officers fired rubber bullets and tear gas today at hundreds of supporters of President Hugo Chávez who attacked some 2,000 antigovernment demonstrators on the streets of the capital.    Several people were injured in skirmishes around...
column10: Riot police officers fired rubber bullets and tear gas today at hundreds of supporters of President Hugo Chávez who attacked some 2,000 antigovernment demonstrators on the streets of the capital. Several people were injured in skirmishes around the National Assembly building. The city police struggled to separate about 300 government loyalists from demonstrators carrying placards reading ''Chávez Out.''

column10: Police used tear gas and pepper spray to disperse fans celebrating Colorado's victory in the Big 12 championship game.

column3: Israeli Missiles Hit Arafat Compound and Other Sites
column9: In the most wide-ranging attack on Palestinian areas in 14 months of conflict, Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded security offices today in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores.  ...
column10: In the most wide-ranging attack on Palestinian areas in 14 months of conflict, Israeli warplanes and helicopters bombarded security offices today in eight areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, killing at least two Palestinians and injuring scores. Helicopters fired three missiles into the walled compound here of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat. The missiles destroyed several cars and punched a hole in the stone wall of a police building less than 100 yards from Mr. Arafat's office, where he was said to have been at work.

column3: A Bare Budget Provokes Another Strike In Argentina
column9: Several major unions staged a 24-hour nationwide strike today, crippling businesses and government functions. They were protesting austerity measures intended to avert a default on the $132 billion public sector debt and economic collapse.    Retail...
column10: Several major unions staged a 24-hour nationwide strike today, crippling businesses and government functions. They were protesting austerity measures intended to avert a default on the $132 billion public sector debt and economic collapse. Retail businesses, railroads, bus service, schools, theaters and garbage collection all halted operations, and hospitals were open only for emergency services. Tens of thousands of workers who did not strike stayed home because of breakdowns in transportation.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-22    Argentine Leader Declares State of Siege Amid Looting  President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across the country. The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas in...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 Argentine Leader Declares State of Siege Amid Looting President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across the country. The police fired rubber bullets and tear gas in several cities, and four people were killed. The disturbances appeared to be a mix of spontaneous pilferage by unemployed workers and organized protests by government opponents. A3 New Terms for Colombia Aid The House attached a series of conditions to aid to Colombia, demanding that the government hold right-wing paramilitary groups and their military allies accountable for violence there. The Senate, which initiated the restrictions, is expected to concur. A19

column3: Reeling From Riots, Argentina Declares a State of Siege
column9: President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across Argentina today, and the police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at rock-throwing protesters in Buenos Aires and several provincial cities....
column10: President Fernando de la Rúa declared a 30-day state of siege after food riots and looting broke out across Argentina today, and the police fired rubber bullets and tear gas at rock-throwing protesters in Buenos Aires and several provincial cities. Five people were killed in the rioting. The most widespread social disturbances since the 1980's came on a sweltering summer day. The near anarchy in many cities appeared to be a mix of spontaneous pilferage by the unemployed seeking to put food on their Christmas tables and organized protests to force the tottering government of Mr. de la Rúa to give up power.

column3: Challenge for Algeria: Berber Anger
column9: When Ouardia Guermah tells the story, her eyes rest on the spot where her son used to do his math homework, right there at the brown Formica dining room table, with the metal legs and the clean white doily on top.     Her son, Massinissa, was seated...
column10: When Ouardia Guermah tells the story, her eyes rest on the spot where her son used to do his math homework, right there at the brown Formica dining room table, with the metal legs and the clean white doily on top. Her son, Massinissa, was seated there the evening he heard a fight outside and went to investigate. He never came back. Witnesses say the gendarmes took him down the road to the station house. There, while he was already semiconscious from a beating, they shot him 27 times, Mrs. Guermah said.

column10: Guards fired tear gas and wooden bullets today to quell a riot by about 300 inmates at a crowded state prison that left 5 inmates seriously injured, the authorities said. Fighting broke out in a prison yard about 10:45 a.m., Margot Bach, a state prison spokeswoman, said.

column3: Hamas Leader Defies Palestinian Authority's Crackdown
column9: As Israeli military pressure on Yasir Arafat eased slightly today, the pressure on him from Palestinian extremists grew.    Defying efforts by Mr. Arafat to arrest him and to restrain his militant group, Dr. Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, a top political...
column10: As Israeli military pressure on Yasir Arafat eased slightly today, the pressure on him from Palestinian extremists grew. Defying efforts by Mr. Arafat to arrest him and to restrain his militant group, Dr. Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, a top political leader of Hamas, said today that Hamas's military wing intended to continue sending suicidal attackers against Israel. For a second night, forces of Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority clashed with Hamas supporters near Dr. Rantisi's house.

column3: ARGENTINE LEADER, HIS NATION FRAYED, ABRUPTLY RESIGNS
column9: President Fernando de la Rúa resigned today, halfway through his four-year term, swamped by violent protests and looting that erupted when his government failed to reverse a deepening economic crisis.    The resignation letter, which was delivered...
column10: President Fernando de la Rúa resigned today, halfway through his four-year term, swamped by violent protests and looting that erupted when his government failed to reverse a deepening economic crisis. The resignation letter, which was delivered to Congress late in the day, followed violent food riots and protests here and in several cities. At least five demonstrators were killed today, bringing the death toll to 21 since the protests began early Wednesday.

column2: GREAT BRITAIN; FRANCE; RED CROSS; EUROTUNNEL PLC AND EUROTUNNEL SA; ILLEGAL ALIENS; ASYLUM (POLITICAL); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CHANNEL TUNNEL
column3: 500 Asylum-Seekers Try to Dash Through Channel Tunnel
column9: More than 500 asylum-seekers broke through fences overnight and early today in two waves and stormed into the Channel tunnel as they made a mad dash for Britain, forcing the tunnel to close for 10 hours and raising new tensions between France and...
column10: More than 500 asylum-seekers broke through fences overnight and early today in two waves and stormed into the Channel tunnel as they made a mad dash for Britain, forcing the tunnel to close for 10 hours and raising new tensions between France and Britain over illegal migration. All the escapees were captured by the French, said the British police, who had 60 officers waiting for them with dogs at a point halfway through the tunnel.

column2: BERENSON, LORI HELENE; PERU; SEX CRIMES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Mistreatment Of Berenson Denied
column9: The government denied assertions that Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year sentence for aiding a leftist rebel group, was mistreated while being transferred to another prison last week. But her lawyer said he would broaden a complaint he had...
column10: The government denied assertions that Lori Berenson, the American serving a 20-year sentence for aiding a leftist rebel group, was mistreated while being transferred to another prison last week. But her lawyer said he would broaden a complaint he had filed to include an accusation of sexual abuse. Her father, Mark Berenson, has also said she was molested. The justice ministry said that it ''denies the 'grave injury' her lawyers have denounced'' and that Ms. Berenson, 32, is ''in good health.'' Ms. Berenson's lawyer, José Luís Sandoval, said she was beaten and sprayed with tear gas by the police when she and another prisoner were taken from their cells last Friday. He also said Ms. Berenson had been fondled by a police officer. The justice ministry said that the transfer had been carried out according to regulations and that tear gas had been used when prisoners resisted the police.

column3: ''Bons Mots? You Decide''
column9: THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness.    Were you paying attention? Try...
column10: THE economy may have slowed during 2001, but news in the business world didn't skip a beat. Among its highs and lows were many moments that were memorable for their importance, their humor or their sheer brazenness. Were you paying attention? Try this test. PART 1 Who spoke these words and about what? 1) ''It is not good news for America.'' 2) ''She has the full support of the board and will continue to lead the company through these challenging times.'' 3) ''The more I see about this deal, the less I like it.'' 4) ''I was smiling going in, because how often in your life do you and your company have an opportunity to make a difference?'' 5) ''I have no desire to be next at bat.'' 6) ''We are on the side of angels.'' 7) ''This is an industrial policy designed for shareholders of the winning companies.'' 8) ''It would be a good time for all parties to sit down together and see what kind of resolution can be worked out.'' 9) ''Today, America goes back to business.'' 10) ''What keeps me up at night is doing my own e-mail. I wouldn't say that anything keeps me up at night worrying.'' PART 2 What were these people talking about when they spoke these words? 1) In April, a senior Bush administration official said, ''It would be like having a cheeseburger without cheese.'' 2) In March, Dick Conway, an economist in Seattle, said, ''Well, it has made us forget the earthquake all of a sudden.'' 3) In September, Alexander Danielides, a junior at the Bronx High School of Science, said, ''The Vietnam generation is a little more cautious than we would be.'' 4) In April, Ira Kay, a consultant at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, said, ''It's the gift that keeps on giving.'' 5) In June, Representative Richard H. Baker, Republican of Louisiana, said: ''It is one thing for one shark to eat another. It is quite another for the shark to eat the minnows.'' 6) In April, Elliot Schrage, senior vice president for global affairs at Gap Inc., said: ''We are not the all-powerful Oz that rules over what happens in every factory. Do we have leverage? Yes. Is it as great as our critics believe? Not by a long shot.'' 7) In March, Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, said, ''I've decided to take this issue off the table.'' 8) In December, Thomas R. Eisenmann, an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, said, ''This was another big move in this continuing clash of titans.'' 9) In January, Kathleen Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman for Lucent Technologies, said, ''Henry decided it was not the best use of our assets.'' 10) In September, Fay Weldon said: ''I thought: 'Oh no, dear me, I am a literary author. You can't do this kind of thing; my name will be mud forever.' But then after a while I thought: 'I don't care. Let it be mud.' '' ''Answers to the Quiz'' PART 1 1) President Bush, commenting on the October unemployment rate. 2) Stanley Silverstein, general counsel of Warnaco, speaking about its chief executive, Linda J. Wachner, as Warnaco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June. Mrs. Wachner was fired in November. 3) Walter B. Hewlett, declaring his opposition to Hewlett-Packard's plan to merge with Compaq Computer. 4) Helge H. Wehmeier, chief executive of Bayer's American operations, referring to the company's agreement to sell its anthrax medicine, Cipro, to the government at a discounted price. 5) Robert W. Pittman, chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, after his peer and rival, Richard D. Parsons, was named to succeed Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive, next May. 6) Jeffrey K. Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, in March, dismissing critics who saw Enron as a profiteer in California's energy crisis. 7) Robert B. Reich, former secretary of labor, criticizing the legislation passed to bail out the nation's airlines after the terrorist attacks. 8) Bill Gates, in June, commenting after a federal appeals court threw out a lower court's order that Microsoft be broken up. 9) Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, reopening the exchange after it was closed for four days as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks. 10) Gordon E. Moore, co-founder of Fairchild Semiconductor and the Intel Corporation, upon his retirement last spring, discussing the widespread use of personal computers. PART 2 1) He was referring in general to the demonstrations that accompany world trade talks (in this case, the Summit of the Americas that took place in Quebec) and specifically to the tear gas that authorities use to break up the protests. 2) He was commenting on the announcement that Boeing was moving its corporate headquarters out of Seattle after decades as the mainstay of the region's economy. 3) This teenage investor was talking, a few days after Sept. 11, about the willingness of his generation to stay in the stock market when conventional wisdom suggested otherwise. 4) He was describing reload stock options, a form of compensation that gives executives who exercise them both a share of stock and a new option. 5) He was questioning Wall Street's erosion of ethical conduct at a Congressional hearing on conflicts among brokerage firm research analysts. 6) He was commenting on the difficulties of trying to improve conditions in foreign factories. 7) He was announcing his decision to sell about $100 million worth of Alcoa stock and options that he had planned to keep. 8) He was referring to the battle over broadband between AOL Time Warner and Microsoft after Comcast outbid rivals for AT&T's cable television business. 9) She was discussing the decision by Henry B. Schacht, the interim chief executive of Lucent, to sell the Hamilton Farm Golf Club, an expensive white elephant that the company developed before its fortunes plunged, causing huge layoffs, write-offs and restructuring. 10) She was commenting on her new novel, ''The Bulgari Connection,'' for which Bulgari, the Italian jewelry company, paid her an undisclosed amount in return for a prominent place in the book.

column3: STORMING THE CHUNNEL
column9: About 500 asylum-seekers who live at a refugee camp near the French end of the Channel Tunnel made a break for England. In two waves, the men -- mostly Afghans, Iranians and Kurds -- broke the electric fence guarding the entrance. Some poured into...
column10: About 500 asylum-seekers who live at a refugee camp near the French end of the Channel Tunnel made a break for England. In two waves, the men -- mostly Afghans, Iranians and Kurds -- broke the electric fence guarding the entrance. Some poured into the tunnel to be chased down by the French police. Others were captured in the barrage of tear gas laid down in the rail yards. Some ran for miles, but none reached the middle of the 30-mile tunnel -- where they would have met British officers with dogs. The incident prompted increased calls for the camp's closure. Donald G. McNeil Jr.

column3: Israelis Bring Help to Arabs In a Village Under Siege
column9: Hundreds of Israelis and Palestinians met at the barricades outside this embattled village today, but instead of bullets and stones the air was filled with hands lifting sacks of rice, bags of sugar and jugs of cooking oil.    In a rare gesture in...
column10: Hundreds of Israelis and Palestinians met at the barricades outside this embattled village today, but instead of bullets and stones the air was filled with hands lifting sacks of rice, bags of sugar and jugs of cooking oil. In a rare gesture in this weary land, more than 250 Israeli peace advocates delivered about two tons of food and clothing to 12,000 Palestinian residents of Beit Umar, which has been closed by the Israeli military blockade for more than a year.

column3: Argentina Drifts, Leaderless, as Economic Collapse Looms
column9: Without a president, a cabinet or a functioning government, Argentina drifted rudderless today, as people waited for the Peronist party to resolve its bitter internal differences over who should run the country and for how long.    The surprise...
column10: Without a president, a cabinet or a functioning government, Argentina drifted rudderless today, as people waited for the Peronist party to resolve its bitter internal differences over who should run the country and for how long. The surprise resignation of the interim president, Adolfo Rodríguez Saá, late Sunday means that by Tuesday Argentina is likely to have its fifth leader in less than two weeks, counting temporary caretakers.

column2: LIMA (PERU); FIRES AND FIREMEN; EXPLOSIONS; FIREWORKS
column3: Grieving and Looking for Survivors in a Charred Lima
column9: From the charred and soggy streets of the empty Mesa Redonda shopping district to clogged and sun-baked sidewalks outside the central morgue, people were desperately clinging today to the old year. For many of them, the remaining hours offered the...
column10: From the charred and soggy streets of the empty Mesa Redonda shopping district to clogged and sun-baked sidewalks outside the central morgue, people were desperately clinging today to the old year. For many of them, the remaining hours offered the slimmest hope that their loved ones survived the fireworks explosions that sent fireballs racing through the narrow streets of the district on Saturday night, setting four blocks ablaze and killing nearly 300 people. Wilfredo Palomino spent the morning holding a fruitless vigil outside the morgue, where the line of relatives snaked down the busy block and onto the lawn. His wife, Rosa, had taken a job selling fireworks with one of the many street vendors in Mesa Redonda only last Friday, after he lost his tailor's job on Christmas Eve. Poverty cost her her life, her mother said, but he refused to believe it.

column2: MWANAWASA, LEVY; ZAMBIA; INAUGURATIONS; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
column3: Charging Vote Fraud, Crowds Storm Zambian Supreme Court
column9: More than a thousand angry opposition party supporters took to the streets today and clashed with the riot police as dozens of protesters stormed into the Supreme Court to accuse the Zambian government of rigging the presidential election last week. ...
column10: More than a thousand angry opposition party supporters took to the streets today and clashed with the riot police as dozens of protesters stormed into the Supreme Court to accuse the Zambian government of rigging the presidential election last week. Judge Peter Chitengi, who was considering delaying the presidential inauguration because of the reported electoral irregularities, rushed into his chambers when he heard the shouts and whistles of the oncoming crowd. Behind closed doors, he ordered the government not to release the final election results tonight.

column2: DUHALDE, EDUARDO; ARGENTINA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Populist Argentine Senator Steps In to Fill the Void, Becoming 5th President in 2 Weeks
column9: Eduardo Duhalde, a veteran Peronist politician with a strong populist streak, was chosen late tonight as Argentina's fifth president in less than two weeks. He immediately announced that he would form a ''government of national unity'' in a...
column10: Eduardo Duhalde, a veteran Peronist politician with a strong populist streak, was chosen late tonight as Argentina's fifth president in less than two weeks. He immediately announced that he would form a ''government of national unity'' in a last-ditch effort to bring the country back from what he called ''the verge of disintegration and chaos.'' ''We're at the limit and we know it,'' he said after being sworn in to run the country until the end of 2003. Though he acknowledged that ''we have no external or domestic credit,'' he nevertheless promised to run a government that will carry out ''a more just distribution of riches.''

column2: MWANAWASA, LEVY; ZAMBIA; FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Uneasy but Outwardly Calm, Zambia Swears In a President
column9: The battered gate at the Supreme Court swung awkwardly on its hinges and shards of glass from smashed streetlights littered Independence Avenue. But with riot police preventing mass protests, this uneasy country inaugurated its president peacefully...
column10: The battered gate at the Supreme Court swung awkwardly on its hinges and shards of glass from smashed streetlights littered Independence Avenue. But with riot police preventing mass protests, this uneasy country inaugurated its president peacefully today. Levy Mwanawasa, the candidate for the governing Movement for Multiparty Democracy, took his oath of office at the Supreme Court a day after more than a thousand opposition party supporters stormed the building, accusing the government of rigging the presidential election last week.

column2: BLOOMBERG, MICHAEL R; NEW YORK CITY; WALDORF-ASTORIA HOTEL; WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: City Girds for Protests at Economic Summit Meeting
column9: In the fall, the organizers of an annual summit meeting for the world's economic, political and academic leaders decided to move the conference from its usual site in Switzerland to New York City as a show of solidarity in the aftermath of the terror...
column10: In the fall, the organizers of an annual summit meeting for the world's economic, political and academic leaders decided to move the conference from its usual site in Switzerland to New York City as a show of solidarity in the aftermath of the terror attacks. Security, the organizers were told by city and police officials of the Giuliani administration, would be little problem for a force accustomed to dealing with large-scale demonstrations. City and police officials of the Bloomberg administration have not backed off that pledge. But they acknowledge that the demonstrations expected during the World Economic Forum, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria from Jan. 31 to Feb. 4, could be unlike any seen before in the city.

column2: LONDONDERRY (NORTHERN IRELAND); NORTHERN IRELAND; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY; REVIEWS; PHOTOGRAPHY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Is the Camera a Reliable Witness?
column9: PHOTOGRAPHY walks many fine lines. Democratic and prolific by nature, it undermines old genius-at-work, precious-object ideas of art. At the same time, it keeps laying claim to art's special powers and perks. One of its traditional selling points is...
column10: PHOTOGRAPHY walks many fine lines. Democratic and prolific by nature, it undermines old genius-at-work, precious-object ideas of art. At the same time, it keeps laying claim to art's special powers and perks. One of its traditional selling points is objectivity. Yet it's a medium of calculation: of measured light and chosen angles, of zooming in and editing out. These opposites define its tensions. Such tensions can be felt even in an exhibition as anti-elitist and programmatically didactic as ''Hidden Truths: Bloody Sunday 1972'' at the International Center of Photography. The show doesn't pretend for an instant to be art. Most of its dozens of pictures are digital scans of umpteenth generation press prints, images made to be transferred to newsprint and valued for information, not formal finesse.

column2: DUHALDE, EDUARDO; ARGENTINA; CURRENCY; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Argentine Peso Drops Sharply After Link to the Dollar Ends
column9: Freed from its link to the American dollar for the first time in nearly 11 years, the Argentine peso dropped sharply on foreign exchange markets here today as the government ended an emergency bank holiday that had halted normal economic activity...
column10: Freed from its link to the American dollar for the first time in nearly 11 years, the Argentine peso dropped sharply on foreign exchange markets here today as the government ended an emergency bank holiday that had halted normal economic activity since before Christmas. An initial wave of nervousness quickly drove down the peso's value to as low as 1.70 to the dollar on the open market, far from the fixed rate of one peso to one dollar that had prevailed before President Eduardo Duhalde was given sweeping economic powers on Sunday. The official exchange rate set then was 1.4 pesos to the dollar, but it applies almost exclusively to foreign trade transactions and is not available to individual Argentines.

column10: Rioters smashed windows and blocked streets with burning tires here today as labor unions began a general strike to protest higher fuel prices. Demonstrators hurled stones at the police and attacked taxis and buses that ventured onto the streets. In several neighborhoods, the police responded with tear gas and by firing bullets into the air.

column9: Israeli forces continued to step up military operations here after a Palestinian gunman opened fire on Thursday night on a Jewish family's celebration in the northern city of Hadera, killing 6 and wounding more than 30.    Israeli troops blew up the...
column10: Israeli forces continued to step up military operations here after a Palestinian gunman opened fire on Thursday night on a Jewish family's celebration in the northern city of Hadera, killing 6 and wounding more than 30. Israeli troops blew up the Voice of Palestine radio station just before dawn this morning, engulfing the five-story building in flames and smoke, witnesses said.

column9: Wearing a blue jacket and carrying an M-16 semiautomatic rifle, the young man looked like just another Israeli soldier, on guard even if off duty, as he strolled through Jerusalem's crowded shopping district late Tuesday afternoon.    But with a cry...
column10: Wearing a blue jacket and carrying an M-16 semiautomatic rifle, the young man looked like just another Israeli soldier, on guard even if off duty, as he strolled through Jerusalem's crowded shopping district late Tuesday afternoon. But with a cry in Arabic of ''God is great!'' the man, a member of a Palestinian militant group, turned the rifle on passers-by, killing two women and wounding 20 other people as he sprayed bullets at two bus stops and several stores.

column2: MAAN (JORDAN); JORDAN; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Unrest In Southern City
column9: Riot police officers in the southern city of Maan used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who set fire to the main police station and post office, ransacked other government buildings and looted a bank. The protests started over the death on Saturday...
column10: Riot police officers in the southern city of Maan used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who set fire to the main police station and post office, ransacked other government buildings and looted a bank. The protests started over the death on Saturday of a 15-year-old boy held by the police on robbery charges. Relatives said he had been tortured to death; the police said he had died of kidney failure. In the past, unrest in Maan has spread throughout Jordan. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

column2: PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; DIET AND NUTRITION; RICE; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; GRAIN; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS; FOOD
column3: Haitian Warehouses Ransacked by Crowd
column9: The riot police fired bullets and tear gas today at hundreds of low-income Haitians who ransacked warehouses and demanded rice imported under a subsidized program called ''rice for peace.''    Protesters had poured out of Cité Soleil, a sprawling...
column10: The riot police fired bullets and tear gas today at hundreds of low-income Haitians who ransacked warehouses and demanded rice imported under a subsidized program called ''rice for peace.'' Protesters had poured out of Cité Soleil, a sprawling slum neighborhood, and surrounded hundreds of trucks and official state vehicles loaded with the rice. Rice is a staple in Haiti, where hunger is endemic.

column2: OPSAHL, MYRNA; OLSON, SARA JANE; HARRIS, WILLIAM; KILGORE, JAMES; HEARST, PATRICIA; BORTIN, MICHAEL; HARRIS, EMILY; CALIFORNIA; CROCKER NATIONAL BANK; SYMBIONESE LIBERATION ARMY; ROBBERIES AND THEFTS; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS
column3: A Symbionese Family Reunion
column9: One more time, state and federal authorities seem determined to reassemble the Symbionese Liberation Army. At this 26th-year reunion, the aging soldiers of the S.L.A. will face trial for the murder of Myrna Opsahl during a 1975 bank robbery in...
column10: One more time, state and federal authorities seem determined to reassemble the Symbionese Liberation Army. At this 26th-year reunion, the aging soldiers of the S.L.A. will face trial for the murder of Myrna Opsahl during a 1975 bank robbery in Carmichael, Calif. Patricia Hearst, in her 1982 book ''Every Secret Thing,'' accused Emily Harris of killing Mrs. Opsahl, and of saying later that ''it really doesn't matter'' and ''she was a bourgeois pig anyway.'' Now Mrs. Opsahl's son Jon says those two comments kept the family pushing for an arrest. ''Those words have always kind of haunted us,'' he said recently.

column2: NEW YORK CITY; WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Now Showing Daily: Well-Rehearsed Play of Discontent
column9: For all the appearances of casual disorder, it is a fairly smooth operation. Having learned from the raucous past, the activists who are gathering in New York to protest the World Economic Forum have put into place a system that addresses everything...
column10: For all the appearances of casual disorder, it is a fairly smooth operation. Having learned from the raucous past, the activists who are gathering in New York to protest the World Economic Forum have put into place a system that addresses everything from whom to call when in police custody to where to get the best vegetarian Thai food. There is an Internet forum for travel arrangements, and another for out-of-towners to find someplace to sleep. There are workshops on civil rights and rehearsals of certain chants, like ''We need a doctor!'' And for the last two nights, there have been the final ''spokes councils,'' at which representatives from dozens of organizations finalize plans for puppet performances, peaceful protests -- and mischief.

column2: POWELL, COLIN L; BUSH, GEORGE W; SOLANA, JAVIER; NEW YORK CITY; IRAQ; IRAN; NORTH KOREA; WASHINGTON (DC); WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; EUROPEAN UNION; WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; HIJACKING; TERRORISM
column3: ECONOMIC FORUM SHIFTS ITS FOCUS TO NEW DANGERS
column9: The world's most powerful policy makers and entrepreneurs, who have in the past used the World Economic Forum to promote the opportunities promised by technology and borderless commerce, seem more obsessed this year with their endless...
column10: The world's most powerful policy makers and entrepreneurs, who have in the past used the World Economic Forum to promote the opportunities promised by technology and borderless commerce, seem more obsessed this year with their endless vulnerabilities. In seminar rooms and in the hallways of the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan this week, the men and women who once trekked to Davos, Switzerland, to talk about how the Internet could revolutionize life in Indian villages have spent much of the last few days discussing more prosaic concerns: Keeping their corporate headquarters secure, their chemical and biological materials out of the wrong hands, and how to best fight terrorism.

column2: ARAFAT, YASIR; BUSH, GEORGE W; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
column3: Waiting Out the Siege, Arafat Remains Defiant
column9: Trapped in Ramallah, on the West Bank, shadowed by Israeli tanks, Yasir Arafat often recalls his decades-long duel with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, visitors to his compound say.    Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, considers himself the only Arab...
column10: Trapped in Ramallah, on the West Bank, shadowed by Israeli tanks, Yasir Arafat often recalls his decades-long duel with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, visitors to his compound say. Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, considers himself the only Arab general to have beaten Mr. Sharon, one of Israel's most storied fighters. A dramatic high point in his narrative is the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982. Besieged in Beirut, Mr. Arafat and his men were forced to evacuate, while Israel became mired in Lebanon until it withdrew unilaterally in May 2000.

column2: NEW YORK CITY; WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Mostly Pleased, but Knowing Few Heard Their Message
column9: They came, they marched, they chanted (and a few landed in jail). But as the last of the rallies and teach-ins petered out yesterday afternoon, the demonstrators who came to New York to rail against the World Economic Forum expressed exhilaration,...
column10: They came, they marched, they chanted (and a few landed in jail). But as the last of the rallies and teach-ins petered out yesterday afternoon, the demonstrators who came to New York to rail against the World Economic Forum expressed exhilaration, vindication and yet frustration, saying that their cause had produced larger-than-expected crowds and had defied predictions of violence -- but that their voices had fallen on largely indifferent ears. Still, after the ugly confrontations in Seattle and Genoa, Italy, organizers said that events in New York represented a turning point for a movement that has been so strongly associated with televised images of riot police and tear gas.

column10: Before Sept. 11, inspectors confiscated only two to three pounds' worth of contraband each day at Orlando International Airport. But since then, the daily haul has grown to approximately 20 pounds. The week these photos were taken, the most commonly seized items were nail scissors, but at least one turkey-basting needle and a vegetable peeler were also among the loot. column3: Seeking Damages From Iran, Ex-Marine Must Battle Bush Administration, Too
column9: Watching the destruction of the World Trade Center, recalling the bombing of the Marine Corps barracks in Beirut in 1983, the kidnapping and execution there of Lt. Col. William R. Higgins of the Marines in 1988 and other terrorist assaults, Rodney V....
column10: Watching the destruction of the World Trade Center, recalling the bombing of the Marine Corps barracks in Beirut in 1983, the kidnapping and execution there of Lt. Col. William R. Higgins of the Marines in 1988 and other terrorist assaults, Rodney V. Sickmann has been rethinking his role in one of the first acts by Islamic extremists against the United States, on Nov. 4, 1979, when he was a Marine guard at the United States Embassy in Tehran. On orders from his superiors, Sergeant Sickmann did not so much as lob a tear gas grenade at the mob coming to occupy the embassy. Now he thinks he and his fellow guards should have started shooting.

column2: OLMERT, EHUD; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; SUR BAHIR (JERUSALEM); PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; TERRORISM
column3: Mideast Turmoil: The Scene; Shock and Anger as Violence Invades an Arab Schoolyard
column9: As hundreds of Palestinian boys filled a schoolyard in the Arab village of Sur Bahir in southern Jerusalem this morning, the headmaster and two teachers noticed an unusual V-shaped contraption under a cluster of pine trees in a corner of the yard.   ...
column10: As hundreds of Palestinian boys filled a schoolyard in the Arab village of Sur Bahir in southern Jerusalem this morning, the headmaster and two teachers noticed an unusual V-shaped contraption under a cluster of pine trees in a corner of the yard. They saw two metallic-looking gray cones, each about a foot and a half long, lying on their sides next to a round object, apparently a timer, that was partly covered with soil. The wide ends of the cones, sealed with styrofoam, were aimed at different parts of the schoolyard, where more than 400 boys, mostly junior high school students, were milling about.

column2: MUGABE, ROBERT; TSVANGIRAI, MORGAN; ZIMBABWE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
column3: Voters Brave Long Lines And Threats In Zimbabwe
column9: Voters in Zimbabwe turned out today in what appeared to be record numbers for the first day of the country's long-awaited presidential election, hopeful that it would bring an end to years of political turmoil but fearful that it could touch off even...
column10: Voters in Zimbabwe turned out today in what appeared to be record numbers for the first day of the country's long-awaited presidential election, hopeful that it would bring an end to years of political turmoil but fearful that it could touch off even more trouble. Here in the capital, voters encountered lines that stretched for hundreds of yards, and tonight the justice minister said that he was prepared to allow voting beyond Sunday if it became clear that more time would be needed to accommodate the ''unprecedented'' turnout.

column2: MUGABE, ROBERT; ZIMBABWE
column3: The World; An Election, Yes. But Free and Fair?
column9: IN the fever of Zimbabwe's recent presidential campaign, more than 20 opposition party supporters were killed while the authorities looked the other way. Officials eliminated polling stations in opposition strongholds, effectively disenfranchising...
column10: IN the fever of Zimbabwe's recent presidential campaign, more than 20 opposition party supporters were killed while the authorities looked the other way. Officials eliminated polling stations in opposition strongholds, effectively disenfranchising thousands of voters, and the police fired choking clouds of tear gas to disperse hundreds more who were waiting to cast their ballots. Last week, President Robert Mugabe was declared the winner of the election, which was promptly condemned as illegitimate by President Bush, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and European election observers. But here in Africa, many leaders bent over backward to praise the election. South Africa's deputy president hailed it as ''free and fair.'' Election observers from Namibia said the outcome ''reflects the wishes of the people of Zimbabwe.'' The Organization of African Unity called it ''transparent and credible.''

column2: TOLEDO, ALEJANDRO; BUSH, GEORGE W; COLOMBIA; LATIN AMERICA; ANDES MOUNTAINS; ECUADOR; BOLIVIA; PERU; PEACE CORPS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; TREATIES; ANDEAN TRADE PREFERENCE ACT; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC
column3: Bush Vows to Help Peru Fight Rebels and Keep Andes Region Stable
column9: President Bush pledged today to help President Alejandro Toledo of Peru fight Marxist guerrillas on Peru's border with Colombia, saying that countering violence and drug trafficking in the Andes was crucial to maintaining the stability of the region....
column10: President Bush pledged today to help President Alejandro Toledo of Peru fight Marxist guerrillas on Peru's border with Colombia, saying that countering violence and drug trafficking in the Andes was crucial to maintaining the stability of the region. ''We will help him in this effort,'' Mr. Bush said at a joint news conference with Mr. Toledo at the Presidential Palace, only three days after a car bomb killed nine Peruvians outside the American Embassy. ''That's part of the reason why I'm here.''

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; ABDULLAH; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); ARAB LEAGUE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: As Arabs Seethe, Saudi Says Uprising Will Go On
column9: With his peace initiative looking forlorn, Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia warned today that no strike against Yasir Arafat would stop Palestinian violence while several Arab governments braced to contain popular outrage over the Israeli...
column10: With his peace initiative looking forlorn, Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia warned today that no strike against Yasir Arafat would stop Palestinian violence while several Arab governments braced to contain popular outrage over the Israeli incursion into Ramallah. Few Arab leaders expected Israel to welcome the peace proposal. But neither did they anticipate the overwhelming Israeli response to the suicide bombing in Netanya on Wednesday.

column2: EGYPT; IRAQ; KUWAIT; ISRAEL; CAIRO (EGYPT); AMMAN (JORDAN); JORDAN; LIBYA; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Across the Mideast, an Outpouring of Anger and a Show of Support
column9: Protests against Israel and the United States intensified across the Middle East today, with the police in Amman and Cairo firing water cannons and repeated bursts of tear gas to prevent demonstrators, mostly students, from surging through the...
column10: Protests against Israel and the United States intensified across the Middle East today, with the police in Amman and Cairo firing water cannons and repeated bursts of tear gas to prevent demonstrators, mostly students, from surging through the streets. The protests took myriad forms. In Iraq, Saddam Hussein demanded that Arabs take the unlikely step of cutting off oil sales to the West. In Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi led marchers through the streets of the capital, Tripoli, and challenged the Arab nations bordering Israel to open the frontiers to allow volunteer fighters to join the Palestinians.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-10    Israeli Push in West Bank; Criticism of Bush Grows  Israeli soldiers and tanks poured into the West Bank in an extensive military deployment, attacking the headquarters of the Palestinian security chief. At least 15 Israeli...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Israeli Push in West Bank; Criticism of Bush Grows Israeli soldiers and tanks poured into the West Bank in an extensive military deployment, attacking the headquarters of the Palestinian security chief. At least 15 Israeli soldiers were wounded in fighting. Palestinians killed two Israelis in attacks. A1 Gunmen in the West Bank killed 11 Palestinians suspected of being informers for Israel. A8 President Bush, facing criticism for his handling of the violence in the Middle East, expressed frustration that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, had not denounced the ''constant attacks'' of suicide bombers. A1 Protests against Israel and the United States intensified across the Middle East, with riot police officers in Amman and Cairo employing water cannons and tear gas. A9 President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is feeling undermined by Washington, upstaged by Saudi Arabia and vulnerable before an angry Arab population, officials in Cairo say. A1 France Acts on Anti-Semitism Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said 1,110 extra police officers would be deployed to guard France's synagogues and Jewish schools after two synagogues were destroyed, one by arson and another by firebombs. A3 World Briefing A6 NATION CHALLENGED A12-13 U.S. Force-Feeding Captives Who Won't Eat Doctors at the naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have begun force-feeding two prisoners from Afghanistan who had become dangerously malnourished after refusing to eat for most of a month, officials said. A12 Afghan Drug Shipment Seized The Turkish police and American drug agents seized 7.5 tons of unrefined morphine, worth an estimated $29 million, that was believed to have originated in Afghanistan and passed through Iran, in the biggest drug haul ever in Turkey, officials said. A12 Lindh Not Linked to Deaths Prosecutors acknowledged that they had no evidence linking John Walker Lindh with the death of any American, but the judge said no direct link with a specific death was necessary to prove that Mr. Lindh had joined a conspiracy to kill Americans. A13 Enforcing Deportation Orders Federal agents have started to track down and arrest Muslim immigrants who failed to comply with pre-Sept. 11 deportation orders. A13 NATIONAL A14-20 Justices Will Review A Three-Strikes Law The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether sentences of 25 years to life in prison imposed under California's three-strikes law are unconstitutionally cruel when the third strike is a minor property crime. A16 1930 Census Gets Personal The National Archives made public information on individuals and families gathered in the 1930 census, data kept secret by law for 72 years. A14 Church Settles for $1.2 Million Lori Capobianco Haigh, who says that a Roman Catholic priest in California began sexually abusing her in 1978, when she was 14, and that when she became pregnant at 16 he paid for an abortion, will get $1.2 million. A14 Wildlife Disease in Midwest Discoveries of sick wildlife in Colorado, Nebraska and Wisconsin raise fear chronic wasting disease may be more widespread than thought. A18 Dartmouth Killings Case Robert Tulloch, 18, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity in the killings of two Dartmouth professors, will change his plea, most likely to guilty or no contest, lawyers said. A20 SCIENCE TIMES F1-8 Move to Alter Climate Panel The Bush administration is said to be planning not to reappoint Dr. Robert T. Watson to lead an international panel assessing global warming. A10 Health & Fitness F5 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 In Towers' Collapse, Echoes of Earlier Disasters A draft of a federal report on the collapse of the twin towers of the World Trade Center notes that some of the problems encountered on Sept. 11 -- like the failure of sprayed-on fireproofing and poor radio communication inside the buildings -- had been encountered and cited in earlier high-rise fires, including one at 1 New York Plaza in August 1970. A1 EDUCATION CUNY to Get Governors Island President Bush said the federal government would turn over Governors Island to New York in a deal that state and city officials said would allow the former Coast Guard base to be transformed into a CUNY campus. B1 FASHION B9 ARTS E1-9 And This Time She Means It Beverly Sills, 72, said that she would definitely resign as the chairwoman of Lincoln Center on May 1, a move that she has been dissuaded from making before. She will retain a nonvoting seat on the board. B1 OBITUARIES A21 SPORTS D1-10 Maryland Takes the Title Maryland beat Indiana, 64-52, to claim the N.C.A.A. national title in men's basketball. D1 Mets Win Opener at Home The Mets beat Pittsburgh, 6-2, at Shea. The Yankees opened their season with a 10-3 loss in Baltimore. D1 Security measures took fans by surprise at Shea Stadium, causing many to miss the early innings. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Andersen Rejected Probation The Justice Department was willing to consider deferring or dropping prosecution of Arthur Andersen if it admitted it had illegally destroyed documents and agreed to a form of probation. But executives believed such an admission would be as harmful as an indictment or guilty plea. A1 Xerox Fined $10 Million Xerox will restate its financial statements dating back to 1997 and pay a $10 million fine to settle a fraud complaint that it expects to be filed by the S.E.C. The fine would be the largest in an S.E.C. enforcement case involving financial reporting. C1 Adelphia Delays Annual Report Adelphia Communications, which disclosed last week that it had $2.3 billion in debts that it might have to pay but had not put on its balance sheet, said it was delaying its annual report to determine the proper accounting. C1 Business Digest C1 World Business W1 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Time for American leadership; new hope for Governors Island; anticipating another year of the Yankee dynasty. Columns: Paul Krugman, Nicholas D. Kristof. Crossword E8 TV Listings E9 Public Lives B2 Weather D10

column3: As Crisis Deepens, Mubarak Finds He Is on the Sidelines
column9: After more than 20 years of standing alongside American presidents in building peace in the region, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is feeling undermined by Washington, upstaged by Saudi Arabia and vulnerable before an angry Arab population,...
column10: After more than 20 years of standing alongside American presidents in building peace in the region, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is feeling undermined by Washington, upstaged by Saudi Arabia and vulnerable before an angry Arab population, officials here say. That anger spilled into the streets here today as riot police officers were forced to fire tear gas and water cannons at large numbers of protesters trying to reach the Israeli Embassy. Forced back, the crowd vandalized a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet instead.

column2: ARAFAT, YASIR; EGYPT; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); CAIRO (EGYPT); JORDAN; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Anger in the Streets Is Exerting Pressure On Arab Moderates
column9: Thousands of Jordanians braved a frigid downpour to march on Parliament today, demanding that the kingdom sever ties with Israel, while protesters in Egypt packed the streets around Cairo University for a fifth straight day.    Up to now the anger in...
column10: Thousands of Jordanians braved a frigid downpour to march on Parliament today, demanding that the kingdom sever ties with Israel, while protesters in Egypt packed the streets around Cairo University for a fifth straight day. Up to now the anger in the streets has not gone beyond the control of any of the autocratic governments in the region. But officials spend each day and much of the night monitoring television reports or checking their mobile phones for the urgent headlines flashed there by subscription services.

column2: DIXON, JUAN; UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND; INDIANA UNIVERSITY; NCAA BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT; BASKETBALL
column3: Dixon Finally Falters, at a Celebration
column9: Maryland's Juan Dixon, wearing a basketball net around his neck, had a hard time containing himself yesterday as he spoke to 5,000 cheering fans in College Park, Md. The night before, he led the Terrapins to their first N.C.A.A. basketball title with...
column10: Maryland's Juan Dixon, wearing a basketball net around his neck, had a hard time containing himself yesterday as he spoke to 5,000 cheering fans in College Park, Md. The night before, he led the Terrapins to their first N.C.A.A. basketball title with a 64-52 victory over Indiana. ''You guys are going to make me be all emotional,'' said Dixon, the tournament's most valuable player, before returning to his seat and burying his face in his hands. Later, Dixon told reporters: ''It was my last night in a Maryland uniform; I'm hurt. It's bittersweet for me to go out on top with a national title.''

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; WEST BANK; BETHLEHEM (WEST BANK); LEBANON; SYRIA; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); HEBRON (WEST BANK); NABLUS (WEST BANK); HEZBOLLAH; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; PALESTINIANS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
column3: Israeli Armor Units Continue Sweeping Through West Bank
column9: A force of Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rumbled tonight into Nablus, the second largest city in the West Bank, continuing a relentless sweep even as international criticism gathered force and some Israelis themselves began questioning the...
column10: A force of Israeli tanks and armored vehicles rumbled tonight into Nablus, the second largest city in the West Bank, continuing a relentless sweep even as international criticism gathered force and some Israelis themselves began questioning the operation. The occupation of Nablus meant that six days into the operation, the Israeli Army was in control of all major Palestinian-ruled centers in the West Bank except Hebron. In each city the army was proving more intense, ruthless and thorough than in any prior incursion, including the raids last month.

column9: Egypt, Israel's largest and most important peace partner, downgraded its relations with the Israelis today in a pointed warning that the intensifying war against the Palestinian Authority of Yasir Arafat was ratcheting up Arab resentment to dangerous...
column10: Egypt, Israel's largest and most important peace partner, downgraded its relations with the Israelis today in a pointed warning that the intensifying war against the Palestinian Authority of Yasir Arafat was ratcheting up Arab resentment to dangerous levels. The Egyptian government said that it was suspending ''all contacts'' with the Israeli government, but that it would keep open a diplomatic channel to deal with the crisis in the West Bank.

column10: Protesters breached the walls of the American Embassy in the tiny Persian Gulf island kingdom of Bahrain today, smashing windows and burning vehicles before retreating under a hail of tear gas and rubber bullets shot by policemen aided by American marines. There were protests across the Muslim world, underscoring the risks facing moderate governments in Muslim countries as the Israeli offensive drags on.

column3: Death in Bahrain Brings Demand That U.S. Leave
column9: Muhammad Jumaa, a 24-year-old hospital worker, died today, two days after being shot in the head at a demonstration that penetrated the grounds of the American Embassy here, his death feeding a brooding resentment of the extensive American presence...
column10: Muhammad Jumaa, a 24-year-old hospital worker, died today, two days after being shot in the head at a demonstration that penetrated the grounds of the American Embassy here, his death feeding a brooding resentment of the extensive American presence on this Persian Gulf island. ''America's blind support for Israel and its silence encourage Israel to kill more Palestinians, just as America did in Afghanistan and Iraq,'' said Ibrahim Abdullah, one of a steady stream of mourners who made their way to the dead man's dusty grave on the edge of a poor village populated by Shiite Muslims just north of Manama, the capital.

column10: Israeli tanks rev their engines all night long outside Yasir Arafat's embattled compound in Ramallah. Some nights tear gas or stun grenades are hurled at the building. On Saturday night, the army fired a missile into one of the walls. People in the compound insist that the intent is to deprive those inside of sleep, though the Israeli Army denies that. It is all a part of life now in Mr. Arafat's compound, more than a week under siege.

column9: At least two people were killed and hundreds more were injured today as increasingly violent protests against the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories roiled the Arab world.    In Egypt, a university student was reported killed and more than...
column10: At least two people were killed and hundreds more were injured today as increasingly violent protests against the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories roiled the Arab world. In Egypt, a university student was reported killed and more than 100 other people were injured when the police fired buckshot, tear gas and water cannons to quell one of several large, angry demonstrations timed to coincide with a visit by the American secretary of state, Colin L. Powell.

column2: EGYPT; ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; ISRAEL-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Egyptians Protest Against Israel and U.S., but Fear Takes Edge Off Bravado
column9: Just after 2:30 this afternoon, the heavy iron gates of the University of Alexandria swung open and waves of angry students swept out into the street.    At either end of the wide avenue that runs past the faded yellow brick of the law school, riot...
column10: Just after 2:30 this afternoon, the heavy iron gates of the University of Alexandria swung open and waves of angry students swept out into the street. At either end of the wide avenue that runs past the faded yellow brick of the law school, riot policemen in black helmets fingered their truncheons and shotguns and their sheathed bayonets. On Tuesday, at least one student was killed and 200 were injured when the police fired tear gas, buckshot and rubber bullets into a huge crowd of protesting students. It was one of the most violent confrontations between Egyptian protesters and the police in years.

column2: PARTHENIOS; MADANI, MUHAMMAD AL-; SABBARA, AMJAD; WEST BANK; BETHLEHEM (WEST BANK); ISRAEL; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; PALESTINIANS; CHURCH OF THE NATIVITY (BETHLEHEM); GREEK ORTHODOX CHURCH
column3: Clerics Tell Of Ritual And Danger Under Siege
column9: Inside the Church of the Nativity, a dozen wounded Palestinian gunmen are being cared for by a nun in the back of the grotto, the site where Christians believe the Virgin Mary gave birth. Palestinian fighters walk around the basilica with assault...
column10: Inside the Church of the Nativity, a dozen wounded Palestinian gunmen are being cared for by a nun in the back of the grotto, the site where Christians believe the Virgin Mary gave birth. Palestinian fighters walk around the basilica with assault rifles slung across their backs, sleeping on pews or on the floor when not on watch duty. And the monks and nuns generally keep to themselves, venturing from their monasteries into the church itself only two to three times a day to check the holy site, light oil lamps and conduct services.

column9: A group of high-ranking generals broke ranks Thursday night to demand the resignation of President Hugo Chávez after at least 10 people were killed and more than 100 wounded when hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on the presidential...
column10: A group of high-ranking generals broke ranks Thursday night to demand the resignation of President Hugo Chávez after at least 10 people were killed and more than 100 wounded when hundreds of thousands of protesters marched on the presidential palace. Among those who rebelled was the army commander, Gen. Efraín Vásquez Velasco. ''Mr. President, I was loyal to the end, but today's deaths cannot be tolerated,'' he said in a news conference this evening.

column2: POWELL, COLIN L; ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS
column3: The World; A Terrible Yearning for War and Peace
column9: WITH Israeli machine-gun fire still slicing through the sour smell of tear gas in the air here, it is hard to imagine a time -- such a short time ago, really -- when Israelis and Palestinians talked about reconciliation without bitterness, or even...
column10: WITH Israeli machine-gun fire still slicing through the sour smell of tear gas in the air here, it is hard to imagine a time -- such a short time ago, really -- when Israelis and Palestinians talked about reconciliation without bitterness, or even irony. Now, despite a yearning on both sides for tranquillity -- maybe in part because of it -- suicide bombings and Israeli incursions have pretty much put an end to such talk, and perhaps even to the dream.

column9: After more than two weeks under curfew in Ramallah, Adam Shapiro and his fiancée came here this week for a brief respite and some organizational work before returning to the battered West Bank city that is still occupied by Israeli troops.    At an...
column10: After more than two weeks under curfew in Ramallah, Adam Shapiro and his fiancée came here this week for a brief respite and some organizational work before returning to the battered West Bank city that is still occupied by Israeli troops. At an East Jerusalem hotel, the couple was fielding calls on three cellphones from fellow activists in West Bank cities that have been invaded by the Israelis. Later, they helped arrange shipments of food and medical supplies to Palestinians confined to their homes.

column2: SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TELEPHONES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS
column3: Secret Hideouts for the Rich and Scared; In Homes and Apartments, Safe Rooms Can Withstand Small Rockets
column9: Gazing at the movie screen, the audience watched tensely as the actress Jodie Foster scrambled into the bunker-like room, secured the door and snatched the emergency telephone for help in the new movie, ''Panic Room,'' a thriller about a woman under...
column10: Gazing at the movie screen, the audience watched tensely as the actress Jodie Foster scrambled into the bunker-like room, secured the door and snatched the emergency telephone for help in the new movie, ''Panic Room,'' a thriller about a woman under siege in a fortified hiding place in her Manhattan brownstone. The look on her face said it all -- no dial tone -- and the audience let out a collective gasp. Well, except for Robert Davis, who snorted so loudly that people turned around in their seats to see what was going on.

column2: CHIRAC, JACQUES; JOSPIN, LIONEL; LE PEN, JEAN-MARIE; EUROPE; FRANCE; EUROPEAN UNION; PUBLIC OPINION; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; ELECTION ISSUES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONCENTRATION CAMPS; ELECTIONS; CRIME AND CRIMINALS; NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES
column3: Extreme Rightist Eclipses Socialist To Qualify for Runoff in France
column9: In a major upset not predicted in weeks of opinion polling, the extreme rightist Jean-Marie Le Pen qualified today to face President Jacques Chirac, a conservative, in the runoff for the French presidency next month.    The 73-year-old Mr. Le Pen,...
column10: In a major upset not predicted in weeks of opinion polling, the extreme rightist Jean-Marie Le Pen qualified today to face President Jacques Chirac, a conservative, in the runoff for the French presidency next month. The 73-year-old Mr. Le Pen, who once called the Nazi gas chambers ''a detail in history,'' benefited from the huge field of candidates that split the vote, an apathetic electorate and a wave of anti-crime fervor to edge past Prime Minister Lionel Jospin.

column3: Palestinian Militant Group Says It Will Limit Bombings
column9: Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, a Palestinian nationalist group responsible for a number of suicide bombings in Israel this year and the only group to deploy women as bombers, said through a commander today that it would not send more bombers into Israel...
column10: Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, a Palestinian nationalist group responsible for a number of suicide bombings in Israel this year and the only group to deploy women as bombers, said through a commander today that it would not send more bombers into Israel to kill civilians. But the commander said suicide bombings were being planned against Jewish settlements and Israeli military targets.

column9: French political leaders buried their differences today in a bid to present a united front against Jean-Marie Le Pen, the rightist leader whose qualification for the second round of the presidential election has convulsed the country.    Dominique...
column10: French political leaders buried their differences today in a bid to present a united front against Jean-Marie Le Pen, the rightist leader whose qualification for the second round of the presidential election has convulsed the country. Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a Socialist and former finance minister, said he would support the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, in the second round because ''It is the honor of our country that is at stake.''

column9: Sometimes Scotty Bowman made hockey history assertively and sometimes he just wandered into it.    He made it again Thursday night when he set the coaching record for Stanley Cup championships at nine and then immediately announced his retirement. As...
column10: Sometimes Scotty Bowman made hockey history assertively and sometimes he just wandered into it. He made it again Thursday night when he set the coaching record for Stanley Cup championships at nine and then immediately announced his retirement. As for wandering, he told one of his intriguing anecdotes a few hours before his Detroit Red Wings clinched the Cup by beating the Carolina Hurricanes, 3-1, in Game 5 of the finals here at Joe Louis Arena.

column3: Peruvians Riot Over Planned Sale of 2 Regional Power Plants
column9: Hundreds of troops took control of Peru's second-largest city today after the government imposed a state of emergency to end violent protests against the sale of two state-owned electricity generating companies.    The protests, which began on Friday...
column10: Hundreds of troops took control of Peru's second-largest city today after the government imposed a state of emergency to end violent protests against the sale of two state-owned electricity generating companies. The protests, which began on Friday and are the largest since President Alejandro Toledo took office 11 months ago, prompted the government on Sunday to ban public protests and suspend constitutional guarantees for 30 days in the city, Arequipa, and its province.
