column10: Like a true spy, Franklin Chaparro was careful not to give away too many details about his assignment. Mr. Chaparro, who once was the government's chief explosives specialist and director of Venezuela's state intelligence agency, has begun using his expertise as the architect of his neighborhood watch association.

column2: MY BROTHER: THE MAKING OF A TERRORIST (BOOK); EL-WAFI, AICHA; MOUSSAOUI, ZACARIAS; MOUSSAOUI, ABD-SAMAD; NEW YORK CITY; WASHINGTON (DC); NARBONNE (FRANCE); WORLD TRADE CENTER (NYC); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; HIJACKING; DISCRIMINATION; TERRORISM
column3: Everybody Has a Mother
column9: Aicha el-Wafi, mother of the accused terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui, has just finished a crème caramel and is on her way out of a restaurant in Narbonne, France, when a waiter stops her. ''I saw your son the other day on television,'' he says. ''He...
column10: Aicha el-Wafi, mother of the accused terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui, has just finished a crème caramel and is on her way out of a restaurant in Narbonne, France, when a waiter stops her. ''I saw your son the other day on television,'' he says. ''He was very good -- very interesting.'' He's not referring to Zacarias, who is being held in isolation in Virginia, charged with conspiracy in the Sept. 11 attacks. The waiter is talking about her other son, Abd-Samad Moussaoui, author of ''Zacarias, My Brother: The Making of a Terrorist,'' an account of his younger brother's life until 1995, when Zacarias was 27, after which the two fell permanently out of touch. Neither Abd-Samad nor the boys' mother knew what had become of Zacarias until Sept. 12, 2001, when the television news started flashing a mug shot of the man thought to be the ''20th hijacker.'' His head was shaved, and his face had gotten beefier, but the Moussaoui family knew it was Zacarias. ''You think it was very interesting?'' el-Wafi says with an engaging smile. Dressed in a camel's hair coat and leopard-print scarf, she shifts her weight to a more comfortable stance; she might be there awhile. Her tone shifts as well, taking on an edge. ''You think it was very impressive? You think it was 'très bien'? Let me ask you something: Is that what you would do if your brother was in jail? Would you write a book telling the world your brother is a racist, an extremist, denouncing your brother, complaining about your mother? Is that what you would do?''

column2: SANCHEZ DE LOZADA, GONZALO; LA PAZ (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; TAXATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: 10 Die as Bolivian Troops Fire on Striking Police and Protesters
column9: Striking police officers and civilian protesters clashed with government troops today, leaving at least 10 people dead, 53 injured and the ruling party headquarters and the main jail in flames here in the capital.    Government troops fired tear gas,...
column10: Striking police officers and civilian protesters clashed with government troops today, leaving at least 10 people dead, 53 injured and the ruling party headquarters and the main jail in flames here in the capital. Government troops fired tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition at the demonstrators, who stormed the presidential palace to protest government proposals to raise taxes and cut spending on social programs.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; HUSSEIN, SADDAM; IRAQ; GREAT BRITAIN; CZECH REPUBLIC; ATOMIC WEAPONS; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: From New York To Melbourne, Cries for Peace
column9: Confronting America's countdown to war, throngs of chanting, placard-waving demonstrators converged on New York and scores of cities across the United States, Europe and Asia yesterday in a global daisy chain of largely peaceful protests against the...
column10: Confronting America's countdown to war, throngs of chanting, placard-waving demonstrators converged on New York and scores of cities across the United States, Europe and Asia yesterday in a global daisy chain of largely peaceful protests against the Bush administration's threatened invasion of Iraq. Three years after vast crowds turned out around the world to celebrate the new millennium, millions gathered again yesterday in a darker mood of impending conflict, forming a patchwork of demonstrations that together, organizers said, made up the largest, most diverse peace protest since the Vietnam War.

column2: AMANDLA! (MOVIE); MASEKELA, HUGH; HIRSCH, LEE; SOUTH AFRICA; MOTION PICTURES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DOCUMENTARY FILMS AND PROGRAMS
column3: With Fury Silenced, Song Raised Its Voice
column9: TEN years ago, a 20-year-old New Yorker named Lee Hirsch left for Johannesburg with $600 in his pocket and the phone numbers of two local contacts. Mr. Hirsch was on a mission: he had become obsessed with the popular music that had sprung up around...
column10: TEN years ago, a 20-year-old New Yorker named Lee Hirsch left for Johannesburg with $600 in his pocket and the phone numbers of two local contacts. Mr. Hirsch was on a mission: he had become obsessed with the popular music that had sprung up around the antiapartheid movement, and he was determined to make a film about it. If his undertaking seemed quixotic -- Mr. Hirsch was white, had never before been to South Africa and had no previous research to guide him -- well, he thought, so be it. ''The music just grabbed me,'' said Mr. Hirsch, now 30, in his Upper West Side apartment. ''There was an urgency in the music that appealed to me, and I wanted to learn more, I wanted to hear more.''

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; HUSSEIN, SADDAM; IRAQ; ATOMIC WEAPONS; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: In Word, Song and Sign, Demonstrators Across the United States Say No to an Invasion of Iraq
column9: Shortly before setting off this afternoon to strut down the spine of this city's neighborhood of South Asian restaurants and shops, Cynthia Castiglione came to Mark Messing, the leader of the newly formed Antiwar Marching Band, with a suggestion.   ...
column10: Shortly before setting off this afternoon to strut down the spine of this city's neighborhood of South Asian restaurants and shops, Cynthia Castiglione came to Mark Messing, the leader of the newly formed Antiwar Marching Band, with a suggestion. ''What about a fallout?'' she asked. ''At one point, we all just die.'' Mr. Messing agreed, noting, ''We'll need a cue for that.''

column2: CACTUS FLOWER (MOVIE); HAWN, GOLDIE; MOTION PICTURES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; APPAREL
column3: Good as Goldie
column9: ''I always thought she was an exalted blonde. She was a deeply joyful blonde! I never thought of her as dumb.'' -- Goldie Hawn, on her screen persona   The morning after she received an Oscar for her film role as Walter Matthau's young lover in...
column10: ''I always thought she was an exalted blonde. She was a deeply joyful blonde! I never thought of her as dumb.'' -- Goldie Hawn, on her screen persona The morning after she received an Oscar for her film role as Walter Matthau's young lover in ''Cactus Flower,'' Goldie Hawn got a call from her publicist telling her that she had won. ''Oh, my God, they were on last night!'' shrieked the ingénue. ''I totally forgot.''

column3: MetroStars' Bradley Continues Casting Call
column9: MetroStars Coach BOB BRADLEY took a page from the tattered and maligned playbook of SVEN-GORAN ERIKSSON, England's national team coach, when he also experimented and sent out two teams in a preseason exhibition against the Chicago Fire, a 2-0 loss,...
column10: MetroStars Coach BOB BRADLEY took a page from the tattered and maligned playbook of SVEN-GORAN ERIKSSON, England's national team coach, when he also experimented and sent out two teams in a preseason exhibition against the Chicago Fire, a 2-0 loss, in Florida over the weekend. The difference is that while Eriksson was excoriated for his novel approach in using 22 players, changing the entire team after 45 minutes, in a friendly against Australia on Feb. 12, Bradley has little choice if he wants to get a good look at the 29 players on his bulging roster less than two months before the start of Major League Soccer's eighth season.

column2: KHADER, SAMI; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; QALQILIYA (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; ZOOS; EMBALMING; MUSEUMS
column3: Qalqiliya Journal; In the Man-Ravaged West Bank, a Petrified Zoo
column9: Palestinians here say that the zebras succumbed to tear gas and that the giraffe died when he collapsed in terror during a burst of gunfire. The lion, they say, died of old age.    But with Qalqiliya enclosed now by Israeli fences, ditches and...
column10: Palestinians here say that the zebras succumbed to tear gas and that the giraffe died when he collapsed in terror during a burst of gunfire. The lion, they say, died of old age. But with Qalqiliya enclosed now by Israeli fences, ditches and soldiers, its tourists gone and its economy in ruins, the zookeepers have not been able to bring in any new animals.

column2: CORRIE, RACHEL; ISRAEL; GAZA STRIP; RAFAH (GAZA); INTERNATIONAL SOLIDARITY MOVEMENT; ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION
column3: Israeli Army Bulldozer Kills American Protesting in Gaza
column9: An Israeli Army bulldozer today crushed to death an American woman who had kneeled in the dirt to prevent the armored vehicle from destroying a Palestinian home in the southern Gaza Strip, witnesses and hospital officials said.    The Israeli...
column10: An Israeli Army bulldozer today crushed to death an American woman who had kneeled in the dirt to prevent the armored vehicle from destroying a Palestinian home in the southern Gaza Strip, witnesses and hospital officials said. The Israeli military said the driver of the bulldozer had not seen the woman, and called it a ''very regrettable accident.'' The woman, Rachel Corrie, 23, from Olympia, Wash., was among eight Americans and Britons who had been acting has ''human shields'' to try to stop the almost daily house demolitions by Israeli forces in Rafah, a town on Gaza's border with Egypt. When the bulldozer approached a house today, Ms. Corrie, who was wearing a bright orange jacket, dropped to her knees, a practice that members of the group to which she belonged, the International Solidarity Movement, have used repeatedly, her colleagues at the scene said. As the bulldozer reached her without slowing up, she began to rise, but was trapped beneath a pile of dirt generated by its blade and the blade itself, said one member of the group, Tom Dale, who said he was standing about 30 feet away. ''We were shouting and waving our arms at the driver,'' said Mr. Dale, who is British. ''We even had a megaphone. But the bulldozer kept going until she was under the body or the tracks of the bulldozer.'' The bulldozer stopped for a few seconds and pulled back, Mr. Dale added. Her colleagues rushed to Ms. Corrie, who was bleeding from the head and face and badly wounded, but still breathing. An ambulance took her to Najar Hospital, where she died. She had a fractured skull and other injuries, said Dr. Ali Moussa, a hospital administrator. At the time Ms. Corrie was run over, she was in an open area in front of the house, Mr. Dale said. The bulldozer came from some distance away, and ''there was nothing to obscure the driver's view,'' he said. But Capt. Jacob Dallal, an army spokesman, said that the armored bulldozer had small windows and limited visibility, and that the driver had not been aware that Ms. Corrie was in his path. In a statement, the Israeli military said soldiers ''were dealing with a group of protesters who were acting very irresponsibly, putting everyone in danger -- the Palestinians, themselves and our forces -- by intentionally placing themselves in a combat zone.'' About an hour before Ms. Corrie was killed, troops fired tear gas and shot into the air during a confrontation with the protesters at a nearby house, both Mr. Dale and the Israeli military said. The International Solidarity Movement is made up mostly of Americans and Europeans in their 20's and 30's who are sympathetic to the Palestinians and oppose the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. They have repeatedly placed themselves in front of Israeli forces operating in those areas. Last May, several members dashed past Israeli troops into the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, where Palestinian gunmen had been holed up for more than a month. The protesters remained for several days, until the standoff ended with the surrender of the gunmen. Ms. Corrie, who was to graduate from the Evergreen State College in Olympia this year, had been in Rafah for two months, living with Palestinians in areas where homes were being demolished, her colleagues said. In Olympia, Colin Reese, a student at Evergreen State and a close friend of Ms. Corrie, said she had focused much of her studies on community organizing. Describing her work in Gaza, he said, ''She was particularly touched by the Palestinian situation and wanted to use her privilege as an American citizen to help defend against the Israeli occupation.'' One of Ms. Corrie's teachers at Evergreen was Larry Mosqueda, a professor of political economy and social change, who said her work in Gaza was a reflection of lessons taught at Evergreen that encourage students to put their education to practical use while still in college. ''She has a strong sense of social justice,'' he said. ''Basically, she wanted to do something about it instead of just talk about it.'' In an e-mail message this month, Ms. Corrie described a Feb. 14 standoff in which members of her group ''stood in the path of the bulldozers and were physically pushed with the shovel backwards, taking shelter in a house.'' She added that ''the bulldozer then proceeded on its course, demolishing one side of the house'' with the protesters still inside. The Israeli Army and Palestinian militants wage frequent gun battles in Rafah. An unarmed Palestinian man was shot and killed by Israeli fire today in the town, said Palestinian security sources and hospital officials. The Israeli Army said it was checking the report. The military has flattened dozens of homes in Rafah, some because militants were using them for cover. The Israeli authorities have said the International Solidarity Movement's protesters prevent soldiers from acting against militants, and they have deported some members. Demonstrators have been hurt on a number of occasions, but Ms. Corrie was the first one killed. The Israeli troops ''have shot over our heads, and shot near our feet -- they have fired tear gas at us,'' said Michael Shaik, media coordinator for the group. ''But we thought we had an understanding. We didn't think they would kill us.''

column2: YEMEN; IRAQ; EUROPE; MIDDLE EAST; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; IRAQ-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: Crowds Protest Iraq War In Cities Around World
column9: Demonstrations against the American-led war in Iraq roiled cities around the world today, with the riot police in several Arab nations turning water cannons, tear gas, batons and finally bullets on unruly protesters who surged by the thousands into...
column10: Demonstrations against the American-led war in Iraq roiled cities around the world today, with the riot police in several Arab nations turning water cannons, tear gas, batons and finally bullets on unruly protesters who surged by the thousands into the streets after Friday Prayers. But the reaction in some countries was more muted than expected.

column2: IRAQ; ISRAEL; HAMAS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; IRAQ-INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS-US; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: Hamas Urges Iraqis to Make Suicide Attacks on the Invaders
column9: As Muslim preachers in the Gaza Strip inveighed today against war in Iraq as a war on Islam, leaders of the Palestinian group Hamas urged Iraqis to use suicide as a weapon against invading troops.    ''As long as there is an American aggression...
column10: As Muslim preachers in the Gaza Strip inveighed today against war in Iraq as a war on Islam, leaders of the Palestinian group Hamas urged Iraqis to use suicide as a weapon against invading troops. ''As long as there is an American aggression against a Muslim country, Iraqis must defend themselves, using all means,'' Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, a Hamas leader, said in a telephone interview from Gaza City. He said the Iraqis should conduct ''martyrdom operations, using explosive belts against the American and British soldiers.''

column2: TONGUE TIED (BOOK); SOUL CIRCUS (BOOK); VANISHED MAN, THE (BOOK); HEX (BOOK); KEEPING WATCH (BOOK); ESTEP, MAGGIE; KING, LAURIE R; STEVENSON, RICHARD; PELECANOS, GEORGE P; DEAVER, JEFFERY; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
column3: CRIME
column9: The characters in George P. Pelecanos's proletarian crime novels all work hard for a living, but none of the honest entrepreneurs in the Anacostia neighborhood of Washington run their operations with the ruthless efficiency of the gun merchants and...
column10: The characters in George P. Pelecanos's proletarian crime novels all work hard for a living, but none of the honest entrepreneurs in the Anacostia neighborhood of Washington run their operations with the ruthless efficiency of the gun merchants and drug dealers in SOUL CIRCUS (Little, Brown, $24.95). With the territorial gang lord Granville Oliver out of commission and on trial for his life, business ethics dictate that two rival gangs should beef up their arsenals and fight it out for his drug trade. To the despair of Derek Strange, Pelecanos's salt-of-the-earth private investigator, more children are recruited for the gang war, and the only person who really benefits is Ulysses Foreman, the local gun dealer and an expert in supply and demand. ''Long as kids down here had no fathers and were looking to belong to something,'' Foreman says, ''then there was gonna be gangs and a need for guns.'' Pelecanos is fascinated with the way things work, and he takes apart the gun trade like an urban anthropologist, fitting the pieces into the drug business and the gang culture with an exactness that is breathtaking -- and depressing. At the same time, he treats his criminals like human beings, talking their talk, driving their cars, listening to their music, getting into their world with something that can only be called sympathy.

column3: Michigan State Fans Go on Rampage
column9: Michigan State basketball fans overturned four cars, tipped vending machines and set fires in trash bins in East Lansing, Mich., after the Spartans lost in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday.     Police officers in riot gear dispersed the crowd using...
column10: Michigan State basketball fans overturned four cars, tipped vending machines and set fires in trash bins in East Lansing, Mich., after the Spartans lost in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday. Police officers in riot gear dispersed the crowd using tear gas. Seven people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct, six of them Michigan State students, police said.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; IRAQ; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; TEAR GAS
column3: U.S. Use of Tear Gas Could Violate Treaty, Critics Say
column9: President Bush has authorized American military forces to use tear gas in Iraq, the Pentagon says, a development that some weapons experts say other countries might see as a breach of the Chemical Weapons Convention.    The Defense Department said...
column10: President Bush has authorized American military forces to use tear gas in Iraq, the Pentagon says, a development that some weapons experts say other countries might see as a breach of the Chemical Weapons Convention. The Defense Department said tear gas, which has been issued to American troops, would be used only to save civilian lives and in accordance with the convention, ratified by the United States in 1997. But critics say any battlefield use of tear gas would violate the treaty, offend crucial allies, including Britain, and hand Saddam Hussein a possible pretext for using chemical weapons against the United States.

column3: With Current War, Professors Protest, As Students Debate
column9: It is not easy being an old lefty on campus in this war.     At the University of Wisconsin at Madison, awash in antiwar protests in the Vietnam era, a columnist for a student newspaper took a professor to task for canceling classes to protest the...
column10: It is not easy being an old lefty on campus in this war. At the University of Wisconsin at Madison, awash in antiwar protests in the Vietnam era, a columnist for a student newspaper took a professor to task for canceling classes to protest the war in Iraq, saying the university should reprimand her and refund tuition for the missed periods.

column9: During a momentous ceremony in the cradle of democracy, the leaders of 10 countries signed treaties here today to join the European Union, extending its reach to a broad swath of Europe once allied with the Soviet Union.    At the same time, leaders...
column10: During a momentous ceremony in the cradle of democracy, the leaders of 10 countries signed treaties here today to join the European Union, extending its reach to a broad swath of Europe once allied with the Soviet Union. At the same time, leaders of the 15 countries already in the union sought to bridge the profound rifts between them that had been opened by the war in Iraq.

column10: A man was shot dead when a gunman fired on opponents of President Hugo Chávez after tens of thousands of pro- and anti-Chávez demonstrators jammed Caracas streets in competing May Day marches. In confused running skirmishes, the police fired tear gas after the shooting to disperse rival bands of demonstrators who clashed in the capital with volleys of rocks and bottles.

column2: BERKELEY ART MUSEUM; PACIFIC FILM ARCHIVE; UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA; BLACK PANTHERS; PHOTOGRAPHY
column3: The Black Panthers' Beauty Moment
column9: FOR certain Americans, the Black Panthers, one the most potent revolutionary groups of the late 1960's, were very over by 1970. That was the year Tom Wolfe's ''Radical Chic & Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers'' appeared. His account of media-savvy young...
column10: FOR certain Americans, the Black Panthers, one the most potent revolutionary groups of the late 1960's, were very over by 1970. That was the year Tom Wolfe's ''Radical Chic & Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers'' appeared. His account of media-savvy young African-Americans wearing berets and shades and hustling a scam, and of rich white types (Leonard Bernstein, Carter Burden) tripping all over themselves in support, was the Panther story people had been waiting for: a Rowan and Martin ''Laugh-In'' skit. A spoof, a circus, a farce. Mortified, the haute bourgeois Left turned off its largesse. The Panthers dropped in status from superstars to superfluous. ''Delicious,'' purred The Wall Street Journal of Mr. Wolfe's caustic little neo-conservative classic. The mainstream press did nothing to help Black Panther Party credibility. The party's membership, and its neighborhood-based food and medical programs, grew. So did F.B.I. surveillance and infiltration. (J. Edgar Hoover called the Panthers ''the greatest threat to the internal security of the United States.'')

column3: Troops and Police Clash With Protesters as Unrest Grows in Peru
column9: Soldiers fired into the air and police used tear gas and water hoses today in violent clashes across Peru with protesters who vowed to continue crippling strikes despite a government state of emergency.    The police said at least seven farmers were...
column10: Soldiers fired into the air and police used tear gas and water hoses today in violent clashes across Peru with protesters who vowed to continue crippling strikes despite a government state of emergency. The police said at least seven farmers were wounded in Barranca, north of Lima, as soldiers fired shots to disperse rock-throwing protesters a day after President Alejandro Toledo imposed a 30-day state of emergency, banning strikers from the streets and giving the military and the police more powers to use force and conduct searches.

column2: TOLEDO, ALEJANDRO; PUNO (PERU); AREQUIPA (PERU); LIMA (PERU); PERU; LABOR; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Student Killed As Protesters Defy President
column9: A student was killed and nearly 50 people injured as demonstrators clashed with troops in some of the worst violence since President Alejandro Toledo declared a state of emergency this week to curb a wave of strikes and protests. Soldiers opened fire...
column10: A student was killed and nearly 50 people injured as demonstrators clashed with troops in some of the worst violence since President Alejandro Toledo declared a state of emergency this week to curb a wave of strikes and protests. Soldiers opened fire on protesting students at a university in the southern city of Puno, while in the city of Arequipa, the police fired tear gas at striking teachers. In Lima, police officers in riot gear chased striking judiciary workers at the National Justice building. Teachers, demanding a pay raise, began a nationwide strike two weeks ago, and demonstrations gradually escalated to include farmers, court workers and other sectors. After the emergency decree, some farmers and health workers suspended their strikes, but court workers and teachers vowed to press on.

column10: The Rolex store on Rue du Rhône, Geneva's equivalent of Rodeo Drive, was not to be outdone by its neighbors. It was not enough to board up the front door and the plate glass windows with knotty pine planks painted yellow and to disguise all identifying signs. Rolex also ringed its second story with garlands of barbed wire.

column9: The protester, his face swathed in black, carried a long ax with a bright blue blade. And when he reached Route de Malagnou in the eastern part of this city, he began smashing a bus shelter, destroying one of its glass panels.    ''Stop! Stop!''...
column10: The protester, his face swathed in black, carried a long ax with a bright blue blade. And when he reached Route de Malagnou in the eastern part of this city, he began smashing a bus shelter, destroying one of its glass panels. ''Stop! Stop!'' shouted demonstrators who were part of a huge protest against the Group of 8 summit meeting that opened today in the nearby French town of Évian-les-Bains. But there were no police officers on the demonstration route, and the ax-wielding man swiftly blended back into the marching crowd.

column3: BUSH PRESSES CASE ON IRAN AND KOREA AT ECONOMIC TALKS
column9: President Bush stepped onto French soil today to meet the European leaders who vociferously opposed the war in Iraq, but rather than rehash their differences he spent the day trying to increase pressure on two other nations he regards as major...
column10: President Bush stepped onto French soil today to meet the European leaders who vociferously opposed the war in Iraq, but rather than rehash their differences he spent the day trying to increase pressure on two other nations he regards as major threats -- Iran and North Korea -- to give up their nuclear weapons programs. Mr. Bush arrived here from St. Petersburg, Russia, after a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin that both men used to put differences over Iraq behind them, and to sign the recently ratified treaty that requires both sides to reduce their nuclear arsenals.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    Iran, North Korea Warned To Curb Nuclear Programs  At the conclusion of a meeting of the Group of 8 leading industrial democracies, President Bush and other leaders called nuclear proliferation ''the pre-eminent threat to...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Iran, North Korea Warned To Curb Nuclear Programs At the conclusion of a meeting of the Group of 8 leading industrial democracies, President Bush and other leaders called nuclear proliferation ''the pre-eminent threat to international security,'' urging North Korea and Iran to curb their programs. A1 Bush Visits Middle East George W. Bush arrived in the Middle East for the first time in his presidency, preparing to answer Arab leaders who are deeply wary of America's intentions in Iraq and to step in as the face-to-face intermediary between Israel and the Palestinians, a role he has long avoided. A1

column3: Police Arrest Mugabe Rival Amid Protests In Zimbabwe
column9: Authorities arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader, beat protesters and fired tear gas and warning shots today to quell demonstrations aimed at presenting the most significant challenge yet to President Robert Mugabe.    Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of...
column10: Authorities arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader, beat protesters and fired tear gas and warning shots today to quell demonstrations aimed at presenting the most significant challenge yet to President Robert Mugabe. Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, was arrested at his home today and charged with contempt of court for planning an illegal demonstration, said his lawyer, Innocent Chagonda.

column2: MUGABE, ROBERT; ZIMBABWE; LABOR; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Strike Idles Zimbabwe as Opposition Tries to Oust the President
column9: A general strike shut down much of Zimbabwe's battered economy today, but security forces prevented efforts to organize large street protests against President Robert Mugabe.    Most banks, shops and other businesses remained closed across Zimbabwe...
column10: A general strike shut down much of Zimbabwe's battered economy today, but security forces prevented efforts to organize large street protests against President Robert Mugabe. Most banks, shops and other businesses remained closed across Zimbabwe on the second day of a weeklong show of antigovernment sentiment by an increasingly defiant opposition.

column2: MUGABE, ROBERT; TSVANGIRAI, MORGAN; HARARE (ZIMBABWE); ZIMBABWE; TREASON; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Zimbabwe Arrests Opposition Leader and Fends Off Protests
column9: Security forces arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader today, charged him with treason and clamped down on the capital to prevent mass protests demanding that President Robert Mugabe resign.    Military helicopters swooped over this capital city,...
column10: Security forces arrested Zimbabwe's opposition leader today, charged him with treason and clamped down on the capital to prevent mass protests demanding that President Robert Mugabe resign. Military helicopters swooped over this capital city, while army vehicles ferried troops around and police patrol cars cruised the streets. Hundreds of ruling party supporters, wearing white T-shirts reading ''No to Mass Action,'' occupied the capital's main square.

column9: The police arrested a second senior Zimbabwe opposition figure today as the party's leader appeared in court after a weekend in jail to face charges of plotting to overthrow President Robert Mugabe.    A police spokesman, Andrew Phiri, said the...
column10: The police arrested a second senior Zimbabwe opposition figure today as the party's leader appeared in court after a weekend in jail to face charges of plotting to overthrow President Robert Mugabe. A police spokesman, Andrew Phiri, said the secretary general of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, Welshman Ncube, had been arrested on treason charges on suspicion of inciting five days of protests against Mr. Mugabe last week.

column3: French Strike Against Cuts In Pensions Jams Traffic
column9: Striking government workers tied up traffic in Paris today for the third time in a month to protest a bill that would slash retirement benefits. Legislators may vote on it within a few weeks.    In the stately National Assembly building, Prime...
column10: Striking government workers tied up traffic in Paris today for the third time in a month to protest a bill that would slash retirement benefits. Legislators may vote on it within a few weeks. In the stately National Assembly building, Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin urged the legislators to pass the bill, a pension revision that would force workers to stay on the job several more years before retirement and cut the benefits due them.

column10: Serbian police commandos stormed a Belgrade apartment early this morning and arrested a top war crimes suspect amid fierce clashes with his hard-line nationalist supporters. A senior member of the Interior Ministry confirmed that the suspect, Veselin Sljivancanin, a former colonel in the Yugoslav National Army, had been taken into custody.

column2: MEDINA, ENRIQUE; BUSH, GEORGE W; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; STATE DEPARTMENT; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; VISAS; REFERENDUMS
column3: Call to Overthrow Chávez Cost Venezuelan a U.S. Visa
column9: A former Venezuelan general whose visa was revoked by the Bush administration had been advocating the overthrow of President Hugo Chávez, American officials said today. The United States has publicly opposed the president's overthrow, urging that...
column10: A former Venezuelan general whose visa was revoked by the Bush administration had been advocating the overthrow of President Hugo Chávez, American officials said today. The United States has publicly opposed the president's overthrow, urging that his fate be settled by democratic means. The visa of the former general, Enrique Medina, was rescinded by the State Department in May on the recommendation of the American Embassy in Venezuela, a State Department official said by phone from Washington. Mr. Medina, a former attaché in the Venezuelan Embassy in Washington, led a group of dissident generals who have for months gathered in a Caracas neighborhood opposed to Mr. Chávez and loudly called for his ouster.

column2: IRAQ; FALLUJA (IRAQ); HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH; ATOMIC WEAPONS; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: Rights Group Says U.S. Soldiers Twice Used Excessive Force
column9: A leading human rights group today accused United States troops of using excessive force in two April shootings that killed 20 Iraqis and wounded at least 86. Commanders said their soldiers were responding to hostile fire from a crowd of protesters...
column10: A leading human rights group today accused United States troops of using excessive force in two April shootings that killed 20 Iraqis and wounded at least 86. Commanders said their soldiers were responding to hostile fire from a crowd of protesters in Falluja, a city of 300,000 about 35 miles west of Baghdad. The group, Human Rights Watch, said researchers found few bullet holes that would suggest that the crowd of protesters fired on the soldiers using a school as a base. But they found more than 100 bullet holes on seven buildings across the street. The evidence, the report said, was inconsistent with American statements that the soldiers responded with ''precision fire'' when they were allegedly attacked.

column3: World Forum Moves Venue From Davos To Dead Sea
column9: For those used to the ramparts of the snowbound Alps, it does not get lower or much hotter than this.    The World Economic Forum, a global assembly of luminaries from boardrooms and governments, usually holds its councils in Davos, the Swiss ski...
column10: For those used to the ramparts of the snowbound Alps, it does not get lower or much hotter than this. The World Economic Forum, a global assembly of luminaries from boardrooms and governments, usually holds its councils in Davos, the Swiss ski resort. This time the forum's managers and King Abdullah II of Jordan determined that it should be held on the shores of the Dead Sea, 1,369 feet below sea level, the lowest place on earth, where temperatures routinely exceed 100 degrees.

column3: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Muslims Riot Over Reported Extraditions
column9: The police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of Muslims protesting the arrest and reported extradition by the United States this week of five suspected members of Al Qaeda. Angry demonstrators in the resort district of Mangochi burned down offices...
column10: The police fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of Muslims protesting the arrest and reported extradition by the United States this week of five suspected members of Al Qaeda. Angry demonstrators in the resort district of Mangochi burned down offices of the global Save the Children charity and a Catholic church, while others attacked the offices of the Muslim Association of Malawi in Blantyre, which they accused of failing to protect fellow Muslims, the police said. The protesters said their government relinquished its sovereignty by succumbing to pressure from the United States. The American Embassy initially denied involvement but has not responded to inquiries since Tuesday.

column2: SILVA, LUIZ INACIO LULA; BRAZIL; SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT; LABOR; PUBLIC WORKS; FINANCES; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES); HIRING AND PROMOTION; INTEREST RATES; CREDIT; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Inflation Eases, But Other Worries Build Up in Brazil
column9: A clash this week between Rio de Janeiro riot police and some 15,000 desperate unemployed people jostling to sign up for jobs as street sweepers and garbage collectors was a stark sign that President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva needs to take swift...
column10: A clash this week between Rio de Janeiro riot police and some 15,000 desperate unemployed people jostling to sign up for jobs as street sweepers and garbage collectors was a stark sign that President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva needs to take swift action to get Brazil's sputtering economy growing again. Since taking office nearly six months ago, Mr. da Silva, the left-leaning former metalworker, has been steering a tricky course between inflation and recession, raising interest rates to four-year highs to keep consumer prices under control but trying not to push them so high as to stop the economy dead in its tracks.

column2: OBASANJO, OLUSEGUN; ABUJA (NIGERIA); LAGOS (NIGERIA); LABOR; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES); STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LOOTING; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: General Strike
column9: The police fired warning shots and tear gas to break up demonstrators as a general strike over raised fuel prices took hold. Stores and offices in Lagos, the commercial capital, were barricaded shut for fear of looting. Airline flights ran hours...
column10: The police fired warning shots and tear gas to break up demonstrators as a general strike over raised fuel prices took hold. Stores and offices in Lagos, the commercial capital, were barricaded shut for fear of looting. Airline flights ran hours late, or not at all. Government offices and businesses in the capital, Abuja, and other cities also closed. In pamphlets, the striking Nigeria Labor Congress urged the public to ransack businesses that opened during the strike. Labor officials held talks with President Olusegun Obasanjo at his presidential villa in Abuja.

column2: COPENHAGEN (DENMARK); CHRISTIANA (COPENHAGEN); SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; HASHISH; GEOGRAPHIC PROFILES; AREA PLANNING AND RENEWAL; COMMUNES; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC
column3: Copenhagen Journal; Free Spirits in Their Fortress, the Law at the Gate
column9: Ever since a group of squatters took over an abandoned military fortress in the heart of this intimate, orderly city 32 years ago, their ''Free Town,'' Christiania, has caused the government untold heartburn.    What began as a social experiment in...
column10: Ever since a group of squatters took over an abandoned military fortress in the heart of this intimate, orderly city 32 years ago, their ''Free Town,'' Christiania, has caused the government untold heartburn. What began as a social experiment in communal living now draws hundreds of thousands of tourists. Hashish is sold freely on Pusher Street and smoked openly, despite the Danish law forbidding both activities. Houses built mostly without official permission are not bought and sold, but loaned to kindred spirits selected by other residents. There are no roads, and thus no cars.

column2: VELASCO, IGNACIO; CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Caracas Protest Quelled
column9: Police officers firing tear gas and shotgun pellets today dispersed supporters of President Hugo Chávez who threw stones and firecrackers at Caracas Cathedral where the body of Cardinal Ignacio Velasco, a critic of Mr. Chávez, was lying in state,...
column10: Police officers firing tear gas and shotgun pellets today dispersed supporters of President Hugo Chávez who threw stones and firecrackers at Caracas Cathedral where the body of Cardinal Ignacio Velasco, a critic of Mr. Chávez, was lying in state, the police said. Mourners and passers-by scattered as detonations rocked the square outside the cathedral.

column3: 3 Student Leaders Seized by Vigilantes in Iran
column9: Armed vigilantes arrested three student leaders this morning after a news conference at which they announced the cancellation of protests to mark the anniversary of the 1999 student protests.     The three students, Ali Moghtaderi, Arash Hashemi and...
column10: Armed vigilantes arrested three student leaders this morning after a news conference at which they announced the cancellation of protests to mark the anniversary of the 1999 student protests. The three students, Ali Moghtaderi, Arash Hashemi and Reza Amerinassab, were thrown into three separate cars by about 15 armed men. Mr. Moghtaderi's face was covered with blood, after having been shoved to the ground by the men.

column2: OSORIO, JUAN; CHAVEZ, HUGO; ANZOATEGUI (VENEZUELA); VENEZUELA; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; LABOR; OIL (PETROLEUM) AND GASOLINE; STRIKES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Protester Killed By Police
column9: An unemployed Venezuelan oil worker was shot dead by a soldier when National Guard troops clashed with workers blocking a highway near a major oil complex, witnesses and the police said. A group of unemployed oil workers demanding jobs occupied the...
column10: An unemployed Venezuelan oil worker was shot dead by a soldier when National Guard troops clashed with workers blocking a highway near a major oil complex, witnesses and the police said. A group of unemployed oil workers demanding jobs occupied the highway near an oil and petrochemical plant in Anzoátegui, in the east. Witnesses said National Guard troops first tried to disperse the demonstrators with tear gas, but one of the troopers opened fire, hitting a protester, Juan Osorio, in the knee and the chest. More than 18,000 employees of the state oil firm Petróleos de Venezuela were fired after taking part in a general strike against President Hugo Chávez in December and January.

column2: MCINNIS, SCOTT; STARK, PETE; THOMAS, BILL; UNITED STATES; CONGRESS; HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES; PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT PLANS; LAW AND LEGISLATION
column3: Sound, Fury, Pension Rules: Nasty Party Clash in House
column9: As protests go, it wasn't much. There were no nightsticks or tear gas, and nobody was arrested.    But the conduct was far from orderly in the House of Representatives this morning, when more than a dozen Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee --...
column10: As protests go, it wasn't much. There were no nightsticks or tear gas, and nobody was arrested. But the conduct was far from orderly in the House of Representatives this morning, when more than a dozen Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee -- infuriated by last-minute changes to a pension bill -- stalked out of a hearing in the Longworth Office Building and holed up in an adjacent library, prompting Representative Bill Thomas, the committee's chairman, to summon the Capitol police.

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; BUSH, GEORGE W; WEST BANK; KAFR KANNA (ISRAEL); ISRAEL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
column3: Israelis Drive Back Protesters Cutting Into Border Fence
column9: Israeli troops fired tear gas and rubber-coated bullets today to drive away several hundred Palestinians, Israelis and foreign activists who were cutting through part of Israel's security fence in the northern West Bank.    The fence, a sensitive...
column10: Israeli troops fired tear gas and rubber-coated bullets today to drive away several hundred Palestinians, Israelis and foreign activists who were cutting through part of Israel's security fence in the northern West Bank. The fence, a sensitive subject between Israel and Palestinian authorities, is expected to be on the agenda on Tuesday when Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel meets President Bush at the White House. Israel says the fence is essential to prevent Palestinian attacks, while the president has been critical of the fence's route, which juts into the West Bank.

column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-8    France and Germany Weigh Their Postwar Roles in Iraq  The open-ended American military occupation of Iraq is forcing European powers that opposed the war, notably France and Germany, to contemplate whether and how to help...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 France and Germany Weigh Their Postwar Roles in Iraq The open-ended American military occupation of Iraq is forcing European powers that opposed the war, notably France and Germany, to contemplate whether and how to help with the aftereffects, as President Bush presses for a more international presence there. A10 Liberia Rebels Take Second City Rebels captured Buchanan, the second-biggest city in Liberia, defeating President Charles G. Taylor's embattled forces on a new front. Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, warned rebels that those who caused suffering to the Liberian people would be held accountable for war crimes. A8

column10: AN HOUR TO KILL By Karin Yapalater William Morrow ($23.95, hardcover) THURSDAY, MARCH 26 By Thursday morning, the Central Park precinct was humming. The burned corpse found on Sunday was Charlene Leone. Same back molars, and the hair in her brush matched the DNA. NYPD had a publicity problem. Leone had been kicked off the force nine months back.

column9: After five weeks of relative calm, violence flared today on two fronts of the Middle East conflict.    Three Palestinians, two of them suspected gunmen from the Islamic militant group Hamas, and an Israeli soldier were killed in a firefight and...
column10: After five weeks of relative calm, violence flared today on two fronts of the Middle East conflict. Three Palestinians, two of them suspected gunmen from the Islamic militant group Hamas, and an Israeli soldier were killed in a firefight and ensuing protest that erupted during what the Israeli Army called a hunt for bomb makers in the West Bank city of Nablus.

column3: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Police Buy Riot Gear
column9: The police placed an order for 13,000 rounds of tear gas ammunition after 500,000 people marched peacefully on July 1 to protest the government's plan for stringent internal security laws. The police have also ordered 9,400 riot-control helmets, and...
column10: The police placed an order for 13,000 rounds of tear gas ammunition after 500,000 people marched peacefully on July 1 to protest the government's plan for stringent internal security laws. The police have also ordered 9,400 riot-control helmets, and said the helmets were to replace gear dating as far back as 1967 while the unusually large order for gas ammunition was to replace rounds that had reached their expiration date. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

column3: Swaziland Quells Protests Over Commonwealth Summit Meeting
column9: The police cracked down on protests in this African kingdom today as a Commonwealth summit meeting began and as demonstrators angrily criticized what they described as the king's increasingly autocratic rule.    The police fired tear gas to break up...
column10: The police cracked down on protests in this African kingdom today as a Commonwealth summit meeting began and as demonstrators angrily criticized what they described as the king's increasingly autocratic rule. The police fired tear gas to break up hundreds of protesters in Mbabane, the capital, and soldiers swung rifle butts to disperse lingering groups of demonstrators, injuring several, witnesses said.

column2: CHILE; CENTRAL WORKERS UNION; HEALTH INSURANCE AND MANAGED CARE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; STRIKES; MEDICINE AND HEALTH; GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: General Strike
column9: The first general strike since the restoration of democratic rule more than a decade ago has been carried out by the country's leading labor federation, with the police arresting some demonstrators and using tear gas to disperse others. The work...
column10: The first general strike since the restoration of democratic rule more than a decade ago has been carried out by the country's leading labor federation, with the police arresting some demonstrators and using tear gas to disperse others. The work stoppage, which failed to paralyze activity as leaders had hoped, was called by the 640,000-member Central Workers Union to protest what it describes as poor working conditions and inadequate health-care coverage in what has been South America's fastest-growing economy. Larry Rohter (NYT)

column3: Dominican Police Disperse Crowd
column9: The police in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, sprayed a chemical substance last night to disperse thousands of fans waiting outside the already-packed volleyball arena before the Pan American Games gold medal game between Cuba and the Dominican...
column10: The police in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, sprayed a chemical substance last night to disperse thousands of fans waiting outside the already-packed volleyball arena before the Pan American Games gold medal game between Cuba and the Dominican Republic. The Dominican women won the match in five sets, 15-13 in the fifth, after blowing a two-set lead. The arena, which holds about 8,000 people, was nearly full two hours earlier as the United States women beat Brazil for the bronze medal. When that match ended, fans were sitting in aisles and on the floor, and armed police officers and militia members were walking through the building with guard dogs.

column2: IMAM, MAZURUL; BANGLADESH; KHULNA (BANGLADESH); ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Protests After Assassination
column9: The police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of protesters who attacked government buildings in the southwestern city of Khulna after the killing of an opposition politician. The protesters took to the streets after gunmen killed Manzurul Imam,...
column10: The police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of protesters who attacked government buildings in the southwestern city of Khulna after the killing of an opposition politician. The protesters took to the streets after gunmen killed Manzurul Imam, 65, a leader of the country's main opposition party, the Awami League, the police and witnesses said. He was riding in a rickshaw when he was attacked outside his house. The rickshaw driver was also killed.

column2: REYNA, CLAUDIO; MANCHESTER CITY; FULHAM; SOCCER
column3: Reyna Reverses His Field
column9: The lure of playing in the UEFA Cup and in the new 48,000-seat City of Manchester Stadium, not to mention a more lucrative contract, was enough for CLAUDIO REYNA to turn his back on Fulham and jump to Manchester City.      The decision by Reyna and...
column10: The lure of playing in the UEFA Cup and in the new 48,000-seat City of Manchester Stadium, not to mention a more lucrative contract, was enough for CLAUDIO REYNA to turn his back on Fulham and jump to Manchester City. The decision by Reyna and his former club, Sunderland, which was relegated from the English Premier League after last season, left officials at Fulham in London fuming.

column2: SHARON, ARIEL; ARAFAT, YASIR; OLMERT, EHUD; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; PALESTINIANS; DEPORTATION
column3: Sharon Aide Says Israel Is Considering Killing Arafat
column9: Israel's vice prime minister said today that killing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was one of several options now under government consideration. His remarks came as a beaming Mr. Arafat soaked up the cheers of supporters who descended on his...
column10: Israel's vice prime minister said today that killing Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was one of several options now under government consideration. His remarks came as a beaming Mr. Arafat soaked up the cheers of supporters who descended on his compound for a fourth consecutive day. ''Arafat can no longer be a factor in what happens here,'' the vice prime minister, Ehud Olmert, told the Israel radio. ''The question is: How are we going to do it? Expulsion is certainly one of the options, and killing is also one of the options.''

column2: FLORIDA; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; PEPPER SPRAY; SUITS AND LITIGATION; GUARDS; TORTURE; TEAR GAS
column3: National Briefing | South: Florida: Inmates' Suit Claims Abuse
column9: Twenty-two inmates have sued the state, saying it allowed prison guards to torture them in their cells by spraying them with pepper spray and tear gas. In a federal lawsuit filed on Friday in Fort Myers, the inmates said the use of chemical agents by...
column10: Twenty-two inmates have sued the state, saying it allowed prison guards to torture them in their cells by spraying them with pepper spray and tear gas. In a federal lawsuit filed on Friday in Fort Myers, the inmates said the use of chemical agents by prison guards had greatly increased. They say the practice violates the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment. Lisa White Shirley, a lawyer for Florida Institutional Legal Services, which is representing the inmates, said that because the inmates sprayed were in their cells they generally did not pose a danger and that the spraying was done as retaliation, punishment or intimidation.

column2: PANAMA CITY (PANAMA); PANAMA; COLON (PANAMA); LABOR; FINANCES; STRIKES; PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT PLANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ORGANIZED LABOR; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Panama: Thousands Strike
column9: Workers participating in a 24-hour national strike protesting what they say is mismanagement of the social security fund clashed with riot police officers on the paralyzed streets of the country's two largest cities. According to reports from Panama...
column10: Workers participating in a 24-hour national strike protesting what they say is mismanagement of the social security fund clashed with riot police officers on the paralyzed streets of the country's two largest cities. According to reports from Panama City and the port of Colón, protesters numbering in the tens of thousands threw rocks and gasoline bombs at the police, who returned fire with rubber bullets and tear gas. The strike was the first nationwide work stoppage in six years. Union leaders called it after the government dismissed the head of the heavily indebted fund, which covers health care and retirement. They accuse the government of mismanaging the fund to the point of bankruptcy. David Gonzalez (NYT)

column2: MESA, CARLOS; SANCHEZ DE LOZADA, GONZALO; LA PAZ (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Bolivian President Remains Defiant as Protests Intensify
column9: Thousands of demonstrators marched in Bolivia's capital and other nearby cities on Monday, calling for the president's resignation. But they were dispersed by military units firing tear gas canisters, and at a midafternoon news conference President...
column10: Thousands of demonstrators marched in Bolivia's capital and other nearby cities on Monday, calling for the president's resignation. But they were dispersed by military units firing tear gas canisters, and at a midafternoon news conference President Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada was defiant and pugnacious. ''I'm not going anywhere,'' he said, citing his determination to remain in office and vowing that ''order will be restored.'' He added, ''It is not possible that democracy be replaced by a dictatorship of the unions'' that will ''pit region against region, class against class and ethnic group against ethnic group.''

column2: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT (BOOK); MARANISS, DAVID; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
column3: Some Rough Days in October, in Microscopic Detail
column9: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT  War and Peace  Vietnam and America  October 1967  By David Maraniss  Illustrated. 572 pages. Simon & Schuster. $29.95.      Tomorrow is the 36th anniversary of a riot at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The police...
column10: THEY MARCHED INTO SUNLIGHT War and Peace Vietnam and America October 1967 By David Maraniss Illustrated. 572 pages. Simon & Schuster. $29.95. Tomorrow is the 36th anniversary of a riot at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The police use of tear gas to subdue rebellious college students made it memorable, but at the heart of the event was a different chemical: napalm. The Dow Chemical Company (''Our position on the manufacture of napalm is that we are a supplier of goods to the Defense Department and not a policy maker'') had sent a recruiter to the campus. His very presence was enough to set off a violent uproar. His name was William L. Hendershot, known as Curly. He had brought a ham sandwich for lunch.

column2: ERNEST, UNIK; PM; VOODOO; NIGHTCLUBS AND CABARETS
column3: The Voodoo That He Does, So Well, Into the Night
column9: UNIK ERNEST, dreadlocks grazing the collar of his Yves St. Laurent blazer, slips into a leather banquette of his new PM lounge in the meatpacking district of the West Village. He nods a quick greeting here and there in the ultratrendy club, designed...
column10: UNIK ERNEST, dreadlocks grazing the collar of his Yves St. Laurent blazer, slips into a leather banquette of his new PM lounge in the meatpacking district of the West Village. He nods a quick greeting here and there in the ultratrendy club, designed to evoke a forsaken gentlemen's club in Haiti circa the 1940's, or something like that. Mr. Ernest, who is 32 and Haitian born, is being interviewed late this night, an insane endeavor because the music is throbbing and the nightspot is starting to jump, with the impossibly tall and thin waitresses in Diane Von Furstenberg wiggling their hips.

column2: ESTRADA, JOSEPH; DAVIDE, HILARIO; ARROYO, GLORIA MACAPAGAL; MANILA (PHILIPPINES); PHILIPPINES; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; COURTS; IMPEACHMENT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Thousands Protest
column9: The police used tear gas and water cannons to break up a demonstration by as many as 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Joseph Estrada, in Manila's business district calling for the resignation of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. The crowd...
column10: The police used tear gas and water cannons to break up a demonstration by as many as 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Joseph Estrada, in Manila's business district calling for the resignation of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. The crowd also protested the failure of efforts to impeach Chief Justice Hilario Davide, a case that has divided the country. A constitutional crisis was averted Tuesday when lawmakers backed a Supreme Court ruling that the impeachment was unlawful.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
column3: Police Act as Protest Becomes Riot in Haiti
column9: Riot police officers fired tear gas at thousands of rock-throwing protesters on Friday as a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was overpowered by throngs of Aristide supporters.    Demonstrators scattered as tear gas canisters...
column10: Riot police officers fired tear gas at thousands of rock-throwing protesters on Friday as a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was overpowered by throngs of Aristide supporters. Demonstrators scattered as tear gas canisters fell and shots rang out. There were reports of at least two people injured and 30 arrests.

column2: FITHIAN, LISA; LATIN AMERICA; MIAMI (FLA); CANADA; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; FREE TRADE AGREEMENT OF THE AMERICAS; FREE PORTS AND TRADING ZONES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Them Against the World, Part 2
column9: On a rain-soaked October night in Miami, the police have commandeered downtown. It is midnight, and patrol cars cordon off the streets of run-down delis and dollar stores. Dozens of black-clad officers maneuver and bullhorn in the distance,...
column10: On a rain-soaked October night in Miami, the police have commandeered downtown. It is midnight, and patrol cars cordon off the streets of run-down delis and dollar stores. Dozens of black-clad officers maneuver and bullhorn in the distance, practicing their tactics. ''We're expecting about 70,000 to 100,000 protesters to come down here in November,'' says a beat cop, guarding a corner from his squad car. ''Our guys are doing exercises all around.'' A few blocks over, at a red light, Lisa Fithian pulls her compact rental car behind a squadron of city police cruisers. Hers is one of the few civilian cars in this area, certainly the only one carrying an advance guard of that human wave heading for Miami. While most people have been ushered out of the downtown area, the 42-year-old Fithian wants to go into it, to do reconnaissance with three fellow activists. Weeks from now, she will be marching in these streets, and the police will no longer be practicing. Since it is difficult to find our way about, Fithian decides, boldly, to follow the cruisers. ''You know,'' she says, ''it's kind of nice to tail the cops for once.''

column2: IRAQ; SAN FRANCISCO (CALIF); WASHINGTON (DC); FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION; SURVEILLANCE OF CITIZENS BY GOVERNMENT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; GAS MASKS; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; TEAR GAS
column3: F.B.I. SCRUTINIZES ANTIWAR RALLIES
column9: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected extensive information on the tactics, training and organization of antiwar demonstrators and has advised local law enforcement officials to report any suspicious activity at protests to its...
column10: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected extensive information on the tactics, training and organization of antiwar demonstrators and has advised local law enforcement officials to report any suspicious activity at protests to its counterterrorism squads, according to interviews and a confidential bureau memorandum. The memorandum, which the bureau sent to local law enforcement agencies last month in advance of antiwar demonstrations in Washington and San Francisco, detailed how protesters have sometimes used ''training camps'' to rehearse for demonstrations, the Internet to raise money and gas masks to defend against tear gas. The memorandum analyzed lawful activities like recruiting demonstrators, as well as illegal activities like using fake documentation to get into a secured site.

column2: ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; FRANCE; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; MILITARY BASES AND INSTALLATIONS; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Protesters Attack French Base
column9: Up to 500 protesters, some with machetes, besieged the French military base in Abidjan. French troops fired tear gas and stun grenades at the protesters, but a French Army spokesman said the youths had not been dispersed. The protest followed a call...
column10: Up to 500 protesters, some with machetes, besieged the French military base in Abidjan. French troops fired tear gas and stun grenades at the protesters, but a French Army spokesman said the youths had not been dispersed. The protest followed a call by Ivoirian Army soldiers on Sunday for the French to let government troops fight rebels holding the northern half of the country.

column2: VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Venezuelan Protesters Clash With Police
column9: The Venezuelan police and national guard troops firing tear gas clashed with rioting street vendors in downtown Caracas on Wednesday and at least one policeman was hurt by stones thrown by the protesters, officials said.    The clashes began after...
column10: The Venezuelan police and national guard troops firing tear gas clashed with rioting street vendors in downtown Caracas on Wednesday and at least one policeman was hurt by stones thrown by the protesters, officials said. The clashes began after the police seized illegal fireworks, raising tensions as electoral authorities prepared to evaluate an opposition request for a referendum on the rule of President Hugo Chávez. The police said the demonstrators, some shouting slogans in support of Mr. Chávez, fired guns at officers and threw firecrackers.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Police And Students Clash
column9: The police fired tear gas and warning shots at thousands of university students who spilled into the streets of Port-au-Prince in the latest protest aimed at ousting President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. One bystander was killed, and two students were...
column10: The police fired tear gas and warning shots at thousands of university students who spilled into the streets of Port-au-Prince in the latest protest aimed at ousting President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. One bystander was killed, and two students were shot and wounded. It was not clear who shot the students. Three others were hurt as Aristide supporters reportedly pelted students with rocks. More than 24 people were hurt last Friday at the University of Haiti when dozens of government supporters attacked about 100 protesting students.

column2: DEMPSEY, MARTIN E; RUMSFELD, DONALD H; HUSSEIN, SADDAM; HATTAM, QAIS; IRAQ; SAMARRA (IRAQ); BAGHDAD (IRAQ); ABU SAFA (IRAQ); CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY; FINANCES; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; TERRORISM
column3: G.I.'s Fight Off Convoy Attack; Raid Iraqi Cell
column9: American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis in ambushes and violent rallies on Monday and Tuesday, the military reported, as repercussions of the capture of Saddam Hussein continued to be felt from Washington to the seething Sunni Muslim heartland of...
column10: American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis in ambushes and violent rallies on Monday and Tuesday, the military reported, as repercussions of the capture of Saddam Hussein continued to be felt from Washington to the seething Sunni Muslim heartland of Iraq. New details emerged Tuesday about documents found when Mr. Hussein was captured, contributing to a clearer picture of those organizing guerrilla attacks. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said in Washington that the Central Intelligence Agency would oversee Mr. Hussein's interrogation.

column2: KELLER, GERTA; PRINCETON UNIVERSITY; PALEONTOLOGY; SPACE; ENDANGERED AND EXTINCT SPECIES; DINOSAURS; METEORS AND METEORITES
column3: Where Dinosaurs Roamed, She Throws Stones
column9: REMEMBER the riddle about the extinction of the dinosaurs? It bedeviled many of us as children. It seemed to have been solved two decades ago with the theory that a single meteor plowed into the Earth 65 million years ago. Poof, we thought, the...
column10: REMEMBER the riddle about the extinction of the dinosaurs? It bedeviled many of us as children. It seemed to have been solved two decades ago with the theory that a single meteor plowed into the Earth 65 million years ago. Poof, we thought, the dinosaurs were gone. But Gerta Keller, 58, a professor in Princeton University's department of geosciences, is part of a small group that is rattling the foundations. And the theory she supports, which argues that the demise of the dinosaurs was more complicated, has unleashed a small tempest of its own among die-hard believers in the meteor theory, who are known as ''impacters.''

column9: Israeli troops arrested a total of 16 wanted Palestinians in a series of overnight raids in the West Bank that ended early Saturday, an Israeli military source said.    The raids took place in five villages north of the city of Ramallah, the military...
column10: Israeli troops arrested a total of 16 wanted Palestinians in a series of overnight raids in the West Bank that ended early Saturday, an Israeli military source said. The raids took place in five villages north of the city of Ramallah, the military said.

column10: At first glance, the confrontation on Friday along Israel's separation barrier seemed unremarkable. About 20 protesters shook the chain-link fence, and some then took out pliers to cut it. After calling out warnings and firing shots into the air, Israeli troops shot at the legs of the protesters with live ammunition, the military admits.

column9: Israel plans a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the Golan Heights, the government confirmed Wednesday. The announcement angered Syria, from which Israel seized the territory in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.    The plan, approved two weeks ago,...
column10: Israel plans a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the Golan Heights, the government confirmed Wednesday. The announcement angered Syria, from which Israel seized the territory in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. The plan, approved two weeks ago, comes just two months after the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, called for renewed peace talks between his country and Israel.
