column9: Two hundred years ago, an army of African slaves defeated French forces on this tropical island, ending Napoleon's ambition to dominate the Americas and paving the way for the first black republic.     On Thursday, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide...
column10: Two hundred years ago, an army of African slaves defeated French forces on this tropical island, ending Napoleon's ambition to dominate the Americas and paving the way for the first black republic. On Thursday, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide led a tense and chaotic observance of that bicentennial, though many found little to celebrate in Mr. Aristide's governance over what, after 200 years of independence, remains an impoverished and troubled nation.

column2: MUBARAK, HOSNI; ARAFAT, YASIR; BAZ, OSAMA EL-; EGYPT; ISRAEL; RAMALLAH (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; TERRORISM
column3: Egyptian Urges Arafat to Subdue Factions
column9: Hoping to revive the stalled Middle East peace effort, an Egyptian government envoy met the embattled Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, here on Thursday and urged him to work with rival Palestinian factions to end attacks against Israel.    ''It is...
column10: Hoping to revive the stalled Middle East peace effort, an Egyptian government envoy met the embattled Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, here on Thursday and urged him to work with rival Palestinian factions to end attacks against Israel. ''It is the duty of the people of the region and first of all us and you and the Arab people to take the decisions and measures from our side that will pave the road toward a better future,'' said the envoy, Osama el-Baz, speaking briefly to reporters outside the sandbagged entrance to Mr. Arafat's blasted West Bank headquarters. ''We hope that Israel will do the same because the issue depends on the will of both sides.''

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Clash At Protester's Funeral March
column9: Firing warning shots and tear gas, the police stopped mourners who left a church funeral in Port-au-Prince to march on the presidential palace with the coffin of a protester killed this month in a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand...
column10: Firing warning shots and tear gas, the police stopped mourners who left a church funeral in Port-au-Prince to march on the presidential palace with the coffin of a protester killed this month in a demonstration against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. At least six people were injured in violence that followed, most of them hurt by hurled rocks or shots fired by Aristide supporters, witnesses said.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: 20,000 March For President
column9: In one of the largest demonstrations in months in Port-au-Prince, the capital, more than 20,000 people marched in support of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the face of calls for his ouster. For the second time in three days, the police prevented...
column10: In one of the largest demonstrations in months in Port-au-Prince, the capital, more than 20,000 people marched in support of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the face of calls for his ouster. For the second time in three days, the police prevented anti-Aristide demonstrators from marching by firing tear gas.

column2: CHUR (SWITZERLAND); LANDQUART (SWITZERLAND); DAVOS (SWITZERLAND); WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Forum Protest Staged From a Distance
column9: Armed with spray cans and paint bombs, about 500 antiglobalization protesters clashed with the police in the eastern Swiss town of Landquart on Saturday, as the officers tried to stop them from heading into nearby Davos to protest illegally at the...
column10: Armed with spray cans and paint bombs, about 500 antiglobalization protesters clashed with the police in the eastern Swiss town of Landquart on Saturday, as the officers tried to stop them from heading into nearby Davos to protest illegally at the World Economic Forum. The police said they fired tear gas and pepper spray at the protesters at the Landquart railway station. Four protesters were injured, the police reported; two were given first aid, and two were taken to the hospital.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES FOREIGN SERVICE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: One Dead In Clash Near U.S. Consulate
column9: One person was killed and several others injured in a clash between the police, supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and antigovernment marchers near the American Consulate in Port-au-Prince. Demonstrators had gathered outside the...
column10: One person was killed and several others injured in a clash between the police, supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and antigovernment marchers near the American Consulate in Port-au-Prince. Demonstrators had gathered outside the consulate, where they burned a coffin and called for the ouster of Mr. Aristide. As the demonstrators were leaving, rock-throwing Aristide supporters confronted them. The police fired warning shots and tear gas to disperse the crowd. Hospital officials said the man who was killed died when he was struck in the chest by a tear-gas canister. A spokeswoman for the consulate said the office closed because of the unrest but that officials hoped to re-open it today. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; CARIBBEAN COMMUNITY; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Haiti's Neighbors Are Pressing Aristide for Reforms
column9: At 24, David Jonathas is barely old enough to remember the political revolution that eventually placed a Catholic priest named Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the presidential palace. And yet, Mr. Jonathas hopes to be part of another movement, equal in...
column10: At 24, David Jonathas is barely old enough to remember the political revolution that eventually placed a Catholic priest named Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the presidential palace. And yet, Mr. Jonathas hopes to be part of another movement, equal in determination to that earlier campaign waged in the late 1980's but with opposite results. ''As long as Aristide is in power, there will be no democracy,'' said Mr. Jonathas, a student at the University of Haiti, wiping his brow moments after he and a few hundred other students finished a march through the winding, pockmarked streets of the capital here calling for Mr. Aristide's ouster. ''He must go. We need a new system.''

column2: SIMMONS, RAMEL; NEW YORK CITY; ALBANY (NY); GALAXY DINER; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS
column3: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Suspect In Shootings Found Dead
column9: A suspect in a shooting spree that wounded nine people at a Brooklyn diner last month was found dead, apparently a suicide, in an Albany apartment Wednesday afternoon after being surrounded by the police, the authorities said yesterday. After the...
column10: A suspect in a shooting spree that wounded nine people at a Brooklyn diner last month was found dead, apparently a suicide, in an Albany apartment Wednesday afternoon after being surrounded by the police, the authorities said yesterday. After the suspect, Ramel Simmons, 23, had been tracked to the apartment, New York City and Albany police officers arrived to arrest him, the police said. After no response to police calls for two hours, tear gas was fired inside, and a fiber-optic camera showed Mr. Simmons dead on the floor with a 9-millimeter handgun, the police said. It is unclear whether Mr. Simmons shot himself before the police arrived or after the tear gas was used, the police said. The police had identified Mr. Simmons as one of two men who opened fire in the Galaxy Diner in East New York on Jan. 17, sending customers diving under tables for cover before taking jewelry and money and fleeing. Another suspect, Mark Blount of East New York, was arrested the following week. The police are seeking a third suspect, possibly a driver, an investigator said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

column2: SOUTH KOREA; CHILE; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Clash in Seoul As Farmers Rally to Protest Chile Trade Bill
column9: Rock-throwing South Korean farmers clashed with riot-equipped police officers outside Parliament on Monday in a battle against passage of a free trade agreement with Chile that the growers fear will flood their markets with cheap produce.    While...
column10: Rock-throwing South Korean farmers clashed with riot-equipped police officers outside Parliament on Monday in a battle against passage of a free trade agreement with Chile that the growers fear will flood their markets with cheap produce. While the violent demonstration raged outside, legislators were unable to bring the measure to a vote. It was the third time Parliament had balked at ratifying the pact.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Haitian Leader's Allies Block Opposition Demonstration
column9: Militant supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide blocked a demonstration planned by civic opposition groups in the capital on Thursday, erecting barricades of flaming tires and throwing rocks at anyone who tried to breach their blockade.   ...
column10: Militant supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide blocked a demonstration planned by civic opposition groups in the capital on Thursday, erecting barricades of flaming tires and throwing rocks at anyone who tried to breach their blockade. Militants loyal to Mr. Aristide and his Lavalas party started gathering in the square late Wednesday night, and Thursday morning hundreds of them threw rocks, taunted and shouted at opposition protesters.

column3: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Police And Strikers Clash
column9: Striking ship builders clashed with the police in Seville. The workers fired slingshots, wounding 12 officers, the police said. The police repelled them with rubber bullets and tear gas, injuring 38 workers, union officials said.   Dale Fuchs (NYT)
column10: Striking ship builders clashed with the police in Seville. The workers fired slingshots, wounding 12 officers, the police said. The police repelled them with rubber bullets and tear gas, injuring 38 workers, union officials said. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; KERRY, JOHN; IRAQ; VIETNAM WAR; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; ELECTION ISSUES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2004; NATIONAL GUARD (US); UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: You Can't Skip Vietnam Twice
column9: WHEN George W. Bush's handlers had him dress up as the 1986 Tom Cruise of ''Top Gun'' to dance a victory jig on an aircraft carrier, they didn't stop to think that he might soon face an opponent who could be type-cast more persuasively in his own Tom...
column10: WHEN George W. Bush's handlers had him dress up as the 1986 Tom Cruise of ''Top Gun'' to dance a victory jig on an aircraft carrier, they didn't stop to think that he might soon face an opponent who could be type-cast more persuasively in his own Tom Cruise role. John F. Kerry was in real life a comrade of Ron Kovic, whom Mr. Cruise played to great acclaim in the 1989 ''Born on the Fourth of July.'' Mr. Kerry, like the movie's hero, was a decorated Vietnam soldier who became a star activist for Vietnam Veterans Against the War upon returning home. In a pivotal scene in the film, delegates at the 1972 Republican National Convention in Miami Beach eject Kovic and his fellow protesting vets from the hall, call him a traitor and spit on him. If that incident has a certain angry passion, it may be because the director was Oliver Stone. Like both Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry, Mr. Stone was a son of privilege who attended Yale in the mid-1960's. Like Mr. Kerry but unlike Mr. Bush, he went on to combat in Vietnam, won a bronze star and then turned against America's most disastrous foreign war.

column2: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; INTERNATIONAL COURT OF JUSTICE; PALESTINIAN AUTHORITY; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; FENCES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
column3: Hearing on West Bank Wall Draws Demonstrators
column9: An international court opened a hearing on Monday about the Israeli barrier being built in and around the West Bank, as pro-Palestinian demonstrators here voiced encouragement in front of worried supporters of Israel.    In a three-hour presentation...
column10: An international court opened a hearing on Monday about the Israeli barrier being built in and around the West Bank, as pro-Palestinian demonstrators here voiced encouragement in front of worried supporters of Israel. In a three-hour presentation to the International Court of Justice, the Palestinian Authority argued that the partly built barrier of ditches, watchposts and concrete walls was a violation of international law and an attempt to annex Palestinian land.

column2: TRAVERS, MARY; STOKEY, NOEL PAUL; YARROW, PETER; NEW YORK CITY; PETER, PAUL AND MARY; MUSIC; PARTIES (SOCIAL)
column3: BOLDFACE NAMES
column9: Now That's What We Call a Fan      PETER, PAUL and MARY had a party at Peter's -- that is to say PETER YARROW's -- apartment the other day. It's a duplex, off Central Park West. There are some hippie vestiges; the high ceiling is peeling badly, the...
column10: Now That's What We Call a Fan PETER, PAUL and MARY had a party at Peter's -- that is to say PETER YARROW's -- apartment the other day. It's a duplex, off Central Park West. There are some hippie vestiges; the high ceiling is peeling badly, the coffee tables are wooden crates, but it's still an impressive address. So despite the group's iconic status, there is one important question to be dealt with, before Mr. Yarrow, who bought the apartment in 1978, drags us single-mindedly into a one-way conversation on issues.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: In Haiti, All the Bridges Are Burned
column9: The world is now watching what is going on in Haiti. Everyone has seen how the population of Cap Haitien, Haiti's second-largest city, welcomed as liberators a motley group of rebels who now vow to march here to the capital. But that's only the most...
column10: The world is now watching what is going on in Haiti. Everyone has seen how the population of Cap Haitien, Haiti's second-largest city, welcomed as liberators a motley group of rebels who now vow to march here to the capital. But that's only the most obvious sign of a resentment against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide that has been growing for years. The most popular song of the Carnival that just ended, for example, was an attack on a government official, ''Madan Gougou,'' and by extension, on Mr. Aristide's Lavalas party. Schoolchildren pass around unflattering caricatures of the president, and anti-Aristide graffiti have proliferated in the streets. That's why Haitians weren't surprised when the democratic opposition, with no ties to the rebels, this week rejected an American-drafted proposal that would give it more power but also let President Aristide complete his term in office. The only solution, the opposition said, was for Mr. Aristide to go.

column2: QUREI, AHMED; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; BIDDU (WEST BANK); BEIT SURIK (WEST BANK); GAZA STRIP; INTERNATIONAL COURT OF JUSTICE; PALESTINIANS; FENCES; BANKS AND BANKING
column3: 2 Palestinians Are Killed and Dozens Wounded in Clashes With Israeli Troops Over Barrier
column9: Israeli security forces shot dead two Palestinians and wounded dozens, according to Palestinian doctors, in daylong clashes on Thursday with stone-throwing protesters in two West Bank villages. It was the deadliest confrontation yet linked to...
column10: Israeli security forces shot dead two Palestinians and wounded dozens, according to Palestinian doctors, in daylong clashes on Thursday with stone-throwing protesters in two West Bank villages. It was the deadliest confrontation yet linked to Israel's separation barrier. Also, two Palestinian gunmen killed an Israeli soldier at an industrial zone in the northern Gaza Strip, where thousands of Palestinians work in Israeli-run factories. Both attackers were fatally shot by other soldiers.

column2: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; CARACAS (VENEZUELA); RECALL (ELECTIONS); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; REFERENDUMS
column3: 2 Killed as Troops Fight Protesters in Venezuela
column9: Venezuelan troops and antigovernment demonstrators clashed Friday in the streets of the capital, Caracas, leaving at least two people dead and several wounded as President Hugo Chávez convened a summit meeting of developing nations.    The...
column10: Venezuelan troops and antigovernment demonstrators clashed Friday in the streets of the capital, Caracas, leaving at least two people dead and several wounded as President Hugo Chávez convened a summit meeting of developing nations. The confrontation, in which National Guard troops repeatedly fired tear gas at protesters and gunfire broke out, came two days before a government electoral board was to rule on the validity of signatures government opponents had collected to force a referendum on recalling Mr. Chávez from office.

column2: SHAKAH, GHASSAN W; WEST BANK; ISRAEL; JERUSALEM; GAZA STRIP; NABLUS (WEST BANK); PALESTINIANS; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES
column3: A Day of Israeli-Palestinian Violence; Civil Disorder in Nablus
column9: At least one Palestinian gunman shot and killed two Israelis as they drove near the southern edge of Israel's boundary with the West Bank on Friday night, the Israeli Army said.    The attack came on a day of chaotic violence, as a suicide bomber...
column10: At least one Palestinian gunman shot and killed two Israelis as they drove near the southern edge of Israel's boundary with the West Bank on Friday night, the Israeli Army said. The attack came on a day of chaotic violence, as a suicide bomber riding a bicycle blew himself up near a Gaza Strip settlement, hurting no one else, and stone-throwing Palestinians clashed with riot-equipped police officers at a Jerusalem site sacred to Muslims and Jews.

column2: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; FENCES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Ideas & Trends: Tactical Shift; On the West Bank, a Hint of Resistance Without Blood
column9: THE barrier Israel is building against West Bank Palestinians has had a striking, if unintended, effect: It has stirred a sustained, bloodless protest movement among Palestinians for the first time in more than three years of conflict.    As the...
column10: THE barrier Israel is building against West Bank Palestinians has had a striking, if unintended, effect: It has stirred a sustained, bloodless protest movement among Palestinians for the first time in more than three years of conflict. As the bulldozers have swept south toward Jerusalem and cut deeper into West Bank land, villagers who have mostly stayed on the sidelines of the uprising have joined with Israeli leftists to demonstrate. In places, as in this hamlet, they have blocked the machines with their bodies.

column2: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; RECALL (ELECTIONS); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; REFERENDUMS
column3: Venezuelans' Plan to Recall Chávez Is Near Defeat
column9: A campaign by opposition groups for a recall referendum to try to oust President Hugo Chávez appeared on the brink of collapse on Monday.    Opposition leaders, expecting election officials to disqualify enough of the 3.4 million signatures they...
column10: A campaign by opposition groups for a recall referendum to try to oust President Hugo Chávez appeared on the brink of collapse on Monday. Opposition leaders, expecting election officials to disqualify enough of the 3.4 million signatures they have collected for a recall to keep the measure off the ballot, accused Mr. Chávez of influencing the process.

column3: Anger Rises In Pakistan After Attack On Shiites
column9: Troops enforced a curfew in Quetta on Wednesday as Shiite Muslims reacted angrily to an attack on a religious procession the day before that killed 44 people.    Shiite leaders delayed the funerals of 32 of those killed in the attack by guns and...
column10: Troops enforced a curfew in Quetta on Wednesday as Shiite Muslims reacted angrily to an attack on a religious procession the day before that killed 44 people. Shiite leaders delayed the funerals of 32 of those killed in the attack by guns and grenades, and they demanded the resignations of the provincial local police chief and others for failing to prevent the attack despite heavy nationwide security.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; LATORTUE, GERARD; JAMAICA; HAITI; UNITED NATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; FOREIGN AID
column3: Haiti's New Leader Sees a Long Transition
column9: The newly appointed prime minister, Gérard Latortue, said Thursday that it might take as long as two years to prepare for elections. That would put a new elected government beyond the 2005 timeline envisioned in the United States-backed transition...
column10: The newly appointed prime minister, Gérard Latortue, said Thursday that it might take as long as two years to prepare for elections. That would put a new elected government beyond the 2005 timeline envisioned in the United States-backed transition plan to help Haiti recover after the departure of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. ''We really want to give an equal chance to all political parties, to all candidates,'' said Mr. Latortue, in his first interview since returning to Haiti on Wednesday after decades of living in United States and elsewhere. ''We want not to go fast, but to take time.''

column2: KOSOVO (SERBIA); SERBIA AND MONTENEGRO; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED NATIONS
column3: NATO Expanding Kosovo Forces to Combat Violence
column9: NATO ordered reinforcements to Kosovo on Thursday as peacekeepers struggled to stem a wave of ethnic violence across the province, in southern Serbia.     The additional 1,000 troops, which will bring the overall NATO force to 19,000, began arriving...
column10: NATO ordered reinforcements to Kosovo on Thursday as peacekeepers struggled to stem a wave of ethnic violence across the province, in southern Serbia. The additional 1,000 troops, which will bring the overall NATO force to 19,000, began arriving Thursday evening, at the end of a second day of violence between ethnic Albanians and Serbs in which at least 31 people have been killed and hundreds injured, according to United Nations officials. Most of the dead were Serbs.

column2: HELLING, RICK; MINNESOTA TWINS; BASEBALL
column3: Sports Briefing
column9: BASEBALL    Broken Leg Sidelines Twins Pitcher Helling      Rick Helling, who was expected to be the Minnesota Twins' No. 5 starter, will miss at least a month with a broken right leg after being hit by a line drive on Saturday. He will wear a...
column10: BASEBALL Broken Leg Sidelines Twins Pitcher Helling Rick Helling, who was expected to be the Minnesota Twins' No. 5 starter, will miss at least a month with a broken right leg after being hit by a line drive on Saturday. He will wear a walking boot for about four weeks, said Sean Harlin, a team spokesman. (AP)

column2: SISTANI, ALI AL-; IRAQ; UNITED NATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: Shiite Ayatollah Is Warning U.N. Against Endorsing Charter Sponsored by U.S.
column9: Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, has warned of ''dangerous consequences'' if the United Nations endorses the American-sponsored interim constitution for an independent Iraq that was adopted over Shiite protests...
column10: Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, has warned of ''dangerous consequences'' if the United Nations endorses the American-sponsored interim constitution for an independent Iraq that was adopted over Shiite protests two weeks ago. The warning came in a letter released by Ayatollah Sistani's office on Monday, four days after it was delivered in New York to Lakhtar Brahimi, the chief United Nations envoy to Iraq. It amounted to a warning that the ayatollah's followers, by far the most powerful political bloc in Iraq, could move to paralyze American plans for a smooth transfer of sovereignty on June 30 unless Shiite terms for changing the interim constitution were met.

column2: ABIDJAN (IVORY COAST); IVORY COAST; FRANCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 25 Killed in Antigovernment Protest in Ivory Coast
column9: Violent clashes erupted on the streets of Abidjan, the commercial capital of Ivory Coast, on Thursday, killing 25 people, prompting rebels to withdraw from a power-sharing government and raising new doubts about the prospects for disarmament.   ...
column10: Violent clashes erupted on the streets of Abidjan, the commercial capital of Ivory Coast, on Thursday, killing 25 people, prompting rebels to withdraw from a power-sharing government and raising new doubts about the prospects for disarmament. Ivory Coast was once an oasis of stability in West Africa, but the outbreak of war in September 2002 left the country partitioned between government and rebel-held territories. Under a French-brokered peace accord, rebels and opposition parties joined a government of national reconciliation, French troops monitored a cease-fire between the warring parties, and plans were under way to deploy a United Nations peacekeeping force. The first of 6,000 peacekeepers were to arrive next month.

column2: GYANENDRA; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; ROYAL FAMILY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Dozens Injured In Anti-King Protests
column9: The police fired tear gas and used batons to break up a rally by political parties against King Gyanendra, officials said. They said more than 100 protesters were injured in clashes with the police that began after the demonstrators tried to defy a...
column10: The police fired tear gas and used batons to break up a rally by political parties against King Gyanendra, officials said. They said more than 100 protesters were injured in clashes with the police that began after the demonstrators tried to defy a government order banning rallies on main streets leading to the king's palace and government buildings in Katmandu, the capital. It was the second day of protests demanding the restoration of democratic politics. Organizers of the protests called for a general strike today.

column2: GYANENDRA; KATMANDU (NEPAL); NEPAL; ROYAL FAMILY; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Nepal Police Seize 1,000 Marchers At Antimonarchy Rally in Capital
column9: With opposition to Nepal's monarchist government growing in intensity, more than 1,000 people were detained Friday in Katmandu, the capital, for violating a ban on public gatherings that was imposed this week.     As many as 25,000 demonstrators...
column10: With opposition to Nepal's monarchist government growing in intensity, more than 1,000 people were detained Friday in Katmandu, the capital, for violating a ban on public gatherings that was imposed this week. As many as 25,000 demonstrators defied the ban, according to news agency reports, capping a week of pro-democracy, antimonarchy protests.

column2: CHAVEZ, HUGO; VENEZUELA; HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH; ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TORTURE; TEAR GAS
column3: Venezuela Abused Protesters, Human Rights Groups Charge
column9: Once seen as deferential to civil liberties despite his increasing hold on power, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela is now coming under sharp criticism from human rights groups that say that torture and excessive force were used to tame recent...
column10: Once seen as deferential to civil liberties despite his increasing hold on power, President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela is now coming under sharp criticism from human rights groups that say that torture and excessive force were used to tame recent anti-Chávez protests. In the latest report, released on Friday in a six-page letter to Mr. Chávez, Human Rights Watch, which is based in New York, accused National Guard troops of using tear gas and electric batons to torture protesters after their arrests.

column2: ADAM, SULIEMAN ABDALLAH; SUDAN; GENEINA (SUDAN); DARFUR (SUDAN); IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
column3: Uprooted Sudanese Balk at Invitation to Return Home
column9: The governor of this rugged stretch of earth, where the climate and the outlaws are equally harsh, declared Thursday that Darfur was safe again. Speaking in his office in the regional capital of West Darfur, the governor, Sulieman Abdallah Adam, said...
column10: The governor of this rugged stretch of earth, where the climate and the outlaws are equally harsh, declared Thursday that Darfur was safe again. Speaking in his office in the regional capital of West Darfur, the governor, Sulieman Abdallah Adam, said it was time for the million or so people amassed in makeshift camps across western Sudan, including 23,000 on the edge of this town, to head back to their villages again. The only problem with his decree is that the displaced villagers know better. They have the wounds to prove that Darfur remains deadly, no matter what the government says. Some of their wounds are fresh, so fresh that they plan to flout the governor's order.

column2: RHODE, DAVID; BANGLADESH; DHAKA (BANGLADESH); LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Member Of Parliament Killed
column9: Gunmen opened fire at a political rally held by Bangladesh's main opposition party in the capitol of Dhaka, killing a senior opposition member of Parliament and at least one other person, Reuters reported. The gunmen escaped. Hundreds of members of...
column10: Gunmen opened fire at a political rally held by Bangladesh's main opposition party in the capitol of Dhaka, killing a senior opposition member of Parliament and at least one other person, Reuters reported. The gunmen escaped. Hundreds of members of the opposition Awami league gathered to protest the killing, and were dispersed by police officers wielding batons and tear gas. David Rohde (NYT)

column2: OBASANJO, OLUSEGUN; KANO (NIGERIA); NIGERIA; YELWA (NIGERIA); CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Muslim Mobs, Seeking Vengence, Attack Christians in Nigeria
column9: Muslim mobs brandishing machetes and clubs attacked Christians in the streets of Kano on Wednesday as security forces struggled to quell a two-day rampage to avenge a massacre of hundreds of Nigerian Muslims.    The police confirmed that at least 30...
column10: Muslim mobs brandishing machetes and clubs attacked Christians in the streets of Kano on Wednesday as security forces struggled to quell a two-day rampage to avenge a massacre of hundreds of Nigerian Muslims. The police confirmed that at least 30 had been killed in strife engulfing Kano in northern Nigeria. Thousands of people, most of them belonging to the city's minority Christian population, cowered in army barracks and police stations as mobs attacked people outside. Witnesses said dozens more had been killed.

column2: LOVEMORE MADHUKU; MUGABE, ROBERT; GWERU (ZIMBABWE); ZIMBABWE; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CONSTITUTIONS; LOBBYING AND LOBBYISTS; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS; TEAR GAS
column3: Police Break Up Rally for Reform In Zimbabwe
column9: The police fired tear gas and beat people who were preparing to hold a meeting on constitutional reform in the central Zimbabwe city of Gweru on Saturday, the coalition organizing the event said.    About 80 people were arrested, including the...
column10: The police fired tear gas and beat people who were preparing to hold a meeting on constitutional reform in the central Zimbabwe city of Gweru on Saturday, the coalition organizing the event said. About 80 people were arrested, including the coalition's chairman, Lovemore Madhuku, said Ernest Mudzengi, spokesman for the group, the National Constitutional Assembly.

column2: OBASANJO, OLUSEGUN; SOYINKA, WOLE; NIGERIA; LAGOS (NIGERIA); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: In a New Nigeria, a Once-Exiled Nobelist Still Finds Trouble
column9: For the first time since the return of civilian democracy in his home country, Wole Soyinka, the once-exiled Nigerian writer and Nobel laureate, took part in a political protest in the capital, Lagos.     He received a mixed welcome. A crowd of...
column10: For the first time since the return of civilian democracy in his home country, Wole Soyinka, the once-exiled Nigerian writer and Nobel laureate, took part in a political protest in the capital, Lagos. He received a mixed welcome. A crowd of hundreds turned up with banners and trumpets Saturday morning. Then, according to demonstrators, the police lobbed tear gas and whisked Mr. Soyinka away to a police station, only to release him less than an hour later and offer apologies for the trouble.

column2: ARISTIDE, JEAN-BERTRAND; HAITI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TEAR GAS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Police Break Up Pro-Aristide Rally
column9: The police used tear gas and fired assault rifles in the air to break up a march by 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Thousands of people poured out of the slums to demand his return, making it one of the largest...
column10: The police used tear gas and fired assault rifles in the air to break up a march by 10,000 supporters of the ousted president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Thousands of people poured out of the slums to demand his return, making it one of the largest demonstrations of lingering support for Mr. Aristide since he left the country for exile in February.

column3: Sports of The Times; Olympic Doomsayers as Cyclical as Cicadas
column9: LIKE 17-year cicadas, journalists emit their own cyclical loud buzzing noises before every set of Summer Games. Listen. You can hear us now, fretting about construction, security and ambience in Athens in August.    The other day, the Greek prime...
column10: LIKE 17-year cicadas, journalists emit their own cyclical loud buzzing noises before every set of Summer Games. Listen. You can hear us now, fretting about construction, security and ambience in Athens in August. The other day, the Greek prime minister, Costas Caramanlis, visited the offices of The New York Times. We peppered him -- politely, of course -- about the progress of these Games.

column2: SAAKASHVILI, MIKHAIL; GEORGIA (GEORGIAN REPUBLIC); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS
column3: The Not-So-Velvet Revolution
column9: Georgia's president, Mikhail Saakashvili -- called Misha by just about everyone in the country -- took power on Nov. 22, 2003, by storming Parliament on live national television. Yelling from the back benches, he ordered Eduard Shevardnadze, who was...
column10: Georgia's president, Mikhail Saakashvili -- called Misha by just about everyone in the country -- took power on Nov. 22, 2003, by storming Parliament on live national television. Yelling from the back benches, he ordered Eduard Shevardnadze, who was widely seen as having stolen the recent parliamentary elections, to step aside. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet foreign minister and custodian of Georgia's descent into poverty and lawlessness, seemed frozen, then shaken by Saakashvili's rhetorical fire. As Shevardnadze was shuttled out the backdoor, Saakashvili, who had served a contentious term as justice minister under Shevardnadze, marched to the lectern, scanned the riotous scene, found the cameras and drank Shevardnadze's tall glass of tea. Out in the streets, protesters stuck flowers in the barrels of soldiers' assault rifles, and the Rose Revolution, as it was called, was over. Saakashvili, a charismatic 36-year-old graduate of Columbia Law School, was elected president two months later, winning 97 percent of the vote. Georgia -- a nation cracked open by three breakaway regions, racked by corruption and a tsunami of crime, reeling from two civil wars, pocked by constant electricity and water shortages and unable to collect taxes from its citizens -- was his to govern.

column2: SHAMZAI, NIZAMMUDIN; KARACHI (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; AFGHANISTAN; TALIBAN; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; SUNNI MUSLIMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Gunmen Kill a Leading Pro-Taliban Sunni Cleric in Pakistan
column9: Unidentified gunmen killed a leading pro-Taliban Sunni cleric on Sunday morning in the southern port city of Karachi. Enraged protesters then took to the streets and clashed with the police, according to police officials and news reports.     The...
column10: Unidentified gunmen killed a leading pro-Taliban Sunni cleric on Sunday morning in the southern port city of Karachi. Enraged protesters then took to the streets and clashed with the police, according to police officials and news reports. The cleric, Mufti Nizammudin Shamzai, had worked to bring together Pakistan's warring Islamic sects and was considered one of the country's most powerful Sunni voices.

column2: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; KARACHI (PAKISTAN); PAKISTAN; BOMBS AND EXPLOSIVES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
column3: 14 Die in Bombing of Shiite Mosque in Karachi
column9: At least 14 people were killed and 38 wounded Monday night when a powerful bomb exploded in a Shiite mosque here, police officials said. The attack set off a wave of violent protest, and angry demonstrators clashed with riot police officers across...
column10: At least 14 people were killed and 38 wounded Monday night when a powerful bomb exploded in a Shiite mosque here, police officials said. The attack set off a wave of violent protest, and angry demonstrators clashed with riot police officers across the city. At least two people were killed in the rioting, local news media reported. The bombing was the fourth terrorist incident in a single month in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city and a center of sectarian attacks in recent years.

column2: REUTHER, VICTOR; REUTHER, ROY; REUTHER, WALTER; UNITED AUTOMOBILE WORKERS; AUTOMOBILES; LABOR; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; ORGANIZED LABOR; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
column3: Victor Reuther, Influential Labor Leader, Dies at 92
column9: Victor Reuther, the last of three brothers who helped unionize Detroit amid the labor strife of the 1930's and remained central to the growth of industrial unionism for the next third of the century, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 92.    His...
column10: Victor Reuther, the last of three brothers who helped unionize Detroit amid the labor strife of the 1930's and remained central to the growth of industrial unionism for the next third of the century, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 92. His death was announced by his family and Ron Gettelfinger, president of what is now the United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America in Detroit, which says it has 710,000 active members in the United States and Canada.

column2: MPALA, DAVID; MUGABE, ROBERT; ZIMBABWE; LUPANE (ZIMBABWE); FRAUDS AND SWINDLING; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: New Wave of Repression Seen in Zimbabwe By-Election
column9: Like scores of opposition politicians in Zimbabwe, David Mpala knew violence firsthand. As he campaigned for this region's seat in Parliament in 2000, 40 government supporters clubbed him so soundly that he was permanently scarred. In 2002, 18 thugs...
column10: Like scores of opposition politicians in Zimbabwe, David Mpala knew violence firsthand. As he campaigned for this region's seat in Parliament in 2000, 40 government supporters clubbed him so soundly that he was permanently scarred. In 2002, 18 thugs dragged him into the bush, beat him and stabbed him in the back. Mr. Mpala, 48, died in February, and the government held an election last month to fill his seat. This time, government critics say, it was democracy that got mugged.

column2: NEW YORK CITY; HSBC BANK USA; SUBWAYS; DYES AND DYESTUFFS; BANK ROBBERIES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; TRANSIT SYSTEMS; TEAR GAS
column3: Dye Paints Subway, And a Robber Flees (Yes) Red-Handed
column9: Ideally, the pack of dye that a bank teller slips into a robber's money bag explodes while the robber is in midflight, sending up an eye-catching puff of red smoke. This is exactly what happened to a robber in a subway station yesterday -- but with...
column10: Ideally, the pack of dye that a bank teller slips into a robber's money bag explodes while the robber is in midflight, sending up an eye-catching puff of red smoke. This is exactly what happened to a robber in a subway station yesterday -- but with less than ideal results. According to the police, a man walked into the HSBC branch at the Avenue of the Americas and 14th Street just before 9:30 a.m. and passed a note demanding money. The robber then ran out of the bank with an undisclosed amount of cash and into the 14th Street subway station, a busy spot at the crossroads of the F, V, L, 1, 2, 3 and 9 lines, as well as two PATH lines.

column2: ISRAEL; HEBRON (WEST BANK); RECORDINGS (VIDEO); PALESTINIANS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Former Israeli Soldiers Tell of Harassment of Palestinians
column9: When Israeli soldiers opened an exhibit this month documenting some of their own misdeeds while serving in the tense West Bank city of Hebron, they caused a brief stir.    At a photographic institute in Tel Aviv, the soldiers, all recently...
column10: When Israeli soldiers opened an exhibit this month documenting some of their own misdeeds while serving in the tense West Bank city of Hebron, they caused a brief stir. At a photographic institute in Tel Aviv, the soldiers, all recently discharged, offer video testimony of gratuitous harassment and abuse of Palestinians, like firing tear gas just to get a reaction. Hanging on the wall are dozens of car keys confiscated from Hebron residents, a punishment both common and unauthorized, soldiers say. And a photo taken by a soldier shows graffiti, presumably written by civilians, which reads, ''Arabs to the gas chambers.''

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; RUMSFELD, DONALD H; GERMANY; IRAQ; FRANCE; AFGHANISTAN; NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY ORGANIZATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; TERRORISM; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE

column9: NATO leaders agreed Monday to help rebuild Iraq's security forces just hours after the American-led occupation forces transferred formal sovereignty to Iraq. But for NATO, many crucial details remain unresolved.     Bush administration officials...
column10: NATO leaders agreed Monday to help rebuild Iraq's security forces just hours after the American-led occupation forces transferred formal sovereignty to Iraq. But for NATO, many crucial details remain unresolved. Bush administration officials heralded the training accord and an agreement to increase NATO troops in Afghanistan to bolster security for elections there in September as proof the alliance could overcome divisions to reach consensus on contentious issues far beyond its members' national borders.

column3: Bush Urges All Autocrats To Yield Now To Democracy
column9: President Bush called on Muslim nations on Tuesday to embrace democracy and warned Middle East autocrats, including those who are American allies, that they ''must recognize the direction of events of the day.''    Speaking at the end of a five-day...
column10: President Bush called on Muslim nations on Tuesday to embrace democracy and warned Middle East autocrats, including those who are American allies, that they ''must recognize the direction of events of the day.'' Speaking at the end of a five-day trip to Europe and Turkey, Mr. Bush acknowledged that Western nations have helped nourish extremism by supporting repressive Middle Eastern leaders for the sake of regional stability.

column2: AYACUCHO PROVINCE (PERU); PERU; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Teachers And Police Clash
column9: Thousands of protesters overran the southern city of Ayacucho after the police used tear gas to break up a demonstration by striking teachers. At least 15 people were reported injured. Television pictures showed crowds running wild in the narrow...
column10: Thousands of protesters overran the southern city of Ayacucho after the police used tear gas to break up a demonstration by striking teachers. At least 15 people were reported injured. Television pictures showed crowds running wild in the narrow streets of the Andean city. The government ruled out calling a state of emergency, but Interior Minister Javier Reategui said he was sending more police officers.

Members of the Women's Affairs Technical Committee of Palestine, they had gathered in June in a hotel conference room in Gaza City for a symposium titled ''After the Withdrawal From Gaza.''

column3: Threat of Police Pickets Adds to Boston's Worries
column9: Besides the threat of a terrorist attack at the Democratic National Convention here later this month, the police will have to deal with at least 70 sets of demonstrators, including opponents of abortion, particularly passionate in this heavily Roman...
column10: Besides the threat of a terrorist attack at the Democratic National Convention here later this month, the police will have to deal with at least 70 sets of demonstrators, including opponents of abortion, particularly passionate in this heavily Roman Catholic area; Quakers who want to protest the war in Iraq with 800 pairs of empty combat boots and a plowshare forged from 10,000 spent bullet casings; anarchists; Buddhists -- and even themselves. That's right. Boston police officers, along with the city's firefighters, are locked in a long-running contract dispute and plan to picket several convention events, beginning with the 32 welcoming parties for various state delegations given by Mayor Thomas M. Menino.

column2: STRUGA (MACEDONIA); MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Ethnic Macedonians Riot Over New Laws That Aid Albanians
column9: Police officers used tear gas and rubber bullets early Friday morning to help quell rioting in Struga, a lakeside town in southwestern Macedonia. It was the first major outbreak of civil unrest since the end of an interethnic conflict in the country...
column10: Police officers used tear gas and rubber bullets early Friday morning to help quell rioting in Struga, a lakeside town in southwestern Macedonia. It was the first major outbreak of civil unrest since the end of an interethnic conflict in the country three years ago. Government officials said at least 17 people were injured in clashes as ethnic Macedonians, protesting plans that would give the country's Albanian minority greater rights and powers, ran through the town. Mobs attacked Albanian-owned shops and property as well as government cars and vehicles belonging to a European Union police monitoring mission.

column2: UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE
column3: The Quest for the Nonkiller App.
column9: I recently was invited to the Pentagon to watch a film depicting field tests of a new weapons program called the Active Denial System, which, it occurred to me, could have been named by an unhinged cognitive therapist. The live-action video opened on...
column10: I recently was invited to the Pentagon to watch a film depicting field tests of a new weapons program called the Active Denial System, which, it occurred to me, could have been named by an unhinged cognitive therapist. The live-action video opened on a vista reminiscent of Iraq or Afghanistan. Scattered amid the scrub of a desert plain, angry demonstrators howl unintelligible slogans and advance menacingly on a handful of soldiers who nervously pivot their rifles back and forth trying to deter the mob. For safety's sake during this test run, the ''crowd'' -- played for the most part by off-duty soldiers -- flings bright green tennis balls at the uniformed servicemen instead of rocks. As one member of the crowd hurls a ball, a soldier operating the Active Denial System (it looks like a squat satellite dish) targets an unruly protester in the weapon's viewfinder, squeezes a trigger that releases a beam of energy and, in a split second, one ''civilian'' howls and scampers away, fanning his rear end. Other demonstrators suffer similar fates, yelping and fleeing in panic, as if they have encountered a wall of invisible fire. After tumbling backward, the horde spins around, pointing and hollering like a Stone Age tribe encountering modern weaponry for the first time. What they were feeling was a blast of electromagnetic energy that causes a great deal of pain but does no lasting harm. That, in essence, is the point of a new generation of nonlethal weapons being developed by the military: to enforce and do battle without killing, or in the words of the Defense Department, ''to incapacitate personnel or matériel, while minimizing fatalities, permanent injury to personnel and undesired damage to property and the environment.'' Along with the Active Denial System, the military is testing bullets that disintegrate in mid-air, propelling their nonlethal payload to their targets, slimy goo that stops people in their tracks and, eventually, guns that shoot pulses of plasma energy that stun and disorient.

column2: VERAVAL (INDIA); INDIA; GUJARAT STATE (INDIA); RAJKOT (INDIA); ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Asia: India: 2 Killed In Religious Riots
column9: Muslims and Hindus burned buildings and clashed with the police in a third day of religious riots in Veraval, in western Gujarat State, throwing acid at officers who shot at the crowd. The unrest spread to Rajkot, another town in Gujarat and left 2...
column10: Muslims and Hindus burned buildings and clashed with the police in a third day of religious riots in Veraval, in western Gujarat State, throwing acid at officers who shot at the crowd. The unrest spread to Rajkot, another town in Gujarat and left 2 dead and at least 10 wounded. The police fired tear gas and used bamboo sticks to break up the rioters. Thousands of officers were on patrol, fearing the religious violence could increase. More than 1,000 people were killed in three months of Hindu-Muslim rioting two years ago in Gujarat State.

column3: For Athens, U.S. Team Packs Emergency Masks
column9: Security precautions in Athens for the 531 United States athletes will include emergency masks in the event of tear gas, pepper spray or pollutants, a United States Olympic official said Friday.    Team trainers will carry the masks, in flat bags, in...
column10: Security precautions in Athens for the 531 United States athletes will include emergency masks in the event of tear gas, pepper spray or pollutants, a United States Olympic official said Friday. Team trainers will carry the masks, in flat bags, in their equipment, and more than 1,000 will be available for the 800-person delegation, which includes officials.

column2: STANDER (MOVIE); FLETCHER, DEXTER; JANE, TOM; O'HARA, DAVID PATRICK; HUGHES, BRONWEN; MOTION PICTURES; REVIEWS
column3: A Policeman Turns Against Apartheid and Becomes a Bank-Robbing Folk Hero
column9: After the Holocaust, racial apartheid in South Africa may be the 20th-century curse most people would identify as unequivocally evil. And the first half hour of ''Stander,'' which tells the true story of Andre Stander (Tom Jane), the notorious...
column10: After the Holocaust, racial apartheid in South Africa may be the 20th-century curse most people would identify as unequivocally evil. And the first half hour of ''Stander,'' which tells the true story of Andre Stander (Tom Jane), the notorious Johannesburg police captain who turned against a system he found repugnant, plays like a smoothly executed if predictable drama of one man's heroic rebellion. But just when you begin to relax and wait for the usual buttons to be pushed, ''Stander'' swerves in a more uncertain direction. The issue of apartheid recedes, and the film, which opens today in New York, becomes an unsettling character study camouflaged as a heist movie. The further the volatile title character evolves into a swaggering self-styled Robin Hood, the more his nobility begins to tarnish. By the end of the film, his demons have taken over, and he has become a compulsively self-destructive outlaw addicted to flouting authority.

column2: HINDI, ABU ISSA AL-; GREAT BRITAIN; AL QAEDA; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; TERRORISM
column3: Officials Investigate a Qaeda Suspect's Shadowy Life
column9: Abu Issa al-Hindi, the operative of Al Qaeda who American officials say is one of 13 men arrested in raids last week in England, has lived a life of subterfuge and survival.      As an Islamic fighter in the 1990's he took part in a guerrilla...
column10: Abu Issa al-Hindi, the operative of Al Qaeda who American officials say is one of 13 men arrested in raids last week in England, has lived a life of subterfuge and survival. As an Islamic fighter in the 1990's he took part in a guerrilla campaign against the Indian Army in the rugged and perilous terrain of Kashmir. As an instructor in the Qaeda terrorist indoctrination camps of Afghanistan, he passed on his martial skills to the next generation of volunteers. And as a reconnaissance agent who slipped in and out of the United States in 2000 and 2001, he helped build an archive on the vulnerability of American financial centers on behalf of the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks.

column2: WALLING, JEFF; BEDS AND BEDDING; PRICES (FARES, FEES AND RATES)
column3: For the Sleeper Who Counts Monsters
column9: WHAT your mother said is true: orange alerts, fire drills and early warnings of impending tornadoes do not mean much without a good night's sleep. Jeff Walling, a 46-year-old boiler inspector from Virginia Beach, hopes he has come up with the latest...
column10: WHAT your mother said is true: orange alerts, fire drills and early warnings of impending tornadoes do not mean much without a good night's sleep. Jeff Walling, a 46-year-old boiler inspector from Virginia Beach, hopes he has come up with the latest tool in home safety. Behold, the Quantum Sleeper -- where a Martha Stewart thread count meets a 007 bulletproof protective canopy. ''You don't have to run to a 'safe room,' '' Mr. Walling said. ''You're already in it.''

column2: BANGLADESH; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Violence in Bangladesh
column9: An angry mob set fire to a passenger train, and protesters clashed with the police across Bangladesh on Sunday, leaving dozens of people injured, as violence spread a day after a grenade attack on an opposition rally killed 19 people and wounded...
column10: An angry mob set fire to a passenger train, and protesters clashed with the police across Bangladesh on Sunday, leaving dozens of people injured, as violence spread a day after a grenade attack on an opposition rally killed 19 people and wounded hundreds. The train, the Subarna Express, was attacked as it was entering a station in the town of Bhairab, 50 miles east of its destination of Dhaka, the capital, said Mostafa-e-Jamail, a spokesman for state-run Bangladesh Railways. About 20 people were injured, most of them passengers trying to flee while protesters angry about the attack on Saturday doused at least 15 of about 25 train cars with gas and ignited them, the police said. Police officers fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

column2: NAIROBI (KENYA); KENYA; RIFT VALLEY (KENYA); MASAI (TRIBE); RENTING AND LEASING; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LAND USE POLICIES; TEAR GAS
column3: Tribe, Claiming Whites' Land, Confronts Kenya's Government
column9: In scenes reminiscent of Zimbabwe's land seizures, angry Masai tribesmen have begun marching onto sprawling ranches held by white settlers in Kenya's lush Rift Valley and claiming the tracts as their own.    But while President Robert Mugabe backed...
column10: In scenes reminiscent of Zimbabwe's land seizures, angry Masai tribesmen have begun marching onto sprawling ranches held by white settlers in Kenya's lush Rift Valley and claiming the tracts as their own. But while President Robert Mugabe backed -- and even encouraged -- the forced redistribution of land in Zimbabwe as a way of righting colonial wrongs, the Kenyan authorities are rebuffing the recent trespasses by the Masai.

Powell. The anti-American protest was the first disturbance to mar the Summer Olympics in Athens, where Greek authorities and NATO have mobilized sea, air and land forces to guard against terrorist attacks.

column10: DON'T strut on the Greeks' last nerve or preen over anti-American tripwires, they were warned. Don't ridicule their Olympic hosts' red-white-and-blue conspiracy theories; don't scowl at the kind of Schadenfreude-induced mocking the American men's basketball team faced; don't taunt the type of catcallers who teased the American volleyball players or spit at the brand of hostile chants that drowned out the starter's pistol at track.

column2: POWELL, COLIN L; GREECE; ATHENS (GREECE); UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; OLYMPIC GAMES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; OLYMPIC GAMES (2004)
column3: Powell Cancels a Visit to Athens to Attend Closing of Olympics
column9: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, citing urgent business at home, has canceled his visit to Athens to attend the closing ceremony of the Olympic Games, the State Department announced Saturday. An aide to the secretary said Mr. Powell did not want...
column10: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, citing urgent business at home, has canceled his visit to Athens to attend the closing ceremony of the Olympic Games, the State Department announced Saturday. An aide to the secretary said Mr. Powell did not want to encourage anti-American protests that would distract from the ceremony. The announcement came after a demonstration in Athens on Friday involving 2,000 people protesting the planned visit disintegrated into a rock-throwing melee. At least three people were injured, and the police fired tear gas to break up the crowds.

column3: Bathrooms, Taxis, Other Basics
column9: PLEASE consider, O Republican conventiongoers, a possibly radical but altogether friendly suggestion from a native New Yorker.    Escape the experiment.
column10: PLEASE consider, O Republican conventiongoers, a possibly radical but altogether friendly suggestion from a native New Yorker. Escape the experiment.

column2: STRUGA (MACEDONIA); MACEDONIA (FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; REFERENDUMS
column3: Boundary Changes Put Ethnic Peace to the Test in Macedonia
column9: Angered by the national government's plans to change local boundaries, this rundown resort of 36,000 people on the shores of Lake Ohrid is preparing to declare independence.      The town's crusade, however quixotic, to become a city-state has struck...
column10: Angered by the national government's plans to change local boundaries, this rundown resort of 36,000 people on the shores of Lake Ohrid is preparing to declare independence. The town's crusade, however quixotic, to become a city-state has struck a chord across Macedonia. That is because the boundary changes are part of a delicate peace arrangement that ended fighting between Albanian guerrillas and government security forces three years ago, when the country was on the brink of a civil war.

column2: CHENEY, DICK; NEW YORK CITY; ACT UP; POLICE DEPARTMENT; REPUBLICAN PARTY; MADISON SQUARE GARDEN; CONVENTIONS, NATIONAL (US); SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION OF 2004; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
column3: Police Tactics Mute Protesters And Messages
column9: New York police have developed a pre-emptive strike policy, cutting off demonstrations before they grow large.
column10: As the Republican National Convention approached its final evening tonight, nearly 1,800 protesters had been arrested on the streets, two-thirds of them on Tuesday night alone. But for all the anger of the demonstrations, they have barely interrupted the convention narrative, and have drawn relatively little national news coverage. Using large orange nets to divide and conquer, and a near-zero tolerance policy for activities that even suggest the prospect of disorder, the New York Police Department has developed what amounts to a pre-emptive strike policy, cutting off demonstrations before they grow large enough, loud enough, or unruly enough to affect the convention.

column2: CARLUCCI, DAVID E; NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC; BETHEL WOODS CENTER FOR THE ARTS; MUSIC; APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; CULTURE
column3: Arts Briefing
column9: HIGHLIGHTS    INTO THE WOODS -- The Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in Sullivan County, N.Y., rising on the site of the 1969 Woodstock Festival, has a president and executive director. He is David E. Carlucci, currently general manager of House of...
column10: HIGHLIGHTS INTO THE WOODS -- The Bethel Woods Center for the Arts in Sullivan County, N.Y., rising on the site of the 1969 Woodstock Festival, has a president and executive director. He is David E. Carlucci, currently general manager of House of Blues Concerts Midwest, operator of the Blossom Music Center in Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio; the Scene Pavilion in Cleveland and the Timberwolf Amphitheater at Kings Island in Cincinnati. Mr. Carlucci's background in arts management includes 17 years at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in New York. The Bethel Woods Center, where ground was broken in July, is to open on July 1, 2006, with an inaugural concert by the New York Philharmonic. It is to have a 4,800-seat pavilion with lawn seating for 12,000. FILM PROTEST -- The new Pedro Almodóvar film, ''Bad Education,'' which deals with the sexual molestation of a young boy by a Roman Catholic priest, has come under attack in Poland, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. In Warsaw, where the movie opened on Friday, posters were defaced with graffiti, and in the town of Poznan, tear gas was lobbed into a theater, according to Malgorzata Kostro-Olechowska, a spokeswoman for Gutek Film, the distributor. She said that despite the attacks, the film would not be withdrawn, ''as we don't consider that it is against the church.'' ''Bad Education'' is to be shown at the New York Film Festival on Oct. 9 and 10.

column2: PORT-AU-PRINCE (HAITI); GONAIVES (HAITI); HAITI; UNITED NATIONS; CARE INTERNATIONAL; CHOLERA; JEANNE (STORM); MEDICINE AND HEALTH; HOSPITALS; FOREIGN AID; LOOTING; TYPHOID; FLOODS; HURRICANES AND TROPICAL STORMS
column3: Floodwaters Recede From Haitian City, but Hunger Does Not
column9: Chaos and looting in Haiti has hamstrung efforts to distribute food in the flood ravaged nation, United Nations officials said Friday.
column10: Floodwaters receded Friday in this city where flooding from a tropical storm took more than 1,000 lives, leaving behind thousands of tired and hungry people who labored to clear the mud and debris from what was left of their homes. United Nations officials managed to distribute more than 40 tons of corn, flour and water in two of the hardest-hit neighborhoods of the city, Raboteau and Bienac, avoiding the mob scenes that have hampered aid efforts in recent days. But the United Nations soldiers at Raboteau used tear gas and fire shots in the air to control the crowd in the afternoon, witnesses said.

column2: PEARL, DANIEL; FAROOQI, AMJED HUSSAIN; MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; PAKISTAN; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; TERRORISM; NEWS AND NEWS MEDIA
column3: Suspect in Attacks on Pakistan President Is Killed
column9: Amjad Hussain Farooqi, who is accused of twice attempting to assassinate Gen. Pervez Musharraf was killed by law enforcement authorities on Sunday.
column10: Amjad Hussain Farooqi, who is accused of being the mastermind of the two assassination attempts on Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, was killed by law enforcement authorities on Sunday, Pakistani officials said. Mr. Farooqi, who was also suspected in the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, had been pursued in a nationwide hunt. The interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, confirmed Sunday evening that Mr. Farooqi had been killed.

column3: Zimbabwe Court Clears Opposition Leader of Treason
column9: Surprising many critics of Zimbabwe's government, the nation's highest court on Friday acquitted the leading political opposition figure, Morgan Tsvangirai, on treason charges after a yearlong trial left the prosecution's case in shambles.    ...
column10: Surprising many critics of Zimbabwe's government, the nation's highest court on Friday acquitted the leading political opposition figure, Morgan Tsvangirai, on treason charges after a yearlong trial left the prosecution's case in shambles. Hundreds of supporters of Mr. Tsvangirai's opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, cheered and danced outside the colonial-style courthouse in the capital, Harare, after Judge Paddington Garwe announced the verdict. Mr. Tsvangirai said at a news conference that he hoped his acquittal would set the stage for ''national reconciliation'' of Zimbabwe's political crisis.

column2: THAILAND; NARATHIWAT PROVINCE (THAILAND); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ASPHYXIATION AND SUFFOCATION
column3: 78 Arrested in Thai Protests Suffocate in Crowded Trucks
column9: At least 78 people died from suffocation while being transported in overcrowded military trucks after a violent demonstration in south Thailand.
column10: At least 78 people died from suffocation while being transported in overcrowded military trucks after a violent demonstration in Thailand's largely Muslim south, officials said Tuesday. Six others were shot to death and about 20 were wounded during the demonstration on Monday when the police fired live rounds as well as water cannons and tear gas into wild, rock-throwing crowds, witnesses and officials said.

column2: LIBERIA; UNITED NATIONS; VIOLENCE; CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY
column3: Violence Erupts in Liberia
column9: Violence between Muslims and Christians engulfed Liberia's war-battered capital, with United Nations peacekeepers firing warning shots and tear gas to restore order.
column10: Violence between Muslims and Christians engulfed Liberia's war-battered capital on Friday, with machete-wielding crowds rampaging through the streets and United Nations peacekeepers firing warning shots and tear gas to restore order. At least three people were killed, crushed under the wheels of a United Nations armored vehicle that was moving in to disperse a crowd, a policeman said. The number of dead and wounded elsewhere was unclear, with some residents reporting up to five dead.

column2: SNELGROVE, VICTORIA; WEXLER, CHUCK; BOSTON (MASS); BOSTON RED SOX; NEW YORK YANKEES; POLICE EXECUTIVE RESEARCH FORUM; VIOLENCE; PLAYOFF GAMES; FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND EXPRESSION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FENWAY PARK (BOSTON); POLICE; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Student's Death Returns Crowd Control to the Fore
column9: The death of a student outside Fenway Park is only the latest reminder that crowd control has re-emerged as one of the toughest challenges for the police nationwide.
column10: The death of a 21-year-old college student outside Fenway Park on Oct. 21, the night the Red Sox beat the Yankees for the American League pennant, is only the latest reminder that crowd control has re-emerged as one of the toughest challenges for the police nationwide. ''I've known some police chiefs who now hope their hometown team doesn't win because controlling a big crowd can be so difficult,'' said Chuck Wexler, the executive director of the Police Executive Research Forum, an organization of police chiefs meant to promote smarter law enforcement.

column2: PRONK, JAN; ANNAN, KOFI; SUDAN; DARFUR (SUDAN); UNITED NATIONS
column3: New Violence Hinders Relief Efforts in Western Sudan
column9: Even as peace talks continued in an effort to stanch the suffering in western Sudan, kidnappings, land mines and, most recently, a government crackdown on a camp for displaced people, have created new pockets of no-go areas on the ground and made it...
column10: Even as peace talks continued in an effort to stanch the suffering in western Sudan, kidnappings, land mines and, most recently, a government crackdown on a camp for displaced people, have created new pockets of no-go areas on the ground and made it impossible to deliver relief to tens of thousands of Sudanese, aid groups said. The latest trouble came early Tuesday when, officials with the World Food Program said, the Sudanese military and police surrounded two camps in the state of Southern Darfur, used tear gas to disperse crowds and began forcibly moving some people from the camps.

column2: ABBAS, MAHMOUD; QUREI, AHMED; ARAFAT, YASIR; ISRAEL; PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANIZATION; PALESTINIANS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; CIVIL WAR AND GUERRILLA WARFARE
column3: Odd Question on West Bank: Who Is Arafat, Really?
column9: Like so much else they consider beyond their control, Palestinians in Nablus are adjusting to the prospect of Yasir Arafat's death.
column10: The only overarching Palestinian leader he has ever known lay near death in Paris, but for the moment Khaled Khalaf had a more pressing concern. He wanted to go shutter his pharmacy here on Monday night, but it was down the hill, right beside the boys throwing stones at Israeli soldiers, who were raiding Nablus in armored personnel carriers and armored jeeps.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; IRAQ; CHILE; SANTIAGO (CHILE); ASIA-PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; TERRORISM
column3: Thousands Demonstrate Against Bush in Santiago
column9: Police dispersed hundreds of protesters who gathered to demonstrate against the presence of President Bush at a summit meeting in Chile.
column10: Using tear gas and water cannons, riot police officers dispersed hundreds of rock-throwing protesters on Friday after thousands of people had gathered peacefully to demonstrate against the presence of President Bush at a weekend summit meeting here. Mr. Bush, in his first trip abroad since his re-election, is one of 21 world leaders scheduled to attend the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, being held here for the first time. The group, known as APEC, aims to encourage economic growth and trade among member nations, who account for more than half of the world's economy. The Chilean government has trumpeted the decision to hold the meeting here as an indication that this country of 15 million has achieved elite status.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; CHILE; SANTIAGO (CHILE); ASIA-PACIFIC ECONOMIC COOPERATION FORUM; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTELLIGENCE SERVICES; SECURITY AND WARNING SYSTEMS; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS
column3: Security Dispute Dulls Luster of Bush's Trip to Chile
column9: The Chilean government disinvited more than 200 guests to a dinner with President Bush rather than let them be screened for weapons.
column10: President Bush's visit to Chile ended on a bizarre note here this evening when the Chilean government disinvited more than 200 guests to a dinner with the president rather than let the Secret Service screen them for weapons on their way into the presidential palace. Mr. Bush and President Ricardo Lagos of Chile did not mention the dispute when they gave a news conference at the palace this evening, with Mr. Lagos hailing the ''modern and mature'' relationship between Chile and the United States. ''Most of the time we will be in agreement,'' he said. ''Sometimes we won't.''

column2: TRANSPORTATION DEPARTMENT; FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION; TRANSPORTATION SECURITY ADMINISTRATION; ACCIDENTS AND SAFETY; FINES (PENALTIES); AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES; HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC SUBSTANCES; AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL; TERRORISM
column3: Report Faults F.A.A. Action On Handling Risky Cargoes
column9: A recent report criticizes the Federal Aviation Administration's actions in the campaign to keep hazardous materials off airplanes.
column10: The Federal Aviation Administration's campaign to keep hazardous materials off airplanes, begun after an improper shipment caused a crash in the Florida Everglades that killed 110 people eight years ago, has generated thousands of enforcement cases and tens of millions of dollars in civil penalties. But the punishment is sometimes too little, too late, the inspector general of the Transportation Department said Friday in a report that called for major improvements.

column2: JIANG ZEMIN; SANCHAWAN (CHINA); SHAANXI PROVINCE (CHINA); CHINA; YULIN (CHINA); AGRICULTURE; FARMERS; SURVEYS AND SERIES; REAL ESTATE; ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; RURAL AREAS; URBAN AREAS; LAND USE POLICIES
column3: Farmers Being Moved Aside By China's Real Estate Boom
column9: A two-tiered property system favors city dwellers while handicapping the farmers once at the core of Chinese society.
column10: For five months, Gao Lading and other angry farmers had occupied the walled compound of the Communist Party's village office. They had pitched tents, eaten rice and sweet potatoes, and waited. It was a sit-in born of desperation. Officials from the nearby city of Yulin had seized land that had been part of the village since imperial times. The farmers had protested for nearly two years before finally seizing the village government's seat of power.

column2: MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; ZARDARI, ASIF ALI; BHUTTO, BENAZIR; PAKISTAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: A Leading Opponent Of Pakistani President Is Under Arrest Again
column9: The husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was arrested Tuesday, barely a month after being released on bail.
column10: Asif Ali Zardari, the husband of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, was arrested Tuesday, barely a month after being released on bail, government and opposition officials said. He was taken into custody after landing in Islamabad, where he had been scheduled to address a political rally. At the same time, hundreds of armed police officers set up barricades to prevent members of Ms. Bhutto's political party from going to the airport or attending the rally. After word of Mr. Zardari's arrest spread, supporters clashed with the police at the airport, smashing windows as the police fired tear gas and carried out baton charges.

column2: LAVERY, PETER; CONNECTICUT; NEWINGTON (CONN); POLICE DEPARTMENT; ATTACKS ON POLICE; HOSTAGES; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; DOMESTIC VIOLENCE; SUICIDES AND SUICIDE ATTEMPTS; POLICE
column3: Officer Is Dead After Standoff In Connecticut
column9: A standoff between law enforcement officials and a gunman who shot a local police officer ended Friday when the gunman killed himself, the authorities said.
column10: An overnight standoff between dozens of law enforcement officials and a gunman who shot a local police officer and then took him hostage ended on Friday when the gunman cut off communication with negotiators and killed himself, the authorities said. The police finally stormed the house where the standoff took place, where they found the bodies of the gunman and the officer, who appeared to have died from his wounds, the police said.

column2: YUSCHENKO, VIKTOR A; POPKOV, SERGEI; YUSHCHENKO, VIKTOR; KUCHMA, LEONID D; YANUKOVICH, VIKTOR F; SKIBINETSKY, OLEKSANDER; GALAKA, OLEKSANDER; SMESHKO, IHOR P; SKIPALSKY, OKEKSANDER; UKRAINE; KIEV (UKRAINE); ARMAMENT, DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES; INTELLIGENCE SERVICES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
column3: How Top Spies in Ukraine Changed the Nation's Path
column9: As protests against a rigged election grew, Kiev seemed headed for a Soviet-style crackdown. Then, inside Ukraine's security apparatus, strange events began to unfold.
column10: As protests here against a rigged presidential election overwhelmed the capital last fall, an alarm sounded at Interior Ministry bases outside the city. It was just after 10 p.m. on Nov. 28. More than 10,000 troops scrambled toward trucks. Most had helmets, shields and clubs. Three thousand carried guns. Many wore black masks. Within 45 minutes, according to their commander, Lt. Gen. Sergei Popkov, they had distributed ammunition and tear gas and were rushing out the gates.

column2: CASTRO, FIDEL; GONZALEZ, ELIAN; MIAMI (FLA); CUBA; IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE; ILLEGAL ALIENS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; CHILD CUSTODY AND SUPPORT; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; SUITS AND LITIGATION; CUBAN-AMERICANS
column3: 5 Years Later, a Miami Trial Over the Seizing of Elián
column9: Neighbors who claim they were traumatized by the three-minute raid have filed lawsuits and are seeking up to $250,000 each in damages.
column10: The moment 5:14 a.m. on April 22, 2000 -- remains as vivid to them as yesterday. Armanda Santos was fixing her daughter a drink in the predawn quiet of their kitchen. Carmen Valdes was praying the rosary. Leslie Alvarez was eating a slice of pizza, and Madeleine Peraza was holding vigil with friends in her living room. The calm -- and for years to come, they said, their well-being -- was shattered when federal agents with long guns descended on NW Second Street in Little Havana, swarming a small white house and snatching a boy named Elián González. Now, almost five years after the government seized Elián from his great-uncle's home and returned him to his father in Cuba, neighbors and others who witnessed the three-minute raid are getting their day in court.

column2: GNASSINGBE, FAURE; EYADEMA, GNASSINGBE; MALI; TOGO; BENIN; NIGER; NIGERIA; GHANA; COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: West African Leaders Spar With Togo's Army-Backed President
column9: West African leaders summoned Togo's new president to talks in Niger, threatening immediate sanctions if he did not attend.
column10: West African leaders on Friday summoned Togo's new president to talks in Niger on Saturday, threatening immediate sanctions if the Togolese leader did not attend. Faure Gnassingbé was installed as president by the army just hours after his father, Gnassingbé Eyadéma, died a week ago. West African leaders denounced his appointment, which violated the Constitution, as a military coup.
