The Constitution was hastily amended to allow Mr. Gnassingbé to succeed his father and to run the country until 2008.

column2: BONUS ARMY, THE: AN AMERICAN EPIC (BOOK); ALLEN, THOMAS B; DICKSON, PAUL; REVIEWS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; VETERANS
column3: Home From the War, Yet the Battle Is Just Beginning
column9: Paul Dickson and Thomas B. Allen's bleakly fascinating book tells the story of a veterans' crusade for compensation during World War I.
column10: 'The Bonus Army' 'An American Epic' By Paul Dickson and Thomas B. Allen. Illustrated. 370 pages. Walker & Company. $27. Paul Dickson and Thomas B. Allen began their prodigious research project on the Bonus Army of 1930's America with a nagging question: ''How could this all be forgotten?'' Certainly the events the authors sought to describe were well known in their day. These were the repeated marches on Washington by aging World War I veterans who had been promised federal funds in recognition of their wartime sacrifice. These veterans came home as heroes only to discover, in the words of one historian, that ''the Keys to the City had turned out only to be a pass to the flophouse.'' In 1924, the returning soldiers had been promised government recompense for the time they had spent overseas. By the early 1930's, with the nation in the throes of the Great Depression, this issue took on added urgency. There were veterans who had given up their main sources of income in order to enlist. They came back jobless, unable to pay their taxes and in danger of losing their homes.

column2: SUMMERS, LAWRENCE H; HARVARD UNIVERSITY; MEN; COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; WOMEN; SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY; ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERS
column3: Ideas & Trends; The Battle Behind the Battle at Harvard
column8: Technology; Science; Education; Week in Review
column9: The crisis at Harvard was more than a matter of an impolitic president. At stake is the university's very identity: Is Harvard liberal or conservative?
column10: WHEN Lawrence Summers, president of Harvard, theorized last month at a conference on ''Diversifying the Science and Engineering Work Force'' that men might have an innate advantage over women in scientific aptitude, he could scarcely have anticipated the protests that unfolded last week on the university's campus. While the Coalition for an Anti-Sexist Harvard rallied outside the science center, a hastily formed group with the laid-back name Students for Larry was milling about Lowell Lecture Hall. But the crisis wasn't just about Larry Summers. Gendergate -- to give the scandal its obligatory suffix -- was more than a matter of an impolitic president. At stake is the university's very identity: Is Harvard liberal or conservative?

column2: ABBAS, BONFOH; TOGO; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
column3: Crowds Protest in Togo
column9: Demonstrators said the march was prompted by anger at the selection of Bonfoh Abbas as interim president of Togo.
column10: Demonstrators protested Sunday against Togo's new president, lighting flaming barricades in the capital's streets and throwing rocks at riot police officers who fired tear gas to keep crowds from moving toward government buildings. Demonstrators said the unannounced march was prompted by anger at the selection on Friday of Bonfoh Abbas as interim president of Togo until nationwide elections can be held in the coming months. Mr. Abbas, the deputy speaker of Parliament, was named interim president in a special session of Congress after Faure Gnassingbé stepped down. He had been installed as president after the death of his father, Gnassingbé Eyadéma, who ruled as strongman for nearly four decades.

column2: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; GANGS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
column3: Gang Fight and Fire in Overcrowded Prison In Dominican Republic Kill 133 Inmates
column9: Rival gangs armed with guns and knives and battling for dominance in a prison set a fire that swept through a crowded cellblock.
column10: Rival gangs armed with guns, knives and machetes and battling for dominance in a prison in the Dominican Republic set a fire early Monday that swept through a crowded cellblock, killing at least 133 inmates and injuring 26, the authorities said. The fight in the prison in Higüey, 90 miles east of Santo Domingo, began late Sunday night and was briefly quelled by guards firing tear gas. But it flared anew about 2:30 a.m. when several members of one of the gangs set pillows and bedding on fire in the cellblock, known as Vietnam.

column2: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC; RED CROSS; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; FIRES AND FIREMEN; GANGS; FIRES AND FIREFIGHTERS
column3: After Prison Horror, Dominican Republic Plans a Study
column9: The Dominican government has appointed a commission to investigate a deadly fire that killed 136 prisoners.
column10: Zacaria Martínez is not sure how he survived the fire that swept through his prison cell, packed almost to the roof with inmates, killing nearly everyone inside. The only explanation he has is that it was ''at the hands of God.'' Inside the overcrowded prison here early Monday, a battle broke out in a cell known as Vietnam, the authorities said. Shots were fired and punches flew. Mattresses, machetes and other objects sailed through the air before a burst of flame came, then torrents of black, choking smoke.

column2: BERGER, OSCAR; SANTA CRUZ DEL QUICHE (GUATEMALA); GUATEMALA; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Protesters and Police Clash
column9: Protesters clashed with riot police who fired tear gas in the highland town of Santa Cruz del Quiché, in the eighth day of protests around the country over a free-trade deal with the United States. President Óscar Berger signed the accord into law...
column10: Protesters clashed with riot police who fired tear gas in the highland town of Santa Cruz del Quiché, in the eighth day of protests around the country over a free-trade deal with the United States. President Óscar Berger signed the accord into law on Tuesday, as a teacher was killed and several people seriously injured when hundreds of police officers and soldiers tried to disperse a protest in the Huehuetenango region, near Mexico. Witnesses said the security forces used live ammunition.

column2: EISDORFER, SIMON; NEW YORK CITY; POLICE DEPARTMENT; BIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
column3: Simon Eisdorfer Dies at 87; Began Police Hostage Team
column9: Former New York City police chief Simon Eisdorfer first conceived of his negotiating team in 1972, after 11 Israeli athletes were taken hostage at the Olympic Games in Munich.
column10: Simon Eisdorfer, a retired New York City police chief who developed the department's widely emulated hostage negotiation team, died on Wednesday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Cedarhurst, N.Y. The cause was heart failure, his granddaughter Jennifer Waitman said.

column2: GUTIERREZ, LUCIO; ECUADOR; ANDEAN COMMUNITY; JUDGES; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; APPOINTMENTS AND EXECUTIVE CHANGES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ATTORNEYS GENERAL
column3: Ecuador's Chief Seeks Help in Court Dispute
column9: President Lucio Gutiérrez asked for international help to end a dispute over the dismissal of the country's Supreme Court.
column10: President Lucio Gutiérrez asked Wednesday for international help to end a dispute over the dismissal of the country's Supreme Court. Congress dismissed the judges in December at the president's behest.

column2: WOODROW, DAVID; SOLLAND, JAMES; DAYTON (OHIO); SCHENECTADY (NY); MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS
column3: Metro Briefing | New York: Fugitive In 1999 Murder Arrested In Ohio
column9: A man wanted in a 1999 murder in Schenectady was captured in Dayton, Ohio, after the police and federal marshals forced him out of a house with tear gas, the authorities said. Marshals had received a tip that the suspect, David Woodrow, 31, was...
column10: A man wanted in a 1999 murder in Schenectady was captured in Dayton, Ohio, after the police and federal marshals forced him out of a house with tear gas, the authorities said. Marshals had received a tip that the suspect, David Woodrow, 31, was living in the area, and that trail led to the house. Mr. Woodrow, who is accused of fatally shooting James Holland, barricaded himself in the house when the authorities arrived, but surrendered after resisting the tear gas for about half an hour. Deputy Marshal Craig Martin said Mr. Woodrow was being held without bond at the Montgomery County jail. He is scheduled for a court appearance today.

column2: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER; STEROIDS; LABOR; SOCCER; TESTS AND TESTING; DRUG ABUSE AND TRAFFIC; ORGANIZED LABOR
column3: Contract Has Strict Drug Policy
column9: M.L.S. has adopted the list of banned substances issued by the World Anti-Doping Agency.
column10: Under the terms of the first collective-bargaining agreement between Major League Soccer and the union representing its players, Commissioner Don Garber has the authority to nullify a player's contract for testing positive for a performance-enhancing drug. In the context of the steroids controversy that has engulfed baseball and has affected other professional sports in North America and some Olympic sports, M.L.S. asserts that its policy, while strict, is not new and has only been codified in the new union contract. The policy includes random testing for illegal steroids and recreational drugs.

column2: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA; MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY; NCAA BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT; BASKETBALL
column3: Michigan St. Fans Turn Rowdy
column9: Police officers in riot gear dispersed rowdy Michigan State fans who poured into the streets after their team's loss in the men's Final Four on Saturday night, resulting in more than 60 arrests.    Most of the arrests were for disorderly conduct, the...
column10: Police officers in riot gear dispersed rowdy Michigan State fans who poured into the streets after their team's loss in the men's Final Four on Saturday night, resulting in more than 60 arrests. Most of the arrests were for disorderly conduct, the police said Sunday.

column2: LOME (TOGO); TOGO; CHILDREN AND YOUTH; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
column3: In Togo, Youths Fight Police Over Vote Plan
column9: Youths burned tires and hurled rocks at riot police officers in Togo's capital after security forces broke up a march that demanded that presidential elections be delayed.
column10: Youths burned tires and hurled rocks at riot police officers in Togo's capital on Friday after security forces broke up a march that demanded that presidential elections scheduled for this month be delayed. There were unconfirmed reports of protests in other parts of Togo. A leading opposition party said one protester was shot dead and five injured in Yoto, northeast of here.

column2: GUELLEH, ISMAIL OMAR; DJIBOUTI; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Djibouti's Leader Wins Uncontested Vote
column9: The incumbent, Ismail Omar Guelleh, won Djibouti's presidential election in an uncontested race.
column10: The incumbent, Ismail Omar Guelleh, won Djibouti's presidential election in an uncontested race on Friday, election officials said, after hundreds of people protesting against the voting clashed with police. Officials said early results showed that 73 percent to 86 percent of the electorate had voted for Mr. Guelleh, with ballots from 149 of the more than 200 voting booths counted.

column2: GUTIERREZ, LUCIO; QUITO (ECUADOR); ECUADOR; ATTACKS ON POLICE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Police And Protesters Clash In Capital
column9: The police in the capital, Quito, clashed with protesters who blocked streets with burning tires after the government and Congress failed to reach a truce in a struggle for control of the country's courts. Yelling slogans against President Lucio...
column10: The police in the capital, Quito, clashed with protesters who blocked streets with burning tires after the government and Congress failed to reach a truce in a struggle for control of the country's courts. Yelling slogans against President Lucio Gutíerrez, several thousand demonstrators brought parts of the city to a halt and paralyzed transport. Schools and municipal offices remained closed and commercial activity was disrupted. Riot police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters, and soldiers guarded the presidential palace.

column2: GUTIERREZ, LUCIO; PALACIO, ALFREDO; QUITO (ECUADOR); BRAZIL; ECUADOR; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; ASYLUM (POLITICAL); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; FOREIGN SERVICE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Ecuador's Leader Flees and Vice President Replaces Him
column9: President Lucio Gutiérrez of Ecuador fled after the Congress, meeting in special session, voted to remove him.
column10: President Lucio Gutiérrez of Ecuador fled his presidential palace on Wednesday after the Congress, meeting in special session, voted to remove him. The Congress then swore in Vice President Alfredo Palacio, a 66-year-old cardiologist, to replace Mr. Gutiérrez, 48, a former army colonel who had faced mounting street protests against what critics called an illegal overhaul of the Supreme Court. Mr. Gutiérrez, who took office in January 2003, became the third president since 1997 to be ousted from power in the small but oil-rich Andean country, which has close economic ties to the United States. In 1997, Abdalá Bucaram was declared mentally unfit to govern and fled into exile. In 2000, President Jamil Mahuad was ousted in a coup supported by Mr. Gutiérrez, then an army colonel.

column2: TOGO; PRESIDENTS AND PRESIDENCY (US); ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Word of Togo Leader's Victory Ignites Clashes
column9: After the announcement that the son of longtime leader Gnassingbé Eyadéma had won Sunday's presidential election, police and opposition supporters clashed.
column10: Togo's electoral commission on Tuesday declared Faure Gnassingbé, the son of the longtime leader Gnassingbé Eyadéma, the winner in Sunday's presidential election. Within minutes of the announcement, police officers and opposition supporters were clashing on the streets, and the skies grew dark with smoke from burning barricades. Clashes continued throughout the day, with the police firing tear gas and bullets at protesters who threw rocks, cut down trees to block thoroughfares and stockpiled Molotov cocktails. At least four people were reported wounded by gunfire, and many homes and stores were looted. By the end of the day, the country's borders remained closed and all phone service had been cut off.

column2: EYADEMA, GNASSINGBE; GNASSINGBE, FAURE; TOGO; ANEHO (TOGO); VIOLENCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Togo Troops Kill 9 After Attack on Police Station
column9: After residents attacked and burned a police station, Togolese soldiers rampaged through the town on Tuesday and Wednesday, killing nine people and wounding 61.
column10: After residents attacked and burned a police station here, Togolese soldiers rampaged through the town on Tuesday and Wednesday, killing nine people and wounding 61, a Red Cross official reported Thursday. The violence indicated that the government and armed forces are taking a hard line against the violent protests that followed a presidential election on Sunday in which Faure Gnassingbé, the son of the country's longtime dictator, Eyadéma Gnassingbé, was declared the winner, with 60 percent of the vote. The opposition contends that the election was unfair.

column2: BOLTON, JOHN R; WASHINGTON (DC); UNITED NATIONS
column3: Never Shy, Bolton Brings a Zeal to the Table
column9: John Bolton, the U.N. nominee, is a conservative among conservatives who has long embraced the role of contrarian.
column10: In the tumultuous days before John R. Bolton graduated from Yale University in 1970, he and his roommates leaned mattresses against the windows to keep out stray tear gas shells. The trial of a top Black Panther in New Haven had ignited riots and set off a national uproar. The National Guard patrolled the campus in tanks. A bomb went off at the hockey rink.

column2: PEARL, DANIEL; LIBBI, ABU FARAJ AL-; BUSH, GEORGE W; ZAWAHIRI, AYMAN AL-; MUSHARRAF, PERVEZ; FAROOQ, AMJAD HUSSAIN; BIN LADEN, OSAMA; PAKISTAN; PESHAWAR (PAKISTAN); AL QAEDA; WALL STREET JOURNAL; ASSASSINATIONS AND ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATIONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; TERRORISM
column3: Pakistan Reports Arrest of a Senior Qaeda Leader
column9: President Bush called Abu Faraj al-Libbi's arrest a "critical victory in the war on terror," but counterterrorism experts were skeptical.
column10: Pakistani authorities announced yesterday the arrest of a senior operative for Al Qaeda who is suspected of directing two failed assassination attempts against the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. Both Pakistani and American officials described the man, a Libyan named Abu Faraj al-Libbi, as the third most senior leader in Al Qaeda's terrorist network, and President Bush called the arrest a ''critical victory in the war on terror.'' But counterterrorism experts in Europe immediately raised questions about Mr. Libbi's importance.

column2: KENNEDY, EDWARD M; DOYLE, JIM; UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN; PEACE CORPS
column3: Heart From the Heartland: Peace Corps Is Special Tradition at Wisconsin
column9: For each of the last 10 years, the University of Wisconsin has supplied the most entrants to the Peace Corps of any college or university.
column10: FOUR hundred miles deep into the North African desert, Jim Doyle gathered the bundle of aerograms and month-old magazines that were his link to a former world, the one he had left behind to join the Peace Corps. This particular day in November 1967, the mail carried news about his college campus and hometown, the University of Wisconsin in Madison. There had been a protest against the Vietnam War, specifically a blockade against recruiters for the company that made napalm, and it had ended with tear gas, billy clubs, arrests and demonstrators taunting cops with cries of ''Sieg heil!'' Even at such a distance, Mr. Doyle could not call himself entirely surprised. In his senior year, he had seen the university's radicals shout down Senator Edward M. Kennedy. This was the brother of the president who had created the Peace Corps, and who before that was the presidential candidate a 14-year-old Jim had met on a campaign stop in Madison. ''I understand you play shortstop,'' John F. Kennedy had said, having been well-briefed about the son of a prominent local politician.

column3: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Clashes Outside Congress
column9: The police in La Paz lobbed tear gas to repel dynamite-throwing protesters and protect Congress as thousands of people converged on the capital demanding nationalization of the energy sector while cutting off airport access and paralyzing public...
column10: The police in La Paz lobbed tear gas to repel dynamite-throwing protesters and protect Congress as thousands of people converged on the capital demanding nationalization of the energy sector while cutting off airport access and paralyzing public transportation. Despite a guarantee of safety from President Carlos Mesa, who has struggled to stay in office, just a quarter of the country's lawmakers ventured into the city's narrow colonial streets and past heavily guarded police barriers for first congressional session in weeks.

column2: ETHIOPIA; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Ethiopian Students and Police Clash Over Disputed Election Results
column9: The violence killed one person, injured seven and led to hundreds of arrests.
column10: Student demonstrators clashed with the police on Monday over disputed Ethiopian election results, a police statement said. The violence killed one person, injured seven and led to hundreds of arrests. Students at Addis Ababa University campuses had defied a government ban against demonstrations, holding the first public protest against how legislative elections on May 15 were conducted. The police charged into crowds to grab protesters, beating some with riot sticks.

column2: MESA, CARLOS; SILES, JOSE IGNACIO; LA PAZ (BOLIVIA); BOLIVIA; ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES; SUSPENSIONS, DISMISSALS AND RESIGNATIONS; INDIANS, AMERICAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Bolivia's Capital Reels From Surging Protests
column9: Thousands streamed into the Bolivian capital as Indian protests against the ruling elite gained force even after President Carlos Mesa offered his resignation.
column10: Thousands streamed into the Bolivian capital, La Paz, on Tuesday as Indian protests against the ruling elite gained force even after President Carlos Mesa offered his resignation. The critical highway to the highlands, where the international airport is situated, remained cut off by roadblocks, and the city of one million people was hit by food shortages and a transport strike.

column2: CALIFORNIA; ROADS AND TRAFFIC; KIDNAPPING
column3: National Briefing | West: California: Man Captured After Freeway Standoff
column9: A man suspected of attempted kidnapping was captured after a freeway chase and standoff in Southern California that lasted six and a half hours. The man, whose identity was not immediately released, tried to kidnap a woman in the wealthy Lake...
column10: A man suspected of attempted kidnapping was captured after a freeway chase and standoff in Southern California that lasted six and a half hours. The man, whose identity was not immediately released, tried to kidnap a woman in the wealthy Lake Sherwood area, the police said. The woman escaped, and the man drove off in a van, the police said. He was chased for three hours until crashing in Alhambra, the police said. The driver, who the police said was armed, remained in the van for three hours before Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies shoved a tear gas grenade into the van, shot and wounded the man and sent a dog to drag him out. Traffic on Interstate 10 was backed up for miles while a negotiator talked to the man.

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-7    U.S. Trained Uzbek Forces Tied to Recent Crackdown  Uzbek law enforcement and security ministries implicated by witnesses in the deadly crackdown in the city of Andijon last month have for years received training and...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 U.S. Trained Uzbek Forces Tied to Recent Crackdown Uzbek law enforcement and security ministries implicated by witnesses in the deadly crackdown in the city of Andijon last month have for years received training and equipment from counterterrorism programs run by the United States, according to American officials and Congressional records. A1 Brazil Official Resigns Brazil's deepening corruption scandal has claimed its first prominent victim, with the man who is President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's chief of staff and closest adviser stepping down after allegations that he knew of and encouraged a multimillion-dollar scheme to buy votes in Congress. A3 North Korea Demands Respect North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, said that the nation was ready to resume negotiations over its nuclear arms program as early as next month, provided the United States treated the country with respect, according to the South Korean government. A5 House Votes Cut in U.N. Dues Defying the Bush administration, the House passed a bill that would cut by half the dues paid by the United States to the United Nations unless the international organization drastically overhauled its operations. A5 Kyrgyzstan Political Protesters Several hundred protesters stormed the main government building in Bishkek in support of a minor presidential candidate, but riot police officers using tear gas and batons retook the building hours later. A6 Iran to Hold Runoff Election For the first time since the Islamic revolution in 1979, Iran will have a runoff election to chose a president after voters failed to give any one of the seven candidates in the race the 50 percent of the vote needed to win, an Interior Ministry spokesman announced. A7 NATIONAL A8-10 Governor Asks for Inquiry Into Schiavo's Collapse Gov. Jeb Bush asked a state prosecutor to investigate the circumstances of Terri Schiavo's 1990 collapse, saying a new autopsy report revealed a possible gap between when Ms. Schiavo fell unconscious and when her husband called paramedics. A1 Bush Encounters Protest President Bush visited Maple Grove, Minn., to promote the Medicare drug benefit enacted 18 months ago, but was greeted by people protesting his plan to overhaul Social Security. A10 A Shaken State Even in California, a state accustomed to earthquakes, there has been an unbearable outbreak the past few days, with four sizeable temblors since Sunday. A8 Restoring Felons' Votes Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa said he would restore voting rights for all felons who finished their sentences, ending what advocates had called one of the country's most restrictive disenfranchisement laws. A8 Concerns About a Speech Senator Barack Obama, the Illinois Democrat, said he might try to block the confirmation of a high-level nominee to the State Department out of concerns over racially insensitive comments attributed to her. A10 Bishops Maintain Abuse Policy The nation's Roman Catholic bishops voted overwhelmingly to continue barring abusive priests from public ministry, a policy written as the American church was engulfed in a clergy abuse scandal. A10 SCIENCE/HEALTH Draft on Global Warming The Bush administration has succeeded in removing language from a joint statement being negotiated in advance of the annual Group of 8 summit calling for prompt action to control global warming and specific targets for doing so. A9 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 2nd Helicopter in 4 Days Crashes Into the East River For the second time in less than a week, a helicopter taking off from Manhattan crashed into the East River, sending the chief executive officer and other top officers of MBNA, the nation's largest credit card company, into a watery chaos where they struggled to survive. B1 Republican Leaders Wanted As Gov. George E. Pataki prepares to reveal his political plans for 2006, New York's Republican Party is riven by conflicts in finding formidable candidates for three key races next year: governor, attorney general and the United States Senate seat held by Hillary Rodham Clinton. A1 Killed in Betrayal The hometowns of the soldier accused of killing his commanding officers in Iraq and of the officers themselves are struggling to understand this episode from Iraq so confounding that it stands apart from the already bewildering pulse of war. B1 Beliefs B5 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-8 Three Share Lead at Open The second round of the United States Open finished with a three-way tie for the lead, shared between Retief Goosen, first-round leader Olin Browne, and Jason Gore. D1 OBITUARIES A11 ARTS B7-19 Politics at PBS E-mail messages obtained by investigators at the Corporation for Public Broadcasting show that its chairman extensively consulted a White House official shortly before she joined the corporation about creating an ombudsman's office there. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Ex-Tyco Executives Convicted L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, and his top lieutenant were convicted of fraud, conspiracy and grand larceny charges. A1 Heart Devices Are Recalled At the urging of the Food and Drug Administration, the Guidant Corporation said it was recalling about 29,000 implanted heart devices because of flaws that might cause them to short-circuit when they are supposed to deliver a potentially life-saving shock. A1 Theft of Credit Card Data MasterCard International reported that more than 40 million credit card accounts of all brands may have been exposed to fraud through a computer security breach at a payment processing company, perhaps the single largest case of stolen data to date. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: Who we are; Congress assaults the courts, again; politics and Terri Schiavo; Eleanor Randolph on barbecue. Columns: Stacy Schiff, John Tierney. Bridge B14 TV Listings B19 Crossword B18 Weather B20

column2: KYRGYZSTAN; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Kyrgyz Police Oust Protesters at Capital Offices
column9: Police officers using tear gas and batons routed protesters who stormed the main government building in support of a minor presidential candidate.
column10: Several hundred protesters stormed the main government building in Bishkek on Friday in support of a minor presidential candidate, but riot police officers using tear gas and batons retook the building hours later. In events reminiscent of the ousting of President Askar Akayev in an uprising on March 24, a crowd of around 2,500 supporters of the candidate, Urmatbek Baryktabasov, a wealthy businessman, rallied in the capital to demand that he be allowed to run in the July 10 elections. Then an estimated 500 forced their way inside the building.

column3: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Third Term For Leader Backed
column9: Parliament overwhelmingly backed the removal of presidential term limits, a measure critics say is intended to install President Yoweri Museveni for life. The police fired tear gas to disperse scores of protesters. The opposition has warned that the...
column10: Parliament overwhelmingly backed the removal of presidential term limits, a measure critics say is intended to install President Yoweri Museveni for life. The police fired tear gas to disperse scores of protesters. The opposition has warned that the lifting of term limits may lead to political turmoil.

column3: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Police Break Up Protest Over Election Delay
column9: The police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse large demonstrations in Kinshasa staged by activists upset that presidential elections have been delayed into next year. News services reported numerous injuries and dozens of arrests. President...
column10: The police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse large demonstrations in Kinshasa staged by activists upset that presidential elections have been delayed into next year. News services reported numerous injuries and dozens of arrests. President Joseph Kabila, the transitional leader, will remain in office until the nationwide elections are held. A peace deal that ended years of war in Congo set June 30 as the election day but allowed the government to delay voting for up to a year. Marc Lacey (NYT)

column3: NEWS SUMMARY
column9: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Strict Shiite Religious Rule Dominates Oil Port in Iraq  The once libertine oil port of Basra, 350 miles south of Baghdad and far from the insurgency raging in much of Iraq, is steadily being transformed into a...
column10: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Strict Shiite Religious Rule Dominates Oil Port in Iraq The once libertine oil port of Basra, 350 miles south of Baghdad and far from the insurgency raging in much of Iraq, is steadily being transformed into a mini-theocracy under Shiite rule. A6 The group that claims it kidnapped Egypt's top diplomat in Iraq said in an Internet posting that a religious court had condemned him to die and that he had been handed over to fighters to carry out the sentence. A10 Israel Denies Discord in Gaza The spokesman for Prime Minister Ariel Sharon denied an article published in The New York Times that said Israelis and Palestinians had failed to agree on how to deal with the houses of settlers who will be pulled out of Gaza. A10 Bush Arrives for G8 Summit President Bush arrived in Scotland for a summit meeting of the big industrial nations after signaling that he would not budge on one of the most contentious issues dividing the United States from its allies, how best to address global warming. A14 Temple Attack Sparks Protest Police in India fired tear gas at demonstrators in New Delhi who were protesting an attack on a disputed religious site, that has emerged a potent symbol of sectarian strife. A9 U.S. Balks at Colombian Law Colombia's new law to demobilize paramilitary death squads suffered a blow when lawmakers in Washington threatened to block money President Álvaro Uribe's government needs to put the law into effect. A5 Prince Albert II Recognizes Heir Prince Albert II of Monaco recognized paternity of a boy born to a former stewardess nearly two years ago, conferring to the boy the rights to a portion of his fortune. A4 NATIONAL A15-20 Times Reporter Is Jailed For Keeping Source Secret Judith Miller, a reporter for The New York Times, was sent to jail after a federal judge declared that she was ''defying the law'' by refusing to divulge the name of a confidential source. Matthew Cooper of Time magazine, was spared a prison sentence after announcing a last-minute deal that he said would allow him to testify before a grand jury. A1 First Hurricane of the Season With fresh memories of last year's barrage of deadly storms, Floridians kept a watchful eye on Hurricane Dennis, the year's first. A20 New England Fights for Bases Officials from five New England states asked the independent commission analyzing the proposed military-base closings to spare their states, saying the Pentagon used faulty information, inflated savings and incomplete criteria. A15 Trial on Clean Air Act Opens American Electric Power, the nation's biggest power generating company, broke the Clean Air Act by failing to cut emissions at plants in four states, a federal lawyer argued as the government opened a lawsuit against the utility. A15 Limbaugh Records Released A Florida judge released medical records of the commentator Rush Limbaugh to prosecutors, allowing them to move forward in an investigation into whether Mr. Limbaugh illegally bought painkillers. A18 Bush Presses Senate on Court In his most extensive comments to date on the subject, President Bush admonished the Senate not to heed ''the special interest groups, particularly those on the extremes'' as he moves towards a Supreme Court nomination. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 Rapper Lil' Kim Sentenced To One Year for Perjury The rapper known as Lil' Kim was sentenced to serve a year and a day in federal prison and pay a $50,000 fine for perjury, after she made a surprise admission that she had lied to a grand jury and again during her trial. B1 Obstacle for Brooklyn Arena A rival of developer Bruce C. Ratner submitted a competing bid to buy and develop the site of a proposed Nets arena, throwing up the first significant obstacle to Mr. Ratner's plan to create an urban hub at the eastern edge of Downtown Brooklyn. A1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-7 London Wins 2012 Games In a surprising upset over front-running Paris, London was chosen by the International Olympic Committee to host the 2012 Summer Games. New York, one of the five cities in contention, was knocked out of the race in the second round of voting. A1 After his hopes of bringing the Olympics to New York collapsed, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged what many others had been saying for several years -- that the bid had been a long shot. A1 HOUSE & HOME F1-8 THURSDAY STYLES G1-8 ARTS E1-10 OBITUARIES B10-11 L. Patrick Gray III The former acting director of the F.B.I., whose early missteps in handling the Watergate investigation made him a victim of a scandal he helped expose, he was 88. B11 BUSINESS DAY C1-17 Cnooc Head Discusses Unocal The chairman of Cnooc Ltd. faces delicate dual tasks in his company's $18.5 billion bid to buy Unocal -- he must prove his political reliability to Chinese leaders as he works to persuade the United States that his company cares only about commerce. A1 Health Insurer Acquisition UnitedHealth Group made a big push into the rapidly growing Medicare market by agreeing to buy Pacificare Health Systems for $8.14 billion. C1 Study Faults Insurers A study to be released by the Center for Justice and Democracy finds that net claims for medical malpractice paid by 15 leading insurance companies have remained flat over the last five years, while net premiums have increased 120 percent. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Judith Miller goes to jail. Columns: Bob Herbert. Bridge E4 TV Listings E9 Crossword E6 Weather D8

column2: NEW DELHI (INDIA); INDIA; AYODHYA (INDIA); HINDUISM; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Thousands Are Arrested in India in Unrest Over Temple Site
column9: Demonstrators on Wednesday protested an attack on a disputed religious site that has emerged as India's most potent symbol of sectarian strife.
column10: The police on Wednesday fired tear gas at hundreds of demonstrators in the center of this city, the Indian capital, who were protesting an attack on a disputed religious site that has emerged as India's most potent symbol of sectarian strife. A day after the attack on the site, the temple compound in the northern town of Ayodhya, protesters led by the opposition Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, and their allied organizations, also stormed the airport and hurled potted plants in Indore, a central Indian city, and smashed car windows in Ranchi, in eastern Jharkhand State.

column2: NETHERLANDS; EUROPEAN UNION; MURDERS AND ATTEMPTED MURDERS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ISLAM
column3: Tolerating a Time Bomb
column9: How Holland, land of Erasmus, became a jihadist hotbed.
column10: FOR centuries the Netherlands has been considered the most tolerant and liberal nation in the world. This attitude is a byproduct of a disciplined civic society, confident enough to provide space for those with different ideas. It produced the country in which Descartes found refuge, a center of freedom of thought and of a free press in Europe. That Netherlands no longer exists.

column2: LOS ANGELES (CALIF); POLICE DEPARTMENT; VIOLENCE
column3: Neighbors Mourn Child Killed in Shootout and Say the Police Should Have Held Their Fire
column9: Many in the Watts neighborhood seemed as angered with the Los Angeles Police Department as they were with the 19-month-old girl's father.
column10: Neither the stream of visitors paying their respects to 19-month-old Suzie Marie Peña nor the anger over how she died has abated in the neighborhood where she was killed by the police a week ago in a shootout between her father and SWAT officers. Residents gathered at a makeshift memorial outside the run-down car dealership where the girl and her father, Jose Raul Peña, 34, died as he held her to his chest last Sunday while exchanging gunfire with the police for nearly three hours.

column2: XINCHANG (CHINA); CHINA; WATER POLLUTION; HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC SUBSTANCES; ENVIRONMENT; DRUGS (PHARMACEUTICALS); POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ETHICS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; FACTORIES AND INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; RURAL AREAS
column3: Riots in a Village in China as Pollution Protest Heats Up
column9: Recent riots in Xinchang are a part of a rising tide of discontent in China, where the number of mass protests is skyrocketing.
column10: After three nights of increasingly heavy rioting, the police were taking no chances on Monday, deploying dozens of busloads of officers before dusk and blocking every road leading to the factory. But the angry residents in this village 180 miles south of Shanghai had learned their lessons, too, they said, having studied reports of riots in towns near and far that have swept rural China in recent months. Sneaking over mountain paths and wading through rice paddies, they made their way to a pharmaceuticals plant, they said, determined to pursue a showdown over the environmental threat they say it poses.

column2: GREAT BRITAIN; TRANSIT SYSTEMS; TERRORISM
column3: BRITAIN SAYS MAN KILLED BY POLICE HAD NO BOMB TIE
column9: The man was identified by police as a 27-year-old Brazilian, described by officers as an electrician on his way to work.
column10: Scotland Yard admitted Saturday that a man police officers gunned down at point-blank range in front of horrified subway passengers on Friday had nothing to do with the investigation into the bombing attacks here. The man was identified by police as Jean Charles de Menezes, a 27-year-old Brazilian, described by officers as an electrician on his way to work. ''He was not connected to incidents in central London on 21st July, 2005, in which four explosive devices were partly detonated,'' a police statement said.

column3: POLICE IN LONDON AND ROME ARREST 4 BOMB SUSPECTS
column9: The police in London and Rome, acting several hours apart on Friday, arrested the remaining bombing suspects in the July 21 failed attacks in London, according to a Scotland Yard official, placing the four main suspects in police custody.      In...
column10: The police in London and Rome, acting several hours apart on Friday, arrested the remaining bombing suspects in the July 21 failed attacks in London, according to a Scotland Yard official, placing the four main suspects in police custody. In addition, the police arrested a man in West London who they say might have been a fifth bomber in the plot , the official said, speaking in return for anonymity under police rules.

column2: SEIDEN, MARK; COMPUTER SECURITY; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; BANKS AND BANKING
column3: The Sniffer vs. the Cybercrooks
column9: Sniffers, people paid to test a computer network's security, must do their best to think like an enterprising cyberthief.
column10: THE investment bank, despite billions in annual revenue and the small squadron of former police, military and security officers on its payroll, was no match for Mark Seiden. ''Tell me the things you most want to keep secret,'' Mr. Seiden challenged a top executive at the bank a few years back. The executive listed two. One involved the true identities of clients negotiating deals so hush-hush that even people inside the bank referred to them by using a code name. The other was the financial details of those mergers and acquisitions.

column3: Suspect Held in Italy Said to Admit Carrying Bomb in Train
column9: A suspect in the failed July 21 bombings arrested in Rome on Friday confessed to investigators to carrying a bomb through London's subway, but claimed it was meant as a ''demonstration'' rather than as a means of killing, a person with firsthand...
column10: A suspect in the failed July 21 bombings arrested in Rome on Friday confessed to investigators to carrying a bomb through London's subway, but claimed it was meant as a ''demonstration'' rather than as a means of killing, a person with firsthand knowledge of the interrogation said on Saturday. The investigation appeared to move quickly on Saturday, with this first reported confession from one of five suspected plotters in custody. Britain pressed for the suspect in Rome to be returned for interrogation, and the police in Italy continued to carry out raids.

column2: WEST BANK; ISRAEL; UNITED STATES; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
column3: Israel to Freeze Growth of West Bank Settlement, Official Says
column9: Israel has bowed to the U.S. and frozen a much-criticized plan to add 3,500 new housing units near a large West Bank settlement.
column10: Israel has bowed to the United States and frozen a much-criticized plan to add 3,500 housing units near a large West Bank settlement, Maale Adumim, according to Ehud Olmert, Israel's deputy prime minister and a close ally of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. But Mr. Olmert's comments, in an interview published Friday in The Jerusalem Post, were more an indication of political repositioning in a heated right-wing political competition than an enunciation of new policy. Israel has often made it clear that any building near Maale Adumim, an area known as E-1, would not begin for at least two years.

column3: Synagogue Dispute Clouds Gaza Transfer
column9: The Israeli Army demolished the last of its buildings and watchtowers in preparation for a handover to the Palestinians on Sunday or Monday.
column10: The Israeli Army completed the removal of its military equipment from the Gaza Strip on Friday, demolishing the last of its buildings and watchtowers, in preparation for a transfer to the Palestinians on Sunday or Monday. The only Israeli buildings that remain standing in Gaza are the army division headquarters, which will be handed over to the Palestinian Authority, and most of the synagogues of the Israeli settlements, which became the topic of a dispute within the Israeli government.

column2: ALABAMA; BLACKS; CIVIL RIGHTS; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
column3: Joseph Smitherman, Mayor In Selma Strife, Dies at 75
column9: In more than 35 years as mayor of Selma, Ala., Joseph T. Smitherman went from ardent support of segregation to pride in his backing among blacks.
column10: Joseph T. Smitherman, who in more than 35 years as mayor of Selma, Ala., went from ardent support of segregation at the time of the notorious 1965 beatings there to pride in his backing among blacks, died on Sunday in Montgomery, Ala. He was 75. No specific cause of death has been determined, said Jackie Checkler, a manager at Lawrence Brown Service Funeral Home in Selma. The Associated Press reported that he was recuperating from hip surgery and had heart problems.

column2: FRIED, CHARLES; LEWIS, JOHN; BUSH, GEORGE W; THORNBURGH, RICHARD L; TOBER, STEPHEN L; ROBERTS, JOHN G JR; TALLMAN, ANNE MARIE; SENATE; SUPREME COURT
column3: Republicans Speak of Respect of Roberts's Peers, and Democrats Issue Warnings
column9: Following are excerpts from the Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearings yesterday for Judge John G. Roberts Jr., President Bush's nominee to be chief justice. Among those testifying were Stephen L. Tober, the chairman of the American Bar...
column10: Following are excerpts from the Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearings yesterday for Judge John G. Roberts Jr., President Bush's nominee to be chief justice. Among those testifying were Stephen L. Tober, the chairman of the American Bar Association; two Republican witnesses, Richard L. Thornburgh, attorney general under the first President Bush, and Charles Fried, a professor at Harvard Law School and the solicitor general in the Reagan administration; and two called by Democrats, Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, and Anne Marie Tallman, president and legal counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund. The statements were recorded by the Federal News Service. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/supremecourt. Mr. Tober For more than 50 years the A.B.A. Standing Committee has provided a unique and comprehensive examination of the professional qualifications of candidates for the federal bench. It is comprised of 15 distinguished lawyers who represent every judicial circuit in the United States and who individually volunteer hundreds of hours in public service to our profession. This committee conducts a thorough, nonpartisan, nonideological peer review. And it does so by using long-established standards that measure the nominee's integrity, professional competence and judicial temperament. In the sense that a major portion of the investigation consists of scores and scores of interviews with judges and lawyers, it is very much the voice of the bench and bar of this nation. ...

column2: UZBEKISTAN; EUROPEAN UNION; EMBARGOES AND ECONOMIC SANCTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Europeans Set Arms Embargo To Protest Uzbeks' Crackdown
column9: The European Union imposed sanctions seeking to punish Uzbekistan for its refusal to allow an investigation into the bloody crackdown of an uprising in May.
column10: The European Union imposed sanctions on Uzbekistan on Monday, seeking to punish the country for its refusal to allow an international investigation into the bloody crackdown of an uprising in May in Andijon. The sanctions embargo exports to Uzbekistan of arms and equipment that might be used for internal repression, and suspend meetings between the union and Uzbekistan that were intended to accelerate the nation's reconciliation with the West after decades as a Soviet republic. The sanctions also ban travel by Uzbek officials directly involved in the Andijon crackdown to the 25 members of the European Union.

column2: ISRAEL; PALESTINIANS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: At Israeli Barrier, More Sound Than Fury
column9: The Israeli Army and a crowd of protesters squared off almost joyfully for their weekly tactical battle over the construction of Israel's separation barrier.
column10: The Israeli Army and a crowd of protesters squared off almost joyfully on Friday for their weekly tactical battle here over the construction of Israel's separation barrier, one of the closest spectacles the region provides to Kabuki theater. The protesters, on this day a mix of 150 Israelis, foreigners and local Palestinians, were eager to take their case against the barrier to the world through the news media and to try to provoke the army and the police into overreacting.

column3: Violence Halts White Supremacist March
column9: A crowd gathered to protest a white supremacists' march turned violent on Saturday, throwing rocks at police, vandalizing property and setting fires.
column10: A crowd that gathered to protest a white supremacists' march turned violent on Saturday, throwing baseball-size rocks at the police, vandalizing vehicles and stores, and setting fire to a neighborhood bar, the authorities said. Mayor Jack Ford blamed the rioting on gangs taking advantage of a volatile situation. He declared a state of emergency, set an 8 p.m. curfew through the weekend and asked the State Highway Patrol for help.

column2: ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Church Play Sets Off Muslim Riot in Egypt
column9: Thousands of Muslims rioted outside a Coptic Christian church to denounce a play deemed offensive to Islam. One person died and more than 90 were injured.
column10: Thousands of Muslims rioted outside a Coptic Christian church on Friday to denounce a play deemed offensive to Islam, prompting the police to beat protesters and fire tear gas into the crowd, officials said. One person died and more than 90 were injured. The police said 53 protesters were arrested as people hurled stones, smashed windows and tried to storm St. George Coptic Orthodox Church. Protesters also set a police car on fire and wrecked eight other cars, the Interior Ministry said in a statement.

column2: EGYPT; CHRISTIANS AND CHRISTIANITY; ISLAM; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Egyptian Police Guard Coptic Church Attacked by Muslims
column9: Riot police forces guarded a Coptic Christian church, a day after Muslim protesters tried to storm the building in a demonstration.
column10: Riot police forces armed with shotguns guarded a Coptic Christian church here on Saturday, a day after Muslim protesters tried to storm the building in a demonstration that was broken up when security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets into the crowd. Three people were killed and many more injured in what officials called the worst case of sectarian violence to strike this Mediterranean city in recent memory. The streets remained tense Saturday, and many people warned that foreigners were not welcome. The mood in the city was sour and explosive.

column2: KURLANDER, LAWRENCE T; MONTESINOS, VLADIMIRO; ANDES MOUNTAINS; YANACOCHA (PERU); PERU; NEWMONT MINING CORPORATION; NEWMONT MINING CORP; RECORDINGS (AUDIO); MINES AND MINING; METALS AND MINERALS; SURVEYS AND SERIES; GOLD; BRIBERY
column3: Tangled Strands in Fight Over Peru Gold Mine
column9: Where miners see wealth, local people see sacred mountains and water that sustains their lives.
column10: The Rev. Marco Arana drove his beige pickup over the curves of a dirt road 13,000 feet high in the Andes. Spread out below lay the Yanacocha gold mine, an American-run operation of mammoth open pits and towering heaps of cyanide-laced ore. Ahead loomed the pristine green of untouched hills. Then, an unmistakable sign that this land, too, may soon be devoured: Policemen with black masks and automatic rifles guarding workers exploring ground that the mine's owner, Newmont Mining Corporation, has deemed the next best hope.

column2: KENYA; VIOLENCE; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: 3 Dead and Dozens Hurt in Riot Over Kenyan Charter
column9: Police officers in riot gear opened fire after hundreds of youths tried to stop a rally by four cabinet ministers who support the draft constitution.
column10: At least three people, including an 8-year-old boy, were shot dead and dozens were wounded Saturday in western Kenya as security forces tried to break up a riot over the country's proposed constitution, police and hospital officials said. Police officers in riot gear opened fire after hundreds of youths tried to stop a rally by four cabinet ministers who support the draft constitution, the officials said.

column2: ZANZIBAR (TANZANIA); TANZANIA; VIOLENCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Police and Opposition in Zanzibar Clash During Vote
column9: Regional elections turned violent as the police and the governing party's militia engaged in running clashes with opposition supporters.
column10: Regional elections turned violent on Sunday as the police and the governing party's militia engaged in running clashes with opposition supporters in the streets of the main town in Zanzibar, which is a semiautonomous part of Tanzania. On the edges of the town, Stone Town, the police fired tear gas and water cannons while militiamen for the party, Chama Cha Mapinduzi, beat suspected opponents. More than a dozen people were wounded, hospital officials said.

column2: PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; CLICHY-SOUS-BOIS (FRANCE); IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Violence In Paris Suburb
column9: Clashes between the police and gangs of youths continued for a fourth straight night in the Paris suburb of Clichy-sous-Bois. Six police officers were injured. The interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, pledged to increase security in the district, a...
column10: Clashes between the police and gangs of youths continued for a fourth straight night in the Paris suburb of Clichy-sous-Bois. Six police officers were injured. The interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, pledged to increase security in the district, a poor area with a large immigrant population. He also confirmed reports that a tear gas grenade had been fired toward a local mosque and said an investigation was under way. John Tagliabue (NYT)

column2: KYRGYZSTAN; PRISONS AND PRISONERS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Kyrgyzstan Quiets Two Prisons; Troops Kill 4 Inmates in Battles
column9: Soldiers stormed two prisons, restoring at least the appearance of order to a penitentiary system that had partly slipped from government control last month.
column10: Special forces soldiers stormed two prisons in this Central Asian nation on Tuesday, restoring at least the appearance of order to a federal penitentiary system that had partly slipped from government control last month. Four inmates were killed, the authorities said. Two inmates died in a clash between government troops and prisoners loyal to a crime boss who the authorities said had operated with near impunity here inside Prison No. 31. The crime boss, Aziz Batukayev, was ultimately captured, the authorities said, and moved to the headquarters of Kyrgyzstan's successor to the Soviet K.G.B.

column2: HAILU, BERHANU; ADDIS ABABA (ETHIOPIA); ETHIOPIA; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; VIOLENCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Ethiopian Protesters Killed as East African Clashes Spread
column9: At least two dozen people were killed in an escalation of the discord over the results of the May parliamentary elections.
column10: Ethiopian security forces clashed with protesters on the streets of Addis Ababa on Wednesday, killing at least two dozen people and wounding 150 in an escalation of the discord over the results of the May parliamentary elections. Witnesses described hundreds of police officers and soldiers sweeping through the streets, rounding up young men believed to be tied to the opposition that is challenging the governing party's victory.

column2: SARKOZY, NICHOLAS; PARIS (FRANCE); FRANCE; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; VIOLENCE; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Rioting Spreads in Paris Suburbs as Angry Youths Burn More Cars
column9: Angry youths clashed with police and firefighters outside Paris in the worst of seven straight nights of violence set off by the accidental death of two teenagers.
column10: Angry youths clashed with police and firefighters outside Paris late Wednesday in the worst of seven straight nights of violence set off by the accidental death of two teenagers. By late Thursday, more cars were burning in at least one of the city's northern suburbs. Gunshots were fired at police officers and firefighters in three separate incidents Wednesday night, said Prefect Jean-François Cordet, the government's top official in Seine-St.-Denis, a department north of Paris that includes a belt of working-class neighborhoods with a large immigrant population from North Africa and the sub-Saharan region.

column2: BUSH, GEORGE W; CHAVEZ, HUGO; ARGENTINA; FREE TRADE AREA OF THE AMERICAS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: PROTESTERS RIOT AS BUSH ATTENDS 34-NATION TALKS
column9: As protesters turned violent blocks from the Argentina summit, the Venezuelan chief led a peaceful rally against the U.S.
column10: President Bush's troubles trailed him to an international summit meeting here on Friday as anti-Bush protesters turned violent just blocks from the gathering site, and Hugo Chávez, Venezuela's fiery populist leader, rallied a soccer stadium filled with at least 25,000 people against the United States. Mr. Chávez, who has tried to use the summit meeting to stage a showdown with Mr. Bush, pronounced dead a free trade accord backed by Mr. Bush, the Free Trade Area of the Americas. Left-wing groups throughout Latin America have long opposed the agreement, and some governments want more generous terms from Washington, so Mr. Bush had come here with hopes of jump-starting the stalled negotiations.

column2: TORRIJOS, MARTIN; BUSH, GEORGE W; LATIN AMERICA; PANAMA; PANAMA CANAL; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CANALS
column3: Bush, Meeting Panama's Leader, Endorses Widening of the Canal
column9: The friendly reception was in contrast to some of the hostility President Bush had encountered on a trip to Latin America.
column10: President Bush on Monday endorsed widening the Panama Canal and cited progress in reaching a free-trade agreement with Panama's president, Martín Torrijos, whose friendly reception here was in sharp contrast to some of the hostility that Mr. Bush had encountered on a four-day trip to Latin America. But Mr. Bush, after saying ''we're getting close'' on the trade pact between the United States and Panama, said Democrats might block it in Congress, and blamed them for holding up recent trade deals.

column2: KASHMIR AND JAMMU (INDIA); INDIA; PAKISTAN; KASHMIR AND JAMMU; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Angry Crowds Protest Delays In Reopening Kashmir Border
column9: Protests marred the partial opening of a crossing point along the line of control dividing the Pakistani- and Indian-administered portions of Kashmir.
column10: Protests on Monday marred the partial opening of one of five planned crossing points along the line of control dividing the Pakistani- and Indian-administered portions of Kashmir, Pakistani officials said. Hundreds of Kashmiri men who had gathered on the Pakistani side grew angry when officials blocked them from crossing into Indian-controlled territory, Pakistani officials said. At one point, two men ran toward the boundary with their children but were arrested. Later, the police fired tear gas and shots in the air to disperse protesters, who had begun chanting, ''We want an independent Kashmir.''

column2: CHIRAC, JACQUES; DE VILLEPIN, DOMINIQUE; FRANCE; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; CURFEWS; ARSON; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: FRENCH OFFICIALS TRY TO EASE FEAR AS CRISIS SWELLS
column9: The civil unrest in France claimed its first death while the government sought to show that it could control the situation.
column10: The civil unrest sweeping France spread to nearly every major city in the country by Monday, claiming its first death, and even touched two cities elsewhere in Europe as the French government sought to reassure a jittery nation that it can quickly bring the escalating situation under control. ''The government response is one of firmness,'' Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin said on television late Monday, calling the violence ''unacceptable and inexcusable.'' He said the government would call up 1,500 police reserves to reinforce the 8,000 police officers already waging nightly battles in the streets. He said some towns would impose curfews to keep marauding youths off the streets, but ruled out for now sending the army into the suburbs with populations largely of West African and North African origin where the unrest has grown.

column2: SARKOZY, NICOLAS; CHIRAC, JACQUES; DE VILLEPIN, DOMINIQUE; TOULOUSE (FRANCE); FRANCE; SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; VIOLENCE; IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEES; DISCRIMINATION; CURFEWS; LAW AND LEGISLATION; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: France Declares Emergency; Curfews to Be Imposed
column9: Bands of youths continued to burn cars and battle with the police in strife-torn suburbs across the country.
column10: Unable to quell nearly two weeks of civil unrest across the country, the French government declared a state of emergency on Tuesday, authorizing curfews in its strife-torn suburbs, where bands of youths continued to burn cars and battle with the police. After a series of mostly ineffectual pledges by French leaders to restore order and crack down on vandals, the government invoked a 50-year-old law, dating from the colonial war in Algeria, which gives local officials the authority to call curfews, among other expanded law-enforcement powers.

column2: INDIA; PAKISTAN; KASHMIR AND JAMMU; TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS; EARTHQUAKES
column3: Quake Victims Still Kept Apart in Kashmir
column9: Nothing, not even the death of more than 74,000 people, appears to have made relations between India and Pakistan easy.
column10: With great fanfare 10 days ago, Indian and Pakistani officials agreed to allow people from the earthquake-devastated areas of Kashmir to cross the Line of Control, the heavily militarized boundary between the countries, to comfort family members on the other side. On Wednesday, at this isolated crossing point, between the Pakistani-controlled town of Chakothi and the Indian-controlled town of Uri, not a single Kashmiri crossed the border. Instead, smiling Indian and Pakistani officials exchanged several hundred sacks of aid, posed for photographs and congratulated themselves on taking a ''step in the right direction.''

column2: JOHNSON-SIRLEAF, ELLEN; LIBERIA; INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS
column3: In First for Africa, Woman Wins Election as President of Liberia
column9: Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf emerged victorious as the first woman elected head of state in modern African history.
column10: Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, a Harvard-educated economist and former World Bank official who waged a fierce presidential campaign against the soccer star George Weah, emerged victorious on Friday in her quest to lead war-torn Liberia and become the first woman elected head of state in modern African history. ''Everything is on our side,'' said Morris Dukuly, a spokesman for Ms. Johnson-Sirleaf. ''The voters have chosen a new and brighter future.''

column2: FRANCE; VIOLENCE; ARSON
column3: Paris Police Are on Guard As Fear Rises Over Threats
column9: Unrest continued to percolate through poor, predominantly minority neighborhoods across France on Saturday.
column10: Unrest continued to percolate through poor, predominantly minority neighborhoods across France on Saturday, though by the afternoon there were no signs that the arson attacks would again reach into the heart of the capital as had been feared. The police have invoked emergency measures in Paris, banning unauthorized gatherings until Sunday morning and fanning out across the city to guard landmarks and patrol subways and trains in an effort to prevent further violence. The precautions were taken after the police intercepted calls for ''violent actions'' in the city that had been posted on the Internet or passed by text messages to cellphones.

column2: VATICAN CITY; SWITZERLAND; SWISS GUARD; ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH; POPES
column3: Swiss Guard Marks 500 Years as Popes' Potted Plants
column9: Swiss mercenaries served in a number of countries, but the papal guard is the only one to survive.
column10: In late 1505, Pope Julius II asked the Swiss, an impoverished people at that time before bank secrecy, whose exports consisted mainly of their own sons, to dispatch 200 soldiers to Rome to serve as his personal palace guard. Swiss mercenaries once served in a number of European countries, most notably as the guard of the French kings, but the papal guard is the only one to have survived.

column2: BLAIR, TONY; ZENAWI, MELES; ETHIOPIA; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT
column3: Mr. Good Governance Goes Bad
column9: The only example Meles Zenawi, the Ethiopian prime minister, is setting is one of autocratic repression.
column10: Somebody needs to remind Meles Zenawi that he is supposed to be setting the example for how democracy should work in Africa. As things stand, the only example Mr. Meles, the Ethiopian prime minister, is setting is one of autocratic repression. Mr. Meles has often been lauded as an exemplar of good government by the likes of the British prime minister, Tony Blair, who picked him to help draft his Commission for Africa report on how to reduce poverty and promote democracy on the continent. But it turns out that Mr. Meles is in favor of democracy only when people are voting for him.

column2: ALIYEV, ILHAM; AZERBAIJAN; POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; ELECTIONS
column3: U.S. Warns Azerbaijan
column9: The U.S. urged Azerbaijan to punish those behind a crackdown over the weekend against supporters of the political opposition.
column10: The United States urged Azerbaijan on Monday to punish those behind a violent crackdown over the weekend against supporters of the political opposition. ''We would expect that the government of Azerbaijan hold to account those responsible for the violence against peaceful protesters,'' said the State Department spokesman, Sean McCormack.

column2: EGYPT; MUSLIM BROTHERHOOD; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; VIOLENCE; ELECTIONS; FREEDOM AND HUMAN RIGHTS
column3: Egyptian Vote Is Again Marred By Attacks On Opposition
column9: Security forces killed one person and blocked voters from getting to the polls, independent poll watchers said.
column10: Egyptian security forces killed one person and blocked voters from getting to the polls in opposition strongholds on Thursday in the third round of voting in parliamentary elections, repeating a pattern of violence and intimidation that began after a strong showing by candidates supported by the Muslim Brotherhood, independent poll watchers and election monitors said. In the city of El Mansoura, in the Nile Delta region, men carrying machetes and knives chased away voters and shoved and pushed journalists as police officers stood by and watched, witnesses said.

column2: GRESCOE, TARAS; KINCAID, JAMAICA; FRANCKE, LINDA BIRD; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; TRAVEL AND VACATIONS
column3: TRAVEL
column9: In travel writing, the travel and the writing are important, of course, but don't bother doing either unless you have a third element: the gimmick.
column10: IN travel writing, the travel and the writing are important, of course, but don't bother doing either unless you have a third element: the gimmick. That, at least, seems to be the lesson offered by many of this season's travel books, sometimes subtly, sometimes with a declarative squawk.

column2: BELUSHI: A BIOGRAPHY (BOOK); ONION PRESENTS EMBEDDED IN AMERICA, THE (BOOK); BELUSHI, JOHN; COLBY, TANNER; PISANO, JUDITH BELUSHI; ONION; COMEDY AND HUMOR; BOOKS AND LITERATURE
column3: Sad Clown And Mocking Onion
column9: Belushi is a frank and wide-ranging oral history by John Belushi's widow.
column10: BELUSHI A Biography. By Judith Belushi Pisano and Tanner Colby. 288 pp., Rugged Land. $29.95. The Onion Presents Embedded in America Complete News Archives Volume 16. 312 pp., Three Rivers Press. Paper, $18.95. MANY people's most vivid memory of the comic actor John Belushi is of his performance as the Omega fraternity beast Bluto in the 1978 movie ''Animal House,'' in which he crumpled beer cans on his forehead, danced in a toga to ''Shout'' and stuffed his face at a college cafeteria, then slapped his cheeks to produce a geyser of food, announcing to scandalized coeds, ''I'm a zit.''

column9: Violence on the Final Day of Egypt's Election  Egyptians fled tear gas fired by policemen at a voting site in Zagazig. The Islamist Muslim Brotherhood gained parliamentary seats, raising the question whether political success will moderate its...
column10: Violence on the Final Day of Egypt's Election Egyptians fled tear gas fired by policemen at a voting site in Zagazig. The Islamist Muslim Brotherhood gained parliamentary seats, raising the question whether political success will moderate its image. Page A18. New Plan to Rebuild Iraq President Bush said the strategy for reconstruction was shifting to smaller projects, while he conceded that early efforts had been riddled with mistakes. column2: MUBARAK, HOSNI; EGYPT; LEGISLATURES AND PARLIAMENTS; VIOLENCE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; ELECTIONS
column3: Egyptians Rue Election Day Gone Awry
column9: The end of parliamentary elections was a day to bury the dead, to pray for the wounded and to curse the government.
column10: It seemed as though the whole village had turned out, hundreds of people packed into a narrow cemetery road to express their sorrow and rage at a funeral on Thursday for Moustafa Abdel Salam, a 60-year-old grandfather who took a bullet in the head and became a fatal footnote to Egypt's parliamentary elections. The three rounds of voting ended Wednesday in the fertile farming region of the Nile Delta north of Cairo. But the day after was not a day to discuss politics. For the people of this village and others throughout the area it was a day to bury the dead, to pray for the wounded and to curse the government, which they universally held responsible.

column2: DONGZHOU (CHINA); CHINA; GUANGDONG PROVINCE (CHINA); POLICE BRUTALITY AND MISCONDUCT; ELECTRIC LIGHT AND POWER; WIND; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS; LAND USE POLICIES
column3: Police Fire on Protesters in China, Killing Several
column9: At least four protesters and possibly many more were shot dead this week, as a dispute over land use turned into a protracted confrontation.
column10: At least four protesters and possibly many more were shot dead this week by riot policemen in Guangdong Province, as a simmering dispute over land use turned into a protracted violent confrontation, a rights group and Hong Kong news outlets reported Thursday. The incident occurred in Dongzhou, a coastal village, when paramilitary policemen shot into a crowd of angry villagers who were trying to prevent the construction of a wind-powered electricity plant, according to Amnesty International.

column2: CHINA; DEMONSTRATIONS AND RIOTS
column3: Protesters Say Police in China Killed Up to 20
column9: The unusually violent clash marked an escalation in the widespread social protests roiling the Chinese countryside.
column10: Residents of a fishing village near Hong Kong said Friday that as many as 20 people were killed by the paramilitary police this week, in an unusually violent clash that marked an escalation in the widespread social protests roiling the Chinese countryside. Villagers said as many as 50 other residents remained unaccounted for since the shootings on Tuesday. It was the largest known use of force by security personnel against citizens since the killings around Tiananmen Square in 1989. That death toll is still unknown, but is estimated to have been in the hundreds.

column2: MCCARTHY, EUGENE J; MINNESOTA; SENATE; POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; DEATHS (OBITUARIES)
column3: Eugene J. McCarthy, Senate Dove Who Jolted '68 Race, Dies at 89
column9: Eugene J. McCarthy, a Minnesota Democrat, triggered one of the most tumultuous years in American political history.
column10: Eugene J. McCarthy, the sardonic Senate dove who stunned the nation by upending President Lyndon B. Johnson's re-election drive amid the Vietnam War turmoil of 1968, died early yesterday. He was 89. A courtly, sharp-witted presence in capital politics for half a century, Mr. McCarthy, a Minnesota Democrat, died in his sleep at an assisted-living home in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, where he had lived for the last several years.

column3: Eugene J. McCarthy, Senate Dove Who Jolted '68 Presidential Race, Dies at 89
column9: Eugene J. McCarthy, the sardonic Senate dove who stunned the nation by upending President Lyndon B. Johnson's re-election drive amid the Vietnam War turmoil of 1968, died early Saturday. He was 89.     A courtly, sharp-witted presence in capital...
column10: Eugene J. McCarthy, the sardonic Senate dove who stunned the nation by upending President Lyndon B. Johnson's re-election drive amid the Vietnam War turmoil of 1968, died early Saturday. He was 89. A courtly, sharp-witted presence in capital politics for half a century, Mr. McCarthy, a Minnesota Democrat, died in his sleep at an assisted-living home in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, where he had lived for the last several years.

column2: HONG KONG; WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET
column3: Trade Ministers Continue Talks as Protesters Are Jailed
column9: Trade ministers from around the world made slow progress on Sunday morning, after a night in which the police battled rioting South Korean rice farmers with tear gas and fire hoses.
column10: Trade ministers from around the world tried Sunday morning to conclude a narrow, four-part deal at a conference here, after a night in which police officers outside battled rioting South Korean rice farmers with tear gas and fire hoses. Officials from Australia and the European Union said that the ministers were close to an agreement that would set 2013 as the deadline to eliminate all agricultural export subsidies, but were still debating the pace to phase them out.

There will also be jockeying for important posts within the major Shiite, Kurdish and Sunni Arab blocs. 26 More Saudi Students in U.S. The Saudi Arabian government, urgently trying to improve relations with the United States, has been promoting a scholarship program that has more than doubled the number of Saudi students at American colleges and universities since last year. 34 Slow Progress in Trade Talks Trade ministers from around the world made slow progress at a conference in Hong Kong, with setting a deadline to phase out agricultural export subsidies one of the biggest issues to be negotiated. Overnight, the police battled rioting South Korean rice farmers outside with tear gas and fire hoses. 38 Bolivians Vote for President Bolivians go to the polls to choose a president, with the leading candidate, Evo Morales, promising to decriminalize the cultivation of coca, the crop used to make cocaine. If Mr. Morales gains the presidency, hundreds of millions of dollars in American anti-drug and economic aid could be put in jeopardy. 13 Seeking Recognition in Nigeria Gay Nigerians fighting for acceptance in their country's Anglican church reveal a wider struggle between Africa's deeply conservative religious beliefs and a movement for self-determination. 3 Anthropology's Dream Tribe The Ariaal, a reclusive nomadic community of about 10,000 people in northern Kenya, who are favorites of anthropologists, are now straddling modern life and more traditional ways, after moving closer to a town with cellphone reception and sporadic Internet access. 1 NATIONAL 41-44 Bush Told Agency to Spy President Bush acknowledged that he ordered the National Security Agency to conduct an electronic eavesdropping program in the United States without first obtaining warrants and said he would continue the highly-classified program because it was ''a vital tool in our war against terrorists.'' 1 The National Security Agency first began to conduct warrantless eavesdropping on telephone calls and e-mail messages between the United States and Afghanistan months before President Bush officially authorized a broader version of the agency's special domestic collection program, according to current and former government officials. 44 Congress's Budget Scramble Congress readied a stop-gap bill to keep the Pentagon and other agencies running while lawmakers scrambled to complete a budget-cutting plan and remaining spending measures. 43 Many Victims Died After Storm A study by The New York Times of more than 260 Louisianans who died during Hurricane Katrina or its aftermath found that almost all survived the height of the storm but died in the chaos that followed. 1 Sharp Rise in Cuban Migrants Coast Guard data show that 2,683 Cubans have been intercepted at sea this year, nearly double the amount for all of 2004. The sharp rise is inflaming tensions over a policy that allows Cubans without visas to stay if they reach American soil but turns back those caught at sea. 1 OBITUARIES 57-58 Jack Anderson The Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist, whose column once appeared in more than 1,000 newspapers, he was 83. 58 NEW YORK/REGION 49-56 Candidate Faces Scrutiny Former officials from Decker College in Kentucky have said they consider some of William F. Weld's practices as the chief executive improper and possibly illegal. Mr. Weld, the former Massachusetts governor, is seeking the Republican nomination for governor of New York. 1 Union May File Complaint The transit workers' union, which is in deadlocked contract negotiations with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, intends to file a complaint with the state asserting that the M.T.A. cannot legally insist that the union accept less generous pensions for future workers. 49 Neediest Cases 56 Chess 56 Weather 59

column2: EUROPE; VENEZUELA; INDIA; WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION; EUROPEAN UNION; AGRICULTURE; INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND WORLD MARKET; CROP CONTROLS AND SUBSIDIES; CUSTOMS (TARIFF); THIRD WORLD AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; TELEPHONES AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS; BANKS AND BANKING
column3: Orthodoxies On Trade Worn Down In Marathon
column9: What made the World Trade Organization's agreement possible was the weaving of a series of deals - all night, in marathon talks.
